DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Denies Defense Request For Document Inventory
DOC.TEXT: A federal magistrate on Wednesday denied a request by ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega for an immediate inventory and inspection of materials seized from his homes and offices since the U.S. invasion of Panama. Prosecutors already have promised to provide an inventory of seized documents and materials. But defense attorneys say the government is dragging its feet, and claim officials may remove or destroy materials critical to Noriega's case. ``Defense counsel has reason to believe that some documents and tangible objects ... have been stolen by members of the U.S. military forces occupying Panama,'' the motion said. ``In order to avoid any more mishandling, compliance with (the previous order) is mandatory.'' ``The U.S. attorney's office is dragging its feet,'' Noriega attorney Steven Kollin told Magistrate William C. Turnoff, who last month ordered that an inventory be provided to the defense. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, declined to comment on whether any potential evidence in the possession of the military had disappeared. ``We do not believe anything has been removed from inventory'' in Miami, she said. Turnoff set a hearing for Feb. 14 to check the progress in providing such lists. While Turnoff said it's critical the defense be provided access to all materials, he denied the motion for a prompt inventory and immediate access to seized material. ``We fear that this material will be lost or destroyed or somehow disappear,'' Kollin said. One concern about the Noriega case was that some materials could be used by the defense to make embarrassing disclosures of sensitive intelligence information. Kollin said some material seized by the military may be favorable to his client's case. Prosecutors have agreed to provide lists of Noriega materials, but complains the defense hasn't provided specific details about locations of his homes and offices. During the hearing, Turnoff suggested that a cutoff date be set for the government to provide the inventory. But Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael P. Sullivan protested, saying discovery ``is a continuing process under the law'' and the court should not set a deadline. Turnoff instead set the status hearing. The magistrate said he has found ``that the government has made a good-faith effort to comply, but I want them to continue their efforts.'' Kollin said he intended to go to Panama to view the items listed in inventory, but he was told by Sullivan in a letter that the government has no objection but cannot guarantee access. At Kollin's request, Turnoff directed that material in the inventory be withheld from the Panamanian government. Sullivan said he might appeal that part of the order. ``We're not in a position to direct the U.S. government not to turn over materials to Panama.''

DOC.HEAD: One Suspect in Family Slayings Killed in Shootout, Mother Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CLARIFY mother charged with one count each of arson and possession of stolen property; MOVES UP reference to charges against mother; DELETES redundant 3rd graf; picks up 7th graf, `According to...
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed maintenance worker suspected in the Christmas weekend killings of four family members who were bound, shot and set on fire during a robbery died Wednesday in a shootout with police. His mother was charged with second-degree murder in the case. State police said it was unclear whether the man, Anthony Turner, 33, was killed by officers' gunfire or by a blast from his own shotgun. He was holding the shotgun to his chin when officers burst into his apartment, said State Police Superintendent Thomas Constantine. Turner's 2-year-old child was turned over to social workers. Authorities had a warrant charging Turner with the Dec. 22 murders of Warren Harris, 39, Dolores Harris, 41, and their children, 15-year-old Shelby and 11-year-old Marc. Turner's mother, Shirley Kinge, 54, was arraigned Wednesday night in Dryden Town Court on four counts of second-degree murder and one count each of arson and criminal possession of stolen property. Town Justice Edwin Sweetland ordered her held without bail in Tompkins County Jail. According to court papers, police discovered Ms. Kinge's fingerprints on a gasoline can found in the Harris home. Police also alleged she used a bank card belonging to Warren and Delores Harris to get $200 from an automatic teller machine. Police discovered the bodies the morning of Dec. 23 after a neighbor reported hearing a smoke alarm in the Harris' farm house in an affluent section of this Ithaca suburb. The parents and Marc were found in one room, bound hand and foot, with pillowcases over their heads, Constantine said. Each had been shot in the back of the head with a .22 caliber gun. The teen-age girl was found in another room. She had been sexually assaulted and shot in the head, police said. All four bodies were set on fire some time after the killings, Constantine said. The fire went out. Money and credit cards were taken from the house, and robbery is considered the motive. Turner was traced through composite drawings of a man who used credit cards taken from the Harris home, police said. Shortly before 7 a.m. Wednesday, troopers forced their way into Turner's apartment, which is about three miles from the Harris home, on a rural street dotted with mobile homes and rusting trucks. When troopers told Turner to put his shotgun down, he turned toward them and fired at least one round, Constantine said. At the same time, a trooper opened fire. Turner had been a suspect for seven to 10 days. Neighbors said his apartment had been staked out since Friday. The search warrants that allowed police to enter were issued Tuesday. Turner lived in one half of the duplex and his mother and grandmother, Sally Reese, lived in the other half, state police said. Turner, who had worked off and on in cleaning jobs, had a record of arrests in New York City for burglary, robbery and theft with a deadly weapon, Constantine said. Turner may have known he was wanted, Constantine said. An unidentified associate of Turner's told police Turner always had guns and would shoot it out with officers if they tried to arrest him, Constantine said. Investigators said they don't have any other suspects.

DOC.HEAD: `Imagining Brad,' A New Play by Peter Hedges, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: The title character in ``Imagining Brad'' has no arms, no legs, almost no hair, cauliflower ears and flaky, crusty skin that makes him look, in the words of his wife's good friend, like ``a Christmas cookie.'' These are some of the qualities that make Brad an ideal husband, according to Peter Hedges' dark comedy that the Circle Repertory Company brought to off-Broadway's Players Theater on Tuesday night. But as the centerpiece of Hedges' blessedly short, 80-minute play, Brad, who is neither seen nor heard, makes for less than riveting dramatic material. The comedy, a bleak meditation on marriage, is absurd without being insightful. The characters are long on weirdness, short on sympathy. Much of the play consists of tedious, unenlightening conversations between Brad's wife _ she is never identified by name _ and Dana Sue, her new best friend. In church, at bars, even driving around town, the two women discuss their men. Dana Sue can't speak highly enough of her husband, whom she describes as handsome and a good lover. It's only later in the evening that the audience discovers that he is a violent man. But Brad's wife is content with her mate. Their relationship is a happy one, even if it only consists of her singing songs to her bedridden husband. The woman even suggests that Dana Sue ditch her husband for a man like Brad. There are a lot of them out there, she confides. Better a vegetable than a wifebeater, Hedges seems to be saying. The play includes a prologue, a long speech by a girl named Valerie who grows up to be Brad's wife. It's her birthday, but she spends most of the time talking about her first menstrual cycle _ either on the phone to her girlfriends or holding a mock news conference about it. Director Joe Mantello allows the charming Melissa Joan Hart, who plays the the teen-age Valerie, to rush through her monologue, making some of it unintelligible. Sharon Ernster gives a good ol' girl performance, complete with honey-dipped Southern accent, as Dana Sue, while Erin Cressida Wilson displays an earnest looniness that lends Brad's wife some credibility. But the play isn't funny enough to be a comedy, no matter how outrageous its situations, or compelling enough to be a good drama. Like its inert hero, ``Imagining Brad'' just lies there.

DOC.HEAD: Stars Remember Irving Berlin
DOC.TEXT: Actress Helen Hayes says Irving Berlin saved her marriage plans with playwright Charles MacArthur by playing his then-newly written song ``Always.'' ``Our spirits were very low,'' she recalled Tuesday during a two-hour salute to the songwriter. ``There were so many impediments to that marriage. My protective friends were always warning me I was going to be in terrible trouble: `He's fickle and he'll break your heart.' I was beginning to feel fear and Charlie was disconsolate.'' Berlin played them the song he had finished that afternoon. ``Well, we were healed and we felt secure and that became our song for the rest of our lives,'' Hayes said. ``For 30 anniversaries we sang that or played it on the phonograph.'' The tribute to Berlin, who died in September at age 101, was held at the 1,010-seat Music Box Theater, which Berlin and Sam Harris built in 1921. Samuel Goldwyn Jr. recalled that as a child he asked Mary Ellin Berlin what her father did. Her reply: ``He writes some songs for a Miss Merman to sing. Sometimes she doesn't sing them the way he wants and Daddy gets very angry.'' In 1937, the Berlins took Goldwyn with them on their boat to Alaska. There was a piano in the room where the children played, Goldwyn said. ``Each morning he would come in and bang on the piano while we tried to play,'' he said. ``It was very distracting for us.'' Tony Bennett sang ``It's a Lovely Day'' and ``Let's Face the Music and Dance.'' Rosemary Clooney and Howard McGillin sang a duet on ``You're Just in Love.'' Roberta Flack sang a vibrant ``Always'' and Dorothy Loudon an emotional ``Falling in Love Is Wonderful.'' Mandy Patinkin sang ``Puttin' on the Ritz'' with two sets of lyrics. Songwriters Sammy Cahn, Jule Styne and Burton Lane each performed a Berlin song. Cy Coleman called Berlin ``our No. 1 songwriter,'' and when he played ``Alexander's Ragtime Band,'' everyone joined in singing. The show was presented by Berlin's daughters, Mary Ellin Barrett, Linda Emmet and Elizabeth Peters. The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, which Berlin helped establish, produced it.

DOC.HEAD: Cartoonists Become Hong Kong's Conscience
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Cartoonists have become the conscience of Hong Kong as they acidly etch the desperation felt by a people destined to live under the flag of Communist China in seven years. With politicians bickering and editorial writers anxious not to irritate the leaders in Beijing, comic strips have become one of the few platforms where Hong Kong's fears are expressed with often brutal clarity. Just after the crackdown June 4 in Beijing on the democracy movement, cartoonist Juan Tze drew Premier Li Peng in a bathtub of blood. ``Is it hot enough?'' asked a soldier holding a bucket of steaming ``people's blood.'' After Sir Geoffrey Howe, then the British foreign secretary, told Hong Kong that Britain could not guarantee the territory's future, Larry Feign, an American expatriate, summed up the feelings of many. ``I don't know who to hate more, Deng Xiaoping or Margaret Thatcher,'' says one of his comic strip characters. After 149 years of British rule, Hong Kong returns to China in 1997. Although Beijing has promised to retain the territory's free-wheeling economic and social system for 50 years, many of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people lost faith in that promise after the June 4 crackdown. Many also have little confidence in faction-ridden local politicians, says Joseph Y.S. Cheng, a leading educator and writer in the colony. Newspapers also practice self-censorship in their criticism of Beijing, he said. ``People look to comic strips as an outlet for their frustrations,'' Cheng said. ``Their popularity demonstrates that we have a solid groundswell of anti-communist, anti-China feeling, especially after June 4.'' Adds Feign: ``Cartoons appeal to the Chinese becaus you can get your meaning across indirectly.'' Cheng said that only in the last few years have comic strips become an important political outlet in Hong Kong. A recent exhibition of cartoons at the Hong Kong Arts Centre drew 40,000 people over several weeks. Feign and Juan are perhaps the two best known cartoonists in the colony. Frenetic and balding, Feign, 34, is author of a comic strip for the English-language South China Morning Post called ``The World of Lily Wong.'' For the five years since he moved to Hong Kong from Orange County in California with his Chinese wife, Feign has charted the lives of Lily, a smart, sexy Hong Kong woman, and Stuart Wright, a bumbling but good-hearted American. Stuart wants to marry Lily and give her the passport she covets but Lily isn't in love and so far has refused him. Through their relationship, Feign explores the often blatant racism inflicted on Chinese by Westerners. He also pokes fun at the ways Chinese view Westerners, known as ``devils'' in Cantonese. A tall man, with the comportment of a Mandarin official in old China's imperial court, Juan is more self-consciously political than Feign. He grew up during Hong Kong's most turbulent times and remembers watching the bloody anti-British riots in 1967 from a rickety balcony on his tenement home. He began drawing comics as an art student at the Chinese University of Hong Kong in the 1970s. He took a page from early 20th century Chinese history, during which cartoons were a popular form of political agitation, and decided to use comics to fight for Hong Kong's common man. He went to work at the Chinese-language Ming Pao. ``My generation is different from my parents','' said Juan, now 33. ``They came from China and are concerned with basic things like food and money. We are searching for other things, from the spirit.'' When China recently announced its opposition to a British plan to give passports to key Hong Kong professionals and officials, Juan drew a man sitting on his bed, his birth certificate, identity card and passport scattered beneath him. ``Who am I? Who am I?'' the man screamed as his wife snored beside him. ``We have an identity crisis in Hong Kong,'' Juan said. ``London and Beijing are deciding our fate and we can't influence them. I wanted to describe our feeling of hopelessness.'' Following the crackdown in Beijing, Juan drew Chinese Premier Li Peng explaining why tanks were used to put down the rebellion. ``We ran out of cars,'' Li tells a visitor. Another strip shows an Englishman offering Hong Kong on a fork into the drooling mouth of a corrupt Chinese cadre. ``Be a brave Chinaman,'' the Englishman says. Juan, who hopes to stay in Hong Kong after 1997, has recently published a book of his work, ``Black Goods.'' ``I guess the Chinese might call me a counterrevolutionary,'' he said with a wry smile. ``I'm just helping them gather proof.'' If Juan expresses the desperation of Hong Kong, Feign captures the absurdity of its life. Living on the cusp of two worlds _ Hong Kong Chinese and Western expatriate _ Feign has a unique vantage point. ``In the beginning, my position gave me a chance to pull off a lot of good gags,'' said Feign. ``But now as things get serious I find it harder to draw. It's becoming a tragedy.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Film star Bruce Willis caused young hearts to throb when he turned up unannounced at a ski area while the set for ``Die Hard II'' was being arranged. ``Oh yeah, he created quite a stir,'' said Gordon West, a manager at the Mission Ridge ski area. ``He had every lady going `ooh ah ooh.' He came in incognito and rented his skis under some other name.'' Jason Stromme, a 17-year-old high school student, said he noticed Willis eating lunch Sunday with four people at the central Washington ski lodge. ``He got up and left because everyone was looking at him,'' Stromme said, and then youngsters pounced on his table, grabbing the water glass and other items the star had touched. Scenes from the thriller ``Die Hard II'' were being filmed this week in Leavenworth, said Chamber of Commerce director Laura Jobin.

Guitar virtuoso Eric Clapton is planning a six-week U.S. tour that will bring the British rocker to 27 cities in the spring. It will be Clapton's first U.S. tour since 1987, although he appeared with the Rolling Stones several times during their just-completed ``Steel Wheels'' tour. Clapton's smashing groups of the 1960s and early '70s included Cream, Blind Faith and Derek and the Dominoes. Unlike other megastars on the road in the past year, his tour will not have a corporate sponsor, publicist Mitch Zamarin said Tuesday. The tour opens in Atlanta on March 28, then heads up the Eastern Seaboard before moving west and ending May 5 in San Francisco. Clapton's band features guitarist Phil Palmer, keyboardists Greg Phillanganes and Alan Clark, bassist Nathan East, percussionist Ray Cooper, drummer Steve Ferrone and backing vocalists Tessa Niles and Katie Kissoon.

Prince Charles appealed to architects and planners to minimize their use of tropical hardwoods, whose harvest is one cause of rampant deforestation. ``The sands of time in the tropical hour glass are running out fast and we can't turn it upside down and watch the sands run out again,'' Charles said Tuesday in a speech to the Royal Botanical Gardens. Despite agreements to import only timber grown in sustainably managed forests, it is impossible to know whether given shipments come from properly managed forests or not, he said. Charles criticized the International Tropical Timber Organization for making no mention of the rights and needs of the forest-dwellers in its articles of agreement, and said new mechanisms are needed to protect rainforest regions. ``This is clearly a massive challenge, but it seems to be that we cannot simply go on talking about the need to protect the world's rain forests and not create the kind of institutions and mechanisms which will actually make that possible,'' Charles said.

Ticky-tacky _ that's how actress Kirstie Alley of ``Cheers'' fame first saw the city of angels. ``I was very amazed at how most houses in Los Angeles looked alike,'' Alley told Good Housekeeping for its March issue. ``After a while I thought that if I saw one more white-on-white-on-white room I would gag. The furniture's too big, also.'' When she headed for Los Angeles in 1981 to become an actress, the Kansas-born Alley said, she left behind a job as an interior decorator and a $400-a-week cocaine habit. ``I had spent a fortune decorating peoples' homes and I didn't even know what I was doing,'' she said. With roles in ``Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan'' and the miniseries ``North & South'' under her belt, she is happily settled into life with husband Parker Stevenson and their myriad pets and guests, in a 22-room mansion on the former Al Jolson estate. ``She's a biker's chick,'' ``Cheers'' co-star Ted Danson said. ``If you want to have a verbal flirtation, Kirstie's your girl,'' Danson said. ``He's a very good kisser,'' Alley responded.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Single name Carman cq.
DOC.TEXT: Singer Steven Curtis Chapman was named a finalist for eight Gospel Music Association awards, including artist of the year and top male vocalist. Chapman, 27, will vie for songwriter of the year, song of the year, contemporary recorded song of the year, southern gospel recorded song of the year, inspirational recorded song of the year and contemporary album of the year, the association announced Tuesday. He joined perennial gospel award-winner Sandi Patti among the five finalists for the artist of the year award. The others were Carman, Michael W. Smith and Take 6. Joining Chapman as finalists for male vocalist of the year were Steve Green, Smith, Russ Taff and Bebe Winans. Miss Patti was a finalist for her ninth straight award as female vocalist of the year. Other nominees were Margaret Becker, Kim Hill, Twila Paris and Cece Winans. Winners will be announced April 5.

The Atlanta Braves are hiring Jim Varney, who plays the homespun character Ernest P. Worrell, to do television ads promoting the National League club in hopes of boosting attendance. The team's director of marketing and broadcasting, Wayne Long, said Tuesday that the one-year contract with the Carden & Cherry advertising firm of Nashville, Tenn., which represents Varney, will include nine television spots, print advertising and three scheduled appearances by Varney. Varney, star of the movies ``Ernest Goes to Camp'' and ``Ernest Saves Christmas,'' is a veteran of more than 9,000 television commercials. Advertising previously had been handled in-house by Turner Advertising. The Braves were last in attendance in the major leagues the last two seasons, drawing 848,089 in 1988 and 984,930 last year.

DOC.HEAD: Networks to Cover Drug Summit With Expanded Press Pool
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Similar version in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Despite its early worries about reporters' safety during President Bush's drug summit next week in Colombia, the White House will let an expanded press pool cover the meeting. That was reported Tuesday by Tim Russert, NBC's Washington bureau chief, chairman of the network TV pool covering the one-day trip. ``This is an extremely difficult, sensitive trip because of the security, but the White House accomodated us in everything we _ certainly television broadcasting _ asked for,'' said Russert. The four-nation drug summit is being held in Cartagena, a coastal town on Colombia's Caribbean side about 400 miles north of the capitol city of Bogota. The usual White House press contingent _ 11 reporters traditionally fly with Bush on Air Force One, followed by others on a chartered plane _ will go with him to Cartagena, Russert said. In addition, an expanded press pool will be allowed to accompany the president to the actual meeting site at Barranquilla 65 miles to the northeast. The expanded pool could have as many as 35 members, said Sig Rogich, a White House spokesman. He estimated that at least several hundred foreign and American news staffers will be on hand in Cartagena. Each U.S. network will be allowed to send a correspondent and a camera crew to the actual summit meeting, Russert said, contrasting that with the usual pool arrangement in which one network team provides coverage for all. After the meeting, Bush is to hold a news conference, Rogich said. He said he had no additional details, but network officials expect the press conference will be held in Cartagena. There have been reports of threats of violence against Bush and others in Colombia by drug lords angered by the Columbian government's crackdwn on their operations. CBS News said last month that drug terrorists were buying surface-to-air missiles to try to shoot down Bush's plane. On Jan. 24, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, citing worries about reporters' safety, said the Secret Service was confident it could protect Bush in Colombia but had no authority to protect journalists covering his trip. No network anchor is scheduled to go to the Colombian summit, although ``NBC Nightly News'' anchor Tom Brokaw flew to Bogota last weekend to tape reports and interviews as part of NBC's reportage on Bush's trip. Brokaw said that although he was more uneasy while on a story in Beirut, ``you can certainly sense the tension'' in Bogota, where the drug war has made fear and personal weapons part of daily life. ``Everybody's armed, and everybody who can afford one drives a big Mercedes with armor plating,'' he said. Russert said White House officials with whom he discussed televison coverage of Bush's trip cited nothing specific that they worried about, ``but they obviously are extremely concerned about security.'' ``And frankly, so are news organizations,'' he said. However, ABC News Vice President Jeff Gralnick downplayed the potential of danger to reporters. ``Right now, we haven't heard anything from our people in Cartagena that says `Get excited,''' Gralnick said. ``We're going to be cautious and and sensitive to cirumstances that might exist,'' he said. ``We'd be crazy not to. ``But we have had people in and out of Colombia since this (drug) story first became a major concern. And they're all fine, and they continue to be fine.''

DOC.HEAD: After 20 Months, Grand Jury Tells Jacksonville It Stinks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The nose knows without any help from the legal system, but a grand jury report tells residents what they know already: Jacksonville smells. The grand jury issued the report on June 14, 1988, but it had been sealed as two paper mills and two chemical plants criticized in the report challenged it in court. The four companies say that have taken expensive steps to eliminate smelly emissions. ``I don't think we need a grand jury to tell us Jacksonville smells,'' said Dick Kennedy, a frequent critic of the city's pollution policies. ``I don't think anybody should be put out of business, but I think they should stay out of court and spend their money cleaning up the air,'' said Kennedy, who said he lives downwind from the two paper mills. After months of court challenges, Chief Circuit Judge John E. Santora ordered the report released Monday evening. ``The history of Jacksonville's achievements is preceded only by its reputation as `The City That Smells.' To each of us individually, and to the community as a whole, this situation can only be termed an embarrassment,'' the report said. The report by the 23-member panel said emissions have resulted in more than 4,000 citizen complaints since 1985. ``The odors have an adverse impact on their property values, and unreasonably interfere with their health, welfare, and comfortable enjoyment of life and property,'' it said. Mayor Tommy Hazouri has campaigned to clean up Jacksonville's odors and the city council approved a tough anti-odor ordinance to cite offending industries in March 1988, parts of which have been thrown out by the courts. The panel also found that local industries have not taken all the steps they could to solve odor problems and could have made improvements years ago. The grand jury report concluded that if industries fail to get rid of stinky odors that city, state and federal officials should pursue civil and criminal remedies to stop further emissions. At the same time, the grand jury indicted SCM Glidco Organics Corp., Jefferson Smurfit Corp., Seminole Kraft Corp. and Union Camp Corp. for violating air pollution laws. The charges since have either been dropped or struck down. The four companies challenged the report, and Santora Jr. ordered it sealed. The Florida Times-Union and the state attorney's office challenged the sealing of the report. The case wound its way up to the 1st District Court of Appeals and through another round of motions before Santora ordered it released. Chief Assistant State Attorney John Delaney said Tuesday he wishes the report could have been released when the grand jury completed its work. John Baggett, operations director for Union Camp, said Tuesday the chemical company fought the presentment because it was unfair to the industries. ``We were not objecting to the fact that there are objectionable odors in Jacksonville,'' Baggett said. ``We did not agree with their broad-brush approach that the industries had done nothing to address the problem.'' Union Camp has spent about $1 million in 1988 and 1989, installing and improving equipment to cut down on odors. But he said the company had committed to do that before the grand jury investigation. ``The report is grossly biased, factually deficient and very misleading to the general public,'' said SCM Glidco President George Robbins. His company has spent more than $2 million to reduce odors. Robbins pointed out that about a third of the odor complaints in 1989 were directed at plants operated by the City of Jacksonville. Most of them concerned a sewage treatment plant. Fewer than 7 percent of the complaints involved SCM Glidco. Seminole Kraft, a paper mill, announced last week that it was spending $100 million to convert is cardboard-making process to use recycled cardboard instead of wood chips, eliminating a major source of odor.

DOC.HEAD: Midseason Shows Stumble, Sweeps Month Openers Lag
DOC.TEXT: ``Lethal Weapon'' outmuscled the Walker family spy ring, two debut shows ran into trouble and a new show's rise suggested Americans like to watch themselves, according to the latest A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings. NBC's shows captured half the spots in the Nielsen's top 10 for last week, which started February's sweeps, one of four periods a year when ratings are used to compute advertising value. ABC put four shows in the top 10, including No. 1 ``Roseanne.'' CBS' lone entry was its perennial favorite ``60 Minutes.'' ``Roseanne'' led with a 24.1 rating; NBC gave viewers ``Cheers'' with 22.7, ``The Cosby Show'' with 22.4 and ``Golden Girls'' with 21.5. CBS'`60 Minutes'' was fifth at 21.3 and NBC's ``Empty Nest'' was sixth at 20.0. In seventh place with 19.8 was ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' on ABC, a Sunday night show that uses home video clips sent in by viewers. ABC claims the show has increased its audience 10 percent since it premiered Jan. 14. Rounding out the top 10 were ABC's ``The Wonder Years'' with 19.2, ABC's ``Coach'' with 18.8 and NBC's ``Unsolved Mysteries'' with 18.7. Each ratings point represents the nation's 92.1 million homes with televisions. Two mid-season replacements had unspectacular premieres. ``City,'' featuring Valerie Harper as a city manager, made its CBS debut at No. 35, and CBS' ``Grand Slam,'' about competing bondsmen, failed to make bail at No. 68. Despite widespread distribution in video and cable, the Mel Gibson-Danny Glover cop movie ``Lethal Weapon,'' on NBC's Sunday night lineup, managed only to stake out 12th place. But that was well above the 28th place for the first part of CBS' ``A Family of Spies,'' the miniseries about the John A. Walker spy ring, which was also shown Sunday night. Two sweeps specials were in the top 20 shows, NBC's ``David Letterman Eighth Anniversary Special'' at No. 17 and ABC's ``Sammy Davis Jr.'s 60th Anniversary Celebration'' at No. 19. In the battle of the Monday night movies, NBC's ``Where Pigeons Go To Die'' was in a three-way tie for 24th place (with ``Family Matters'' and ``Murphy Brown'') but outflew the sexier-sounding ``Rich Men, Single Women,'' in 27th place on ABC. NBC was the lead network with a 14.0 average, followed by ABC's 13.5 and CBS' 11.7. For the season, NBC leads with 14.8 followed by ABC's 13.0 and CBS with 12.3. For news shows, ABC's ``World News Tonight'' was first with 11.1, followed by ``NBC Nightly News,'' 10.4, and ``The CBS Evening News,' 10.0.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Watches War Games, Says World Dangers Justify Military Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 27-28: ``Bush was,'' with two grafs to CORRECT that others, also heckled, not just Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told U.S. troops taking part in war games Tuesday that political proposals by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are encouraging but that America must not let changes in Eastern Europe ``lull us into a sense of complacency.' The president, getting a first-hand look at U.S. forces in action, declared: ``Military challenges to democracy persist in every hemisphere and America must always be prepared to fight for freedom and security.'' Critics, especially congressional Democrats, contend that Bush's military budget ignores the dismantling of the Communist empire. The president defended his plan to make military cuts in select areas _ such as bases _ but to spend more on strategic weapons as he began a three-day trip combining visits to defense installations with Republican fund-raising. A continent away, the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee kept up the pressure for changes, saying the administration's $292.1 billion defense budget, with a continued emphasis on big strategic programs such as long-range missiles, fails ``to match the new political realities at home or abroad.'' ``This administration's approach reflects old thinking rather than these new realities,'' Rep. Les Aspin of Wisconsin said at a congressional hearing in Washington. Bush told the soldiers the U.S. Army ``the premier land force in the world today.'' He said, ``The realistic battles you wage here forge tactical expertise, leadership, and a fighting spirit. And that's what we need.'' Bush's talk was carried by radio to troops on both sides of the mock battle at Fort Irwin's National Training Center in the remote Mojave desert. ``Now, back to the war,'' Bush said. ``We've never stopped a battle before to listen to the president on the radio,'' joked Army Col. Michael Ryan, chief of plans and operation. Bush, in his first remarks on changes proposed on Monday by Gorbachev, said: ``I can speak for all Americans when I say we are pleased to see chairman Gorbachev's proposals to expand steps toward political pluralism in the Soviet Union.'' ``It's especially encouraging to see anything which might bring the day of true democracy a bit closer to the Soviet people.'' From a ridge, Bush watched puffs of smoke emerging from tank columns, saw bursts of artillery shells and saw planes sweeping low to provide air cover over the desert valley floor. He watched as the team portraying a Soviet-style ``opposing force'' smashed through the defending side's lines. Bush watched the simulated battle from Hill 781, his tie off, a khaki jacket over his shirt, military binoculars around his neck. His wife, Barbara, was nearby, wearing a colorful jogging suit. After his remarks, he heard the commander of the ``blue army'' from Fort Lewis, Wash., Col. A. J. Bergeron, tell him over a television monitor, ``This for us is a training Super Bowl.'' He said he was ``absolutely delighted'' that Bush came. However, one of his men, 2nd Lt. Barry Hale, ``hit'' in the simulated battle, said ruefully to reporters, ``We would have been great if we hadn't been blocked from going around Hill 781. ... They called it a chemically contaminated area.'' Bush, in his formal remarks, said, ``It is important not to let ... encouraging changes, political or military, lull us into a sense of complacency. Nor can we let down our guard against a worldwide threat.'' ``The Soviet Union still does maintain formidable forces,'' he said. Bush said that the U.S. military would face ``its share of uncertainties and danger'' in the years ahead, despite the current easing of tensions. The president said his defense strategy is one of active forces which are ``smaller but more agile and flexible,'' such as the contingent sent to Panama in the raid against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Later, in Los Angeles, the president again trumpeted his 1991 defense budget at a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinner for California Republicans. ``As the nature of the threats to American security change, so too must our response,'' Bush said. ``Our forces will remain robust, well-trained, highly professional but geared to the new array of challenges of the '90s.'' Bush cited ``rapid and welcome change as people from Panama to Prague strive for democracy.'' But he said the lessening of East-West tensions should not lessen the military mission, only refocus it. Switching subjects to fit his GOP audience, Bush lashed out at ``Democratic gerrymandering'' in California that he said had made it hard in the past for Republicans to win House seats. Noting that new congressional district lines will be drawn after this year's census, Bush declared ``the time has come for redistricting reform.'' Bush and other speakers was interrupted by five hecklers at various times, three shouting something about El Salvador and two something about AIDS. All were led from the room. After one interruption, Bush ad-libbed, ``Pretty tough.'' Several hundred demonstrators paraded for a variety of causes outside the hotel. The military-spending debate also includes an issue some have portrayed as political: The Bush plan calls for closing or scaling down 72 U.S. military installations, many of them in Democrats' districts. In his war-games remarks, Bush declared: ``As we enter the 1990s, the United States is shaping its military to meet a changing international environment, one that may be potentially safer; but one that will almost surely have its share of uncertainties and dangers.'' He praised the Dec. 20, 1989 invasion of Panama that toppled Noriega as an example of the kind of role he envisions for the modern military.

DOC.HEAD: Wright's Stuff: Industrial Artist Gets 1st Major Show 200 Years After Death
By GRAHAM HEATHCOTE
DOC.TEXT: One artist grasped the importance of what was happening in England in the 18th century when he chose scientific demonstrations, iron forges and blacksmiths' shops for his ``peculiar'' subjects. Joseph Wright's first major show in London, opening today, comes almost 200 years after his death. ``He deserved one before but this often happens in England,'' said Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate Gallery, at Tuesday's preview. To avoid confusion with artists of the same name, Wright was known in his lifetime as Wright of Derby, the Midlands town where he was born and worked. He died in 1797 and the title has stuck ever since. His most famous picture is of a group of people watching a demonstrator pump air from a glass globe, causing a bird inside to flutter in distress as it loses oxygen. The viewers react in fascination or shock and one covers her eyes. A critic who saw it in 1768 wrote: ``Mr. Wright, of Derby, is a very great and uncommon genius, in a peculiar way.'' In those days, ``peculiar'' meant ``individual'' or ``unlike others,'' says the exhibition organizer, Judy Egerton, who has gathered about 200 works from around the world for the show. Two years earlier, Wright had shown another unique painting, of a lecturer explaining the workings of an orrery, a clockwork model of the solar system. His listeners, including two little boys, are entranced and one man makes notes. There are no pictures like these anywhere else, art historians say. The scene in each painting is illuminated by a candle lamp, demonstrating Wright's mastery of light effects. His industrial pictures show workers lit by the fires at which they work metals. Wright's scientific and industrial paintings won for him the honor of being the first artist to directly express the spirit of the industrial revolution. He was gripped by fire and light and returning in 1775 from a visit to Italy he brought his paintings of the annual firework display in Rome, the Girandola, and of a nighttime eruption of the Vesuvius volcano. All these are in the Tate show along with many of the portraits, by which Wright earned the bulk of his income. ``Wright fell into obscurity in the 19th century but in the 1920s he was appreciated by American collectors,'' Serota said. His paintings then rose in value. In 1984, London's National Gallery paid $1.7 million at auction for his portrait, ``Mr. and Mrs. Coltman.'' Wright had charged Coltman 63 pounds for it in 1771, then the equivalent of about $300. The ``Wright of Derby'' exhibition goes to Paris this summer and to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York in the fall, the first time the Tate has loaned a show to the Met, Serota added. ``Wright captures the excitement of scientific discovery,'' said David Fraser, curator of Derby's museums. Derby Art Gallery has the largest collection of Wright's work because its residents admired him and contributed in Victorian times to the museum's purchase of his paintings. In the 1960s, the Derby church he was buried in was demolished and its site now lies under a beltway. His remains were so carelessly reburied in a local cemetery that no one now quite knows where they are, the curator said. The exhibition is at the Tate Gallery through April 22, at the Paris Grand Palais May 17 through July 23 and at the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art Sept. 6 through Dec. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Leona Helmsley Calls `Little People' Line a Lie
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire tax evader Leona Helmsley has denied ever telling a housekeeper ``only the little people pay taxes,'' and predicts she will not go to prison because ``I've done nothing.'' In her first interview since her August conviction, Helmsley told ``A Current Affair'' that the quote was ``an out and out lie.'' ``This is the most ludicrous, ridiculous thing that ever happened to me in my entire life. ... ``We paid a fortune in taxes and I sat down with a housekeeper, and I said, `Do you know that only the little people pay taxes?''' she said, her voice rising mockingly. ``This is nonsense,'' she told interviewer Cindy Adams, adding, ``Then I'm the little people. I'm the one paying the taxes. We paid $344 million. ... I really don't know where it came from. But it didn't come from this mouth.'' The interview was taped at her Central Park South apartment on Jan. 29. It will be broadcast nationally tonight and Thursday on the Fox network. Helmsley, who was convicted of evading more than $1.2 million in federal taxes between 1983 and 1985, was sentenced to four years in prison and ordered to pay a $7.1 million fine and $1.7 million in back taxes. She is free on $25 million bail, pending an appeal. Asked how she will survive if her appeal fails, Helmsley said, ``If I went to jail? I'm not going to jail. I've done nothing. I can't believe ... that the system in the United States of America has stopped working.'' Several times during the interview, Helmsley tried to keep her voice from cracking when talking about the trial and dabbed her nose with a tissue when asked about her lawyer's assertion in court that she was a ``tough bitch.'' She said she may have cultivated that image by being tough on her employees and said, ``If you pet me, I'll purr. But if you hit me, I might scratch, of course.'' The 69-year-old hotel magnate said she was ``terrified'' of what was happening to her, adding, ``It's like being on a roller coaster. You're just being pushed with no control whatsoever.'' Since her trial, she said, she and her husband, Harry, ``don't go anywhere,'' but added that when they do reporters are always nearby. During a recent trip to Arizona, she said, ``there were helicopters flying over the house'' and when they went to the beach near their Sarasota, Fla., home ``there was a reporter lying on the sand and he had his camera aimed at us. It's terribly unfair.''

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Makes Major Gains; Concern Grows About Return to Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Khmer Rouge guerrillas have made major gains since Vietnamese troops left in September and worry grows that the movement, which ruled Cambodia with terror in the late 1970s, may regain power. Guerrilla and Western officials say Khmer Rouge fighters have overrun dozens of government positions, capturing a 250-mile stretch of territory in northern and western Cambodia. They have closed many jungle camps on the Thai border and moved tens of thousands of civilians and soldiers to the newly seized areas, including the gem-mining district of Pailin in Battambang province. Hundreds of thousands of Cambodians were executed or died of disease or starvation while the Communist Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia from April 1975 until the Vietnamese invasion of December 1978 that overthrew Pol Pot's government. The Khmer Rouge says those days are gone, and it has changed. Mit Noly, a guerrilla major interviewed on a trip through the region, said in the district capital of Tmar Puok: ``We are trying to separate ourselves from the past. We are willing to accept the will of the people. ``In 1982, we changed. Our struggle became one of national liberation against the Vietnamese. Our policy is now one of justice. We tell people that theft is wrong, that murder is wrong.'' Western analysts say, however, that Pol Pot and others who directed the massacres of the 1970s remain in control. There is considerable documentation of continued human rights violations by the Khmer Rouge in recent years. Thousands of civilians under Khmer Rouge control serve as porters to move food, weapons and military supplies from border to the new base camps, according to the reports by guerrilla and Western officials. Ok Serie Sopheak of the non-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front, another group fighting the Vietnam-sponsored government of Premier Hun Sen: ``The Khmer Rouge have been very successful on the battlefield. They now operate quite freely almost everywhere in the country.'' The tour of northwestern Cambodia sometimes involved traveling in jeeps supplied by the Chinese, the Khmer Rouge's main supporters, and eating in marketplaces. Khmer Rouge guerrillas could be seen in dozens of newly captured villages, visiting relatives and mingling with villagers who went about their regular work of the harvest season. Other guerrillas were en route to interior provinces such as Kompong Thom, where they must operate far from the supply lines leading from the Thai border. Analysts say that, despite its bloody record, the Khmer Rouge has recruited thousands of fighters and continues to get some help from villagers as its units move deeper inside Cambodia. ``They are seen by many as patriots,'' a senior Thai intelligence officer said privately. ``In rural Cambodia, the average villager is not nearly as opposed to the Khmer Rouge as the international community.'' Outside the country, the analysts say, the more the Khmer Rouge wins on the battlefield, the more it loses diplomatically. After the Khmer Rouge seized its first district capital _ Pailin, in October _ several Western countries tried to isolate it, fearful of a return to power. The Khmer Rouge is the strongest member of a three-party resistance coalition that also includes the non-Communist forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. Khmer Rouge guerrillas increased attacks after the Vietnamese withdrawal in the last days of September and now control more 6,250 square miles in the north and west, according to Thai and Western intelligence sources. Much of the area is sparsely populated. Since September, the Khmer Rouge has captured at least three district capitals in Battambang and Siem Riep provinces. In January, its guerrillas attacked Battambang's provincial capital, also called Battambang. Thai intelligence officers close to Khmer Rouge leaders say the plan is to to capture Battambang before monsoon rains start in April. Battambang is Cambodia's second-largest city after Phnom Penh, the capital. A Western diplomat in Bangkok said: ``They are cutting roads, trying to isolate Battambang. If all supply lines can be cut, they can seize the city.'' According to intelligence sources, the Khmer Rouge recognizes its increased isolation and is ready if China yields to international pressure and cuts off aid. The guerrillas are reported to have arms and ammunition caches throughout Cambodia. Western diplomats and ruby miners say the Khmer Rouge collects the equivalent of more than $500,000 a month in taxes from gem miners in Pailin, which the guerrillas captured Oct. 22. ``If all international support stopped tommorrow, the Khmer Rouge could fight for five more years,'' a Thai intelligence officer said. ``If the Khmer Rouge are shut out of a peace settlement, there will be no peace.''

Gov't Announces Huge Arms Seizure
DOC.TEXT: Authorities seized 17 tons of weapons from a ship that had arrived from Europe and the United States and said they were investigating to determine who was responsible for the shipment. The attorney general's office showed reporters the haul, which included 270 rifles, 4,988 cartridges, machine guns, pistols and other firearms. ``Until now, we have not detained anyone because the shipment was going to a dummy company called Super Comercial Agropecuaria San Pablo,'' the attorney general's office said in a statement. The Mexican flag ship Sonora left Belgium on Dec. 5 and stopped in the Netherlands, West Germany, France, Miami and Houston before arriving in Veracruz on Jan. 27, the statement said. The weapons were in a container labeled as containing garbanzo paste from Lebanon, the government said. The statement did not say where the arms were loaded onto the ship. One spokesman for the attorney general's office said the weapons could be destined for Mexican drug traffickers, while another speculated that they were headed for another country.

DOC.HEAD: Rock Star Billy Idol Injured in Motorcycle Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to CORRECT that surgery lasted seven hours, sted three, UPDATE that Idol suffered broken arm, was working on album called `Charmed Life,' plans uncertain for movie role, concert tour, other details; picks up 10th graf, `Idol _ with ...'
DOC.TEXT: Rock singer Billy Idol suffered a badly broken leg and fractured arm when he ran a stop sign on his motorcycle and smashed into a car on a Hollywood street Tuesday, police said. Idol, 34, underwent seven hours of surgery on his right leg and left forearm, and was listed in serious but stable condition at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center's intensive care unit late Tuesday. The rock star, who was not wearing a helmet, also suffered some lacerations on the back of his head, said police Officer Don Lawrence. Idol ran a stop sign at 8:30 a.m. while southbound on a street and hit a car eastbound on another street, according to Lawrence. The car's driver was not injured. The singer will be cited for failing to stop for a stop sign, Lawrence said. Such a citation usually results in a fine. Idol was brought to the hospital at 9:10 a.m., said Cedars-Sinai Medical Center spokesman Ron Wise. Idol suffered a compound fracture between the knee and ankle, said Wise, who described the fracture as serious. Wise earlier said the performer suffered a fractured wrist, but said later that surgeons discovered the arm was broken. His publicist, Ellen Golden, knew only sketchy details of the collision, which occurred after Idol wrapped up work on a new album, ``Charmed Life,'' at a Hollywood studio and was riding home. She said she was initially told Idol was not at fault in the crash. She said earlier that he was not intoxicated. Golden said it was not immediately known what impact, if any, the accident would have on Idol's plans to begin work in three weeks in director Oliver Stone's motion picture about the Doors rock band. Idol was to play a close friend of the late lead singer Jim Morrison, she said. It also was unknown whether Idol's plans to release ``Charmed Life'' in late April and launch a concert tour in July would be affected, Golden said. Idol _ with his blond spiked hair, tight leather garb and curled lip _ personifies the bad boy rock 'n' roll image. He is best known for his 1984 album ``Rebel Yell,'' which produced the hit songs ``Eyes Without a Face,'' ``White Wedding'' and ``Rebel Yell.'' He followed his ``Rebel Yell'' success with the ``Whiplash Smile'' in 1987, which produced the hit singles ``To Be a Lover'' and ``Sweet Sixteen.'' He also had hits with ``Dancing with Myself'' and ``Mony Mony'' off his first album, ``Don't Stop.'' Idol was most recently seen as part of the Who's ``Tommy'' tour.

DOC.HEAD: Tulsa Takes First Step in Forming New Form of Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT spelling of Republican mayoral candidate's name to `Pitezel,' sted `Pietzel.' Rodger is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Rodger Randle took three-fourths of the vote in a Democratic primary Tuesday, pitting him against Republican state Rep. Frank Pitezel in his bid for a second term. Voters also narrowed the number of city council candidates from 72 to 20 in the city's first step toward replacing its 82-year-old commission form of government. Randle, who'll meet Pitezel in a general election April 3, received 17,662 votes, or 75 percent, to 4,332, or 18 percent, for Joe Williams, president of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Virginia Jenner garnered 1,064 ballots, or 4 percent, and Guilford Escue had 624, or 3 percent. Pitezel easily won the GOP primary with 11,661 votes, or 63 percent, to 2,234, or 12 percent, for Reba Yeskavich, and 1,552, or 8 percent for Andrew Harriman. Tulsa has had a commission form of government since 1908. City residents last year approved changing Tulsa's charter to replace commissioners with a council representing nine districts in an effort to regain neighborhood representation. That drew a flood of candidates for city posts with backgrounds ranging from dishwashers to ministers and bank executives. Under the new form of government, the mayor will be the city's chief administrator responsible for overseeing all city operations and appointing 16 department heads. The charter change also increased the mayor's term from two years to four. The nine council members will serve two-year terms.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Recommends Sterilization for Late Child Support Payments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed until 11 a.m. EST; time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: A bill on today's state Senate agenda calls for the sterilization of a person who falls a year behind in child support payments. The legislation being introduced by Sen. Charlotte Pritt, a Democrat, calls for a court to find the offender in contempt before ordering the sterilization. ``I think we need to have a discussion in the subcommittee about it,'' said Pritt, a 41-year-old school teacher and leading abortion rights advocate in the Senate. ``The whole thing is a legitimate area for discussion.'' Pritt also introduced a bill that calls for a physician who is counseling a woman about tubal ligation to counsel her husband on vasectomies. Her third bill would require a spouse's written consent before a man could obtain a vasectomy. ``Notice is not required if the performance of the vasectomy is necessary to save the man's life,'' the bill said.

DOC.HEAD: Annie Sprinkle's Porn Show Prompts Attack on Arts Endowment
DOC.TEXT: When porn queen Annie Sprinkle performed her stage show, members of the audience might have thought they saw art. But when Rep. Dana Rohrabacher heard about it, he saw red. ``The National Endowment for the Arts is at it Again!'' the conservative California Republican exclaimed in the headline over a letter to his House colleagues accusing the federal arts agency of using tax funds to subsidize pornography. Endowment Chairman John E. Frohnmayer says his agency didn't underwrite Miss Sprinkle's sexually explicit show at the Kitchen, a private, avant-garde performing arts center in lower Manhattan. He said the endowment gave the Kitchen $60,000 last year solely for the theater's operating expenses. Rohrabacher didn't actually see Miss Sprinkle perform but relied on press reports for the lurid details. During one breathless pause in her act, Rohrabacher said, the star of 150 X-rated videos commented: ``Usually I get paid a lot of money for this, but tonight it's government-funded.'' The program for the show included a ``Post Porn Modernist Manifesto'' that said its adherents ``celebrate sex as the nourishing life giving force'' and ``utilize sexually explicit words, pictures and performances to communicate our ideas and emotions.'' Rohrabacher urged his fellow House members to remind Frohnmayer ``he is dealing with taxpayer funds and is accountable for how they are spent, just like every other head of every other federal agency.'' ``If the NEA can't hold itself responsible to the U.S. taxpayer, it's our job to make them responsible,'' he said. Barbara Tsumagari, executive director of the Kitchen, said in New York that Miss Sprinkle's 12 performances were not financed with federal funds. Ms. Tsumagari said the New York State Council on the Arts, which receives funds from the NEA, gave a $25,000 grant to underwrite part of the Kitchen's current season of 54 performances, but specifically excluded Miss Sprinkle's show. That was confirmed by state arts council spokesman Tim Mulligan, who said her ``presentation was not of an artistic quality to warrant council support.'' Frohnmayer, in a telephone interview, said the NEA gave the New York arts council a $500,000 grant last year for staff salaries and other administrative expenses. Rohrabacher's press secretary, David Eisner, said the congressman plans to circulate similar letters about every week to highlight further examples of what Eisner called the endowment's ``use of tax dollars for triple-X, hard-core pornographic stuff.'' Eisner said NEA supporters dismiss such reports as ``isolated incidents,'' but ``we are starting a campaign to really work hard to show that's not the case. This is a systemic problem.'' Rohrabacher's campaign could prove politically embarrassing to Frohnmayer as the House and Senate prepare for hearings on legislation authorizing an extension of the NEA's life. Last October, a controversy over endowment support for a traveling exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe _ including some sexually explicit photos _ led Congress to include a ban on federal funds for ``obscene'' art in the NEA's $171 million budget. A Rohrabacher proposal to abolish the arts endowment was rejected. ``I don't intend to rise to the bait any time someone comes up with a new horror story,'' Frohnmayer said Tuesday. ``I want to make it very clear that we do not fund anything that is obscene and, in fact, my view is that art and obscenity are mutually exclusive terms,'' he said. ``I think those who oppose obscenity _ and I count myself among them _ might more fruitfully look elsewhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Economic Report Replays Many Reagan Hits
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The dogma may be toned down a bit, but in many respects President Bush's first annual report on the state of the U.S. economy could just as easily have been former President Reagan's ninth. When Bush sent Congress his 419-page epistle on the economy Tuesday, all the hits from yesteryear were playing once again: _Tax cuts to stimulate growth. _Balanced budgets down the road just a bit, accomplished without the need for higher taxes. _Promises of economic growth as far as the eye can see. Just as they did with Reagan's economic outlooks, the critics griped about overly optimistic economic forecasts and accused the Republicans of promoting tax cuts for the wealthy in the guise of boosting investment. They charged Bush failed to note the biggest policy failures of the Reagan era _ the mountain of federal debt and the huge trade deficits which have transformed America from the world's largest creditor country to the largest debtor nation. Bush officials, meanwhile, complained the critics ignored the Reagan era's successes, including an unprecedented seven straight years of peacetime economic growth and the creation of more than 20 million jobs, while inflation was kept under control. This economic debate, which raged for all of Reagan's two terms, likely will continue for some time to come. Democrats aimed much of their fire Tuesday at Bush's tax proposals. His economic report repeated his call for a capital gains tax cut and a new Family Savings Account to let Americans put away up to $5,000 a year in tax-free savings accounts. The critics called the capital gains tax cut a giveaway to the wealthy and said the savings plan would not boost Americans' dismal savings rate any more than similar plans advanced during the Reagan years. ``Tinkering with the tax code is the worst thing we could do. This is just gimmickry that we are going to suffer for in the long run,'' complained Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Bush's first ``Economic Report of the President'' did offer some subtle changes by avoiding some of the more doctrinaire monetary and supply-side economic positions sounded during the Reagan years. In a departure from the monetarist leanings of Reagan economists, Bush's report warned against relying on ``rigid monetary targeting,'' in which the central bank focuses solely on controlling the growth of the nation's money supply to hold down inflation. Bush's report gave general approval to the Fed's work under Chairman Alan Greenspan, saying the central bank was correct in using a variety of economic barometers to direct interest rate policies. Bush extolled the benefits of free markets and open world trade, while proclaiming ``the primary economic goal of my administration is to achieve the highest possible rate of sustainable economic growth. Growth is the key to raising living standards, to leaving a legacy of prosperity for our children, to uplifting those most in need and to maintaining America's leadership in the world.'' Asked to explain the differences between Reagan and Bush on economic issues, Michael Boskin, Bush's chief economic adviser, suggested the primary difference lies in the two men's views of government. ``I think that President Reagan believed that not only was the government the problem, but that it was rare indeed that government could be a positive force in solving the problem,'' Boskin said. Bush is more willing to use government to solve problems in such fields as promoting long-term research, fighting illegal drugs or boosting support for the Head Start preschool program, Boskin said, adding that Bush ``does believe in some areas the federal government has an important role to play.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITORS NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Martin Crutsinger has covered economic issues in Washington for the AP since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: President Mixes Politics and Business on the Road
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will spend a good part of this election year traveling about, mixing politics with war. And with peace. And maybe with the environment, education, crime and the battle against drugs as well. Any time Bush mixes a political appearance with an ``official'' presidential event, it reduces the amount the Republican Party must pay for his appearance. In this congressional election year, people can expect to see Bush making plenty of stops combining political and non-political events. Some critics see the tactic as a partial taxpayer subsidy for political activity. In any event, Bush is not the first president to do it, nor likely to be the last. This week's three-state swing, focusing on national defense issues, is a good example of mixing the business of politics with the nation's business. On Tuesday, Bush's first stop in Southern California was to watch Army war games in the Mojave Desert and to talk to U.S. troops. Afterward he came to Los Angeles for an evening $1,000-a-plate GOP fundraiser for Sen. Pete Wilson, who is running for governor of California. Election law requires political parties or candidates to pay for purely political visits by a president _ and the cost of moving a president and his entourage can be quite high. Thus, the fact that Bush had an official event in the same state as the fundraiser means taxpayers will bear some of the cost of the visit, on a pro-rated basis. Further official stops today _ a foreign policy speech in San Francisco and a tour of a laboratory where Star Wars research is done _ will also trim the cost to California Republicans for getting Bush to the Wilson fundraiser. On Thursday, Bush will combine a visit to the Strategic Air Command Headquarters in Omaha, Neb., with a fundraising breakfast for Nebraska's Republican Gov. Kay Orr. The SAC tour will help defray the cost to the Nebraska GOP. Then, before returning to Washington, he will tour a Head Start center in Colombus, Ohio. The political twin? An Ohio GOP dinner. ``This should be a very good trip, emphasizing some of our defense requirements, needs. And a little politics mixed in here,'' Bush told reporters accompanying him aboard Air Force One. ``We'll be doing more of that this year.'' ``It raises a serious question about abuse of taxpayer funds,'' said Ellen Miller, director of the Center for Responsive Politics in Washington D.C., a private organization that studies the role of money in politics. She said the key is whether the president would have made the trip anyway without the political event _ or whether the official appearances were just added to generate a partial taxpayer subsidy for a political visit. Not surprisingly, White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen says the official business, not the political stops, pace the president's schedule. ``He goes on trips to get his message out,'' she said. But she added, ``on the flip side, the president is very committed to the Republican Party.'' Bush, a former national GOP chairman, started combining presidential business with politics early on. Last fall he combined a fundraising speech for Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., a 1990 Senate candidate, with a trip to a Chicago inner-city school where he talked about drugs. Earlier this year, he mixed an appearance at a glitzy Miami hotel fundraiser for Florida Gov. Bob Martinez with a meeting with a group of sixth graders in Everglades National Park. Would Bush have made the ``official'' trip to the Everglades in the absence of the Miami fundraiser? Doubtful, claims Bob Dreyfus of Public Citizen, a watchdog group set up by consumer advocate Ralph Nader. Dreyfus says the practice of scheduling official visits to help defray the costs of political visits is ``a flagrant abuse'' of the public trust. But many political veterans see it as a legitimate way to exercise the powers of the presidency. Stephen Hess, a political analyst at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said, ``the president is both president of all and at the same time, the titular elder of his party. It's sometimes hard to balance those two conflicting interests.'' ``I don't think it's all bad,'' Hess added. ``I must say, if a president has nothing better to do, it's useful for him to get around the country and meet the people up close.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Defense Higher Spending for Strategic Force
DOC.TEXT: Democrats are attacking the Bush administration's belief that the United States must keep paying to upgrade its strategic force until new U.S.-Soviet arms control treaties are completed. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, defending his $292 billion military budget for fiscal 1991, said Tuesday the dramatic changes of pro-democracy movements in Eastern Europe and the diminishing Soviet threat to the West ``are, in fact, reflected in the budget.'' President Bush's proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 calls for a nearly $1 billion increase in spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative, $5.5 billion for the B-2 stealth bomber and more than $3 billion on two new long-range nuclear missiles. The defense secretary told the House Armed Services Committee ``a good deal of prudence is in order.'' Cheney argued no major cuts in spending or changes in defense strategy should be considered until new arms control treaties are completed. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of Armed Services panel, said the administration appeared to be trying to use the arms control process to justify building both the mobile MX and the smaller Midgetman missile systems, as well as the B-2 bomber. ``There is old thinking in strategic arms control,'' Aspin said, adding the administration should not be seeking to build the MX and Midgetman just because they would be permitted under terms of the emerging Strategic Arms Reduction Talks treaty to reduce both superpowers' strategic arsenals by up to 50 percent. ``You stand logic on its head when you use arms control as an argument for a larger defense budget,'' Aspin said. Under questioning by Aspin, Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the service chiefs would reconsider their support for the proposed START treaty if Congress decided to kill either the MX or Midgetman programs and if the B-2 bomber program were canceled. Powell said he personally ``would have to make a very careful reassessment of the START treaty'' if the B-2 program were killed. Aspin said Congress may not accept the administration's request to buy five B-2s in fiscal 1991, and a bipartisan group of congressmen introduced legislation to kill the bomber program. ``It is as relevant to modern nuclear warfare a the Polish cavalry was to German tanks in 1939,'' said Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., a member of the Armed Services panel. ``It could only effectively be employed after nuclear annihilation had already occurred.'' Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio, another panel member, said ``cheaper, but just as effective, alternatives to the stealth'' are available, including cruise missiles that could be fired outside an enemy's borders. The bill would allow completion of the 15 planes now in production. The Pentagon plans to build 132 planes at a cost of about $70 billion, including more than $23 billion that has already been spent. Cheney's proposal to close or realign more than 72 domestic military facilities and 14 foreign bases prompted charges of partisanship from Aspin, who proposed that an independent commission determine the hit list of bases. ``You want to work together we'll close some bases, but it's going to have to be a commission,'' said Aspin. ``I wonder, Mr. Chairman, if you would have been as eager to hold a press conference to introduce your new ... commission legislation if I had not started with a list,'' Cheney said. Aspin rejoined: ``Cheney, you got to play this thing a little less confrontational if you want it to happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Repression Continuing, Human Rights Group Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Eagleburger testifies before Senate Foreign Relations 10 a.m. EST; prenoon lead likely
DOC.TEXT: In a report harshly critical of the Bush administration's policies toward China, the human rights group Asia Watch says repression of Chinese dissenters is deepening despite the lifting of martial law. The findings, largely mirroring a still-confidential State Department report on human rights violations in China, come as Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger was appearing today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to defend the administration's China policy. Some in Congress believe the evidence of Chinese repression makes it even more difficult for Bush to defend his current efforts at rapprochement, just eight months after the brutal crushing of the pro-democracy movement. Eagleburger has been at the center of Bush's secret policymaking, traveling on two clandestine trips to China with national security adviser Brent Scowcroft in the months since the crackdown. The administration, since the massacre of hundreds and perhaps thousands of protesters in Beijing last June 4, ``has reverted ... to a shabby double standard insofar as the question of human rights in China is concerned,'' the Asia Watch report concluded. The 89-page document, based largely on press reports, catalogs continuing arrests of peaceful dissidents, secret trials of protesters, new executions and death sentences and government use of torture against political opponents. It also adds a layer of criticism, calling Bush's reluctance to anger the rulers in Beijing a ``shamefully supine policy'' and concludes: ``The burden of trying to shape a policy that reflects concern for human rights still rests largely on the Congress.'' Sources have said the State Department report, which has been sent to Capitol Hill but not publicly released, offers a matter-of-fact recitation of abuses by the Beijing government throughout 1989, including terming the June 4 Tiananmen Square killings a ``massacre.'' It describes the government of Deng Xiaoping as a totalitarian regime that has tightened its grip on information and throttled opposing ideologies while restricting foreign travel and suppressing labor and religious groups, sources said. The Asia Watch report said between 10,000 and 30,000 people remain jailed because of pro-democracy activities. ``The recent lifting of martial law in Beijing ... has little significance if viewed as anything other than a public relations exercise,'' the report contends. ``Arrests have continued, largely in secret, right through to the present,'' and reports of continued executions persist, the report said. Most of those detained have not been charged or tried, and their families are not told where the prisoners are being held, it said. When they are tried, ``verdicts are usually decided upon before the trial even begins,'' it said. Torture of prisoners is common, and at least 40 people have been executed in connection with the events of last June, it added. ``China's criminal justice system is among the most deeply flawed in the world,'' the report said. ``Indeed, it is essentially pre-modern.'' ``To sum up,'' it said, ``the continuing arrests and executions in China form the cutting edge of a protracted, government-led campaign of punitive repression, and they serve a purely political purpose.''

DOC.HEAD: Blind Lobby for Bill to Ban Seating Limitations on Airliners
DOC.TEXT: Scores of blind people are lobbying Congress to overturn a proposed Federal Aviation Administration rule that would bar them from seats next to emergency exits in airliners. The blind say they have the same rights as anyone else to sit by the exit door. The FAA, which has not yet announced its final rule, is proposing the seats be unavailable to blind people or anyone else who might not be able to operate the doors quickly or lead other passengers to safety. More than 150 blind people crowded a hallway outside a congressional news conference Tuesday to protest the FAA proposal which they predicted soon would become final. Using seeing-eye dogs and white canes, they then spread through congressional office buildings to lobby for the legislation. The FAA proposed last March to prohibit blind or deaf passengers or passengers who might inhibit the use of an airliner emergency door from sitting in the exit row seats. The agency called the matter ``a critical safety issue'' and said the rule would enhance the safety of all passengers. FAA spokesman Dick Stafford said the agency is in the final rule-making procedure, which means it still could impose the rule as proposed, modify it or withdraw it. Bob Marx, Transportation Department spokesman, said the department is expected to issue next month an access rule that would not preclude the FAA from imposing safety restrictions on seating. Leaders of the National Federation of the Blind said the government actions would be discriminatory and decrease a blind person's chances of surviving an airplane crash. Some airlines already prohibit blind travelers from sitting in exit-door seats and several blind people have been arrested in recent years for refusing to move from the seats. A half-dozen members of Congress expressed support for bills that would ban rules to bar passengers from certain based on whether the passenger can see. The measure has passed a Senate committee. ``Blind people must not be treated as second-class citizens and pushed to the back of the bus,'' said Rep. James Traficant, D-Ohio, chief sponsor of a bill in the House. He said there is no evidence to show that blind people pose any kind of safety hazard when sitting next to airline exit doors. James Gashel, government affairs director for the blind federation, said a sightless passenger's ability to maneuver in a smoke-filled or darkened airliner might actually enhance safety if he or she is in a position to lead other passengers. Gashel said the FAA rule would give blind people ``more of a chance to die.'' Gashel told of his own arrest in April 1988 after he refused to leave an exit row seat on a United Airlines plane. More than 200 other passengers were evacuated, the flight was canceled and he was carried off the aircraft by police, but no charges were filed, he said. Other blind people have been arrested after refusing to leave seats. Airline rules on the seats differ, with some barring pregnant women and handicapped people, and others allowing handicapped people to use the seats if they insist.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Seeks Flexibility in Crop Programs
With PM-Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's ``flexibility'' plan for farmers calls for reviving the NCA to use with the ARP and ARC, says the USDA. In that way, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday, farmers would have more choices in planting crops without being penalized. Farmers often complain that Agriculture Department rules to control production are too severe and often penalize them for not following complicated program regulations straight down the line. Wheat farmers must abide by rules in the wheat program. Feed grains producers following feed grains regulations, and so on. If there is deviation, the acreage base or history of a crop may be reduced, thereby meaning reduced USDA payments and other benefits. Current law passed in 1985 expires at the end of the 1990 crop season. It generally denies program benefits if farmers harvest crops other than the ``program'' crop for which they have a base acreage. A change in the strict rules is being sought by the administration and many farm groups and members of Congress. The American Farm Bureau Federation favors acreage flexibility, with a couple of stipulations of its own. And the National Farmers Union, which is often at odds with the administration on farm policy, also likes the idea but wants to study the fine print on the administration's plan. Yeutter explained the administration's version of flexibility at a news conference. It's not exactly a new idea, he said. Here's how it might work: Each farm is assigned a normal crop acreage, or NCA, which is the total acreage bases of program crops such as wheat, feed grains, upland and extra-long staple cotton. Plus a farm's historical plantings of oilseeds: soybeans, sunflowers and rapeseed, including canola. As it does now, the USDA would determine each year whether to apply individual crop ``acreage reduction programs'' called ARPs, if necessary, to each crop's base acreage. If so, a percentage of the farm's base _ with the exception of oilseed acres _ must be idled as an ``acreage conservation reserve,'' or ACR. To qualify for price supports and other program benefits, the farmer must comply with the ARP requirement for that crop. In addition, the sum of all NCA-crop plantings, plus land idled under the acreage reduction programs, cannot exceed the NCA for the individual farm. In return, the farmer is allowed some flexibility without losing benefits or suffering penalties on the farm's acreage base. ``We're proposing that we would establish ARPs, acreage reduction programs, on a crop-by-crop basis, just as we do now,'' Yeutter said. ``In other words, there'll be a wheat ARP and a corn, or a feed grains ARP, and a rice ARP, whatever it may be.''
