Basically, on the rest of the acreage, the farmer will be able to grow any of the so-called program crops, plus any of the oilseed crops, he said. ``It's really what I would call a modified NCA program ... as the NCA existed back in the '70s or thereabouts,'' Yeutter said. In an example, a 300-acre farm included a 100-acre wheat base, a 100-acre corn base, and 100 acres of soybeans. The mythical wheat program included a 5 percent ARP and the corn program a 10 percent ARP. ``That means the farmer has to pull out 5 acres of land for his wheat ARP, 10 acres for his corn ARP, and then under present law, that means he'll plant 95 acres of wheat and he'll plant 90 acres of corn,'' Yeutter said. ``And then on the other 100 acres he'll grow soybeans or whatever.'' Shifting to ``the simplest example'' of flexibility as proposed in the administration plan, Yeutter said the ARPs would be the same _ five acres of wheat and 10 acres of corn. But on the remaining 285 acres, Yeutter said the farmer would be allowed to grow wheat, corn, any of the oilseeds, rice, cotton or whatever. ``And he can plant that in any proportions he wishes,'' Yeutter said. ``If he wants to plant it all to wheat, he can plant it all to wheat. If he wants to plant it all to corn, he can plant it all to corn.'' Yeutter described several variations of the plan in which the 300-acre farmer could plant certain crops on his set-aside acres, provided his acres eligible for payments are reduced accordingly. Oilseeds and experimental crops such as kenaf used for newsprint are among the options under the flexibility plan, he said.

Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says the nation's environment would benefit if planting rules in the government's commodity programs were made more flexible. By requiring only basic cropland set-asides under a ``normal crop acreage'' arrangement, farmers generally would be free to plant whatever they choose on the remaining acreage without penalties, Yeutter said Tuesday. Yeutter said the flexibility plan would ``permit crop rotations or facilitate and foster crop rotations which are very difficult to carry out'' under current, more rigid farm program regulations. ``The rigidities that exist today discourage the kinds of rotation practices that were often followed in past year,'' he said. ``One pays a very significant price in shifting from one program crop to another today because it affects deficiency payments (subsidies).'' Yeutter added: ``Under this program, those kinds of shifts can be undertaken much more readily and it would not be difficult under our flexibility provisions to carry out the kind of rotation _ multi-year rotation _ that is often suggested by people who are engaging in low-input, sustainable agricultural research.''

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Closing of Burial Ground Subject of Public Hearing
DOC.TEXT: A hearing on a proposal to close an exhibit of skeletal remains of prehistoric Indians at a museum turned into a noisy display of emotions among opposing factions Tuesday. Indians in headgear, beads and feathers showed up from half a dozen states to urge that the display be closed. ``Their bodies need to be reburied to let their spirits continue on their journey,'' said Jerry Bear Shield of Wounded Knee, S.D. One Indian punctuated the hearing with drum beats when speakers said things he liked. Others among the 400 people in attendance repeatedly shouted and applauded through the hearing. State Rep. David Leitch of Peoria, said he objected to closing the exhibit at the Dickson Mounds museum. ``We're not talking about a peep-show here,'' he told the crowd. ``These remains can't be traced to any existing tribe or group of people. Each of us can share in their history and culture.'' Michael Haney, of Seminole, Okla., said he came to the hearing with petitions signed by 250,000 Indians from 26 tribes opposing the exhibit. ``We demand that the remains of our ancestors be taken off display,'' he said. Haney threatened to set up picket lines at the museum if the exhibit is not closed on the proposed date of Feb. 15. The hearing was held to gauge grass-roots reaction to the decision by Gov. James R. Thompson's administration to close the site. The Illinois Department of Energy and Natural Resources, which runs the museum, announced plans last month to close the exhibit, citing growing sensitivity to the public display of human remains. Similar exhibits in Kansas, Alabama and Kentucky have been closed or will be shut down in deference to American Indian groups who objected to the displays. The exhibit of exposed graves in an excavated Indian burial ground is the centerpiece of the Dickson Mounds museum near Lewistown, 35 miles southwest of Peoria. The museum, one of the only ancient Indian burial plots open to public view, attracts about 80,000 visitors each year. When the natural resources agency decided to close the exhibit effective Feb. 1, with Thompson's approval, there was an outcry from lawmakers who contended the move would cripple the museum's drawing power and educational value. The state House of Representatives approved a non-binding resolution that opposed closing the exhibit and called for public hearings on the proposal. The hearing and original closing date were postponed by a snowstorm in late January. Attorney General Neil Hartigan, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, has criticized Thompson for agreeing to close the museum, complaining that Illinois children should not be denied access to their past. Spokesmen for the governor have labeled Hartigan a political opportunist and questioned his sincerity. The museum was opened in 1927 after an amateur archeologist, Don Dickson, unearthed the remains of 237 people who lived in the Illinois River Valley 800 to 1,000 years ago. It was privately operated until 1945, when it was purchased by the state and turned into a public museum.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Protests Proposed Cut to Seniors Jobs Program
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's proposed $14 million cut in a jobs program for elderly Americans will prevent 10,000 needy senior citizens from receiving help, a Senate chairman says. Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, who heads the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that oversees funding for the Labor Department, complained Tuesday of the agency's plan to scale back the jobs program. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, who testified on the department's $26.3 billion budget, said the administration chose to cut the program because of the nation's tight financial situation. Under the program, older citizens are placed in community service jobs such as in hospitals, schools and libraries. The jobs usually pay minimum wage. ``It's a great employment opportunity that keeps elderly Americans off welfare and gives them some respect, some dignity,'' Harkin said. ``This is one cut that just does not make sense.'' President Bush's budget proposes $343 million be spent on the program in the 1991 budget year; it got $357 million in the current fiscal year. ``It's a result of the budget constraints. I wish that it did not have to be so,'' Mrs. Dole said. Harkin, noting the hourly minimum wage is set to increase from $3.35 to $4.25 next year, said the program's funding would also have to increase to employ the same number of Americans in 1991. He suggested funding be restored through the supplemental appropriations process to account for the minimum wage difference, but Mrs. Dole said that process should be reserved for ``dire emergencies.'' ``Dire emergency is in the eye of the beholder,'' Harkin said. Many participants in his home state had lost their farms and the community service jobs helped them ``through a period of time to something else.'' On another issue, Mrs. Dole said the department's proposed $252.6 million increase for new youth job training programs would help an estimated 683,000 of the nation's ``most at-risk youth.'' ``If we're going to remain competitive in a global market, we must address ourselves to this skills gap and a motivational gap that exists in many areas as well,'' Mrs. Dole said. She said the department was working on ways to help high school students make the transition to the workforce, since many students now get out of school and ``kick around for a couple of years trying to find the right spot.'' Many senators praised the labor secretary for her role in bringing about a tentative settlement in the Pittston-United Mine Workers strike, but she again found herself explaining the government's hands-off approach at Eastern Air Lines, where machinists remain on strike. ``I think you always have to go case by case,'' Mrs. Dole said, citing different federal labor laws that govern the transportation industry. She also said the airline strike was not causing an emergency in the travel industry. ``This was not the kind of situation that would tie up transportation in a section of the country,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Groups Join in Asking for Assault Weapon Limits
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcement organizations are joining forces with gun control crusader Sarah Brady and religious and professional groups in urging quick Senate action to ban specified semiautomatic assault weapons. ``Drug traffickers are increasingly utilizing `assault weapons' to assist and protect them in the selling of death and destruction,'' Baltimore Police Chief Cornelius J. Behan, firearms chairman of the International Association of Chiefs of Police, said Tuesday. Behan and others appeared at a news conference with Mrs. Brady, whose husband, former presidential press secretary James Brady, was wounded in an assassination attempt on former President Reagan in 1981. ``This is the first time these fine groups have gathered together to speak out for sensible gun laws,'' said Mrs. Brady, who heads Handgun Control, Inc. ``But I'm angry that we have to be here at all.'' She said backers of the legislation were told it would be considered by the Senate this week, but it now appeared it might be put off until after the February congressional recess. Congress is to recess Friday for Lincoln's Birthday and return Feb. 19. The bill would impose a three-year ban on the sale, transport and possession of the semiautomatic weapons. Penalties include a mandatory 10 years in prison for use of a semiautomatic assault weapon in the commission of a drug trafficking or violent crime. ``We cannot begin to curb crime and the epidemic of random violence which plagues our cities while we continue to legitimize the wholesale arming of ordinary citizens, including the mentally defective and the street gangs,'' said Rabbi Lynne Landsberg, assistant director of the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism. The National Rifle Association opposes the bill, saying the restrictions would apply to guns used for hunting. But Warren Eisenberg, director of the International Council of B'nai B'rith, said his organization does not believe the bill would ``interfere with the legitimate activities of sportsmen.'' ``In an age when hate criminals and narcoterrorists use assault weapons to commit their crimes, it is ridiculous to try to defend certain categories of domestic and imported weapons as sporting equipment,'' Eisenberg said. Robert Z. Alpern, director of the Washington office of the Unitarian Universalist Association, said the bill ``would be a small step toward limiting the supply of semiautomatic weapons that have taken an unconscionable toll of human lives and terrorized our nation.'' ``Assault weapons are a life and death issue to police officers,'' said Sgt. William Pattison of Nassau County, N.Y., executive vice president of the National Association of Police Organizations. ``The police officers of this country are at war to reclaim our streets. We must end the maiming and killing of our children, our citizens and our police officers.'' Spokesmen for the American Bar Association, American Medical Association and American Federation of Teachers, AFL-CIO, also supported the bill.

DOC.HEAD: North's Lawyers Press for Line-by-Line Judgement on Iran-Contra Testimony
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North's lawyers say a ``line-by-line'' review of testimony from every witness should have been made to ensure the former White House aide's case was untainted by immunized congressional testimony. Defense attorney Barry Simon made the argument Tuesday in urging a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals to overturn North's convictions in the Iran-Contra scandal. Appeals Judge Patricia Wald asked whether Simon was urging that ``every line'' of testimony be scrutinized to determine whether its origin was independent of North's immunized statements in 1987 on national television. ``We believe that is what it requires,'' Simon said of the 1972 Supreme Court ruling declaring that prosecutors must show that none of their case comes from a defendant's previously immunized testimony. ``We would have gone through trial testimony line by line,'' Simon added. Simon also argued former President Reagan should have been called as a witness at North's trial. ``Frankly, I don't see how his testimony could not have been relevant,'' said Simon. North was convicted May 4 of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, altering and destroying National Security Council documents and accepting an illegal gratuity. North's defense to the first two convictions is that all his activities were authorized by his superiors, including then-national security adviser John Poindexter and Reagan. Government attorney Gerard Lynch said North's own testimony at his trial was that ``he never met alone'' with Reagan and that North ``never said the president told him to do anything.'' But appeals judge Laurence Silberman said that even if Reagan didn't give specific authorization, the ex-president's testimony could have been helpful to North. ``Suppose the ex-president says that `I never gave specific authorization' (but) `I did indicate that I didn't wish this information to be revealed,''' said Silberman. During nearly 2{ hours of arguments, Silberman also noted Reagan's written answers to questions in the Iran-Contra affair were submitted to a grand jury but were never provided to North's lawyers. ``Why as a matter of basic fairness'' weren't Reagan's answers turned over to North? asked Silberman. Lynch said the judgment was made that Reagan's written answers would not have been helpful to North. ``But our system'' of justice, said Silberman, is based on a defendant getting a wide latitude in obtaining information for his defense. Silberman said, ``what troubles me is we don't have a very good idea of what the president'' would testify had he been called as a witness at North's trial, indicating Reagan's still-secret written answers in the Iran-Contra scandal were general in nature. If North had worked in the State Department and Reagan had been secretary of state, Reagan would certainly have been called to testify, said Silberman. Wald is a Carter administration appointee. Silberman and David Sentelle, the third member of the panel that will decide North's appeal, were appointed by Reagan.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Says States, Farmers Must Keep Drugs Out of Milk
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration says it cannot bear the sole responsibility for ensuring the nation's milk supply is safe from veterinary drugs that may be harmful to humans. ``We know that traces of drug residues may sometimes be found in milk, and that such trace levels are rarely of public health concern,'' the FDA's Gerald B. Guest told a House panel Tuesday. ``While FDA and the states must continue to play a larger role in solving this problem, the responsibility for this situation is not totally a federal and state responsibility,'' said Guest, head of the FDA's Center for Veterinary Medicine. ``In fact, a share of the burden for reducing illegal residues in milk falls clearly on the dairy farmer, the veterinarian and the milk industry,'' he told the House Government Operations subcommittee on human resources and intergovernmental relations. But subcommittee Chairman Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., said, ``The honest answer is, you just don't know the extent to which the milk supply is safe.'' The hearing followed Monday's release of an FDA survey which purported to strike down the findings of private studies by The Wall Street Journal and the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer group. Weiss challenged the methods used in the FDA tests and questioned its reluctance to accept a relatively new screening test known as the Charm II. That test was used in the two private surveys. The test is highly sensitive, able to show drug residues in amounts as low as five parts per billion, advocates say. But the FDA said the test yields too many false positives and none of its positive findings could be validated in what it considered more accurate, newer tests. Charm II is also limited because it deals with only classes of drugs, not individual ones, FDA says. The FDA said its follow tests for sulfa drugs eliminated all samples. But the agency admitted its more advanced follow-up tests, the final being mass spectrometry, were far less sensitive to small amounts. Joseph Settepani, an FDA scientist, criticized the agency for failing to control extra-label drug use, under which veterinarians may prescribe drugs, under certain conditions for purposes other than those for which the drug was initially approved. He said an internal memorandum in 1988 listed 30 drugs believed to be used by milk producers. Sixteen are used extensively, he said. ``Many of these medicines are quite toxic, but the BS disk assay (test) only has any likelihood of being able to detect residues in milk from 2 of the 30 drugs on the list,'' he said. The BS test _ which stands for bacillus stearothermophilus _ is the only FDA standard test for state inspectors under the milk inspection program.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Weighing Federal Aid to National Teacher Certification Panel
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate reconvenes 9:30 a.m. EST; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is embroiled in a dispute over whether $25 million should go to a private national board seeking to set higher standards for public school teachers. Arguments over such a federal role in teacher certification held up quick action Tuesday on a $1.5 billion, five-year program aimed at upgrading the quality of education in the United States. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., sought unsuccessfully to strip the money from the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. But he promised to renew that fight today. ``What this board wants is ... to be the sole voice of setting the standards by which teachers operate _ that only teachers and their unions should decide who can and who cannot teach,'' he argued. ``Now, I think that's an outrage.'' Sen. Strom Thurmond, D-S.C., said the provision ``could set a precedent for federal funding of other private organizations, could move this country to federal control of teaching standards,'' he said. But the Senate defeated, on a 64-35 vote, Helms' amendment to remove funds for the board from the education bill. The board was created in 1987 at the urging of the National Governors' Association. It is an independent, nonpartisan organization governed by a 64-member board of directors, including representatives of teachers' unions. Activities so far have been low-key. Tuesday's vote upholding funds for the board came after several senators said public education in the United States had fallen into disarray. Sen. David Boren, chairman of the Intelligence Committee, said declining educational standards pose the greatest national security threat to the United States. Supporters of the funding said the board _ with federal encouragement _ would lend badly needed prestige to the teaching profession. They said it would give teachers the sort of professional competency reviews that doctors and lawyers get from the American Medical Association and American Bar Association. Teachers could voluntary submit for review by the national accreditation board, backers of the provision said. The proposal to authorize $25 million for the certification board is part of a wide-ranging education bill the Congressional Budget Office says would likely cost close to $1.5 billion over five years. The bill seeks to combat drugs in public schools, establish a presidential merit schools program and increase aid to schools seeking to reduce dropout rates. Earlier Tuesday, the Senate passed 99-0 legislation providing $50 million in fiscal 1991 to attack illiteracy _ said to affect at least 23 million Americans _ with a goal of eliminating illiteracy by the year 2000. Helms argued that the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards would be dominated by the National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers. ``The control of these unions over the board will enable them to use taxpayers money not so much to professionalize teachers as to finalize who does and does not teach in America,'' he said. Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., said a vote against the bill was ``a vote for parents.'' But Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., charged opponents were using ``misinformation'' to defeat the provision. Supporters noted that none of the $25 million could be used to pay the board's operating expenses. Instead, the money could be used only for research and development of teaching standards.

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Drug Treatments Slowing Spread of AIDS
DOC.TEXT: A new government study shows drug treatments are slowing the rate of AIDS cases among homosexual men, but that the new therapies aren't reaching intravenous drug users and others among the poor. The study shows about 36 percent fewer homosexual men have developed AIDS than had been projected by the Public Health Service. This rate began slowing around the middle of 1987, around the time the anti-AIDS drug AZT and other AIDS treatments came into wide use. However, the number of intravenous drug users developing AIDS is continuing upward along the same path as projected. ``A good conjecture is they had less access,'' since IV drug users tend to be poor and underserved by the health care system, said Mitchell H. Gail, a National Cancer Institute epidemiologist who prepared the study with NCI colleagues. ``Although we don't have good data yet, it's a reasonable guess that they are not being treated as intensively as they should be,'' Gail said., The study is to be published in the March issue of the Journal of AIDS. AIDS can take years to develop after a person has been infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. The study confirms early treatment with AZT and drugs such as aerosol pentamidine, which treats opportunistic infections that can kill AIDS patients, can slow progression of the disease. ``This is a significant report since it provides independent evidence that early intervention and treatment for people with HIV infection slows progression of their disease,'' Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health at the Department of Health and Human Services, said in a statement. He added, ``I am delighted that treatment programs are effective.'' But he said, ``It is extremely important to remember that this good news is not a substitute for sustained behavior choices and effective prevention efforts by all people who are at risk.'' Gail said the numbers show that although treatments may be slowing progress of the disease, people infected with the virus will eventually get the disease. No one is known to have recovered from AIDS. ``We have to be prepared for this large pool of infected people to work their way to the more severely immune depressed and to an AIDS diagnosis, unless we develop a cure,'' he said. ``So we can't be that sanguine. We have to be alert that AIDS incidence is going to rise in the future.'' The federal Centers for Disease Control, which tracks reported AIDS cases, is reassessing its projections. Last month, the agency said its estimates of the potential number of AIDS cases, ranging from 1 million to 1.5 million, may be too high. The CDC now believes the number to be in the range of 700,000 to 1.4 million, according to an HHS source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Zero Inflation Resolution Backed by Four Regional Fed Officials
DOC.TEXT: Four Federal Reserve Bank presidents are supporting a congressional resolution calling for an inflation rate near zero within five years, but warn it will require temporarily higher unemployment and slower economic growth. ``There is absolutely no question that bringing the underlying inflation rate down from its current level of 4.5 percent to something like 1 or 1.5 percent will involve costs,'' said E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. ``Indeed, I am very hard-pressed to recall a single case where a significant reduction in inflation was accomplished in a major industrial country without relatively large costs,'' he told the House Banking subcommittee on monetary policy on Tuesday. ``Over the last decade, in both Germany and the Netherlands _ the European superstars on the inflation front _ the unemployment rate has been quite high by historic and international comparative standards,'' he said. Nevertheless, Corrigan and the three other presidents endorsed a zero inflation resolution proposed by Rep. Stephen L. Neal, D-N.C., chairman of the monetary policy subcommittee. In the long run, zero inflation will bring the greatest possible economic growth and lower interest rates, they argued. The nation's monetary policy is set mainly by the Federal Open Market Committee, which is composed of the seven-member Federal Reserve Board in Washington and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks. Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said work done by his staff indicates that in the short term slower growth and higher unemployment, but not an outright recession, are necessary to bring inflation down to zero by 1994. The unemployment rate, now at 5.3 percent, could rise to between 6.75 percent and 7.75 percent, he said. At the same time, growth, as measured by the gross national product, would have to be 1 to 2 percentage points slower than the 2.5 percent to 3 percent growth that the bank presidents said was the fastest achievable without accelerating inflation. Congress and the administration can ease the pain by cutting the budget deficit and stimulating savings and investment, Corrigan said. ``It's going to take much more than rhetoric,'' he said. However, Neal's resolution, if passed, would give the Fed the political backing it needs to do its part, said Robert P. Black, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va. ``Inflation may well re-accelerate in the absence of a clear signal to the public that Congress fully supports the Federal Reserve's commitment to lower inflation,'' he warned. ``The (Federal Reserve) is under constant pressure to `do something' with monetary policy in the short run to improve the economy's performance,'' Black said. ``Such pressures have, at times ... actually contributed to an acceleration of inflation. There is obviously a risk that history will repeat itself.'' The fourth Federal Reserve Bank president endorsing the resolution was H. Lee Hoskins of Cleveland. In recent weeks, the Bush administration, with no noticeable effect, has called on the Fed to lower interest rates and stimulate economic growth. Michael Boskin, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, told reporters Tuesday that the administration supports reducing inflation over time, but not necessarily within the timetable required by Neal's resolution. ``Our primary goal is to sustain the highest possible growth. In the course of obtaining a sensible monetary policy, we think it is desirable to maintain growth and employment,'' Boskin said.

DOC.HEAD: House Sends Senate a Bill Easing Voters' Registration
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats are raising images of democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and the U.S. civil rights movement to pressure President Bush into backing a House-passed bill easing voter registration. Over the objections of the White House and some other top Republicans, the House approved the legislation 289-132 on Tuesday and sent the measure to the Senate. Sixty-one of the chamber's 175 Republicans broke with party leaders to vote for the proposal. The so-called motor voter bill requires states to include voting registration forms with drivers' license applications and to establish procedures to sign up voters by mail and at numerous government offices. It would take effect in January 1993. States would have to search voting lists at least once every four years for people who have moved or have registered fraudulently. The federal government would provide up to $50 million to help states pay for the new procedures. The White House complained last week that the measure, written by Reps. Al Swift, D-Wash., and William Thomas, R-Calif., would allow too much fraud and be too expensive for states. Democrats spent much of Tuesday attempting to capitalize on the administration's opposition. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., noted the bill was being debated ``at the very time the leaders of Eastern Europe are trying to bring democracy to their countries.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., told reporters Democrats and Republicans are ``proud and happy'' about the political reforms under way in Eastern Europe. If President Bush opposes improvements at home, he said, ``I would be interested in knowing why.'' Even Democratic Party Chairman Ronald H. Brown got into the act, telling reporters, ``As the Iron Curtain falls abroad, we must open fully the voting curtain here at home.'' Other Democrats drew connections between the legislation and the American civil rights movement. Arguing the bill would be the broadest extension of voting rights since the 1965 Voting Rights Act, Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga. _ a 1960s civil rights activist _ said, ``We should not be afraid to open fully the doors of political participation and let the people come in.'' The legislators rejected by a 291-129 vote a White House-backed alternative introduced by Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan. The measure would have made the bill's new procedures voluntary and provided $120 million to help states boost their voter registration efforts. ``Our campaigns are too long, they're too expensive, they alienate potential voters,'' said House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill. ``If you want more people to vote, then we should run more stimulating and competitive campaigns.'' Swift argued the GOP amendment would ``gut'' the underlying bill. The bill is aimed at dwindling voter turnout, which dipped to 50 percent of the 120 million registered voters in the 1988 presidential polling. Experts say about 60 million Americans who are eligible to vote are not registered. Advocates of the measure believe the ``motor voter'' section would be particularly effective because 91 percent of the 180 million voting-age Americans have drivers' licenses or motor vehicle department identification cards. The legislation would apply to every state but North Dakota, which does not require voters to register.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0431, fixing heading.
A Country On The Brink Of Collapse
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For about $5 you can get a room at Saalfeld's best hotel. Cheap, but you might not be pleased by the failing furnace, sagging floors and a bed that remains unmade unless you do it yourself. ``East Germany is just like this hotel,'' remarked a worker at the Hotel Anker who said he would be fired if his name was published. ``The whole place is falling apart and no one in their right mind would want to stay here.'' East Germany seems like it is crumbling. Despair at economic conditions and uncertainty about East Germany's future, an exodus of workers to West Germany, strikes, and absenteeism are bringing the country to the brink of collapse. East Germany is also suffering a political paralysis stemming from a leadership vacuum and constant bickering among opposition forces. ``This country is in serious trouble, and there's not a lot of agreement about what to do about it,'' said Guenter Bader, a member of the New Forum opposition group in Saalfeld, a town of about 30,000 people near the Bavarian border. Karl Gruenheid, head of a government economics committee, said in East Berlin that the shortage of workers and strikes are seriously driving down production. Mail is no longer delivered in some areas because there's no one to deliver it. Soldiers are being used to operate trolleys because of a driver shortage. Production at a giant potash mine near Erfurt was paralyzed by striking workers demanding more pay and assurances they won't lose their jobs as East Germany goes through the painful process of adopting free-market principles. Production slow-downs are starting to create serious shortages of some key products, such as rolled steel, coal and natural gas, West German news media report. At least one-tenth of Saalfeld's citizens have fled to West Germany and the number grows every day, Bader said. ``If something isn't done soon, Saalfeld will be nothing but an old folk's home with a few jobless Stasi (state security agents) left behind,'' he said. West German companies have plans to help bail out East Germany's economy as the two countries gradually move toward reunification, but the rescue operation will cost billions and take years. East Germany once had one of the strongest economies in the East bloc. But an exodus of more than 400,000 people in little more than a year and rising despair among the people have steered the economy to the edge of disaster. Financial experts say East Germany has many assets on which to build a thriving economy. But over 40 years the Communists did little maintenance on plants and factories and a total overhaul may be needed to make them profitable. Experts say tourism could also become an important moneymaker in East Germany, but enormous and costly renewal efforts would be needed. Saalfeld, for example, sits on the edge of the picturesque Thuringian Forest and would probably draw tourists with the right accommodations and entertainment possibilities. But like most small-town hotels across East Germany, the main one in Saalfeld _ the Anker _ has standards most Westerners would not tolerate. The hotel furnace failed on at least two recent cold February nights, the maid showed up only to announce it was time for the guest to leave, and noxious coal fumes filtered into the room from someone else's furnace. ``Whenever West German businessmen think about our country's economy, what they see is a place where a lot of money has to be invested. This hotel, for example, would have to be totally rebuilt. It's an embarrassment,'' said a hotel employee. During a rally in Saalfeld, New Forum speakers promised they would work for the preservation of local jobs if residents sent their candidate to Parliament in March 18 elections. But the 500 or so rally participants were less interested in the elections than they were in calling for unity with West Germany. East Germany's leaders have finally had to swallow the idea that German unification is inevitable. But they want it to come from a gradual process. Communist Premier Hans Modrow has pleaded for workers to stay on the job and for citizens to remain in East Germany, saying the country has to work out its problems in an orderly manner. ``Above all, I call on the citizens ... to abstain from anything _ and I mean anything _ that damages our economy, and assistance for and welfare of the people,'' Modrow told Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Group Promises No Move to Block Judicial Nominee
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has one less roadblock toward confirmation as a federal appeals judge with a major civil rights group's promise not to stand in his way. ``While we cannot give him our unqualified endorsement, we will, however, not oppose the nomination,'' NAACP Executive Director Benjamin L. Hooks said Tuesday. The statement was issued as the Senate Judiciary Committee heard testimony on the nomination of Clarence Thomas, a prominent black conservative in the Reagan and Bush administrations. Civil rights forces over the last seven years have continuously criticized the 41-year-old Yale law graduate and former aide to Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo. They say he has been lax in enforcing anti-bias laws. It appeared the nomination of Thomas to succeed Robert Bork on the U.S. Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia could become the first skirmish this year between the Bush administration and liberals over judicial nominees. But there didn't appear at the hearing to be enough opposition in the Senate to block the nomination, with the NAACP standing aside. In his brief statement, Hooks said, ``we do have questions about his management of EEOC.'' Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, a member of the panel, said, ``Frankly, I have questions about the nominee's commitment to the law.'' But he told Thomas, ``We haven't always agreed, but I respect your views.'' Nancy Kreiter of Chicago, research director of the Women Employed Institute, testified that under Thomas the commission ``failed to fulfill its mandate to protect the rights of victims of discrimination.'' ``Mr. Thomas' actions in the areas of policy and enforcement performance demonstrate a lack of respect for law and a disregard for individuals,'' she said, arguing people who file complaints have been treated with increasing hostility. ``A careful look at his record raises serious questions about his qualifications for a lifetime appointment to administer justice on the federal bench,'' she said. Rutgers law professor Alfred W. Blumrose, an advocate of rights for senior citizens, told the committee the commission apparently violated its own regulations by eliminating a policy of pursuing hiring goals and timetables in 1985 without taking any formal action under the federal government's ``sunshine'' law. He said there was a ``sort of quiet suggestion by innuendo leading the lawyers in the agency to alter the process.'' Thomas testified that as an appeals judge he would not ``have the option of roaming unfettered through judicial terrain'' and injecting his personal views into decisions. Thomas vowed ``to faithfully adhere to the Supreme Court decisions'' and not ``torture a case to reach a preconceived notion of what a result should be.'' He acknowledged the statute of limitations on 900 cases of alleged bias against the elderly lapsed before the commission acted on them. ``It happened on my watch,'' he said. But he said the lapses were because he initiated more extensive investigative procedures that may have been ``too ambitious.'' Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., asked him about reports that 13,000 cases actually lapsed. Thomas said: ``I don't have the slightest idea where that number comes from.'' Thomas, who is black, said as a conservative he often finds himself at odds with ``an expected orthodoxy from black Americans.'' He said criticism from civil rights groups ``is something that is uncomfortable, but it is something that I'll have to live with.'' ``I think the choice between principle and popularity is something that each individual will have to make and I've made mine and I'll live with the consequences,'' Thomas said. Danforth, who twice hired Thomas as an aide, praised him as ``a person who calls them as he sees them.''

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Agreement Reached to Limit Toxic Industrial Releases
DOC.TEXT: Senate negotiators on clean air legislation are working toward a compromise on curbing auto emissions, now that sources say they reached a tentative agreement to limit toxic industrial releases. ``I hope we can conclude the discussions this week,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, in a telephone interview Tuesday night after daylong closed-door bargaining on key parts of the clean air bill. The legislation, which would require tighter pollution controls on everything from automobiles to industrial facilities and electric power plants, would be the first tightening of federal clean air law in 13 years. A subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee planned to begin considering that chamber's clean air bill today. Mitchell said several proposals on auto emissions were being considered and that he hoped that issue could be resolved by the end of today. According to Senate sources, negotiators reached a tentative agreement that would require industry to use the best available technology to curb toxic chemical releases and eventually meet specific health standards based on cancer risk. Industry and the Bush administration had opposed the health-risk criteria, arguing it would be too expensive and some plants would be unable to comply. But the compromise would make it easier for certain plants to avoid the most stringent health-based standards because the government would have to calculate risks using ``real world'' situations at specific plants and not rely on mathematical models. Sources said the negotiators also reached agreement on urban smog pollution from sources other than motor vehicles. The compromise, however, exempts most smaller polluters which complained that they might be driven out of business if required to install pollution control equipment. The negotiations have involved a relatively small number of senators and senior Bush administration officials including EPA Administrator William Reilly, his deputy for air pollution issues, William Rosenberg, and Roger Porter, a senior presidential adviser. Regular participants have been Mitchell, Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, and Sens. Max Baucus, D-Mont., and John Chafee, R-R.I., the bill's two floor leaders, as well as other senators with interest about specific parts of the bill, according to Senate sources. The talks are aimed at heading off a floor fight on the clean air bill, which Mitchell has made a target for early action. Negotiators on Tuesday narrowed the discussions on auto emissions to a small number of proposals, including a compromise reached between Mitchell and Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., who had championed the concerns of the automakers. But the Mitchell-Levin proposal was not endorsed by the Bush administration and both Baucus and Chafee also were said to have reservations about it. The Mitchell-Levin proposal would retain tough second-stage tailpipe standards scheduled to go into effect in the year 2003, but eliminate a requirement for automakers to sharply increase fuel economy through mandated reductions in carbon dioxide emissions. The carbon dioxide reductions have been strongly opposed by automakers who maintain they are not feasible, while being pushed by environmentalists as a way to deal with global warming. Meanwhile, some senators not directly participating were said to be privately expressing some concern about the closed-door deal making. Even Baucus suggested some discomfort Tuesday, saying he wants to ``make sure that all that has been written (into the bill) in public is not unwritten in these closed sessions.''

DOC.HEAD: Polygraph Expert Appears Before Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury's questioning of a polygraph expert who is helping investigate the bombing of Pan AM Flight 103 indicates the Justice Department's probe is entering a new phase. A federal grand jury in Washington heard testimony last Friday from James Keefe, a polygraph expert for a security consulting firm hired by lawyers representing Pan Am in a civil suit over the Dec. 21, 1988 bombing. Keefe testified about giving polygraph tests to three Pan Am baggage handlers in Frankfurt, West Germany, during his appearance before the grand jury, said a source familiar with the case. Keefe told the panel two of the three baggage handlers failed the polygraph tests when they said they knew nothing about the transfer of a piece of luggage to Flight 103, said the source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The source confirmed a report published in Tuesday's editions of the Syracuse Post Standard. Keefe's appearance before the grand jury indicates U.S. authorities are stepping up their investigation of the bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland that killed 259 passengers and crew members and 11 people on the ground. Anti-terrorism laws give federal prosecutors in Washington jurisdiction to bring cases in acts that occur abroad. Scottish police believe the bomb was in a suitcase that was placed aboard Pan Am Flight 103 in Frankfurt before it took off for London. Passengers and luggage were transferred to a Boeing 747 at London's Heathrow Airport for the trans-Atlantic leg of the trip to New York City. The suitcase is believed to have been brought to Frankfurt aboard a plane from Malta. Investigators found clothing fragments in Lockerbie that were traced to a clothing store in Malta, according to a federal law enforcement source. The bombing investigation has focused on a number of terrorist organizations, including the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. Polygraph tests cannot be admitted in court, but the questions Keefe asked the baggage handlers and their responses may provide investigators with new leads in the case. Keefe works for Interfor Inc., a New York-based security consulting firm retained by lawyers representing Pan Am's insurance carrier in a $300 million damage suit filed by relatives of people killed in the bombing. He was served with the grand jury subpoena on Jan. 25 as he stepped off a plane at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York following his return from Europe, said the source.

DOC.HEAD: No Planning Now Against Soviet Attack On Iran
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department is no longer planning for large-scale resistance to a Soviet attack through Iran toward Persian Gulf oil fields, according to published reports today. The instructions are contained in the annual Defense Planning Guidance, this year covering the period 1992-1997 and signed by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Jan. 24, according to The Washington Post. The newspaper said a senior Defense Department official briefed several reporters about the document, which is classified. The New York Times today carried a similar description of the contents of the document, attributed to a senior defense official. A Pentagon spokesman, Col. Steve Roy, said Tuesday night he had no information on the guidance document. The United States has had contingency plans to counter a Soviet attack into Iran since the Soviets invaded Afghanistan in 1979. Central Command, based in Tampa, Fla., was established to handle the planning and to direct any military operations in the Persian Gulf area. This command handled the Navy patrols of the gulf and escorts of Kuwaiti tankers under the U.S. flag in 1987 against Iranian attacks. Naval activity drastically curtailed after the end of the Iran-Iraq war. According to the Times, the senior official said the threat of a Soviet drive through Iran was now ``not credible'' and the United States was not capable of mounting a defense in Iran's Zagros Mountains. According to the Post, the United States would still ``consider the contingency of the Soviet attack into Iran'' but no longer make the ``large investments to support forces in Iran,'' according to the senior official. According to both newspapers, the guidance document instructs planners to assume a successful negotiation on conventional forces in Europe will cut Soviet forces there. Both said the services were told to plan to defend the oil fields of the Arabian Peninsula against attacks by unspecified adversaries.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,301.87, down 364.96 points, or 0.97 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Fonda Protesters Put Down Placards
DOC.TEXT: A group that threatened to picket actress Jane Fonda's new film ``Stanley & Iris'' at every movie house in the state has put down its placards. After a delay of more than five months, the movie shot partly in Waterbury will open Friday. But the Waterbury-based ``American Coalition Against Hanoi Jane,'' which staged protests during the filming in Connecticut in 1988, won't be at Hoyt's Mallview Cinema 10 for the opening. Gaetano Russo, the coalition's organizer, said the group has accomplished its goals of educating the public about Fonda's actions during the Vietnam War. The coalition has criticized Fonda for actions such as a 1972 radio broadcast during which Fonda criticized the United States for its role in the Vietnam War. Fonda apologized to Vietnam veterans and their families during a segment of ABC-TV's ``20-20'' shown in 1988 while she was still in Waterbury. She said she never intended to hurt them or make their situation worse. She also appeared at a benefit for the Vietnam Veterans Agent Orange Victims during the summer of 1988 at Quassy Amusement Park in Middlebury to raise money for the children afflicted with illnesses associated with the defoliate Agent Orange, which was used in Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Fire Blamed on Woodburning Stove
DOC.TEXT: Relatives say they listened helplessly to screams for help but were kept back by intense heat as a young couple and four children died in a fire that destroyed their mobile home. A woodburning stove that had been moved and reinstalled in the mobile home just a day earlier caused the fire. Killed in Tueday's predawn fire were Davie Light, 18; Michelle Miller, 22; their 3-week-old daughter, Jessica; Miller's two other children, James, 3, and Alicia, 16 months; and Light's niece, Rachel Hafley, 3. ``I ran over and I could hear Davie yelling and banging, trying to get out,'' said Jim Wills, Light's brother-in-law. ``I tried to yank the back door open, but when I finally did, it was too late.'' The flames blocked the door, he said, trapping the occupants. ``It's an awful thing when you hear someone hollering for help,'' Wills said, ``and you can't do nothing.'' Investigators said the fire started in an improperly installed flue attached to the wood stove. ``Apparently the flue pipe was a couple of inches too short where it ran through the ceiling,'' said Washington County Sheriff Ronnie L. Skiles. ``The stove had also been mounted on wooden blocks.'' Robert Jacobsen, of the state division of fire safety, said the fire probably had smoldered for some time before bursting into flames and that the residents probably could have gotten out had the trailer been equipped with a smoke detector. Skiles said wood stoves were becoming more prevalent in trailers in the area, 65 miles southwest of St. Louis. ``People can't afford gas, they can't afford electricity, especially in a financially depressed area like Washington County. They do it to save money,'' he said. Skiles said although fire codes don't forbid it, ``a mobile home is not made for a wood stove.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down, Dollar Higher on Tokyo Market
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged Wednesday, while the dollar inched up against the yen. The dollar closed at 145.10 yen, up 0.20 yen from Tuesday's 144.90-yen close. The currency opened higher at 145.18 yen, and ranged between 145.03 yen and 145.34 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 364.96 points, or 0.97 percent, ending the day at 37,301.87. It had gained 35.42 points Tuesday. The index fell as most investors stepped to the sidelines amid uncertainties over the U.S. government bond auction and the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee meeting, said a Nomura Securities analyst, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Although many participants evaluated (Mikhail) Gorbachev's achievement in the meeting positively, expecting the move would lead to further reforms and stability, they can't wipe off all the uncertainties,'' he said. Japanese investors reportedly bought substantial amounts of the three-year U.S. government notes auctioned Tuesday, but it remains to be seen if demand will be strong for the sale of 10- and 30-year bonds later Wednesday and Thursday. At the end of the morning session, the dollar stood at 145.13 yen. It opened at 145.18 yen, up 0.28 yen from Monday's close, and ranged between 145.03 yen and 145.34 yen. The dollar-yen rate moved narrowly in thin trading, said Minori Takeuchi, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. ``Market players rather focused on cross-tradings with the West German mark,'' she said. But the trading was mixed as some investors sold the mark against the yen to take profits on the German currency's recent gains, Ms. Takeuchi said. Investors bought the mark encouraged by Gorbachev's initiative calling for an end to the Communist monopoly on power, traders said. Gorbachev's grip on power is believed to be key to stability in Eastern Europe, a key factor in the mark's strength. The Communist Party meeting continues for a third day Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A 156-year-old painting of a mountain by the founder of the Hudson River School apparently shows the highest peak in the Berkshires, not a New York slope as was long thought. Some art historian sleuthing has revealed that what was accepted as a scene near the Hudson River studio of 19th century landscape artist Thomas Cole actually is Mount Greylock of Massachusetts. The 1834 painting had been identified in the 1950s as a scene near Mount Merino in Hudson, N.Y., across the river from Catskill, N.Y., where Cole maintained a studio. Maureen Johnson Hickey, curator of art education for the Berkshire Museum in Pittsfield, said her curiosity was piqued when she began assembling an exhibit of Hudson River School painters' scenes of the Berkshires to open in March. ``All the biggies _ Cole, Church, Duran, Innes _ came to the Berkshires and I just couldn't believe that Cole, living so close, had never painted anything here,'' she said. Ellwood C. Parry III, a professor of art history at the University of Arizona, said Cole was in Pittsfield in 1833 and had mentioned doing a portrait of Hoosac Mountain, as Greylock was then called. At Parry's suggestion, a painting acquired two years ago by the Newark Museum in Newark, N.J., was examined and found to depict Lake Pontoosuc and Mount Greylock, rising 3,491 feet from a sea-level valley in the northern Berkshires, instead of the gentler rise along the Hudson River. Although the lake is larger now, a grove of pines at the right of the painting still stands and the white church steeple and little village of Lanesboro can be seen in the distance, just as they appear in the painting, Ms. Hickey said.

Some asked about former President Reagan's boyhood habit of hiding pennies, others fixated on the football in his bedroom and just about everyone liked his birthday cake. By all accounts, the birthday party for 250 fifth graders at Reagan's boyhood home was a success even though Reagan was not on hand to have a piece of the birthday cake. In honor of his 79th birthday, youngsters from the school system toured the Reagan Home and Visitor's Center on Tuesday and saw a video about his life. Fifth graders were selected for the party because Reagan was about that age when he began school in Dixon, after moving with his family to the northern Illinois town from his hometown of Tampico, about 20 miles southwest. The Dixon City Council and the Illinois General Assembly marked the event by declaring Tuesday Ronald Reagan Day. The birthday party for fifth graders may become an annual event.

As a municipal animal control officer, Dave Opfer has plenty of experience rounding up stray dogs, cats. Now, a stubborn seal has been added to the list. Opfer said the slippery marine mammal wandered into this logging and prison town about 50 miles southwest of Seattle three times Tuesday. The first two times it was herded into a creek and back into Oakland Bay, an arm of Puget Sound. The third time the seal was spotted near the library, eight blocks from the water and heading uphill. Attempts to move it were met by bared teeth and ominous growling. The seal eventually was captured in a net and taken to the Point Defiance Zoo in Tacoma. Marine mammal experts at Cascadia Research identified the animal as a 5-year-old northern fur seal but were unable to say what it was doing in town, police officer Michael Hudnell said.

DOC.HEAD: Black School Chief Reinstated as Racial Turmoil Closes Selma Schools
LaserPhoto MY1
DOC.TEXT: The school board reinstated a black superintendent and closed the schools today to ease racial turmoil that raised discordant echoes from this 1960s battleground of the civil rights movement. With the 25th anniversary of the Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march only a month away, white officials appeared close to bowing to the key demands of black protesters. The six white members of the Selma Board of Education reinstated the city's first black school superintendent, Norward Roussell, and urged the five black board members who had quit over Roussell's treatment to return. Roussell said he was not surprised by his reinstatement, saying he ``did not understand the board's decision to relieve me of my duties.'' The board closed all 11 schools in the 6,000-student system, which is 70 percent black. They will not reopen until racial tensions subside and the threat of schoolhouse violence ends, the board said. The board's decision late Tuesday capped weeks of protests and periodic school boycotts. ``Selma is a magic name for demonstrations,'' said Mayor Joe Smitherman, who has served all but one term as mayor since 1964. ``This is almost like a beginning of a re-enactment of the '60s _ a real re-enactment. ``I hope it doesn't get to that,'' he said. The five black school board members quit in December after the board, in a vote split along racial lines, decided not to renew Roussell's $80,000-a-year contract in June. Supporters claimed Roussell was removed because of race and not because of a lack of managerial skills, as his detractors said. Last week, the white members of the board voted to remove Roussell immediately, and installed the Rev. F.D. Reese, the black principal of Selma High School, as interim superintendent. The decision to reinstate Roussell meant Reese would lose his new job, but Reese said he accepted the decision. Reese called for the orderly dismissal of classes Tuesday after reports of fighting at 1,508-student Selma High, the system's only public high school, which is about two-thirds black. ``We could certainly see and feel the level of tensions among the students,'' Reese said. Police were called but there were no arrests. Dozens of the black students joined in demonstrations outside City Hall, carrying signs saying ``Smitherman Must Go,'' and singing civil rights songs. On Monday, four black protesters were arrested on misdemeanor charges in a melee in the mayor's office. One of the four, Rose Sanders, was taken to a hospital with an apparent neck or back injury and was listed in stable condition. Her husband, state Sen. Hank Sanders, a Democrat, said she was in pain but indicated the injury was not critical. The five black board members said they never signed formal resignation papers, leaving open the possibility of their return. A statement by the board said Selma schools would reopen ``upon adequate assurances to Dr. Roussell and the board that the safety and physical welfare of our students and all school employees can be ensured.'' Roussell was at Selma High as throngs of parents and students left the building with the cancellation of classes Tuesday morning. He joined in helping disperse crowds of students ``so we would not have any trouble.'' Roussell, who became superintendent in 1987, said he was not legally removed from office by the board and was ``officially on vacation'' during recent weeks. In sanctioning his removal, white school board members had cited an unfavorable job evaluation and Roussell's management style.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Issues New Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service is putting out guidelines to help charities determine how much of a contribution is tax-deductible when the donor receives something in return. The IRS also asked charitable organizations to determine beforehand the fair market value of any benefit given to a contributor. Any solicitation, ticket or receipt should state how much of the contribution is deductible. Although the law allows a tax deduction for most contributions to charities recognized by the IRS, it generally requires that any goods or services of value received in return be subtracted from the deductible amount. In the new guidelines, issued Tuesday, the agency acknowledged that some gifts to the donor may be so insubstantial that the entire contribution is deductible. In general, the ``insubstantial'' rule will come into play when the value of all benefits received by a donor is not more than 2 percent of the contribution, or $50, whichever is less; or if the contribution is $27.26 or more and the only benefits are token items such as T-shirts, bookmarks or calendars bearing the charity's name. The cost of the article may not exceed $5.45. The latter two figures represent the inflation-adjusted value of $25 and $5, respectively, which were the limitations when Congress amended the law affecting deductible contributions.
DOC.HEAD: Congressional Study Says Pap Smears Can Help Elderly Women
DOC.TEXT: Pap smear screening to detect cervical cancer, combined with appropriate treatment, could save the lives of many elderly women, according to a new study by the Office of Technology Assessment. Medicare, the federal health care program for the elderly, will begin paying for Pap tests in July 1990, and the study by the congressional agency said the screening will be most cost-effective it is combined with efforts to encourage high-risk women to be tested. According to the study: _Women at high risk of cervical cancer are smokers, poor, nonwhite, were young at first intercourse and have had multiple sexual partners. _Studies have found that women who have been screened are one-half to one-tenth as likely to develop cervical cancer as other women. _Elderly women appear to have lower rates of localized, noninvasive cervical tumors than younger women, but the elderly have higher rates of invasive cervical cancer and higher death rates from cervical cancer. _Since elderly women are less likely to be screened for cervical cancer than younger women, older women are more likely to be in advanced stages of the disease when it is diagnosed.
DOC.HEAD: US Official Says Other Nations Lag in Controlling Drug Chemicals
DOC.TEXT: Governments in West Germany, the Netherlands and Japan are unwilling to control the export of chemicals used to manufacture drugs, says a Bush administration official. ``It does not seem likely that European chemical legislation, as contemplated, will have a significant impact on the diversion and trafficking of chemicals, particularly those destined for the illicit production of cocaine,'' said Gene R. Haislip, deputy assistant administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration. Haislip, testifying before the Subcommittee on Foreign Commerce of the Senate Commerce Committee, said great quantities of chemicals are shipped through the Dutch port of Rotterdam. ``Whereas in the past most of these shipments have come from the United States, I think the shift is on and in the future we're going to see that Europe, and to some lesser extent Brazil and other countries, will become the predominant suppliers, with the Netherlands and the Federal Republic of Germany ... being the two principal exporting countries,'' he said. In an interview after his testimony, Haislip said the West German and Dutch governments are reluctant to interfere with what they see as legitimate business. At the hearing, Sens. Harry Reid and Richard Bryan, both Nevada Democrats, accused U.S. chemical companies of selling chemicals that help make drugs in Colombia. ``The evidence is inescapable that some American chemical manufacturers and distributors have contributed to America's $100 billion cocaine habit,'' said Bryan.

DOC.HEAD: Party Officials Extend Meeting, Gorbachev Criticized From Both Sides
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with meeting convening Wednesday, SUB 8th graf, `He said ... Wednesday morning.' Picks up 9th pvs, `Delegates interviewed ...' ^LaserPhotos MOSB2,3
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party leaders added an unexpected third day to their pivotal meeting Tuesday and sent Mikhail S. Gorbachev back to the drawing board to fill in holes in his blueprint for ending the party's monopoly on power. The extension of the party session, which was supposed to end Tuesday, was a clear sign of the controversy generated by Gorbachev's proposals to revamp the country's political structure. It sharply contrasted with previous sessions, when the Central Committee automatically approved policies that had been worked out at higher levels. Central Committee sources said most speakers agreed with Gorbachev's proposal that the party's monopoly on power, enshrined in the Soviet Constitution, must end. ``All unanimously think it has become obsolete. It has no meaning,'' Central Committee member Vladimir P. Anishchev told reporters who gathered outside the Kremlin's Spasky Gate to await news. The session was closed to journalists. However, partial transcripts of two days of the session, in which 51 speakers took the floor, indicated that neither radical reformers nor hard-liners were satisfied with Gorbachev's proposal. Delegates said Tuesday night's Central Committee session was suspended so a commission, headed by Gorbachev, could complete changes to his nearly 20-page platform. A Central Committee source quoted Gorbachev as saying that the 60-member commission was only half-finished, even though it met all night Monday. The meeting resumed Wednesday morning. Delegates interviewed Monday and Tuesday as they filed out onto Red Square indicated a common objection: the platform contains few specifics. ``A lot of its points, and this is what has been said by many speakers, need major changes and reinforcement, especially in the direction of stepping up decisive action,'' Leonid A. Bibin, a non-voting Central Committee member, said in a Soviet TV interview Tuesday. Bibin said he and others want the platform to stress that the party must remain united. The party's unity has been threatened in recent months by a breakaway of the party in Lithuania and by proposals by Moscow radicals for formal factions. Gorbachev, as he has done on so many issues, has placed himself in the middle, trying to forge compromises. Still, the Soviet leader's platform has yielded to the demands of political reformers _ including the thousands of people who gathered near the Kremlin wall Sunday _ by removing the party's monopoly and advancing to this summer a party congress that will be empowered to clear out conservatives on the Central Committee. Gorbachev is not likely to water down the platform, for fear of displeasing the increasingly active and consolidated reformers. But he also must be careful not to antagonize conservatives, who remain strong in the Central Committee. Formally, the Central Committee has the power to replace the party leader. Indrek Toome, premier of the Baltic republic of Estonia and a guest at the party meeting, emphasized the threat from hard-liners. ``I am worried about the wish of a fairly large proportion of the people in this hall to reverse things, so as to clamp down on things and return to the old order,'' Toome told Soviet TV. Other speakers worried out loud about Gorbachev's political standing. Y.A. Gankovsky, a Siberian party secretary, suggested Gorbachev's position was weakened because he had taken on too many jobs. ``While you, Mikhail Sergeyevich, were only the (party) general secretary _absolutely without flattery I will say _ we felt that new ideas were born in the party, that some kind of reformation work was under way to break up the outlived and outdated. Now you have four posts. One gets the impression that someone wants the general not to be successful at any of them, scattering powers,'' Gankovsky said. In addition to being party general secretary, Gorbachev is president, chairman of the Defense Council and a Politburo member. Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, widely identified as its leading conservative, received warm applause for a speech criticizing failings in perestroika, Gorbachev's reform program, the Central Committee source said. ``After somewhat of an enlivening in the first two years of perestroika, the economy began to decline, inter-ethnic feuds reached bloodshed, people began to experience fear, and in some places there is practically dual power,'' Ligachev said in remarks reported by Tass. He said the Politburo, led by Gorbachev, and the government committed ``serious oversights and mistakes.'' He cited monetary problems that worsened consumer goods shortages, a lack of supervision of new economic forms and a ``weakness of governent discipline.'' ``The gap between the word and deed is intolerable,'' he continued. On political reform, Ligachev demanded the platform include a clause emphasizing the sacredness of party unity, and he said he firmly opposes allowing private property, a demand of radical reformers. Ligachev, 69, has generally taken a cautious approach to reforming the country and last week came under attack in a Soviet newspaper for his conservative views. But in his speech Tuesday, he said he wants reform quickly, denied he was a conservative, and said people who call him one are trying to divert the people's attention. Alexander Fomin, a coal miner invited as a guest to the session, said other speakers criticized the platform as being ``based on old dogmas.'' ``There were not enough radical proposals to solve the party's problems,'' Fomin said. He did not detail the objections, and the Soviet media carried few details of the session. One speaker, Yevgeny P. Velikhov, said the Communist Party would be better off if it split in two so it could compete more effectively in the new political structure. He compared the parties he envisions to the Democratic and Republican parties in the United States. The platforms of those parties, Velikhov said, are difficult to distinguish from one another. Velikhov's remarks were reported by Tass.

DOC.HEAD: Principal Joe Clark Bashes American Education
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT spelling of Paterson, sted Patterson
DOC.TEXT: Former principal Joe Clark, whose bat-wielding cleanup of a New Jersey high school became the subject of a motion picture, says America could become the ``first fully developed Third World nation.'' Public education is ``institutionalized child abuse,'' Clark told 200 Lowndes County High School students. ``American education is in the absolute doldrums of stagnation,'' he said Tuesday. ``Everything points to the fact that the educational process is suffering a type of malady that, unless corrected, America will be the first fully industrialized Third World nation.'' Clark gained notoriety by roaming the halls of Paterson, N.J.'s East Side High School while carrying a baseball bat and talking straight with kids. His effort became the subject of the movie ``Lean On Me.'' Clark told the cheering students Tuesday they must make their own way in life. ``If you want something out of life, you have to go out and work for it,'' he said. ``If you end up a nothing, blame yourself, because that's just what you wanted to be _ a nothing.''

DOC.BYLINE: Court: Mississippi Universities `Perpetuate a Stigma of Inferiority'
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled that vestiges of segregation ``permeate'' Mississippi's public universities 15 years after a lawsuit was filed to change the system. The 2-1 decision by a 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel in New Orleans overturned a lower court ruling in a lawsuit by blacks over policies at Mississippi's five historically white and three historically black universities. ``The badge of inferiority that marks black institutions has not been removed,'' judges Irving Goldberg and Sam D. Johnson wrote in the decision released Tuesday. ``As such, there remains in Mississippi's higher educational system vestiges of discrimination which distort the perceptions of black students.'' Unfortunately, they wrote, ``this case lingered, loitered and lulled for more than a decade'' without adequate changes. Hours after the ruling, state leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People appealed to students and administrators of traditionally white-dominated schools to be more accepting of black students. ``Racism is America's Number 1 problem. This ruling about Mississippi gives a true portrait of Mississippi, but in any other state the ruling could have been the same,'' said state NAACP president Aaron Henry. He said whites had not worked as hard as blacks in the desegregation effort that began when a court ordered the University of Mississippi to enroll James Meredith, its first black student, in 1962. ``The willingness of the black communities to adapt to their (white) presence is more than the whites are willing to accommodate blacks,'' Henry said. In his dissent, Judge John Duhe said Mississippi had fulfilled its legal obligation to open its universities to all students, regardless of race. ``The majority, relying on district and other circuit court decisions, has ... imposed upon the state the same constitutional duty required for primary and secondary education, where freedom of choice is unavailable and services are free of charge.'' The State College Board can ask the panel to reconsider the ruling, or can request an opinion of the full 15-member court. Board attorney Bill Goodman said he would withhold comment until after the ruling is reconsidered. Aubrey Lucas, president of University of Southern Mississippi, said: ``My first reaction was one of regret that we were unable to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the courts some very significant progress has been made.'' Historically white Southern Mississippi, Delta State, Mississippi State, Mississippi University for Women, and the University of Mississippi enjoy distinct advantages over historically black Alcorn State, Jackson State and Mississippi Valley State universities, the panel ruled. ``Vestiges of de jure segregation permeate the public university system of Mississippi,'' the majority decision said. ``Admissions policies, the racial composition of the faculty and administration, funding practices, academic offerings and mission designations all perpetuate a stigma of inferiority.'' More than 99 percent of the state's 26,953 white college students were enrolled in historically white institutions during the 1985-86 school year, while 71 percent of 12,826 black students were enrolled in historically black schools, the court said. Mississippi spent an average $1,351 in 1960 and $8,516 in 1986 per student enrolled at historically white institutions. The average at historically black schools was $718 in 1960 and $6,038 in 1986, the court said. The lawsuit was filed in 1975 by Jake Ayers of Glen Allen on behalf of his son, Jake Ayers Jr., a high school student, and 20 other black students. The elder Ayers has died and his son, now 32, moved to Oklahoma after dropping out of junior college to join the Air Force. His mother, Lillian Ayers, said she has another son who will graduate from high school this year. ``Hopefully he will benefit from the change,'' Mrs. Ayers said. The court sent the case back to U.S. District Judge Neal B. Biggers Jr., who had dismissed the lawsuit in 1987, declaring Mississippi's university system sufficiently desegregated. The appeals panel called for the lower court's re-hearing to include testimony from psychologists, sociologists and other professionals. ``Windows must open to ventilate the courtroom with ideas from the winds of truth,'' it said. ``To this end, testimony, depositions, cross-examinations and opinions can assist. Only then should the parties come forth with a definite plan for'' achieving desegregation.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Remove Bermudez as Top Commander
DOC.TEXT: Enrique Bermudez was ousted as top Contra military leader after weathering years of in-fighting and accusations of corruption, human rights violations and close ties to the hated Somoza regime in Nicaragua. A clandestine Contra radio station announced Bermudez' ouster Tuesday in a broadcast from Central America, military spokesman Alejandro Acevedo said in Miami. Bermudez's position as chief of the military in northern Nicaragua has been eliminated, and rebel forces will be run by the rebels' joint chiefs of staff, headed by Israel Galeano, Acevedo said. The move, which came at a meeting Monday, was intended as a signal to Nicaragua's leftist government, Acevedo said, and did not represent a rejection of Bermudez. ``In a democracy, military officers do not rule for life,'' he said, contrasting Bermudez's departure with the continued military rule of Ortega in Nicaragua. Bermudez, 57, long considered a hard-liner, has run the U.S.-backed Contra army in one post or another since it was formed. Monday, the officers decided he would remain a military officer, but with no current responsibilities, the spokesman said. Just under 10,000 Contra soldiers and about 50,000 family members are living in camps in Honduras, just north of the Nicaraguan border. Galeano, whose nom de guerre is Commander Franklin, pledged in December to place his troops in ``defensive positions,'' limit violence and support international observer groups in advance of Nicaragua's elections Feb. 25. The Contra reorganization followed accusations by the Sandinista government and some human rights organizations that Contra troops under Bermudez's command killed two nuns, one a U.S. citizen, in an attack on a church vehicle in northern Nicaragua last month. The Contras have strongly denied responsibility for the nuns' deaths, blaming Sandinista troops for the attack. Bermudez also was accused in a lawsuit filed in Miami last week of ordering his troops to torture and kill an American engineer, Benjamin Linder, who had been helping the Sandinistas build a dam in Nicaragua. The Contras say Linder, 27, of Portland, Ore., died in a firefight, and was in uniform. Bermudez was the military attache in Washington under the government of former dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle when the Sandinistas overthrew the government in 1979. He assumed the position of leader of the U.S.-supported Contra troops when the force was created by the Reagan administration, and accounts by former Contras have reported him as being a favorite of the CIA and the supply network set up by former White House aide Oliver North. Despite the reports criticizing Bermudez as too close to Somoza's National Guard, he outlasted other Contra civilian and military leaders. When he joined the seven-member ruling directorate as military coordinator in July 1988, several commanders on the Contras' southern front quit in protest. The directorate was abolished by military officers after it lost U.S. funding last year.

DOC.HEAD: Viewers Pushing TV Stations Against `Geraldo'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Lynda Beams doesn't care if Geraldo Rivera interviews men in lace panties, topless donut shop operators, or teen-age satanic murder cultists _ just not in front of her kids, please. ``It's soft-core pornography,'' says Mrs. Beams.
