She would like the show taken off the air, but will settle for it being moved from an after-school time slot. ``It's an adult talk show and it airs when most adults are at work and children are at home,'' she said. Mrs. Beams heads a national grassroots movement against Rivera's program, one of several such loose groupings that have arisen in recent years to battle objectionable TV shows. Last year a Michigan woman, Terry Rakolta, persuaded three corporations to pull ads from Fox network's ``Married ... With Children,'' which Rakolta complained was full of gratuitous sexual innuendo. Other companies withdrew advertising from ``Saturday Night Live'' in response to complaints about an episode in which the word penis was repeatedly used. Many viewers are complaining about ``Geraldo,'' and some stations are listening. Rivera publicist Jeff Erdel said ``Geraldo'' is being carried by 199 stations in all but a few network TV markets, up from 162 stations a year ago. But 25 percent of the stations have let Rivera know they're not happy with his show, Erdel said. Rivera and the show's producers have pledged a return to ``more substantive issues'' in an effort to win back sponsors and viewers, but some stations are holding out on renewals. ``We haven't quite decided about `Geraldo,''' said Joe Bell, program director of KDFW in Dallas, which lost numerous sponsors for the show after Mrs. Beams contacted them. She asked that the program be rescheduled from 4 p.m., but so far the station has refused. In Augusta, Ga., WAGT moved ``Geraldo'' from 5 p.m. to 10 a.m. in September after sponsors pulled out because of viewer complaints, led by Claire Tankersley. Mrs. Tankersley said she boiled after her 4-year-old watched a ``Geraldo'' show in which a prostitute graphically described being sexually abused as a child. ``I was so horrified and aghast that something like that would be on at 5 p.m.,'' Mrs. Tankersley said. ``I'm not for censorship, but I just don't think that kids should be exposed.'' ``Sounds familiar,'' said Jeffrey Ulrich, program director of WROC in Rochester, N.Y., which had so many complaints about ``Geraldo'' last year that it canceled the program with three months left on the contract. ``The opposition we were receiving on the show was tremendous. `Geraldo' really raised a stink here,'' Ulrich said. KNSD in San Diego took ``Geraldo'' off the air last month because advertisers withdrew, said station controller Jay Belbey. Mrs. Beams started her campaign against ``Geraldo'' after seeing a show in which Rivera interviewed guests about bestiality. ``He asked them if they had had sex with animals,'' she said. ``I turned it off.'' Other shows that raised viewers' ire include: _ ``Men in Lace Panties'' _ ``Kids Who Murder in the Name of Satan'' _ ``When the Other Woman is a Man'' _ ``Kiddie Porn Underground'' ``I don't think it's wrong that some of these issues are addressed,'' said Ulrich. ``But it's the way `Geraldo' exploited them. Phil Donahue could cover them and you wouldn't get the same complaints. Geraldo's problem lies in his exaggeration and sensationalism.'' Last month, at the National Association of Television Program Executives convention in New Orleans, Rivera and his producers courted program directors with promises of a more substantive ``Geraldo.'' Executive producer Martin M. Berman said the show ``went a little wild'' during the November ratings period, when it was competing for viewers in 125 markets against ``The Oprah Winfrey Show.'' ``We were pandering, and I'm changing to preserve my own reputation,'' Rivera recently told Electronic Media, an industry publication. Erdel pointed to a show last month about migrant farm workers as evidence of a reformed ``Geraldo.'' He said stations are showing ``very strong support'' and advertisers are coming back. ``That's all fine,'' said Ulrich. ``But I think he's going to have a hard time getting program directors and station managers and viewers to believe `Geraldo' is going to be any different.''

DOC.HEAD: Rizzo Denies He's Decided to Run Again, But ...
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor Frank Rizzo says he hasn't quite decided to seek a third term as mayor, but is leaning toward running. ``I haven't made up my mind yet,'' the 69-year-old Republican said Tuesday in clarifying a previous report that he had decided to run. ``I have all kinds of options, and that's one of my options, and I'm leaning that way a little. I've been watching this great city disintegrate and fall apart, and it needs my type of leadership to bring it back.'' Rizzo, now a local radio talk-show host, served two terms from 1972 to 1980 as a Democrat and lost to Mayor W. Wilson Goode in a Democratic primary in 1983. He switched parties to run again in 1987, losing to Goode by 18,000 votes in the city's closest election in 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Gives Mexico $2 Billion Credit
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank signed an agreement with Mexico that gives the country $2 billion in credits to reduce its $93 billion foreign debt. The accord, signed Tuesday, is part of a larger agreement signed to back a debt refinancing package with foreign creditor banks. Treasury Secretary Pedro Aspe signed the accord for Mexico, along with Syed Shahid Hussain, vice-president of the World Bank for Latin America, the government said in a statement. The agreement was based on the World Bank's support for Mexico's agreement with creditor banks on refinancing the foreign debt, the statement said. The $2 billion credit is the largest ever granted to Mexico by the World Bank. Of the amount, $1.26 billion will go toward guaranteeing the payment of interest on new loans and the rest will guarantee principal. On Sunday, Mexico signed a refinancing agreement with the creditor banks that cut the country's $48.5 billion bank debt by more than $7 billion and will reduce annual interest payments by $1.6 billion. It was the first major debt renegotiation under U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's plan to ease the debt burden for Third World debtors. Agreements for smaller amounts were made with Costa Rica and the Philippines. As part of Sunday's agreement, the World Bank and International Monetary Fund agreed to give Mexico credits to back up the pact. Aspe said Mexico's total foreign debt now stands at $93.6 billion, second among creditor nations only to Brazil, which owes $114 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Two Charged with Breaking into Nine-State 911 Emergency Phone Network
DOC.TEXT: A computer hacker broke into the 911 emergency telephone network covering nine states in the South and another intruder passed on the access data to other hackers, authorities said. Robert J. ``The Prophet'' Riggs, 20, of Decatur, Ga., and Craig M. ``Knight Lightning'' Neidorf, 19, of Chesterfield, Mo., were indicted Tuesday by a federal grand jury and accused of computer crimes, said acting U.S. Attorney Ira H. Raphaelson. He said Riggs was a member of the so-called Legion of Doom hackers group, whose members are involved in numerous illegal activities. Riggs and two other alleged members also were indicted Tuesday in Atlanta and charged in other computer break-ins. The government would not say if any emergency calls were disrupted or whether other damage was done during the tampering. ``These were not teen-agers playing games,'' Raphaelson said. ``They are thieves, they're reckless and they're dangerous.'' In the Chicago case, Riggs is accused of entering Atlanta-based Bell South's 911 system with a computer, stealing a copy of the program that controls the system and publishing this data on a hackers' computer bulletin board in Lockport. Neidorf is accused of transferring the data to his computer at the University of Missouri in Columbia, where he allegedly edited it for a computer hacker publication known as PHRACK. There was no immediate comment from either defendant. Directory information had no listing for Riggs, and there was a recorded message at the Neidorf residence. Neidorf's attorney, Art Margulis, said he had not seen the indictment so he could not comment. Raphaelson said industry specialists estimate that $3 billion to $5 billion is lost yearly to computer fraud. He said this is the fourth hacker case brought by the federal government in the past year. Bell South's 911 controls emergency calls to municipal police, fire, ambulance and emergency services in Alabama, Mississippi, Georgia, Tennessee, Kentucky, Louisiana, North Carolina, South Carolina and Florida. ``People who invade our telecommunications and related computer systems for profit or personal amusement create immediate and serious consequences for the public at large,'' said Raphaelson. He said the 911 data was valued at nearly $80,000, but would not say how a hacker could profit by stealing this data, other than by selling the information to others. Riggs, if convicted on all charges, could be sentenced to 32 years in prison and fined $222,000. Neidorf could be sentenced to 31 years and fined $122,000 on conviction. Riggs and Neidorf are charged with interstate transportation of stolen property, wire fraud and violations of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Scotland Yard Advised Rushdie Not to Make Public Appearance
DOC.TEXT: Author Salman Rushdie said he nearly emerged from hiding to deliver a speech on censorship but was dissuaded by the Scotland Yard guards protecting him from Islamic militants. Today, a group of British writers condemned the continued threat to Rushdie's life. On Tuesday night, Rushdie's friend, playwright Harold Pinter, read his condemnation of the impact of religious fundamentalism on freedom of expression to 200 people at London's Institute of Contemporary Arts. Police guarded the building and security guards searched handbags and screened the audience with metal detectors. Rushdie said his Scotland Yard guards persuaded him not to make his first public appearance since the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on Feb. 14, 1989 said Rushdie blasphemed Islam in his novel ``The Satanic Verses'' and deserved to die. ``I did ... ask my admirable protectors how they would feel if I were to deliver my text in person,'' Rushdie wrote in the lecture. ``The answer was, more or less, `What have we done to deserve this?' With regret, I took the point.'' Rushdie, 42, said he recognized people's profound need for religion, but said it ``must surely remain a private matter.'' Rushdie, a British citizen, was born into a Moslem family in India but renounced his faith as a youth. After Khomeini's death call, two Moslem clergymen in Iran backed Khomeini's call by offering $5.2 million for Rushdie's death. His publisher, Viking Penguin, has also been threatened, and the stress of a life in hiding led to a separation from his wife, American novelist Marianne Wiggins. ``It is an agony and frustration not to be able to re-enter my old life,'' Rushdie wrote. The lecture follows a 7,000-word essay Rushdie wrote for The Independent on Sunday newspaper defending his novel, denying blasphemy, and appealing to moderate Moslems to reconsider their opposition. Sher Azam of the Council of Mosques in Bradford, northern England, a stronghold of anti-Rushdie feeling, said Tuesday night that Rushdie missed an opportunity to come out of hiding ``and show that he wants an end to this very sad episode.'' The president of Britain's Royal Society of Literature, Lord Jenkins; the chairman of the society and writers, including John Mortimer, David Hughes and Penelope Lively, condemned the continuing threat to Rushdie's life. In a letter in today's issue of The Independent, daily sister newspaper of The Independent on Sunday weekly, they wrote: ``We join with those who say it is the right of all people to express their ideas and beliefs and to discuss them with their critics on the basis of mutual tolerance, free from censorship, intimidation and violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Old Movement to Be Honored with Monument
DOC.TEXT: What do a metal soap box, an electronic billboard flashing messages, giant cracks in a plaza, bricks inscribed with speeches and an ``autonomous nation'' inside a 6-inch circle have in common? They are five proposed works of art named as finalists Tuesday in a contest to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the free speech movement at the University of California, Berkeley. Four of artists were infants in 1964, when the movement was born on the Berkeley campus. The movement became the model for a decade of civil rights and anti-war protests across the nation after the university banned campus political activities. ``No one answer is correct when depicting the idea of free speech, certainly not one from people in authority,'' said Charlie Schwartz, a physics professor who dreamed up the project last year. The Berkeley Art Project, a group of artists, professors and protest veterans will commission the selected work with $70,000 in private donations. The committee that selected the finalists said the proposals would be refined and possibly modified. They reserved the right to combine several of the ideas. The winner will be announced after the proposals are displayed at the University Art Museum through March 3. The public can register their favorite with ballots. The finalists were Peter Popielarski of New York, soap box; Lauren Ariel Weingarten, Boston, billboard; Nathaniel Quincy Belcher, Oakland, Calif., cracked plaza; James M. Rosen, Augusta, Ga., bricks; and Mark Brest van Kempen, San Francisco, ``autonomous nation.''

DOC.HEAD: Happy Ending to Deserter's Return to United States
DOC.TEXT: Former GI Arnold Kephart spent his first evening at home in America in 30 years celebrating after the army decided not to court-martial him for deserting to East Germany in 1960. ``The mood here is happy _ quiet and happy,'' said Kephart's brother-in-law, Arlo Dunbar. ``Arnold is just relaxing and visiting.'' It was a warm, low-key ending to a saga that began last week, when Kephart was arrested as he arrived in Omaha, Neb., from East Germany. Kephart was granted a less-than-honorable discharge Tuesday at Fort Sill, Okla., and flew back for a tumultuous reunion. ``I've been eating my stomach full,'' Kephart said Tuesday night. ``I can't explain just how happy I am to be back in the United States.'' Kephart gathered with his family at the home of Dunbar and Dunbar's wife, Flossie. Kephart's 86-year-old father, Ernest, was among those celebrating his return. Kephart's 12-year-old son, Frankie, returned with him from East Germany but was left with relatives in the Omaha area while the Army weighed his father's case. ``We've got to give them a few days to get settled, then we've got to start thinking about a school for Frankie,'' Mrs. Dunbar said. She said the famly had been anticipating Kephart's return since the Berlin Wall came down. ``That was my first thought when I heard the news about the wall _ that Arnold would come back,'' she said. About 40 relatives, friends and well-wishers greeted Kephart on Tuesday as he stepped off the plane from Oklahoma in Omaha. The returning deserter's first welcome had been every bit as emotional, only ``this time, nothing's going to stop us,'' Kephart sobbed as he hugged his father and sister. ``I won't ever think about going back to East Germany,'' he said. ``I'm going to Dad's place now, and I'm never going to let him go.'' ``It's just wonderful,'' Ernest Kephart said through tears as he hugged his son. ``I can't believe it.'' Kephart was declared absent without leave in November 1960 while he was a private stationed in Heidelberg, West Germany. According to Kephart's account, he was driving back to his base from France when his truck crashed. There were three corked bottles of French wine in the truck, he said. ``In the crash, the wine got broke up on our uniforms. The police, they thought that we had been drunk. ... We didn't have one single drink from the wine,'' Kephart said. He said his superiors told him he would be sent to prison and would have to pay for the truck. He eventually escaped. He headed for East Germany because a girlfriend ``said I'd be safe over there.'' Kephart's ex-wife, Brigitte, who is Frankie's mother, and his twin 8-year-old daughters Kathleen and Katharina remain in Schmalkalden, East Germany. He said he wanted them to come to the United States as well. Kephart's discharge will be finalized when he receives the papers from the Army, which his lawyer said should be by week's end.

DOC.HEAD: Hold Egyptian Driver of Attacked Bus as Possible Accomplice
DOC.TEXT: The bus driver is being held as a possible accomplice in the terrorist attack on a busload of Israeli tourists that clained the lives of nine Israelis and left 20 people wounded, newspapers reported today. Saeed Abdel-Raouf, a Palestinian who gained Egyptian citizenship, fell under suspicion after witnesses said he stopped the bus at once when masked gunmen signaled him to do so Sunday, with no warning shot fired, said the newspaper Al-Ahram. When Abdel-Raouf appeared on state-run television Monday night, he said he was taken by surprise and stopped the vehicle after hearing a ``bang'' he thought came from a tire explosion. The masked men attacked the bus with machine guns and hand grenades on a desert road between Cairo and the Suez Canal city of Ismailiya. According to infrmation available to police, Al-Ahram reported, the attack was carefuly planned abroad and carried out in Egypt by three gunmen in addition to the bus driver. Earlier reports spoke of two gunmen. Reports in Al-Ahram and other Cairo newspapers identified the man who rented the white Peugeot station wagon used in the attack as Akram Deeb Ihab, a 34-year-old Palestinian with a Jordanian passport. Al-Akhbar newspaper said Ihab arrived in Egypt on Jan. 21 and left a week later. A photograph of him was printed on the front pages in Al-Ahram and Al-Gomhouria. Al-Ahram said about 60 suspects, mostly Palestinians, and a number of Egyptian non-commissioned police officers were held for questioning. It said their fingerprints were being compared with those found at the scene and on the abandoned white Peugoet. Police sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said those held included a Palestinian believed connected with the ambush but not as a gunman. Al-Ahram quoted police sources as saying the guns, grenades and ammunition used in the assault were smuggled into Egypt from abroad. The newspaper said about five policemen boarded the bus in Rafeh, a divided city on the border with Israel in the Sinai Peninsula, and left the bus when ordered out by the attackers. The terrorists had asked Egyptian hitchhikers on the bus to get out before they opening fire on the Israelis. The only other Egyptians aboard were the driver and the tour guide, who was wounded in the attack. The bus had been carrying 31 Israeli tourists, only two of whom escaped harm. A spokesman at the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for internal security, refused to discuss the newspaper reports. ``We will talk only after making arrests,'' he said, indicating that no formal arrests or charges had been made. Al-Akhbar ran on page one a statement attributed to Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestinian-General Command claiming responsibility for the attack. It said the claim was broadcast Tuesday over Libyan state radio. Monitors in London, however, said they heard no such statement. The official Libyan news agency did not carry the claim. Two Arab groups earlier claimed responsibility for the bus attack. One, in Cairo Sunday night, was made by an anonymous caller to a Western news agency who said he spoke for the previously unknown Organization for the Defense of the Oppressed in Egyptian Prisons. In Jordan, a handwritten message sent Monday to the French news agency Agence France-Presse claimed the assault was carried out by an obscure group calling itself Holy War-Jerusalem. The AFP office received a telephone call on Tuesday reasserting the claim. ``Our young men all over the world are going to hit again, strongly and painfully,'' the caller said, adding that the bus attack ``is an answer to the killing of our people in the occupied territories.'' A senior Jordanian official in Amman said Ihab ``is not a Jordanian'' but was from Rafah refugee camp in Gaza. Israel has occupied the Gaza Strip and the West Bank since seizing them in the 1967 Middle East war. Many Gaza Palestinians have carried Jordanian passports since 1967 but are not considered citizens of Jordan, which does not hold that a passport is a certificate of citizenship. More than 650 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since an uprising against the occupation began on Dec. 8, 1987. Forty-three Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Church Denies Membership to Lawmaker Supporting Abortion-Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to restore dropped word `from'
DOC.TEXT: A Republican lawmaker who describes herself as a ``holy roller'' was excluded from her Baptist church for sponsoring an abortion-rights bill. A letter from the First Baptist Church said it denied state Rep. Stephanie Micklon a family membership because her ``outspoken public position in regard to abortion brings disgrace on Jesus' name.'' Mrs. Micklon, who was baptized and married at the church, called it ``religious blackmail.'' ``I'm not pro-abortion. It is not an insignificant phrase,'' she said Tuesday. ``I am pro-choice, and now they're saying that is a sin.'' Micklon said she knows of no official church stand that a pro-choice position is grounds to deny membership. ``We're Pentecostal,'' she said. ``You're talking to a holy roller here.'' ``We are not questioning your relationship to Christ or your salvation,'' the pastor and Board of Deacons wrote in the recent letter. That, Micklon said, is ``all they should be questioning.'' She said she and her husband were married and baptized in the church, but had attended another church until several years ago. Last summer, the pastor suggested reaffirming their membership in the Salem church. ``They said there would be no problem,'' she said. Last fall, she sponsored legislation to allow abortions at a woman's discretion until the 25th week of pregnancy. The bill prohibits abortion after the 25th week unless a doctor deems it necessary to protect the life of the mother, or the fetus has an abnormality. The Micklons have a disabled child and Micklon said she based her position on abortion on their experience. First Baptist's pastor, the Rev. Clement Sutton III, said the church board discussed Micklon's case at length. ``We felt that if the Scriptures confirm the sanctity of life, the legislation was immoral,'' Sutton said. ``Where Stephanie has so publicly stated her issue, we had to make a choice. Is it proper to take in someone who makes a stand on an issue that is unbiblical? We couldn't before God and a good conscience recommend her for membership.'' The First Baptist Church of Salem is part of the American Baptist Churches-U.S.A., with headquarters in Valley Forge, Pa. Sutton said some church members had been arrested in protests organized by Operation Rescue, the nationwide anti-abortion group. Roman Catholic politicians who support abortion rights have come under criticism from their church. In California last November, a bishop denied communion for then-state senate candidate Lucy Killea for her abortion-rights stand. She was narrowly elected the following month.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Attack Police Bunker, 8 Injured
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants hurled a grenade at a police bunker in downtown Srinagar today and strafed the post with automatic rifle fire, witnesses said. At least six policemen and two bystanders were hurt in the attack, said the witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity. It was not immediately known how many militants were involved in the attack or if any of them were wounded when police returned fire, they said. In another part of the city, a bomb believed planted by the militants exploded in a post office. There were no injuries, other witnesses said. On Tuesday night, suspected militants blew up a truck, injuring one person who was sleeping in the vehicle, witnesses said. The attack on the police post was the latest in a series of confrontations between security forces and militants fighting for secession of the Kashmir valley from Hindu-dominated India. At least 77 people have been killed since authorities launched a crackown on the movement Jan. 20. Most of the victims have been Moslems who were shot and killed for defying curfew orders. Srinagar is the summer capital of northern Jammu-Kashmir state. Jammu-Kashmir is India's only Moslem majority state; 65 percent of its 5 million people are Moslems. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of the population of 880 million. The campaign for an independent Kashmir is four decades old but has flared in recent months. The valley is claimed by both India and Pakistan, and New Delhi has accused Islamabad of fomenting the trouble. Pakistan has routinely denied the charges but says the Kashmiri people have a right to self-determination.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Billy Idol Seriously Injured in Motorcycle Crash
DOC.TEXT: Rock singer Billy Idol had just completed an album called ``Charmed Life'' when he ran a stop sign and crashed his motorcycle into a car, suffering serious leg and arm fractures, authorities said. Idol, 34, whose hits include ``White Wedding'' and ``Rebel Yell,'' was not wearing a helmet during Tuesday morning's crash on his Harley-Davidson, police said. He was listed in serious but stable condition at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center today after seven hours of surgery to repair the right lower leg, which sustained a compound fracture, and his right forearm, hospital spokesman Ron Wise said. Doctors discovered during surgery Idol's arm was broken, he said. Idol also suffered some cuts on the back of his head, police Officer Don Lawrence said. Idol was in Hollywood when he ran a stop sign and hit a car, the officer said. He said Idol will be issued a citation for failure to obey a stop sign, which usually results in a fine. The car's 31-year-old driver, whose name was not released, was not injured. Idol's publicist, Ellen Golden, said the singer was heading home after just completing the album at Conway Studios in Hollywood. It was not immediately known if the accident would affect Idol's plans to begin filming in three weeks in director Oliver Stone's motion picture about the Doors rock band, Ms. Golden said. Idol was to play a close friend of the late lead singer Jim Morrison, she said. It also was unknown whether Idol's plans to release ``Charmed Life'' in late April and launch a concert tour in July would be affected, Golden said. Idol, with blond spiked hair, tight leather garb and curled lip, personifies the bad boy rock 'n' roll image. He is best known for his 1984 album ``Rebel Yell,'' which produced hit songs including the title track, ``Eyes Without a Face'' and ``White Wedding.'' His other hits include ``Dancing with Myself'' and ``Mony Mony'' off his first album, ``Don't Stop.'' He was most recently seen as part of the Who's ``Tommy'' tour. In November 1988, Idol was among Hollywood rockers who held a benefit concert to raise money to help find the motorist who ran down and killed a motorcycle-riding friend, dance club disc jockey Lee Selwyn. Idol is one of many Hollywood and Malibu entertainment personalities known for riding motorcycles, often without helmets. Among them were actors Gary Busey, who has recovered from severe head injuries sustained in a December 1988 crash, and James Caan, who suffered broken ribs and a broken collar bone two months later. Busey had opposed laws requiring helmet but has since changed his mind for younger riders.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Task Force Comes Up With Plan to Reduce Rapes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Laurna Rubinson cq
DOC.TEXT: A survey that found nearly one woman in six at the University of Illinois had been raped could lead campus authorities to stop peformances of the pompon squad and campus drinking parties. A mandatory briefing on sexual violence for new students also was among the other measures recommended by a task force created to resolve problems raised in the survey released Tuesday. Vice Chancellor Stanley Levy created the 13-member task force _ including students, faculty and community members _ in September, after viewing preliminary results of the survey on rape at the campus, which has an undergraduate enrollment of 25,950. The survey, conducted last spring, found that 16.4 percent of the 537 women who responded said they had been raped. That is in the same range as two 1985 college studies on the topic _ one at the University of South Dakota and another conducted on 32 college campuses. Another 23 percent said they were victims of sexual abuse, which meant fondling or touching. ``We're talking about acquaintance rape and men in fraternities or in campus housing who are sexually abusing women,'' said Laurna Rubinson, an associate professor of health who headed the task force. Levy and Ms. Rubinson said colleges across the country face the same problems. The study showed a strong relationship between sexual violence and alcohol use. Sixty-six of the 88 women who reported being raped answered questions about alcohol use. Of them, 80 percent said the men involved in the attacks had been drinking at the time, and 70 percent of the women said they themselves had been drinking. Ideally, alcohol consumption on campus and at tailgate parties outside sporting events would be banned, Ms. Rubinson said. But the school is more likely to increase the number of non-alcoholic social events for students, Levy said. The school allows drinking on campus by students who are 21 or older. The school may also consider a proposal to ban performances by the Illinettes, an all-female pompon squad that performs at football and basketball games, and other activities ``that project women as sexual objects,'' the report said. Other proposals likely to face opposition included requiring a resident director _ generally an older student _ at all fraternities, which were singled out by Ms. Rubinson as the worst source of sexual violence against women. Levy defended fraternities and noted that they have instituted new rules of conduct on their own, including banning keg parties.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Lashes Northwest; Heartland Enjoys Warm Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: Jet-stream winds breezed into the southern Plains and Mississippi Valley today, bringing unseasonably warm weather, and a lingering Pacific storm lashed the Northwest with rain, thunderstorms and gusty winds. Alaska entered its 11th day of deadly cold with no relief in sight. Lows of minus 55 were recorded Tuesday at Ambler, Bettles and Tanana, Alaska. Snowfall across western Oregon on Tuesday included 6 inches or more in the northern coastal range and up to 10 inches in the Cascade Mountains, where more than a foot and a half of snow has fallen since the weekend. Storm warnings were posted today across the Washington Cascades and Olympic Mountains. The storm dusted low-lying valleys with snow, creating icy roads that were blamed for two deaths caused by skidding vehicles in Oregon. Lightning near the state's southern coast knocked out radio and television transmitters. Warmer temperatures were expected from the Gulf states to the lower Great Lakes, with forecasts calling for temperatures from northern Texas to central Indiana and Illinois to be 20 degrees above normal. Rain soaked the Gulf Coast from Texas to Mississippi on Tuesday. Snow blanketed areas from the Pacific coast to western Wyoming. Rain in the Northwest extended across central California, with rain changing to snow in higher elevations. Record highs for the date Tuesday included 45 degrees at Devils Lake, N.D.; 59 at Beckley, W.Va.; 63 at Bluefield, W.Va.; and 67 at Roanoke, Va. The nation's hot spots on Tuesday were Miami, Fla., and Presidio, Texas, with 80 degrees. Milo, Maine, was Tuesday's coldest spot in the Lower 48 with 26 below zero. Other reports at 3 a.m. EST today: _EAST: Albany, N.Y. 27, cloudy; Atlanta 54 foggy; Boston 35 partly cloudy; Buffalo 35; Charleston, S.C., 56 cloudy; Chattanooga 54 foggy; Cincinnati 45 rain; Cleveland 41 cloudy; Detroit 36 foggy; Hatteras 51 cloudy; Jacksonville 56 rain; Key West 69 fair; Knoxville 51 showrs; Macon 56 cloudy; Miami 68 fair; New York 39 cloudy; Philadelphia 38 cloudy; Pittsburgh 46 cloudy; Portland, Maine, 20 foggy; Richmond 48 cloudy; Tampa 62 fair; Washington, D.C. 48 cloudy. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 55 foggy; Bismarck 24 partly cloudy; Chicago 39 foggy; Denver 29 fair; Des Moines 30 fair; Fort Worth 45; Indianapolis 42 cloudy; Kansas City 34 fair; Little Rock 44 fair; Louisville 48 partly cloudy; Memphis 50 fair; Nashville 52 rain; New Orleans 58 foggy; North Platte 23 fair; Oklahoma City 44 fair; Omaha 28 fair; Rapid City 41 fair; St. Louis 38 fair; Minneapolis-St. Paul 25 fair; Sault Ste. Marie 28 cloudy; San Antonio 52 cloudy. _WEST: Albuquerque 33 fair; Anchorage -19 fair; Boise 22 fair; Casper 34 fair; Fairbanks -29 partly cloudy; Great Falls 22 fair; Honolulu 71 showers; Las Vegas 47 cloudy; Los Angeles 52 partly cloudy; Medford 31 cloudy; Pendleton 31 fair; Phoenix 49 fair; Portland, Ore., 34 cloudy; Reno 25 fair; Salt Lake City 36 cloudy; San Diego 50 partly cloudy; San Francisco 42 fair; Seattle 34 cloudy; Spokane 25 windy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 23 partly cloudy; Montreal 23 partly cloudy; Ottawa 23 foggy; Regina 23 partly cloudy; Toronto 32 foggy; Winnipeg 16 partly cloudy; Mexico City 55 partly cloudy; Acapulco 75; Nassau 72; San Juan 70.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Said to Comply With Male Hooker's `Business'
DOC.TEXT: The male prostitute who ran his business out of the Washington apartment of Rep. Barney Frank said the congressman didn't mind until his landlord found out. ``I suggested it; he OK'd it,'' Steve Gobie said Tuesday, at a news conference to promote an article in Penthouse magazine on his relationship with Frank and the sexual underlife of the capital. Frank has said he fired Gobie as his aide and driver when he learned how his apartment was being used. But Gobie said Frank knew not long after the two met in April 1985 and he moved into Frank's apartment, where he received his phone calls and clients. ``I couldn't have done it without him knowing about it,'' Gobie said. ``It's virtually impossible _ the answering machines were connected to the telephones.'' Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat, issued a statement Tuesday saying, ``Gobie's press conference and article are recycled lies with some additional sensationalism, apparently to justify Penthouse paying him a $50,000 fee.'' Gobie said he and Frank parted after the landlord confronted the congressman about the activity in the apartment. ``He was angry because the landlord found out, not because he didn't know it was going on,'' Gobie said. ``It wasn't just phone work that was going on, it was actually individuals coming in and out of the place. ``He was aware of that. He'd call and make sure it was OK for him to come home, if he was due to come home at an inopportune time during the day.'' Gobie, 33, said he has testified for five hours before the House ethics committee, which is probing Frank's conduct. He declined to say what kinds of questions he was asked or what he told the committee. Frank, 49, has acknowledged that he paid Gobie for sex the first time they met. But he says he soon befriended Gobie and hired him to be a personal aide and driver. Gobie declined to divulge how much Penthouse paid him. He has said, and Frank has denied, that the congressman at one point offered him $10,000 to $12,000 to leave Washington and make a new start in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Civil Rights Leader Says He Hopes To See Mandela Freed
By LAURINDA KEYS
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson, beginning a visit to South Africa, said today he hoped to see Nelson Mandela ``walking down the streets of Johannesburg'' before his 12-day trip ends. The U.S. civil rights leader, granted a visa by the government after several rejections in the past decade, planned to meet President F.W. de Klerk and Foreign Minister Pik Botha as well as leaders of the anti-apartheid movement. At an airport news conference, Jackson declined to say if he had requested a meeting with Mandela, the African National Congress leader who is expected to be released soon after more than 27 years in prison. ``I have no commitment from the government to meet him,'' Jackson said. ``I hope to see him walking down the streets of Johannesburg. The whole world hopes to see him free.'' On Friday, in a widely hailed speech, de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC, scrapped other restrictive measures and pledged to free Mandela promptly. ``This is a moment in South Africa's history that must be seized,'' Jackson said. ``If the government moves back, there will be chaos ... But if the government seizes the political moment and moves forward, we will see the dawn of a new, free and democratic South Africa.'' He said he had set two goals for the trip _ to encourage unity among black political factions and to ``address the unfounded fears of the whites.'' Asked whether he favored continuation of sanctions against South Africa, he replied: ``The real issue is to end apartheid. Sanctions will end with apartheid.'' De Klerk gave ``a great speech,'' he said, but ``apartheid is still in place, the caution is that Nelson Mandela is still in jail.'' The Afrikaner Resistance Movement, a neo-Nazi white supremacist group, has threatened to mount protests against Jackson but only a handful of right-wing demonstrators were seen at the airport and they obeyed police orders to avoid displaying placards. Jackson and his wife, Jackie, were welcomed by senior leaders of the anti-apartheid movement, includuing Walter Sisulu, an ANC colleague of Mandela's, and church leaders Allan Boesak and Frank Chikane. On Tuesday, Botha suggested it was an inopportune time for Jackson to visit because of the rapid political changes taking place. Botha also complained that Jackson alternates his statements on sanctions depending on his audience. Botha said Jackson has told South African officials he favors an end to punitive sanctions, while appealing in public speeches for added sanctions. ``The time has come when Jesse and I must talk straight to each other,'' Botha said. He said Jackson's visit has nothing to do with the release of Mandela, because the decision has already been made. ``He can enjoy the aftermath, but not claim any credit,'' Botha said. Mandela, 71, has been in jail since 1962 and is serving life imprisonment for planning the start of the ANC's sabotage campaign against the government.

DOC.HEAD: Tallahassee Mayor Returned to Office; Mayoral Election Set for Tulsa
DOC.TEXT: The black woman mayor of Tallahassee, Fla., was re-elected by a landslide and the incumbent mayor of Tulsa, Okla., easily won the Democratic primary in his bid to be returned to office. Mayor Dorothy Inman won 60 percent of the votes Tuesday in Tallahassee, where voters cast ballots for the city commission. Investment broker Wayne Harris was the closest challenger, with 19 percent. The mayor's office is rotated among commission members every year. Two of the mayor's five white male opponents made openly racist appeals to the city, which is 25 percent black. They were Jim Fair, 72, who received 3 percent of the vote, and Duane Doty, 68, who got less than 2 percent. In Tulsa, Mayor Rodger Randle and Republican Frank Pitezel easily won primaries and will face each other in April 3 general elections. Randle, elected in 1988 to serve a two-year term, received nearly 75 percent of the vote against three challengers. Pitezel, a state representative, received 63 percent of the GOP vote.

DOC.HEAD: State Proposes $910,220 in Fines For Bridge Collapse
DOC.TEXT: The state has levied a record $910,200 in fines against a contractor involved in the rush-hour collapse of a bridge being built over a busy Baltimore-Washington highway. The accident Aug. 31 injured four motorists and six workers. The Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Office cited the J.P. Smith Co. of Edgewater for 128 ``willful'' violations of safety codes, the most serious type of violation, in what the agency called ``a gross disregard for public safety.'' The contractor has 15 days to appeal the fines. Among the violations cited was the use of 112 screw jacks of inferior size and strength to support steel towers that held the bridge in place. ``Anyone with construction experience had the ability to instantly recognize that this was not the equipment that was supposed to be used,'' Craig D. Lowry, the agency's enforcement chief, said Tuesday. Screw jacks rated to hold 10,000 pounds, instead of the 25,000 pounds specified in plans approved by federal engineers, were used, he said. The largest penalty previously proposed by the state agency was $68,000 for a fatal trench cave-in in October. John P. Smith, president of J.P. Smith Co., said last month that he assumed the equipment supplier had provided materials that met plan specifications. The contractor is rebuilding the overpass. A federal Transportation Department panel in December blamed the collapse on inadequate equipment and materials used contrary to approved plans. MOSH also issued a single ``serious'' citation totaling $720 against Highlights Corp. of Towson, a subcontractor on the project, for alleged failure to inspect equipment and supports before the concrete was poured for the bridge.

DOC.HEAD: Health Group Head Says More Than 700 Romanian Children Have AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: The head of AIDS programs for the World Health Organization said today that medical teams have determined more than 700 children in Romania are infected with the AIDS virus. ``The situation appears more serious even than we had thought,'' said Dr. Jonathan Mann. ``The number of infected children now exceeds 700 and it's clearly a very serious situation. We are mobilizing the resources to deal with it, but I am afraid it is worse than we thought.'' He said a WHO medical team is still trying to ``figure out exactly how this has happened and, particularly, what steps must be taken immediately to stop this now.'' ``It is a preventable tragedy,'' Mann said on ABC's ``Good Morning America'' program. ``This need not have happened. We now need to make sure that nothing more happens of this kind.'' Mann said the major route of spread apparently was the use of untested AIDS-infected blood and the repeated use of needles and syringes on children without sterilizing them between uses. Earlier this week Dr. Jacques Lebas, president of the Paris-based Doctors of the World, urged the international health community to provide Romania with disposable needles and blood-screening equipment. Mann said his organization is ``undertaking an initiative'' with all the countries of Eastern Europe ``to determine the scope of the problem, determine what needs to be done and do it, because AIDS is a reality now in Eastern Europe.'' Mann was asked whether he expected to find other situations similar to that in Romania. ``Let's hope that we don't ever have to see something like this again, but I'm afraid that as we look further into the countries of Eastern Europe with the ministries of health, that we are going to find evidence of more infection than was previously discussed, particularly in countries like Poland and Yugoslavia,'' said Mann. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims vulnerable to a wide variety of infections and cancers. A person can carry the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, for years without developing the disease. But almost all cases lead to the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wingers Say They'll Try to Drive De Klerk From Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with right-wing party seeking to drive de Klerk from power, trims. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The pro-apartheid Conservative Party said today it will stage protests and strikes to drive President F.W. de Klerk from power and block his plans to share power with blacks. Koos van der Merwe, chief spokesman for the Conservatives, the main white opposition party, said de Klerk deceived South African whites by suddenly legalizing the African National Congress guerrilla movement and more than 60 other anti-apartheid groups. He said de Klerk's National Party would not be able to retain power in the face of a white backlash. The Conservatives are pushing for a new election. If de Klerk rejects that proposal, the party would organize ``stay-at-home'' campaigns or general strikes that would bring the country to a halt, van der Merwe said. ``We will keep the pressure on him ... until he has no choice but to call a general election,'' he said. If large numbers of whites joined a general strike, they could bring the government to a standstill, halt most transportation and shut down businesses, schools and hospitals. On Friday, de Klerk lifted the ban on the ANC and other opposition groups and partially lifted the state of emergency as part of a plan to begin negotiations that would bring the disenfranchised black majority into the government. The president also said the government would soon release Nelson Mandela, the jailed ANC leader, unconditionally. But he did not give a date. On Tuesday, a leading anti-apartheid activist said the government's drive for peace could be jeopardized by its delay in releasing Mandela. ``He must be released soon or de Klerk will lose momentum,'' the Rev. Allan Boesak said after meeting with Mandela for more than three hours at Victor Verster prison farm north of Cape Town. Boesak said Mandela wants the government to lift the state of emergency and free all political prisoners, including those convicted of violent acts, but would accept freedom whether or not the demands are met. He said Mandela considered de Klerk's speech ``bold, courageous and hopeful,'' but did not believe it had cleared the way for talks between the government and the ANC. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, beginning a visit to South Africa, said today he hopes to see Mandela ``walking down the streets of Johannesburg'' before his 12-day trip ends. At an airport news conference, the civil rights leader declined to say if he had requested a meeting with Mandela, saying only that ``I have no commitment from the government to meet him.'' Jackson was recently granted a visa after several rejections in the past decade. Van der Merwe said today that the National Party tricked the white electorate by stating during the election campaign last year that it would not deal with ANC because of its guerrilla campaign. ``Mr. de Klerk and his political Cabinet are a lot a crooks,'' he said. The Conservatives won 31 percent of the vote in September's election compared to 48 percent for the National Party. However, the Nationalists won 93 of the 166 white parliamentary seats, compared to 39 for the Conservatives. The other seats went to the liberal Democratic Party. Van der Merwe said whites would never accept majority rule because it would result in the 28 million blacks dominating the 5 million whites. He predicted whites would now flock to the Conservative Party, which seeks to establish separate states for whites and blacks. ``We demand the right of self-determination. We do not want to be dominated by the ... blacks,'' he said. The Conservatives have launched a major membership drive and plan hundreds of rallies to demand a new election. The campaign will culminate with a massive rally in Pretoria in May to demand that de Klerk step down, van der Merwe said. He said the Conservative Party stands for Afrikaner nationalism and is not racist. Afrikaners, the Dutch-descended settlers of South Africa, account for about 3 million of the 5 million whites.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Communist Leaders Agree to Give Up Monopoly on Power, Delegate Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines previous, edits to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party leaders today agreed to surrender their monopoly on power guaranteed by the Soviet Constitution, allowing rival parties to compete for the first time in seven decades, a delegate said. The reported vote by the powerful party Central Committee was a victory for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who had urged his fellow party members to face voters and earn the right to rule. Svyatoslav Fyodorov, a famed eye surgeon and participant in the three-day meeting in the Kremlin, said the committee agreed to support abolishing the constitution's Article 6, which guarantees power to the Communist Party. ``Article 6 will no longer be, there will be a multiparty system. There will be a normal democracy,'' Fyodorov said. Both hard-line Communists and reformers had criticized Gorbachev's platform, with hard-liners complaining he was going too far and reformers saying he failed to go far enough. Populist leader Boris N. Yeltsin cast the only vote against the platform, Fyodorov said, apparently because it was not radical enough. Yeltsin on Sunday addressed a huge crowd that gathered outside the Kremlin to demand reforms, and he promised to present the demands to the Central Committee. There also was one abstention, Fyodorov said. There were few major changes in the document Gorbachev presented to the Central Committee on Monday, he said. The 249-member Central Committee was joined in the meeting by more than 700 other officials from around the Soviet Union, and all were allowed to vote on the platform, he said. The official news agency Tass said debate at the closed meeting resumed today but did not give details. Sources inside the Central Committee meeting said the policy-making body would recommend to the Supreme Soviet parliament that it delete Article 6. The Supreme Soviet could take up the issue at its meeting next week, or after the party's Congress, which the Central Committee agreed to move up to summer from October. In either case, final authority rests with the Supreme Soviet's parent legislative body, the Congress of People's Deputies. At its last meeting in December, the Congress of People's Deputies heeded Gorbachev's plea and blocked an effort by reformers to strike Article 6. But since then, Gorbachev said it would be ``no tragedy'' if a multiparty system develops in the Soviet Union. He told the Central Committee on Monday that rather than relying on constitutional guarantees, the party must prove its worthiness to govern. The Central Committee, which had been scheduled to meet only two days, continued to consider how to deal with the breakaway party in Lithuania, which split from the national Communist Party in December. When Gorbachev extended the committee session late Tuesday, he told the Central Committee he wanted its work done by mid-afternoon, but the group was unable to meet that deadline. Gorbachev and his advisers were turning their attention after the Central Committee meeting to the arrival later today of U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Most speakers during debate Tuesday agreed the Communists must end their political monopoly, but Gorbachev's plans for the party's future _ and his tenure itself _ drew harsh criticism from hard-liners. Yegor K. Ligachev, a leading orthodox Politburo member, was warmly applauded Tuesday for a speech that blamed Gorbachev's reform program for the country's dire economic situation and nationalist upheavals, a committee source said. ``After somewhat of an enlivening in the first two years of perestroika, the economy began to decline, inter-ethnic feuds reached bloodshed, people began to experience fear, and in some places there is practically dual power,'' Ligachev told the meeting. In his speech, quoted by Tass, Ligachev demanded that the party platform emphasize the sacredness of party unity and said he firmly opposes allowing private property, a demand of radical reformers. Tass quoted three influential Politburo members _ Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Vitaly Vorontinkov and Vadim Medvedev _ as backing Gorbachev's program, expressing emphatic support for a strengthened presidency. Many people believe Gorbachev hopes to step down as party chief in the Communists' anticipated fall from power and concentrate authority in the presidency and popularly elected legislative bodies. Shevardnadze rejected assertions that Gorbachev's liberalization was to blame for the ouster of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. ``It has been destroyed by the will of peoples who wished no longer to tolerate coercion,'' Tass quoted Shevardnadze as saying. The committee's free-wheeling debate sharply contrasted with previous sessions, when the Central Committee automatically approved policies that had been worked out at higher levels. A decision to abolish the party's leading role _ and allow competing parties for the first time since shortly after the 1917 revolution _ would represent a bold domestic gamble. It could send the discredited Soviet ruling party the way of its fraternal Communist parties in Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary. On the local level, people across the country have recently forced the ouster of Communist officials found to have used their posts to obtain special food supplies and other perquisites unavailable to the average citizen. People must wait in lines for scarce consumer goods, some of which are rationed in some areas. Outside the Kremlin's Spassky Gate on Tuesday, Central Committee member Vladimir P. Anishchev was asked about the consensus at the gathering over the Communist Party's future. ``All unanimously think it has become obsolete. It has no meaning,'' he said. Partial transcripts of Tuesday's session, in which 51 speakers took the floor, indicated that Gorbachev's proposal satisfied neither radicals nor hard-liners. The party has already been fragmented by December's defection of its branch in Lithuania _ the republic leading the way in secessionist efforts _ and Moscow radicals are proposing that it break up into separate wings. Communist candidates are expected to fare poorly in local elections this spring, and some progressives in the party want it to set the democratic example by having all its leaders chosen by secret ballot.

DOC.HEAD: Constitutional Amendment Gives Party its Power Base
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution, which makes the Communist Party the ``leading and guiding force of Soviet society,'' is the key to the party's exclusive hold on political power. It is part of the Constitution adopted Oct. 7, 1977, by a special session of the Supreme Soviet under the leadership of the late Leonid I. Brezhnev. It has been interpreted as ruling out the creation of competing political parties. The Article says: ``The leading and guiding force of Soviet society and the nucleus of its political system, of all state organizations and public organizations, is the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. The C.P.S.U. exists for the people and serves the people. ``The Communist Party, armed with Marxism-Leninism, determines the general perspectives of the development of society and the course of the home and foreign policy of the U.S.S.R., directs the great constructive work of the Soviet people, and imparts a planned, systematic and theoretically substantiated character to their struggle for the victory of communism. ``All party organizations shall function within the framework of the Constitution of the U.S.S.R.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Have Yen for American Campuses
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese yen for things American has extended to college campuses, with a tiny school here announcing a seven-figure infusion of cash is on its way from Tokyo in exchange for students. And Clemson University officials said the Japanese are considering opening a branch of the South Carolina school, with Japanese money, in Kiryu City, 65 miles from Tokyo. Japanese will visit the campus this week. At Iowa's Westmar College, with an enrollment of 470, officials announced that 100 Asian students will arrive in April and ``a cash deposit of significant numbers'' will arrive this week. Westmar President Arthur Richardson said an agreement in principle for the venture with Teikyo University of Tokyo was approved by the college trustees over the weekend. ``Nothing is going to change at Westmar,'' Richardson said. ``We're just making the program bigger and better.'' Richardson said the cash would be for upgrading the faculty. He characterized the agreement as a ``merger'' with the Japanese school, which has an enrollment of more than 13,000. ``Later this week, there will be a cash deposit of significant numbers _ in the seven-figure range _ that will be available immediately for faculty upgrade, in order to prepare to receive the first 100 students the first week of April,'' Richardson said. He said 200 to 400 students would arrive in the fall. Under the agreement, Westmar will keep a local board of directors, Richardson said. The Japanese university already has agreements with Regis College to buy its Loretto Heights Campus in Denver and with Salem College in Salem, W.Va., to form Salem-Teikyo University. The American university branch in Kiryu City has a target opening date of 1992, Clemson officials said. ``They're pretty serious about putting a United States branch campus there,'' said Bobby Wixson, dean of Clemson's College of Sciences. ``They haven't settled on us yet, but they will be visiting our pertinent departments this week, and then our planning committee will meet with them on specifics and see if the proposal is mutually beneficial.'' Classes there would be taught in English by American instructors from Clemson and possibly other universities. Initially, 300 students could enroll, including 50 to 60 Americans. Students would be able to work toward a Clemson degree, then come to the main campus in South Carolina for their junior and senior years.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Bombs Airplane, Missile Plant; Promises More Attacks
DOC.TEXT: An IRA bomb exploded today in a hangar at an aircraft and missile plant, causing no injuries and little damage. The terrorist group said more attacks on the plant would follow. A local radio station said the Irish Republican Army telephoned 22 minutes before the blast at the Short Brothers Ltd. plant to warn that three 20-pound devices had been planted at the huge north Belfast complex. A spokesman for Short Brothers said a bomb exploded in an area of the complex where the company builds the Tucano Royal Air Force training aircraft. The area of the plant was sealed off and an army bomb disposal team sent in to see whether there were more devices, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. Flights at the nearby Harbor Airport were halted during the inspection. The constabulary said it did not know the bomb's contents, but news reports said it was made of Semtex, the Czechoslovak-made explosive favored by the IRA. The IRA issued a statement later saying there would be further attacks on plant but that no warnings would be issued ahead of time. It said that Short's workers are ``no different to contractors and workers providing labor, materials and services for the British Crown forces. They must recognize the consequences of their involvement in such work.'' The IRA has targeted several building contractors and their employees in recent years, saying anybody who carries out any kind of work or service for the security forces is a target. The financially troubled Short Brothers is the biggest employer in Northern Ireland. It was state-owned until last year when it was sold to Canada's Bombardier Inc., an aerospace company. In central Belfast, army explosives experts today blew up a suspected car bomb, said a police spokesman. The car, hijacked earlier, was abandoned outside a bank, and nearby shops and offices were evacuated. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the predominantly Protestant province with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Sakharov's Brain Sent to Research Institute
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Andrei Sakharov's brain has been sent to a research institute that studied the brain of Soviet dictator Josef Stalin, the official news agency Tass said today. Sakharov, a human rights activist, Nobel Prize winner and father of the Soviet hydrogen bomb, was eulogized as the conscience of the country when he died in December at the age of 68. The nuclear physicist's brain was sent to the Academy of Sciences brain institute, which was founded as a laboratory to study the brain of Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin in 1926, two years after Lenin's death, Tass said, quoting the labor newspaper Trud. Results of the research on the brains of Lenin and Stalin is secret, institute Director Oleg Adrianov said. But he said he has suggested to higher authorities that the research be made public. ``No brain of any political figure was sent to the institute after the Stalin days,'' Adrianov said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Calls for Multiparty Cooperation
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party today released a document urging increased cooperation with China's eight tiny non-Communist parties while asserting that China will always be under Communist rule. The release of the Dec. 30 document came as Communist parties in Eastern Europe are abandoning their hold on power and Soviet Communist Party leaders today agreed to surrender their constitutionally guaranteed ``leading role'' in society, according to a Central Committee delegate. China has not commented on Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposals to abolish the party's 70-year monopoly on political power. Communist parties in East Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia, and other Eastern European countries already have eliminated their ``leading role'' status. The Chinese document, however, stressed ``that China's multiparty cooperation must uphold the leadership by the CPC,'' or Communist Party of China, according to a paraphrase by the official Xinhua News Agency. China's state constitution refers to the Chinese people as being ``under the leadership of the Communist Party.'' In an apparent attempt to distance China from the pattern of political reforms that has taken hold of Eastern Europe, the document said China ``differs from the one-party system practiced in some socialist countries.'' The Chinese leadership has watched with concern the developments of the past few months in Eastern Europe, particularly Romania, where the revolution was violent. Some analysts have said China's leaders hope to prevent a viable opposition from forming in their own country by appearing to give the eight officially sanctioned, non-Communist parties more influence in policy-making. The Communist Party has frequently called for more cooperation with what it calls ``the democratic parties,'' but these parties hold no real power and are considered rubber stamps for Communist policy. Formed before the Communists took power in 1949, their aging ranks number about 300,000, compared with the 48-million-member Communist Party. In a Dec. 28 speech to party elders, senior leader Deng Xiaoping said, ``The democratic parties should be turned from flower-vase parties into ones that take part in politics.'' The newly publicized document appeared to be based on Deng's comments, but does not change the non-Communist parties traditionally subordinate role. The document also explicitly denied the formation of other non-Communist parties. ``Political organizations that oppose the four cardinal principles'' _ of socialism, people's democratic dictatorship, Communist Party leadership and Marxism-Leninism-Mao Tse-tung thought _ ``and endanger the state power are absolutely not allowed to exist.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Recall Election Voided; Vote Cast Twice
DOC.TEXT: An election recalling the chairman of the Southern Ute Indian Tribe and four council members has been overturned because an election official afraid of being placed under a spell let a woman vote twice. Once the woman's second, illegal vote was thrown out Tuesday, the election wound up a 182-182 tie, meaning Southern Ute Tribal Chairman Leonard Burch and the other council members will stay in office after all. The outcome of Friday's recall changed after Ruby Garcia, chairwoman of the tribal election commission, disclosed that she let Bertha Grove cast two ballots _ her own and one on behalf of her imprisoned husband. A vote by proxy rather than absentee ballot is illegal. Garcia said Grove ``said we `would not sleep''' that night if the woman were not allowed to cast a ballot for her husband. ``I didn't know if that was some kind of voodoo,'' Garcia said. She added that she was concerned the woman ``was going to put a spell on all of us.'' Recall committee members said they would challenge the recount in tribal court. Renee Baca, recall coordinator, said her group would seek a new election. Recall backers had accused the council of a lack of accountability, raised doubts about the benefits of two water projects and objected to the council's decision to cut from $3,000 to $1,500 a year the per capita payments made to tribal members from oil and gas leases on their land. The tribe has 1,158 members and is based on a reservation in the Four Corners area of Colorado, Utah, New Mexico and Arizona.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Hold Fund-Raising Lead Entering Election Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 10-11, Most of the, to CORRECT Jan. 31 to Dec. 31
DOC.TEXT: The national Republican Party had a dominant fund-raising edge to begin the 1990 election year, holding $14.4 million on hand while the Democratic Party had $5.4 million in its coffers. Federal Election Commission data also show the GOP dramatically outspent the Democratic Party last year, with its three principal national fund-raising groups spending $72.2 million compared to $19.1 million for the Democrats. It was a costly off year for both parties because of eight special congressional elections. The Republicans generated $80.4 million in contributions and other receipts for those committees, with the Republican National Committee taking in $30.6 million, the National Republican Senatorial Committee $35 million and the National Republican Congressional Committee $14 million. An analysis released Tuesday by the FEC showed some marked improvement in the Democratic Party's fund-raising, particularly when compared to other years immediately following a loss in a presidential election. The Democratic National Committee actually began the year with more money than the RNC _ $3.8 million compared to $1.5 million. But the GOP's House and Senate campaign arms were far more successful in raising money than their Democratic counterparts. The FEC report, based on the year-end disclosure reports of the organizations, showed that all told the three principal Democratic groups took in and spent $19 million. The Democratic National Committee, which ended 1988 with a comfortable surplus in the $5 million range, reported receipts of $6.8 million and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee said it received $8 million. Those committees reporting spending of $8.4 million and $6.5 million, respectively, and both made huge reductions in their debts. By contrast, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee had 1989 receipts of $4.1 million but reported spending $4.2 million and a year-end debt of $1.6 million. It reported having just $22,179 on hand to begin the year. While the Republicans enter this election year with more cash on hand, Democrats have the power of incumbency in the majority of House and Senate elections. Incumbents generally run well ahead of their challengers in raising funds. Most of the $14.4 million in the three Republican war chests to begin the year was with the NRSC, which reported having $10.6 million as of Dec. 31. The GOP hopes to chip away at the 55-45 Democratic majority in the Senate as part of a larger strategy that banks on a re-election win by President Bush in 1992 and a coattail effect that would return control of the Senate to Republicans. The GOP Senate committee spent $27 million of the $35.4 million it received last year and reported $589,734 in debts as of Dec. 31, about half its $1.1 million debt at the end of 1987, the last comparable non-federal election year. The NRCC, the GOP's main fund-raising arm for House candidates, spent $13.1 million of the $14.2 million it collected, according to its year-end filing with the FEC. It held $2.3 million heading into this year and reported debts of $794,654, up dramatically from the $34,922 in red ink it reported two years ago. For all of the committees, the totals raised include contributions and other receipts such as interest on bank accounts and certificates of deposit. Separate FEC data on the special elections last year show nearly $11 million was spent on the eight races. There were 41 initial candidates in the eight elections and the 16 who survived for the final, head-to-head contests accounted for $8.9 million of the spending total.

DOC.HEAD: Disaster Status Sought for American Samoa After Hurricane
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with relief planes from Australia and New Zealand to Western Samoa, CORRECT wind speed to 115 mph, sted 132; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `The territory ...'
DOC.TEXT: The government of this U.S. territory asked President Bush to declare it a federal disaster area after Hurricane Ofa devastated the Pacific island chain. Meanwhile, the governments of Australia and New Zealand pitched in with military transport emergency airlifts on Wednesday to Western Samoa, another of the South Pacific island chains hit by the hurricane over three days. Australian dispatched a C-130 Hercules laden with as tents, plastic sheets and tarpaulins ahead of several more relief flights expected from Australia and New Zealand. In a letter Tuesday, Gov. Peter Tali Coleman asked for money to help the American territory rebuild and recover from the hurricane, which passed near the six islands. Ofa battered independent Western Samoa with 115 mph winds before blowing out into open water on Tuesday. Crops, roads, utilities, businesses and residences in American Samoa were damaged, Coleman said. Damage could be as high as $100 million, officials said. The territory is under an austerity plan to reduce its $12 million deficit. ``I have determined that this disaster is of such severity and magnitude that effective response is beyond the capabilities of the teritorial government,'' Coleman wrote. The worst damage was reported in Western Samoa and Niue, about 450 miles south of Pago Pago. The Australian Associated Press said three people were killed in Western Samoa, declared a disaster area Sunday. Power and water have been restored to some parts of Pago Pago, but about two-thirds of the 38,000 residents still were without power and water Tuesday, said Joyita Viena of Lt. Gov. Galeia Poumele's office. Fewer than 20 people in American Samoa received minor injuries in the storm. ``We were very, very lucky the hurricane wasn't any closer,'' said Bob Blauvelt, chief engineer for government TV station KVZK.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Calls for Development of South Korea's Military
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo said today that South Korea must further develop its military forces to prepare for an eventual withdrawal of U.S. troops from the country. Roh made the remarks after receiving a briefing by the Defense Ministry on various security problems South Korea is expected to face in the coming decade. ``We must pursue the `Koreanization' of our defense. American troops are here only to help us. We must be prepared to defend our nation with our own blood and sweat,'' he said. In a report to Roh, Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon said South Korea will have to increase its defense spending substantially in the coming years to prepare for an eventual U.S. troop pullout. The United States announced last week that it would close three of its five air bases in South Korea in a cost-saving measure. The decision will mean the withdrawal of 2,000 of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty. But officials in Washington have not said anything about the United States pulling out the bulk of its forces. South Korean officials later indicated they expected to discuss the withdrawal of some 3,000 more U.S. troops, all non-combatants, when U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney visits Seoul Feb. 14-17. Lee did not disclose the amount of defense spending South Korea envisages in the coming years, but said his ministry would earmark more funds for research and development to produce missiles, combat planes, submarines and other sophiscated weapons in the early 2000s. South Korea, he said, spent only 1.5 percent of its defense budget on research and development in 1980, but the amount will be increased to 3 percent in 1996 and 7 percent in 2000. ``More spending on research and development will enable us to develop next-generation weapons on our own,'' he said. South Korea depends almost entirely on the United States for its weapons systems but the country recently has made impressive progress in developing its own weapons, including new army tanks more suited to Korean terrain. South Korean defense spending is fixed at 6 percent of its gross national product. The GNP has expanded at an annual rate of 8 percent to 9 percent during the past decade. Last year's Korean GNP was estimated at $194 billion. As a deterrent to what he called the growing North Korean military threat, the minister said South Korea needs to maintain close security relations with the United States and share more of the costs of keeping U.S. troops here. He said, however, that South Korea also must be prepared for an eventual pullout of all 43,000 American troops stationed in the country. The withdrawal, if made, should be gradual, he added. Analysts saw Lee's remarks as indicating South Korea would accept a withdrawal of American troops rather than taking on an excessive financial burden to keep them.

DOC.HEAD: Covenant House Names Schools Chief to Take Over Founder's Duties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with successor to Ritter; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `The events ...'
DOC.TEXT: Covenant House named a former school administrator today to take over the Rev. Bruce Ritter's duties while the founder of the runaway shelter is investigated on suspicion of having sex with teen-agers. The appointment of former New York City Schools Chancellor Frank Macchiarola as acting president came as the New York Post reported a fourth man has come forward to say he had sex with Ritter when he was a teen-age runaway. The Franciscan priest who founded Covenant House and has seen it grow into the nation's largest shelter system for runaways reasserted his innocence Tuesday, even as he found himself the subject of new charges. In a statement, Ritter said he had decided to take several weeks off to rest and recuperate from stress. Later in the day, however, church officials said they had instructed him to relinquish his duties. Franciscan officials ``have directed Father Bruce to begin a period of rest and recuperation without responsibility for Covenant House until this inquiry is completed,'' their provincial leader, the Rev. Conall McHugh, said in a statement. A spokesman said he had no idea how long that may be. Ritter, 62, had not considered stepping down, a spokesman said. Covenant House said Macchiarola, schools chancellor from 1978 to 1983, would immediately assume Ritter's duties. Macchiarola has served on the Covenant House board for five years. The events unfolded after The New York Times disclosed the Franciscans' investigation of a former Covenant House client's charges that Ritter had a sexual relationship with him in 1973, when he was 14. Two other former Covenant House clients also have accused Ritter of sexual misconduct. Ritter, who has campaigned against the sexual exploitation of youngsters, characterized such charges as ``garbage,'' telling the Times he ``never, never'' had sexual relations with any youth in Covenant House. ``I am profoundly saddened by the allegations against me and the need to deny them constantly,'' he said in his statement. ``I have no way of proving my innocence. My accusers cannot establish my guilt. I devoutly hope the inquiries currently under way will bring an end to this incredibly painful chapter in my life.'' In addition to the Franciscan investigation, the district attorney is investigating Covenant House's use of funds and its provision of false identification to at least one youth. Covenant House conceded Monday it had provided a former male prostitute with a new identity, that of a 10-year-old boy who died in 1980. It admitted acting without the knowledge of the boy's parents, saying it had sought to protect the ex-prostitute, Kevin Kite, from enemies. It has refused to say how it obtained the documents Kite, now 26, says he was given: a certified copy of the boy's birth certificate and a falsified copy of his baptismal certificate. Kite is one of those now making charges against Ritter. In December, the New York Post reported his allegations that he had an eight-month sexual relationship with the priest beginning a year ago. He said Ritter gave him money, housing and gifts in exchange for sex. Ritter has denied the charges, and Kite's father stepped forward to describe his son as a chronic liar. At a Dec. 14 news conference, Ritter warned that ``copycats'' might make charges similar to Kite's. However, the new accusations from two other men appear to predate the December disclosure. The Village Voice newspaper reported Jan. 24 that John Melican, now of Seattle, charged in an unpublished interview in 1986 that he had a 13-year sexual relationship with Ritter. Melican repeated the charges to the Times, saying the relationship began when he was 13. Darryl Bassile, 31, of Ithaca, charged that he had sexual relations with Ritter in 1973, the Times said. It said notes by Bassile's psychotherapist show that he complained about Ritter in April. Bassile said he complained to the Franciscans after hearing of Kite's charges in December. Today, the Post said Paul Johnson, 33, had a homosexual affair with Ritter when he was a teen-age runaway. Johnson, who was sentenced in 1986 in Los Angeles to a year in jail for corporate fraud, told the Post: ``No one else in this country is doing as much to help kids on the street. He helped me a lot. But I also have to say that I have deep-rooted hatred for the way he manipulated me.'' Covenant House has an $87 million budget, running 17 shelters with more than 2,000 beds in the United States, Canada and Latin America. The Times said it planned to expand this year, but donations, after tripling in four years, have declined since December, and the plans are on hold.

DOC.HEAD: Palauans Rejecting Compact with United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that voting is incomplete. PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `With 23 ...'; Kuniwo pronounced Koo-nee'-woe.
DOC.TEXT: A political arrangement that would bring this remote Western Pacific archipelago more self-government and nearly $500 million in U.S. aid headed for defeat today at the hands of the voters. Early returns showed about half of the voting Palauans supported a Compact of Free Association and subsidiary agreements with the United States, but the results were falling short of the required 75 percent. With 23 percent of the vote counted from Tuesday's polling, 51 percent opposed the compact and 49 percent approved. Final results weren't expected until at least Friday.
