He recalled seeing a gun salesman shooting out designs with a Winchester. ``I'm sure he never intended it to be framed and sold,'' Sutton said. He says he's sold 80 pieces in three years. There are drawbacks, concedes Sutton, who paints houses and takes other odd jobs for his main income. ``Sometimes at the end of the day, I can't hear,'' he said. He also has to buy shells by the case. ``If I miss and booger one up, that's 20 bucks down the tubes,'' he said. On a productive day, Sutton can turn out 25 pieces. They fetch up to $125 apiece, much of it sold through a western art gallery in Arizona. Each piece of art takes about 80 to 100 shots. Sutton said it takes three or four minutes for each, including time for reloading.

Since Seattle is known as the Emerald City, maybe Tacoma should dump its longtime motto as the City of Destiny and become known as the Sapphire City, says Mayor Karen Vialle. Vialle said she's had enough of a smokestack image and embarrassing ``aroma of Tacoma'' themes in national news reports. ``I think we need to come up with another city motto,'' Vialle said earlier this week. ``In our efforts to enhance our image, we need to come up with something that plays to our attributes.'' She didn't mention any specific plans for the change. The idea of sapphire was brought up by a psychology professor last summer. Christine Hansvick, of Pacific Lutheran University, said she found a largely negative self-image of the city and that residents identified with gray. She suggested the sapphire, a blue gemstone, as an antidote. ``You can see the image wherever you look,'' she said. ``We have blue skies, blue waters and a dome with a blue roof,'' referring to the Tacoma Dome arena. Abandoning the City of Destiny, a motto attributed to New York newspaper columnist George Francis Train during the railroad boom in 1886, would show the community's determination to project a fresher face, she said. Brian Kamens of the Tacoma Public Library's Northwest Collection, said the city also had been known over the years as Mistress of the Sea, Portal of the Pacific, City of Fine Homes and Lumber Capital of the World. A contest in 1981 resulted in a switch of Seattle's nickname from Queen City to Emerald City. A top-quality emerald can cost $9,000 and an equivalent sapphire about $6,000, said Jane Horowitz, a buyer for the Ben Bridge jewelry store chain.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Instant Gun Check Law Well Received
DOC.TEXT: Virginia's instant background check on gun buyers is working better than firearms dealers expected, according to a state report. Under the program, which began Nov. 1, nearly 11,000 gun purchases were approved and 130, or 1 percent, were rejected because the buyer had a criminal record, said state Secretary of Public Safety Robert L. Suthard. ``This program has operated in the manner intended,'' Suthard said in a report issued Tuesday. ``If the program had not been implemented, there would be 130 weapons in the hands of persons the General Assembly deems unqualified.'' The law, first of its kind in nation, requires gun dealers to call state police on a toll-free telephone number each time a state resident tries to buy certain firearms. The average time to obtain an approval was less than 90 seconds, the report said. Out-of-state buyers must wait for approval by mail. ``Firearms dealers appear to be generally satisfied with the program,'' the report said. A survey of the state's gun dealers found that 65 percent said the program worked better than they expected, 18 percent said it was worse and 17 percent said it was about what they expected. Gun dealers collect a $2 fee from Virginia residents and a $5 fee from out-of-state residents for each police records check. But the report said the fees have not covered the cost of the records checks because the number of gun purchases has been fewer than estimated. Pending legislation would raise the fees to $5 and $10. Sen. Moody E. Stallings, who sponsored the gun law, said he has been contacted by eight to 10 states interested in enacting similar laws. The law covers the purchases of handguns with a barrel length of less than 5 inches or semiautomatic weapons that hold more than 20 rounds or accommodate a silencer or bayonet.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Implant Patient Dies After Nearly Five Days On Lung-Assist Device
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with girl's identity, quotes from school; PICKS UP 9th graf pvs, `Thye only ...'
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age girl died this morning 4{ days after becoming the world's first recipient of an implanted device that works like a lung. LDS Hospital spokesman Tim Madden said Melicia Harvey, 16, of Arthur City, Texas, died of pulmonary failure at 5:30 a.m. The experimental IntraVascular Oxygenator _ a 20-inch bundle of hollow synthetic fibers that delivers oxygen to the blood _ functioned as intended until the girl's death, Madden said. Miss Harvey had been in critical condition throughout the experiment with severe respiratory distress syndrome, which results from a variety of causes and is characterized by inability of the lungs to transfer oxygen to the blood. The IVOX, approved for use for up to a week to allow damaged lungs to rest and recover, was implanted during two hours of surgery Friday. Miss Harvey, whose father, Atrell Harvey II, is employed by the Campbell Soup Co., had been a member of the student council at North Lamar High School in Paris, Texas, The Paris News reported. The girl's mother, Edith, died Jan. 31 of undisclosed causes. ``Suffice it to say the family has gone through extensive tragedy during the past week,'' Madden said. Linda Bolton, a secretary at the high school, said students were taking Miss Harvey's death ``really, really hard.'' ``We have 740 students at the high school here, so all our students are close, they all know each other,'' she said. She said counselors had been called in to talk with students, who included Miss Harvey's brother and sister. The IVOX, which is inserted via the neck or groin into the inferior vena cava, the large vein that brings blood to the heart, has received Food and Drug Administration approval for up to 10 experimental implants in humans with no better than a 10 percent chance of survival. The inch-wide IVOX bundle of fibers is connected to external tubes the size of a soda straw. One tube delivers oxygen from a hospital system or oxygen tank; the other tube removes carbon dioxide from the body, a waste product of breathing. The only alternative for people with acute lung failure is an extra corporeal oxygenator, a large machine that requires pumping the blood outside the body. ``There were no clinical complications from the use of the device,'' Madden said in a statement. It was unclear how long doctors had planned to leave the device inside the girl. FDA guidelines limit the implants to seven days. Doctors emphasized the IVOX is not an artificial lung but a ``lung-assist'' device capable of satisfying half the body's need for oxygen and for carbon-dioxide removal. But they said it could lead someday to an artificial lung. The inventor, Dr. J.D. Mortensen of CardioPulmonics Inc. in Salt Lake City, said initial experiments will involve only patients with acute lung disease, such as pneumonia or smoke inhalation, not chronic disorders such as cystic fibrosis or emphysema. LDS Hospital is one of four medical centers authorized by the FDA for testing of the IVOX. The others are Hershey Medical Center at Pennsylvania State University, the University of Michigan Medical Center in Ann Arbor and the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Bank Eased Loan Terms For Sen. Durenberger
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger received loans totaling nearly $1 million from Commercial State Bank of St. Paul without collateral and at very low interest from 1979 through 1988, the Star Tribune reported today. Durenberger denied any impropriety. Durenberger's personal finances are under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee, and the loan information could open a new avenue of inquiry. Durenberger did not fully disclose some of the loans as required by Senate rules, the newspaper said. The Minnesota Republican's cousin Jack is a vice president in the bank's commercial lending section, but the senator's staff said today that Jack Durenberger had nothing to do with the loans. ``He had absolutely no involvement in any of the loan transactions for the senator,'' the senator's press secretary, Carrie Collins, told The Associated Press. Durenberger received 23 loans, most not backed by collateral, totaling $927,078 from the bank after entering the Senate in 1978, the newspaper reported. The interest rates on many of the loans through 1981 were so low that industry experts suggested they may not have been profitable for the bank, the Star Tribune said. About half the 23 loans were below the prime lending rate banks traditionally give their most valued customers. Bank officials said the loans were routine for a good customer. Six banking experts contacted by the Star Tribune said many of the loans appeared to be outside standard banking practices. The loan history ``doesn't make any sense from a banker's point of view,'' said Michael Pint, a former state banking commissioner. Pint and other experts who commented on the loans weren't told the identity of the bank or the name of the borrower, but knew it was a political figure, the newspaper said. ``If it happened at my bank, heads would roll,'' said Jim Burkholder, chief operating officer of Investors Savings Bank in Minneapolis. ``It's not prudent to do that ... and based on what I've seen, it appears it smacks of seeking to influence a public official.'' ``You just don't make loans like that because they are losers,'' said Pint, president of Central Financial Services and former chief finance officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Bert McKasy, Durenberger's chief of staff, provided details of the loans to the Star Tribune and set up an interview with Commercial State's president. McKasy said Durenberger did nothing wrong in obtaining the loans and simply took the best interest rate available. Bank officials said they gave the loans to Durenberger because he was a good customer and because they hoped he might return to Minnesota after leaving office and promote the bank to his friends. Bank officials said they never contacted Durenberger for help in his official role. ``We feel our relationship was absolutely above board. It was a very typical relationship,'' said Bank Chairman Victor Reim. Bank President Richard Kastner said Commercial State was never at risk. Durenberger, who refused to be interviewed, provided a written statement outlining his relationship with the bank. He called Reim a close friend and said he began banking at Commercial in 1975. ``I never asked for any special consideration from the bank and don't believe I was ever extended any,'' Durenberger said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers, College Board Say They Cannot Mandate Where Students Go
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with governor's comments, picking up at the 3rd graf previous.
DOC.TEXT: State officials say they're not sure how to respond to an appeals court ruling that segregation still affects Mississippi's public universities because they can't mandate where students will go to school. ``How to integrate the universities in Mississippi is a question beyond me. It's very complicated _ a very thorny-type issue,'' said State College Board member Sidney Rushing of Gulfport. ``You can't force students to attend.'' Gov. Ray Mabus said Wednesday that many education reforms being considered by lawmakers would improve conditions at all the colleges, but declined to comment directly on the court's action. ``There are still areas in which we need to work harder and we have made progress.'' The governor said the universities would benefit from improved literacy programs and other measures to improve the quality and quantity of high school graduates. The 2-1 decision Tuesday by a 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel in New Orleans overturned a lower court ruling in a lawsuit by blacks over policies at Mississippi's five historically white and three historically black universities. The court sent the case back to U.S. District Judge Neal B. Biggers Jr., who had dismissed the lawsuit in 1987, declaring Mississippi's university system sufficiently desegregated. Historically white Southern Mississippi, Delta State, Mississippi State, Mississippi University for Women, and the University of Mississippi enjoy distinct advantages over historically black Alcorn State, Jackson State and Mississippi Valley State universities, the panel ruled. More than 99 percent of the state's 26,953 white college students were enrolled in historically white institutions during the 1985-86 school year, while 71 percent of 12,826 black students were enrolled in historically black schools, the court said. House Speaker Tim Ford and others argue the Legislature tries to promote integration and to equitably fund all eight universities. ``I don't see what else we can do, other than mandating where people can go,'' Ford said. Mississippi spent an average $1,351 in 1960 and $8,516 in 1986 per student enrolled at historically white institutions. The average at historically black schools was $718 in 1960 and $6,038 in 1986, the court said. Legislators say little new money can be squeezed out of the overburdened state budget. Appeals court judges Irving Goldberg and Sam D. Johnson said the black colleges are still inferior and ``there remains in Mississippi's higher educational system vestiges of discrimination which distort the perceptions of black students'' 15 years after a lawsuit was filed against the higher education system. There is no formal plan for desegregating the eight universities, although presidents are encouraged to strive for a racially mixed enrollment by recruiting blacks and whites. ``If the state of Mississippi continues with its tradition, it will delay any changes as long as possible,'' said state Sen. Doug Anderson, chairman of the Senate Universities and Colleges Committee. ``What we do know is at the predominantly white institutions, there is very little black faculty. And there is also the discriminatory way appropriations have been made to predominantly black institutions. Historically, they've received fewer dollars and less attractive, new programs. ``This case is very important to the survival of black institutions. Right now, the lowest salaries, the worst facilities are at predominantly black institutions.'' The College Board can ask the three-member panel of the court to reconsider the ruling or ask the full 15-member court to take up the case. College Board attorney Bill Goodman of Jackson said he is sure the ruling will be considered by the full court. ``I'd rather do my talking in the courtroom,'' he said, declining further comment. State Rep. Aaron Henry, president of the Mississippi NAACP, appealed to students and administrators of traditionally white-dominated schools to be more accepting of black students. ``Racism is America's No. 1 problem. This ruling about Mississippi gives a true portrait of Mississippi, but in any other state the ruling could have been the same,'' said Henry. In his dissent, Judge John Duhe said Mississippi had fulfilled its legal obligation to open its universities to all students, regardless of race. The lawsuit was filed in 1975 by Jake Ayers of Glen Allen on behalf of his son, Jake Ayers Jr., a high school student, and 20 other black students. The younger Ayers later attended junior college but dropped out to join the Air Force. Ayers' widow, Lillian Ayers, said she has another son who will graduate from high school this year. ``Hopefully he will benefit from the change,'' Mrs. Ayers said.

DOC.HEAD: Supervisors Back Away From Blocking View of Wright Civic Center
DOC.TEXT: Bowing to protests from preservationists, the county has backed away from a plan to build a box-like jail that would have blocked a view of the only government building designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. The Marin County Board of Supervisors on Tuesday agreed to consider burying the jail in a hillside next to the Wright-designed Civic Center. Supervisors made the decision after being told by the California Preservation Foundation that they would ``live with their mistake forever because the world will not let you forget.'' The alternative plan would be similar to one rejected by voters two years ago when they turned down a half-cent sales tax to finance an underground jail. The Civic Center, on which ground was broken in 1960, was Wright's last commission before his death in 1959 at age 92. The three-story center, with its long rows of crescent-shaped arches, low dome and spire, is a landmark for residents and motorists. The county is under court order to replace or expand its overcrowded, 110-bed jail, a 22-year-old building in San Rafael. It also is running out of time to qualify for $10 million in state jail-improvement funds. About 150 people, who came together under the banner of Save Our Civic Center, argued at the meeting that a jail could compromise the center's eventual designation as a national landmark and would destroy a major work of art. Board chairman Robert Roumiguiere instructed the county planning staff to bring the underground proposal back for consideration in 60 days.

Couple Charged in Starvation Death of Baby
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with couple jailed, bail, children turned over to grandparents. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A 5-month-old girl starved to death while her parents were on a weekend drinking binge, police said. Doris Franklin, 32, and Eddie James Amous, 39, were jailed on $7,500 bail each on manslaughter charges Tuesday. Amous also was charged with violating probation and Ms. Franklin with public intoxication and disorderly conduct. The infant, Brittany Franklin, and four siblings, ages 1, 2, 4 and 5, were left in the care of their 11-year-old brother Friday afternoon. He found Brittany dead in bed Sunday morning, police said. The boy said the baby fell off a bed and hit her head Saturday night, said Sgt. Fred Clanton. But an autopsy revealed the child died of starvation. Clanton said the couple drank at an unlicensed club Friday night, all day Saturday and Sunday morning without checking on the children. The 11-year-old had tried unsuccessfully to feed the girl, who apparently was malnourished before the weekend, Clanton said. There was food in the house but ``only cereal and stuff like that _ not the kind of stuff you'd want to give a baby,'' Clanton said. The five surviving children were taken into state custody and later turned over to their grandparents. ``I talked to the mother about noon Sunday and she was crying a little bit. I'm not sure if it was hearing the baby was dead or because she got caught,'' Clanton said.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Shoots Partner When Pair Allegedly Attacked by Dogs
DOC.TEXT: A police officer aiming for a dog that had taken after her partner instead shot the officer in both legs, authorities said. The officers were investigating a burglar alarm at a home Monday afternoon when they were attacked in the back yard. Officer Laverne Davis, 29, said she was shooting at a mixed collie shepherd and a black Labrador retriever when she mistakenly hit Sgt. Larry Anderson, authorities said. Anderson, 44, was treated for the wounds and a dog bite to the forearm and released from Santa Monica Hospital Medical Center, said hospital spokesman Ted Braun. Ms. Davis was scratched but didn't require treatment, authorities said. The mixed collie shepherd, which allegedly bit Anderson, was treated for a hip injury at a Santa Monica veterinary hospital. The retriever was put in temporary quarantine at a shelter. Both dogs were up to date on their shots, said shelter supervisor John Sanchez. The dogs' owner, Peter Levin, 19, insisted the animals are sweet, but will go after people if they're provoked.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury: No Clear Evidence Tax Overhaul Reduced Investment in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: There is no clear evidence that the 1986 tax overhaul, which killed a special break for capital gains, reduced the level of investment in the United States, the Treasury Department told Congress on Wednesday. President Bush has made restoration of the capital gains break a major initiative of his administration, contending it's necessary to increase investment. At a House Ways and Means Committee hearing on the impact of the 1986 law, Kenneth W. Gideon, assistant secretary of the treasury for tax policy, said skeptics had predicted investment would decline and that growth of key industries would be stymied. ``The predicted short-run decrease in aggregate equipment investment has apparently failed to materialize,'' Gideon said. ``Such investment has actually experienced a post-1986-act surge as a result of technology-driven increases and expenditures on office, computing and accounting machinery, and an increased growth in output demanded by other sectors of the economy.'' It could be that investment might have been higher without the act, which also ended a special credit for investment while reducing the corporate tax rate from 46 percent to 34 percent. Or, it may be too soon to judge, Gideon said. ``In any case, there is no clear evidence that the 1986 act affected the level of investment,'' Gideon said. Nevertheless, Gideon and Internal Revenue Service Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. renewed the administration's plea for cutting capital gains taxes. ``In order to remain competitive, incentives for savings and investment must be improved,'' Gideon said. Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., said the administration was offering the wrong solution. ``Until the deficit can be significantly reduced, no tax system crafted by Congress will cure the economic ills of this country, while the passage of special tax breaks will only create more economic distortions,'' he said. Capital gains, profits from the sale of stock and other investments, are fully taxed at the same rates applying to wages and other income. Bush has proposed exempting up to 30 percent of gains from taxation. While Rostenkowski repeated that he will resist any cut in capital gains taxes, he said the committee will always consider how to make the tax system simpler. The need for more simplification was the central theme of most witnesses who testified Wednesday. ``We are imposing an unacceptable burden on taxpayers and our system of tax administration,'' Goldberg said. Rep. Bill Archer of Texas, senior Republican on the committee and a foe of the 1986 overhaul, said the new law imposed layers of complexity even while advocates were proclaiming it as simplification. ``As a lawyer and member of this committee for 17 years, I have always prided myself on doing my own tax return,'' Archer said. ``Last year I could not do it.'' Among other judgments on the 1986 act: _Proposals to restore a capital gains break threaten the new law, said Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-backed research organization. ``Tax reform is working _ at least for now,'' he said. ``The question facing Congress today is whether reform will be saved or scuttled.'' _``The tradeoff of certain credits and deductions for lower statutory rates has contributed to overall efficiency in the allocation of capital resources and, thus, had a positive effect on economic growth,'' said Harry Sullivan, senior vice president of the Food Marketing Institute, speaking for a coalition that includes 100 of the Fortune 500 corporations. _While praising the law for removing 6 million lower-income people from the tax rolls, William Lucy, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said its passage led many states into ill-advised tax cuts, resulting in reduced services for citizens. _Don Fuqua, president of Aerospace Industries Association of America, said the law, by eliminating a special accounting method, makes it more difficult for long-term contractors to compete and threatens efforts ``to keep this nation a leader in technological development.'' _Michael J. Miller of the Independent Petroleum Association of America said that because of a reduction of tax benefits, the 1986 law ``is having a severe impact on an already depressed industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Accident at Disney's Haunted House Hurts 5
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't part of the show when pieces of wood dropped from the ceiling at Walt Disney World's Haunted House, slightly injuring five people. The visitors had just started a ride through the attraction Tuesday when the machinery that operates the walls and ceiling of a darkened chamber jolted to a halt. Pieces of the ceiling molding fell on an open car containing the visitors, who were treated for cuts and bruises, Disney spokesman John Dreyer said. The chamber has portraits on the walls and ``stretches'' to dramatize macabre scenes below each portrait. It is automatically operated by a system of cables and pulleys. ``It got hung up. I don't know how it happened,'' said Dreyer. A handful of wood pieces ``no heavier than the molding in your house'' fell, he said. The ride was promptly stopped and everyone evacuated while workers inspected the equipment, Dreyer said.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Proposes Marriage from Senate Floor
DOC.TEXT: State Sen. Jim West proposed marriage to his girlfriend Wednesday from the Senate floor. She said yes, but he knew she would. West wrote a note to Ginger Marshall, who was watching from the gallery. He told her he planned to rise on the Senate floor and ask for her hand but, like all politicians, he wasn't about to ask the question until he knew the answer. Marshall read West's note and nodded yes before he rose to inform his colleagues that he had just proposed to Marshall. She hurried down from the gallery and the two stood for applause at the front of the Senate chamber. ``Why did I do it like this? Because we're in love,'' West said. Neither West, 38, nor Marshall, 27, has ever been married. The couple plan a December wedding.

DOC.HEAD: Man Dials His Stolen Truck
DOC.TEXT: You might call it Dial-A-Thief. When Stephen Dente of Londonderry heard from his wife that someone had stolen his pickup, he dialed the truck's phone. ``Hello,'' came the reply. Dente was shocked and didn't say anything. The thief hung up. He called back and the thief answered again. Dente said he told the thief that police were hot on his trail. The thief left the phone off the hook and Dente said he heard at least three people talking. Dente said he began shouting into the phone and told the thieves his truck was equipped with an anti-theft radio transmitter that can be tracked by police. Dente said the thieves talked among themselves, then the line went dead. His next call was to police. On his third call to his missing truck, he reached a recorded message saying his phone was not in service either because no one was in the vehicle or the phone was turned off. The truck was stolen Monday and still was missing Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Students End Cafeteria Boycott
DOC.TEXT: High school students have agreed to end a five-day boycott of the school cafeteria, which cost the school's food services company up to $3,500, after the company offered to give $1,000 a year in scholarships. Students at Apponequet Regional High School launched the boycott in response to a 10 percent increase in the price of a la carte items such as pizza, hot dogs and ice cream. Prices were raised to pay for spoiled food and cleanup costs associated with a freezer that broke down undetected during a weekend in December. ``The feeling of the kids is that we don't feel we should have to pay for something that is not in our control. There should have been someone there when the freezer broke,'' Student Council President Beth Brooks said. The price increase remains, but students will get seven days' notice of any new increases, said Peter W. Babbitt, ARA's district manager. In addition, they will be ``more involved in the monthly review process'' of food service operations, he said. He could not say exactly what form that involvement would take, however. And the company, based in Philadelphia, will offer two $500 scholarships to graduating seniors starting this year, Babbitt said. Students voted Tuesday to discontinue the boycott. Most of the school's 800 students had refused to eat in the cafeteria. Babbitt said the boycott cost ARA between $600 and $700 a day. He expected sales to return to normal starting Thursday. ARA Services had asked the Freetown-Lakeville Regional School Committee to approve the 10 percent price increase last month to offset a $2,800 food loss caused by the broken freezer. ARA Services also claimed an additional $2,600 in labor costs for cleanup for a total $5,400 loss.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Earthquake Insurance Program Urged
DOC.TEXT: The insurance industry called Wednesday for federal help in the wake of last fall's California earthquake, saying it would be unable to bear the costs of a major tremor. ``Insurers cannot finance a catastrophic earthquake,'' Franklin W. Nutter, chairman of an insurance industry coalition on quake dangers, told a House Banking subcommittee on insurance. ``While it is not possible to predict insured losses from all events at all locations ... it is safe to say that the (earthquake) peril presents the industry with a loss of catastrophic proportions,'' said John P. Drennan, a vice president of Allstate Insurance Co. There is a nationwide threat of earthquakes, said Arch C. Johnston of the Center for Earthquake Research and Information at Memphis State University. A ``major destructive earthquake in the eastern United States is the quintessential example of the low-probability-high-consequence event that invites complacency and defeats mitigation efforts. It is also the nightmare of the insurance industry,'' Johnston said. The long-term solution to quake damage is to design and build tremor-resistant buildings, Grant C. Peterson of the Federal Emergency Management Agency told the subcommittee. But he said his agency is studying possible loss-reduction provisions that could be included in a federal insurance program if one is developed. Drennan said that if the 1906 San Francisco quake ocurred today insured losses would total at least $3.4 billion, and a repeat of the 1811-12 tremor at New Madrid, Mo., would mean paying $1.7 billion. Nutter, however, estimated insured quake claims in another 1906 San Francisco quake could climb to $13.5 billion, with billions more in fire losses and bodily injury claims. Nutter proposed establishing a federal earthquake insurance program similar to the government's flood insurance _ backed by federal money but administered by private companies. Any federal insurance program must include requirements that efforts be made to reduce quake damage, said George Bernstein of the National Earthquake Hazards Review Program. Insurance is an efficient way to reimburse people for their losses, Bernstein testified, ``but without hazard mitigation, the guaranty of compensation from insurance will also create an incentive for irresponsible construction in disregard of known earthquake hazards.'' The flood insurance program imposes requirements for house siting and strengthening to reduce damage, he said. ``The earthquake risk may be different, but the principle is the same.'' Paying billions of dollars in claims could reduce insurance company funds to the point where they might have to stop issuing new policies, Nutter said, adding that if companies were forced to sell investments to pay claims there could be a severe decline in the stock and bond markets. Nutter proposed establishing a federal corporation that would organize earthquake coverage, investing premiums in government bonds as a surplus to pay any claims. If the surplus were not sufficient, federal borrowing authority would be available, he said. Nutter also urged that homeowners whose mortgages were federally insured or held by federally insured institutions be required to have earthquake insurance. That would widen the base of premiums, lowering average cost and increasing the surplus available, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Prime Minister to Visit Washington
DOC.TEXT: Charles J. Haughey, the prime minister of Ireland, will visit Washington on Feb. 27, the White House announced Wednesday. Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Haughey had accepted President Bush's invitation to make an official working visit to discuss developments in Europe, the Irish role as president of the European community and bilateral issues. The announcement was made by the traveling White House before Bush delivered a foreign policy address here.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Question Impact Effect of Disability Legislation
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Republican lawmakers on Wednesday questioned the impact on business of legislation guaranteeing the rights of the disabled. Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas and chairman of the Republican Study Committee Task Force on Competitiveness, said that he and his colleagues were concerned that the Americans with Disabilities Act ``may be moving too quickly through Congress to explore the impact it will have on our businesses, on our judicial system and on our nation's productivity as a whole.'' Equal Employment Opportunity Commissioner Evan J. Kemp Jr. told DeLay's group that President Bush ``knows the issues; he knows everything backwards and forwards in this area'' and fully supports the legislation. Kemp said more than 8 million disabled Americans could be brought into the work force through the employment-protection provisions of the law, saving the government $300 billion in welfare and other payments. The bill is also intended to ensure that the nation's 43 million disabled people have full access to shops, restaurants, lodging and other public accommodations. Kemp was one of several witnesses at a task force hearing on the legislation, which the Senate passed in September on a 76-8 vote. The bill has since cleared one of the four House committees with jurisdiction and is expected to be passed by the full chamber this year. Critics, particularly small-business interests and bus operators, contend that definitions in the law are vague and that its costs are immeasurable. Carolyn L. Weaver, a resident scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, said the act would raise labor costs, inhibit job formation and possibly lead to ``an undesirable distribution of gainers and losers.'' The proposed legislation would phase in employment-rights provisions over three years but exempt businesses with 15 or fewer employees. The legislation requires all businesses to provide ``reasonable accommodation'' to disabled patrons unless those adjustments would create an ``undue hardship.''

DOC.HEAD: New Chinese Envoy Arrives With Conciliatory Statement
DOC.TEXT: China's new envoy to Hong Kong greeted the British colony's elite Wednesday with a speech designed to bolster confidence as the territory approaches Chinese rule in 1997. In his first public appearance since arriving Monday, senior diplomat Zhou Nan acknowledged that China and Britain have disagreed on Hong Kong policy. ``Though some difficulties have emerged recently, I believe that both sides share the desire to have them resolved as soon as possible,'' Zhou said. He expressed hope that Britain and China would ``continue to cooperate sincerely with each other to strive for a brigther future for Hong Kong.'' Zhou, 62, is the new head of the Xinhua News Agency's office in Hong Kong, which functions as China's diplomatic mission to the colony. He takes the post at a troubling time for the territory, whose citizens were shaken when Chinese troops brutally suppressed the pro-democracy movement in Beijing in June 1989. The diplomat spoke at a Lunar New Year cocktail reception given by Xinhua and attended by everal thousand people. Britain and China have been at odds on a number of issues concerning Hong Kong, most prominently the pace of introducing political change. China's proposals for the post-1997 legislature have been widely condemned as not democratic enough. Beijing also has opposed Britain's plan to offer citizenship to 50,000 Hong Kong residents and their families and has accused the colonial government of allowing the territory to become a base for subversion against China. Zhou's speech is the second signal in as many days that China wants to improve relations with Britain. On Tuesday, Premier Li Peng said Beijing viewed relations with Britain as important and hoped they would develop. In a joint declaration with Britain, China said Hong Kong could keep capitalism for 50 years after 1997 and enjoy a ``high degree of autonomy.'' Zhou said China would live up to its obligations under the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Hopes To See Freed Mandela
With AM-South Africa-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson arrived Wednesday for talks with South African leaders and said he hoped to see Nelson Mandela freed and ``walking down the streets of Johannesburg'' before he leaves. Jackson gave a thumbs-up sign as he arrived at the airport for his 12-day visit, ignoring shouts from a handful of white right-wingers who shouted, ``Jesse, go home!'' He was protected by two lines of black and white policeman. A black man started a brief chorus of ``Welcome, Jesse'' among black airport workers lining the balconies. Jackson, granted a visa for the first time since his 1979 visit, said he hoped to encourage unity among black political factions and to ``address the unfounded fears of the whites.'' The American civil rights leader plans to meet President F.W. de Klerk, Foreign Minister Pik Botha and leaders of the anti-apartheid movement. He and his wife, Jackie, were greeted at the airport by African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu, his wife, Albertina, and church leaders Rev. Allan Boesak and Frank Chikane. ``This is a moment in South Africa's history that must be seized,'' Jackson said. ``If the government moves back, there will be chaos. If it stands still, there will be tension. But if the government seizes the political moment and moves forward, we will see the dawn of a new, free and democratic South Africa.'' Jackson declined to say whether he had requested a meeting with Mandela, the ANC leader who is expected to be released soon after more than 27 years in prison. ``I have no commitment from the government to meet him,'' Jackson said. ``I hope to see him walking down the streets of Johannesburg. The whole world hopes to see him free.'' In Cape Town, the pro-apartheid Conservative Party vowed to stage white protests and strikes to drive de Klerk from office and block his plans to share power with the black majority. Koos van der Merwe, chief spokesman for the Conservatives, the main white opposition party, said de Klerk deceived whites last week by suddenly legalizing the African National Congress guerrilla movement and more than 60 other anti-apartheid groups. He said de Klerk promised during the September election not to deal with the ANC until it abandoned violence. ``We will keep the pressure on him ... until he has no choice but to call a general election,'' van der Merwe said. Under the constitution, which de Klerk wants to replace with one produced in negotiations with blacks, the president has the sole power to call a parliamentary election. But if large numbers of whites joined a general strike, they could bring the government to a standstill, halt most transportation and close businesses, schools and hospitals. The Conservative Party promised its actions against de Klerk would be peaceful. But an extreme-right, Nazi-style group called the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, which has been involved in violent confrontations with blacks, promised to protest Jackson's appearances throughout the country during his tour.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves $42 Million Aid Package for Panama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The House approved a $42 million aid package for Panama today that lawmakers said will help the Central American country boost its damaged economy. The measure, which was approved by a voice vote, also includes $10 million to help newly emerging democracies in Eastern Europe prepare for elections. Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y., called the $42 million a way of ``finishing the course that `Just Cause' began. It combines aid, trade and investment.'' The Pentagon dubbed the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama ``Operation Just Cause.'' The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has endorsed a similiar package for Panama, and the Senate is expected to approve it shortly. The Senate Finance Committee today waived the normal 45-day review period and voted unanimously to lift the trade sanctions imposed two years ago because of Panama's involvement then in drug trafficking. Restoring the most-favored-nation and Caribbean Basin tariff preferences are part of identical packages approved Tuesday by House and Senate committees. Bush has said he wants to provide as much as $1 billion to Panama, and intends to introduce legislation later to funnel more money to the country. Several House members objected to rerouting $30 million from accounts for Africa to Panama, even though the administration has promised to restore the money later in the year. ``We are raiding the African account for the third time in recent years,'' said Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif. Others said they want the administration to ensure Panama lifts secrecy restrictions on its banks to prevent drug traffickers from laundering profits. Former President Ronald Reagan imposed the trade and investment sanctions in March 1988 as part of a U.S. effort to drive Manuel Antonio Noriega out of office as Panama's leader. ``We have a new regime in Panama, one which we expect will be much more cooperative than the last in helping us in the war on drugs,' said the finance committee's chairman, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas. Bernard Aronson, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs, told the House panel Panama's economy has declined by 16 percent over the past two years, while unemployment is more than 25 percent. The country's foreign debt has grown to $4 billion, freezing prospects for new borrowing, he said. But he added, ``Panama is not a basket case.'' U.S. aid is intended ``simply to help them do what they can and wish to do for themselves.'' The legislation would provide an immediate $12.5 million in cash and an additional $10 million in guarantees to rebuild the Panama City's Chorillo neighborhood, where fires in the wake of the invasion left 10,000 people homeless. The measure also would provide $7 million for emergency public works and jobs programs; $5.5 million to help agencies of the new government of President Guillermo Endara prepare budgets, and reorganize and train workers; $5 million to help looted businesses reopen their doors; and $2 million to begin training a new police force and start up a new judiciary. In addition, the bill certifies Panama is taking steps to cooperate with the war on drugs, including combatting trafficking and money laundering that flourished under Noriega. The statement would permit Panama to resume receiving favorable trade treatment and to benefit from the Caribbean Basin Initiative and investment incentives, aid the administration values at up to $500 million. In the next week, the administration will formally ask for an additional $500 million in cash aid for Panama, including: $185 million for the country's banks to provide liquidity for private sector lending; $145 million for a government program to generate investment and create jobs; $20 million for more police training and judicial reform; $20 million for private sector export promotion; and $130 million toward clearing Panama's debts to international development banks to make the country eligible for new lending. Meanwhile, a delegation of protesters including actor Edward Asner delivered a petition to the White House today calling on President Bush to ``withdraw the troops now, restore sovereignty to Panama and make reparations to the civilian victims (of the U.S. invasion) immediately.''

DOC.HEAD: Condition Of Rescued Satellite Bodes Well For Space Station
DOC.TEXT: A long-orbiting satellite rescued by a space shuttle crew last month shows some deterioration but not enough to halt NASA's plans for a permanent manned space station, a project scientist said Wednesday. ``There is nothing here to indicate you can't proceed with the space station,'' William Kinard told reporters who viewed the Long Duration Exposure Facility in a sterile room where it is undergoing preliminary examination after six years in space. Kinard reported the 11-ton satellite, sent into orbit to determine how durable various materials would be in space, was peppered with thousands, ``perhaps as many as 10,000,'' of tiny bits of space dust called micrometeoroids. He based the estimate on a count of 40 visible hits on one small section of the LDEF satellite, the size of a small school bus. He said the largest crater was 5 millimeters in diameter, about one-fifth of an inch. Kinard said several spacecraft materials suffered minor erosion from the wearing effects of atomic oxygen and ultraviolet radiation, and that in some instances the micrometeoroid craters were further damaged by the introduction of these elements. He said the crater count enabled researchers to ``establish a data base on micrometeoroid impacts in space.'' Because the damage was not excessive, he said, this should provide confidence for those planning to build NASA's space station Freedom with assembly of the big manned laboratory slated to start in orbit in 1995. Kinard said the aluminum struts which form the main body of LDEF ``were very intact ... I would fly this spacecraft again.'' Aluminum will be the principal metal used in the space station. He said the atomic oxygen erosion of other materials was ``about what we expected. I don't think it is a real problem for the space station. It just means they have to use materials not subject to atomic oxygen erosion, especially on the leading edge.'' Kinard said there was some discoloration and that foil covering some experiments had torn. ``But that's why we sent it up there, to find out what happens to materials after a long time in the space environment,'' Kinard said. ``We're delighted with the condition.'' LDEF was retrieved from orbit on Jan. 12 by the crew of the space shuttle Columbia, just weeks before gravity would have tugged it to fiery destruction in the atmosphere. It was brought here Jan. 26, and since then technicians and scientists have been examining it. There are 57 experiment trays containing various test materials on board. Kinard said these will be removed starting about Feb. 20 for detailed studies by principal investigators. The first tray to be removed contains 12.5 million tomato seeds, which will be distributed to students at various grades around the country for tests to see how they grow after so long in space.

DOC.HEAD: One Suspect Killed, One Arrested in Family's Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with suspects identified, details of shootout. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed maintenance man suspected in the slayings of four family members who were tied up, shot and set afire in their home died today in a shootout with police, and his mother was arrested, authorities said. State Police said it was not clear whether 33-year-old Anthony Turner, who was sitting on a bed and holding a shotgun to his chin when police entered his apartment to arrest him, killed himself or was slain by police gunfire. Authorities carried a warrant charging Turner _ also known as Michael Kinge _ with murder in the Dec. 22 slayings of Warren Harris, 39; his wife, Dolores, 41; and their children, ages 11 and 15. Authorities also arrested Turner's mother, Shirley Kinge, 54, and turned over to social workers a 2-year-old taken from her apartment and believed to be Turner's child. State Police Superintendent Thomas Constantine said Ms. Kinge would be charged in connection with the slayings but he would not say what charges would be filed. ``We are very relieved of course. It's brought a lot of emotion back, and now it's kind of a reality to me. We are very relieved, we are very excited, we are very glad,'' said Pat Lake of Manlius, whose husband, Don, is a brother of Mrs. Harris. The Harrises were tied up, shot in the back of the head and hours later doused with fuel and set on fire in upstairs bedrooms at their home, set far back from a road on a large wooded lot in this affluent Ithaca suburb. The bodies were discovered the next day after firefighters had put out the blaze. Police have said robbery appears the most likely motive for the killings. Mrs. Harris ran a country gifts and antiques store just a few yards from the house. Her husband was a sales director for an electronics distributor. On the day the bodies were found, a man and woman used the Harrises' credit cards to buy clothing, electronics and diamonds at malls in suburban Syracuse and Auburn. Clerks at those stores helped a police artist draw sketches of the people who used the cards. Maj. Robert J. Farrand said the investigators focused on Turner as the result of identifications given by people who had seen composite drawings released by authorities. Farrand said there were no other suspects. Turner had a long criminal history in New York City, including convictions for burglary and theft with a deadly weapon, police said. Turner was holding a gun to his chin when authorities entered, said Constantine. The man turned toward police and fired once, and the three officers returned fire, he said. Constantine said an autopsy would be performed.

DOC.HEAD: Wild Melee Erupts After Shoplifting Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Three store employees who tried to stop four people suspected of shoplifting were kicked black and blue, and a policeman found himself looking down the barrel of a gun _ wielded by a 2-year-old. The merchandise that allegedly wasn't paid for was destroyed in the melee. The women were jailed. Officers said employees of a Marshalls department store reported the women walked out of the store Monday without paying for some clothing they were carrying. Three male employees chased the women to the parking lot, where a fight broke out. By the time police arrived, the fight had broken up and the women were in their car. Officer Charles Bledsoe said that when he approached the womens' car he saw a gun being pointed at him from inside. Bledsoe discovered the gun was being held by a 2-year-old boy, who was then disarmed. The four women arrested were all from Nacogdoches. A spokesman at the Smith County Jail said two were charged with felony robbery. Municipal Court Judge Diane DeVasto set their bail at $15,000 each. The third was charged with unlawfully carrying a weapon and the fourth with theft, and their bail was set at $1,000 each. The store employees all suffered bruises on their legs from being kicked repeatedly, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Indicates Blacks Twice as Likely to Develop Eye Disease
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT middle initial of researcher.
DOC.TEXT: Blacks are twice as likely as whites to have vision problems that cannot be corrected with glasses, according to a survey of more than 5,300 people over age 40. The study's authors could not explain the finding and were ``in the process of exploring what those reasons might be,'' said James M. Tielsch, co-author of the study that appears in this month's Archives of Ophthalmology. It was conducted over a four-year period in east Baltimore, a working-class section, and was designed to provide data typical of multiracial urban populations in the United States, said Tielsch, an ophthalmology professors at Johns Hopkins' Wilmer Eye Institute. Almost 12 percent of those studied were visually impaired even though they wore glasses and saw an eye doctor regularly. ``This translates nationally to more than 9 million people,'' Tielsch said Tuesday. ``The good news is that two-thirds to three-quarters of those were correctable, that is they could move out of the visual impairment category just by the provision of the proper pair of spectacles.'' The study defined impairment as vision of 20-40 and legal blindness as vision of 20-200. The study's two principal findings were that, ``For both visual impairment and for blindness, at every age blacks have a higher proportion of people affected than whites,'' Tielsch said. ``The second point is that there's a dramatic increase with increasing age in both the proportion of people affected from visual impairment and blindness.'' The study found visual impairment in 2.2 percent of whites and 3.94 percent of the blacks. Of the whites, 0.43 percent were legally blind, compared with 1.02 percent of blacks. Among both race, the researchers projected that more than 3 million people nationwide could see no better than 20-40 even with the strongest glasses. Of those, more than 890,000 are legally blind. The study found that in the oldest age group, those over 80, more than 25 percent were blind or visually impaired because of eye disease, said Tielsch, whose co-author was Dr. Alfred Sommer. East Baltimore was chosen because socio-economic conditions of blacks and whites in the area are similar. The area is poor to middle class and has a higher rate of rental housing than the rest of the city and country, the study said. ``We chose Baltimore to serve as a model for the rest of urban America,'' Tielsch said. ``It's a credible study by a credible group. They do good work,'' said Dr. Barbara Klein, an ophthalmology professor at the University of Wisconsin. ``(The study) was done the right way and from their credibility it's likely to be quite true.'' About 50 percent of those interviewed for the study were black. None of the participants was a resident of a nursing home, hospital or institution for the blind. All the participants were given an eye examination, and about one-third were given a complete exam at Wilmer.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Governor Signs Legislation Allowing Riverboat Gambling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The gambling ...' to CORRECT that measure is not intended to raise revenue for the state by RESTORING dropped `not.'
DOC.TEXT: Gov. James R. Thompson today signed legislation allowing riverboat gambling on the Mississippi and Illinois rivers beginning next year. The gambling ``is not designed to make money for the state,'' Thompson said in a statement, ``but rather help local economies by stimulating tourism and economic development revenues for the municipalities that want it.'' The governor also appointed a five-member gaming board to oversee the floating casinos. Supporters say the legislation will give Illinois an edge over Iowa in the race for tourism dollars. Riverboat gambling becomes legal in Iowa in April 1991. The Illinois measure will provide five licenses, each allowing two riverboats, for a total of as many as eight floating casinos on the Mississippi River and two on the Illinois River beginning in 1991. The gaming board may issue five additional licenses, for two riverboats each, in 1992. One such license is designated for the Des Plaines River. In signing the legislation, Thompson urged the Legislature to correct what he described as minor flaws in the bill. Among the recommended changes is a $500 limit on the amount a person could lose during an excursion. Sponsors of the gambling legislation said the limit was inadvertently left out of the bill approved in January.

DOC.HEAD: Hospitals Struggle to Save Lives After Nine Days of Christian Warfare
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 11 grafs to update with plane landing in Paris, French officials reporting 16 people on board, cease-fire committee meeting. Pickup 10th pvs, `If Aoun...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BEI1,2,8
DOC.TEXT: Scores of people wounded in nine days of war between Lebanon's main Christian armies are dying in hospitals that have no power and little blood, medicine or clean water, police said Wednesday. They said 365 people had been killed and 1,682 wounded since the battle for supremacy began Jan. 30 between nearly 20,000 soldiers commanded by rebel Gen. Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces militia of Samir Geagea, which has about 6,000 regulars and an estimated 30,000 reservists. Many of the victims have been civilians, some of them Moslems killed or wounded by shells that strayed out of Christian territory. On Wednesday, families in Christian east Beirut searched for relatives in hospitals where surgeons operated by candlelight. Police said food was so short that some people fought over bread in Christian neighborhoods, where hundreds of thousands of people have spent a week or more in basements or bomb shelters. French Cabinet minister Bernard Kouchner and Rene Ala, the French ambassador, arranged a 90-minute truce on a single street so seven ambulances could take seriously wounded people from a hospital in the Ashrafiyeh district. Snipers from both sides fired overhead as the convoy dashed to evacuate the wounded, who included an 8-month-old baby with a head wound. They were driven to Beirut airport in the Moslem sector, where a French jet took them to Paris for treatment, along with other wounded civilians. The French foreign ministry said the plane carried 16 victims who were transferred to eight hospitals in Paris after their arrival. Meanwhile, mediators representing Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, the highest ranking Christian prelate in the Christian enclave, convened a cease-fire committee with representatives from the two warring factions. Christian-controlled radio stations said the meeting lasted six hours. There was no immediate announcement. A police spokesman said Aoun, who has been dismissed as army commander but refuses to step aside, appeared to be reorganizing his forces for a major drive against Geagea's besieged strongholds in the 310-square-mile Christian area north and east of Beirut. If Aoun is successful, his control of Christian territory might be difficult to break even for the 40,000 Syrian soldiers in Lebanon, with whom Aoun fought a six-month artillery war that ended in September. At a news conference, Aoun blamed the fighting on Geagea and claimed the United States was using the militia chieftain to force implementation of a peace plan designed to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun rejects the peace plan because it does not include a timetable for the withdrawal of the Syrian troops, and he refuses to recognize President Elias Hrawi, who was elected as part of the plan. Hrawi, Aoun and Geagea are Maronite Cathlics, the Christian sect that has dominated the government, army and judiciary since independence from France in 1943. Geagea recognizes Hrawi as president but has not taken a public position on the peace plan negotiated last fall at Taif, Saudi Arabia. ``The Trojan Horse never said in public he was in favor of the Taif accord, although he staged his war against the army with American blessing to enforce implementation of the humiliating agreement,'' Aoun told the news conference, broadcast by his station, Radio Lebanon. Artillery generally was silent Wednesday, allowing civilians to emerge from shelters and search for food and missing relatives, said the police spokesman, whose name cannot be used under standing regulations. ``We received several calls from hospitals asking us to send patrols to deal with thousands of nervous and worried people inquiring about missing relatives,'' he said. ``Many of them had pictures of their missing ones. Others wanted to have a look at the bodies or the unconscious wounded. The hospitals didn't have staff to deal with such cases.'' He said surgeons operated by candlelight, using water boiled on kerosene stoves. Crowds filled the few open bakeries, and some people who didn't want to wait ``tried to steal a few loaves,'' he said. ``Fistfights developed.'' On Tuesday, Aoun achieved his most significant victory by ousting the Lebanese Forces from their seven barracks in the hills of Dbaye on Beirut's northern flank. That put him in postiion to attack the remaining militia strongholds in east Beirut and in Kesrouan, Byblos and Batroun provinces north of the capital. Geagea's men are experienced street fighters, however, and Aoun cannot claim undisputed mastery of the Christian enclave until he drives them from east Beirut and Jounieh, a port town north of the city. Two-thirds of the 1 million Christians live in east Beirut, where the militia is entrenched in the Karantina, Ashrafiyeh and Ein Rummaneh districts, and in Jounieh, where Geagea has total control. Hrawi has hinted at requesting help from the Syrians, who support him, but their intervention would need advance international approval. On Tuesday, Hrawi appealed to Western nations, the Soviet Union, the United Nations and the Arab world for help in ending the fighting. The Syrian soldiers were deployed in Lebanon in 1976 to quell civil war fighting. Aoun says they violated their peacekeeping mandate by siding with the Moslems in the civil war.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Miss America Debbye Turner said she has only pity for Miss West Virginia Lisa Bittinger, who didn't make the top 10 in the finals and then groused about the Atlantic City, N.J., contest. ``I feel sorry for Lisa,'' Turner said during a speech at West Virginia University on Monday night. ``She missed the point entirely about Miss America. ``The point is, isn't it great that in America a black, a Korean, a Japanese, a kidney transplant and a 95 percent hearing impaired (person) can become Miss America and achieve success?'' said Turner, who is black. Bittinger's comments after the contest about the ethnic makeup and physical problems of the winners prompted the state chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to call for her resignation. Turner, 24, is a senior in veterinary medicine at the University of Missouri. Telephone messages left on Bittinger's home answering machine Tuesday and Wednesday were not returned. A magistrate ruled in December that Bittinger was in the right when she pulled a gun on another woman who had kicked out the window of her car and pulled her hair in a late-night fight over a man.

Singers Willie Nelson, John Mellencamp and Neil Young are preparing for the fourth Farm Aid concert here April 7, but their reception from the farming establishment may not be terrific. The three called a press conference Tuesday and attacked corporate interests, slow-to-change government farm policies and the use of chemicals in agriculture. ``We're here to call attention ... to the fact that in order to farm these days, before you can get a loan you have to poison your land,'' said Nelson, the chairman of Farm Aid. The use of pesticides is contaminating the water and killing populations of rabbits and horned toads, Nelson said. ``If you can't drink the water, you shouldn't eat the food,'' he said. Young condemned the ``superfarms that poison the land and have no conscience.'' He also said farmland is being overused because of corporate pressure. ``The land is practically dead,'' said Young. ``In the old days the farmer used to let the land rest. ... We're losing farms to this kind of thinking.'' Lt. Gov. Frank O'Bannon, the state's commissioner of agriculture, joined Gov. Evan Bayh in appearing at the news conference but said most Hoosier farmers don't share the musicians' views on getting rid of farm chemicals. ``Most of our production farmers have to look at the bottom line to stay in business,'' O'Bannon said, ``but they want to do it in an environmentally sound way.'' The first three Farm Aid concerts raised more than $12 million, of which $9 million has been distributed to more than 100 farm organizations, hotlines, churches and service organizations in 41 states.

Martial arts movie star Chuck Norris said he will help a couple of international kick boxing champions pay for their son's funeral. The teen-ager was killed over the weekend in a gang-related shooting. Sonny Rodriguez, 16, was shot in the chest while riding with friends Saturday in a car in suburban Sylmar, police said. His parents, William ``Blinky'' and Lilly Rodriguez are champions in kick boxing, an Asian sport that allows the use of feet as well as fists. Norris said this week that he was a family friend and knew the youth. ``He was a real good athlete,'' Norris said. ``Blinky and I trained together and Blinky was always hurrying off to his son's football games. ``They were a very close family and very religious. I lost a brother in Vietnam, so I can understand how it feels,'' he said. Norris said he will contribute to a trust fund to cover funeral costs. A benefit kick-boxing event at the Hollywood Palladium also will help pay for the funeral. Three young men pulled up beside the auto in which Rodriquez was in, shouted gang slogans and one fired a handgun, said Los Angeles police Detective Steve Fisk. Three suspects have been arrested and charged, police said.

The improbable story of a lawyer with no writing experience ending up writing a hit television series is just what happened to David E. Kelley, the 33-year-old executive producer and script writer for ``L.A. Law.'' ``I knew the character names went in the middle of the page. That was about it. I was a complete novice,'' Kelley said recently of the days in 1983 when he decided to write a script. He wrote it out in longhand, while working for a law firm in Boston, then spent $1,200 for a word processor and typed it out ``two fingers at a time.'' ``I remember thinking all I want out of this is to make back the money for the word processor.'' The rest is show biz. His script was optioned to eventually become the film ``From the Hip,'' which starred Judd Nelson. In the meantime, the option was enough to get him an agent and an interview with the people looking for someone with legal experience to work on what ultimately became NBC's Emmy Award-winning series on lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Political Clash in Karachi Kills 41
DOC.TEXT: Police battled Moslem sharpshooters Wednesday after riots between rival political parties, and the government said at least 41 people had been killed. ``This is terrorism,'' said Qaim Ali Shah, chief minister of Sindh province. ``Innocent people are being killed.'' The government clamped a 24-hour curfew on two more districts of Pakistan's sprawling southern port city of Karachi following a day of clashes between police and sharpshooters, who fired at random from their rooftop perches. The 41 killings Wednesday raised the death toll to 47 since Monday, when clashes began between supporters of the governing Pakistan People's Party and the Mohajir Qaumi Movement, representing Moslems who emigrated from India after British colonial rule ended in 1947. Most of Karachi's 5 million people belong to the immigrant party, which is based in the troubled province of Sindh. ``Most of the people were killed by MQM activists,'' said a government spokesman who refused to be identified. The Mohajirs blame the killings of two party members on supporters of the governing party. Pakistan's official news agency said 120 people were being held in connection with the daylong shootings. No charges have been filed yet. Soldiers in jeeps with machine guns patrolled the city, deserted except for police and militant Mohajirs, who called a 24-hour strike. Some of those killed Wednesday died when police tried to dismantle a roadblock by Mohajir members, a government spokesman said. Snipers opened fire on the police, and before the gunbattle ended, as many as 10 people were dead, police said. Angry protesters also attacked police stations demanding the arrest of several People's Party members. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto condemned the killings and blamed the Mohajirs, without naming their party. In her statement, released from Islamabad, Ms. Bhutto complained about a ``flagrant breach of assurances by a certain political group to the government that law and order would be maintained in Karachi during the strike.'' The Pakistan Peoples Party is supported by Sindh nationalists, while the Mohajir Qaumi Movement represents people who immigrated from India after Pakistan's independence in 1947. Hundreds of people have been killed and thousands injured in ethnic clashes between the Sindh nationalists, who want greater autonomy, and Mohajirs, who want to be recognized as a fifth ethnic group.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Star Wars Needed Now More Than Ever Before
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, The White ... to UPDATE with quotes from San Francisco speech; picks up 4th graf, Bush was ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush visited a Strategic Defense Initiative research lab today and declared that a missile defense shield in space ``makes much more sense than ever before.'' Bush made the pitch for Star Wars in a speech to what he called the ``under-appreciated'' staff at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories, the nerve center of both the Star Wars research effort and nuclear weapons work. The White House also announced Bush has invited West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to Camp David on Feb. 24-25 to discuss East-West issues and the prospects for German unification. Later, in a speech prepared for delivery to the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco, Bush said he will not ``predicate the defense of our people on promising, but as yet unfulfilled, hopes for the future.'' ``Let us not forget that right now the Soviets still have more than 10,000 strategic weapons. They are modernizing them,'' said Bush. ``I am determined to seek with the Soviets the collateral to implement a new peace. ... '' said Bush. ``We have shown that American strength is the catalyst for arms control.'' ``We must not let impatience, born of euphoria, jeopardize all we hope to achieve,'' said Bush. Bush was beating the drum for his defense budget on a cross-country trip at the same time the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee was meeting in Moscow to renounce its seven-decade old monopoly on power in the Soviet Union. After the Commonwealth Club speech, Bush was flying to Omaha, Neb., to visit Strategic Air Command headquarters Thursday. Bush told the Livermore workers the shift toward democracy and freedom in the East Bloc ``is a direct result of our ability to stand firm in the face of threats to peace and stability.'' ``We're working on a significant reduction in arms. I think that's what the world wants. I believe in it strongly,'' Bush said. ``But to protect the American people we will settle for nothing less than the highest confidence in survivability, effectiveness and safety of our remaining forces.'' ``Programs like the Strategic Defense Initiative and one of its most promising concepts, `Brilliant Pebbles', complement our ability to preserve the peace into the 1990s and beyond,'' Bush said. ``If the technology I've seen today proves feasible _ and I'm told it looks very promising _ no war planner could be confident of the consequences of a ballistic missile attack,'' said Bush, who praised the nuclear weapons workers. ``I have a funny feeling that because of the nature of the work, it is somewhat under-appreciated by the average man on the street in our country,'' said Bush. ``In the 1990s strategic defense makes much more sense than ever before,'' said Bush, who is asking Congress to boost the Star Wars research budget by $1 billion to $4.8 billion for fiscal 1991. Congress cut $1 billion from its budget this year. On Tuesday night, in a Los Angeles speech where he was heckled by AIDS activists and critics of U.S. aid to El Salvador, Bush took a sharp jab at Democrats who say his proposed $292 billion Pentagon budget for fiscal 1991 is too fat in view of the diminished Soviet threat. Bush appealed to the crowd to back his go-slow approach to defense retrenchment. ``I'm in a big battle in Congress, and I'd like to have your support to keep reasonable levels of defense. I'm not going to miss an opportunity to cut, but I want to do it prudently and I want to get something from the other side when we do it,'' he said. Star Wars is no longer billed as an impregnable shield capable of blocking any enemy launch of a nuclear missile against the United States. The favored concept now is the so-called ``brilliant pebbles'' idea conceived by a team of Livermore scientists to deploy thousands of tiny satellites or miniature rockets in low-earth orbit, where they could ram and destroy enemy missiles. Bush planned to deliver a foreign policy address before the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco before departing for Omaha, Neb., where he will tour the underground headquarters of the Strategic Air Command on Thursday. Several hundred demonstrators, many bearing signs attacking U.S. military support for El Salvador, jeered, chanted and whistled outside a Los Angeles hotel where Bush spoke at a $1,000-a-plate fund-raiser Tuesday night for the California Republican party. Bush took note of the ``rapid and welcome change'' around the world ``as people from Panama to Prague strive for democracy.'' ``As the nature of the threats to American security change, so too must our response,'' said Bush. ``Our forces will remain robust, well-trained, highly professional but geared to the new array of challenges of the '90s.'' Earlier, Bush watched an armored Army brigade wage a mock battle in the Mojave Desert against a training force at Fort Irwin that emulates Soviet-style tactics. Addressing the troops by radio before watching the training exercise, Bush said, ``The events of Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union have changed our strategic defense posture. It is important not to let these encouraging changes, political or military, lull us into a sense of complacency. Nor can we let down our guard against a worldwide threat.'' Back in Washington, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., kept up the pressure for defense cuts Tuesday, saying Bush's desire to boost spending on big strategic weapons programs fails ``to match the new political realities at home or abroad.'' This was Bush's third trip as president to California, a state he won narrowly in 1988. He is hoping to bolster the gubernatorial campaign of Sen. Pete Wilson, running to succeed fellow Republican George Deukmejian.

DOC.HEAD: President Urges Rebels To Accept Cease-Fire, Claims Battle Victory
DOC.TEXT: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, claiming a key battle victory over U.S.-backed rebels, has urged rebel leader Jonas Savimbi to accept a cease-fire in the nation's 15-year-old civil war. Dos Santos, speaking at a meeting of Angolan farmers Tuesday night, said Savimbi would receive ``humane treatment'' if he accepted the cease-fire, part of a government amnesty offer to lead to the rebels' integration into Angola's military, economic and social structures. He said that as part of the deal, candidates independent of the governing Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola would be allowed to compete in elections held after the war. In previous statements, dos Santos said elections would not end one-party rule by the Marxist governing party. He also had ruled out Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA, from running in any elections. UNITA officials contacted in Lisbon, Portugal, Wednesday refused to comment on dos Santos' speech. In the past, Savimbi has rejected government amnesty and integration offers. He has insisted that a cease-fire be followed by the formation of a transitional government to prepare for free, multiparty elections. The president claimed victory in a battle for control of the strategic Mavinga base in southeast Angola, 700 miles southeast of Luanda. In a statement Wednesday, government military headquarters said the base fell Friday and that 543 guerrillas died in the fighting. It put government casualties at 55 dead. The rebels, however, continued Wednesday to claim they controlled Mavinga. In a statement from Lisbon, UNITA said its lines were holding out against intense bombing raids from the government's Soviet-supplied planes and helicopters. A Western diplomat monitoring the fighting from Lisbon said government troops had captured Mavinga's airstrip but that the rebels remained in control of their base nearby and were mounting counter-attacks against government forces. Army sources in Luanda said the fall of Mavinga would open the way for government troops to attack the rebel headquarters at Jamba, 160 miles futher south. The battle for Mavinga is the first major conventional military confrontation since South Africa agreed to halt support for UNITA and Cuba began a withdrawal of its troops backing government forces. Those moves were made in accordance with a 1988 accord signed in New York. Dos Santos claimed the government advance on Mavinga was a response to UNITA violations of a cease-fire agreement sealed in June when he met Savimbi in Zaire. Peace talks mediated by Zaire's President Mobuto Sese Seko followed the Zaire agreement, but they broke down last summer as the cease-fire crumbled amid renewed fighting. Attempts to bring the two sides back to the negotiating table have failed. President Denis Sassou-Nguesso of Congo is due to discuss Angola with President Bush in Washington later this week. The United States is UNITA's main backer, supplying the rebels with an estimated $50 million yearly in military equipment. UNITA has been fighting to share control in Angola since the country gained independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Attorney General Withdraws as Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Steve Clark withdrew as a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination on Wednesday, one day after being notified that authorities were looking into his expense accounts. ``After much reflection and discussion with my family and friends, I have reached the conclusion that the mistakes in my expense records and subsequent news coverage about those mistakes have virtually destroyed my ability to run an efficient and effective campaign for governor,'' the statement said. Clark also said he would complete his term as attorney general. Clark read his statement in less than a minute and then left the room without answering questions. Prosecutor Chris Piazza on Tuesday notified Clark that state police and auditors were looking into his expenses. Piazza requested the inquiry in response to news reports that people claimed by Clark as fellow diners on state expense forms actually never ate with him. Clark apologized and repaid nearly $4,000 to the state, saying his mistakes were due to sloppy bookkeeping. The attorney general said the mistakes occurred when he tried to reconstruct how he used a state-issued Visa card 60 to 90 days after the fact.

DOC.HEAD: Police Respond to Disturbance Report, Find Former Heavyweight Champion
DOC.TEXT: Officers responding to a report of a street disturbance found former heavyweight champion Muhammad Ali at the middle of the crowd, police said Wednesday. ``When the officers arrived, they found it was just a group of juveniles talking to a celebrity,'' Capt. Eugene Kyle said. Ali, who suffers from a brain disorder, had Floyd Bass, groundskeeper of Ali's estate near Berrien Springs, Mich., as his spokesman.
