Bass explained Ali was asked several weeks ago to visit the West Side home of a teen-age girl who has cancer. After visting the girl's home Tuesday evening, Ali decided to mingle with youngsters in the neighborhood, said Bass. ``He likes to surprise people,'' Bass said. He said Ali also performed magic tricks for the youths before police arrived. Ali and officers who responded to the disturbance report then agreed to play a practical joke on those at the Central Police Station. Cpl. John Collins brought Ali into the station in handcuffs, claiming he had arrested the ex-fighter. After everyone had a good laugh, it was handshakes, autographs and photographs for the police officers. Collins and several other officers then escorted Ali as he visited several downtown restaurants and night spots. Following the brief visit to South Bend, Ali returned to his home in Berrien Springs, said Bass.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Average Trucker Supports Testing of Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Interstate truck drivers generally approve of drug testing for themselves and their peers, a survey shows. Richard Beilock, a transportation expert for the University of Florida's Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences, said Wednesday his survey of 1,300 drivers in 1989 indicates most interstate truckers welcome the federal government's new policy of mandatory drug testing, part of which went into effect Dec. 21. Department of Transportation regulations reguire, among other things, pre-employment drug testing and post-accident testing of certain companies engaged in interstate commerce. The survey showed 66 percent of drivers approve random drug-testing, while 90 percent support mandatory post-accident testing. It also showed that 84 percent approve of drug tests as an employment condition, and 76 percent believe a trucker should be tested if he gives his employers reason to believe he is a drug abuser. ``What this reflects is that the vast bulk of those drivers are good men and women who are concerned about their own safety, the public's safety, and their image,'' said Beilock. ``They feel very bad that they're no longer viewed as knights of the road.'' The survey was conducted on every trucker who came through certain state agricultural inspection stations on a specific day.

DOC.HEAD: AFL-CIO President Urges National Health Care Reform
DOC.TEXT: AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland spoke Wednesday of ``a growing wave of fear'' among Americans over escalating health costs and urged Congress to enact some form of national health care reform. Kirkland joined Washington Gov. Booth Gardner before the Senate Budget Committee, where there was agreement about the problems of health care costs but few specifics on what to do. ``We have a paradox of excess and deprivation,'' said Sen. Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the committee. ``We spend more on health than any other nation. ... Yet many millions of Americans have no access to health care of any kind.'' Sasser said 32 million Americans have no health insurance and that there are 21 countries that have a lower infant mortality rate than the United States. Kirkland said rising health care costs have become a major obstacle in resolving labor contract disputes. ``There is in this country a growing wave of fear, well grounded fear,'' about health care, Kirkland said. ``Fear of ruin _ fear of physical ruin and fear of economic ruin.'' Kirkland said the AFL-CIO did not support nationalized health care or other specific plans for assuring universal access to care. ``We are deliberately keeping all options open,'' Kirkland said, adding that he opposes employers' use of pension fund surpluses to finance health care benefits except for retirees who are beneficiaries of those funds. Gardner, who will make health care the top priority of the National Governors' Association when he becomes its chairman this summer, urged Congress consult the states. He said health care costs consume 14 percent of Washington State revenues, and at current rates of growth will take up 23 percent in 10 years without improving access. Gardner called for reform that would provide ``universal access to necessary health services,'' combined with controls on costs. ``Ultimately we need to make all residents of this country automatically eligible for health coverage,'' Gardner said. Meanwhile, Louis Sullivan, secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, told the Senate Labor-HHS appropriations subcommittee that there should be more emphasis on primary care and disease prevention. ``There's no challenging that at its best the American health care system has no equal,'' Sullivan said. ``But while we have emphasized our high technology with spectacular results, we have developed a system that is very expensive and we have also neglected a fundamental bedrock of our system, and that is providing basic health services to all of our citizens.'' Health care spending in the United States this year is expected to exceed $600 billion, or more than 12 percent of the nation's gross national product. Canada spends about a third less per capita on health care than the United States while covering all citizens, said subcommittee chairman Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa.

DOC.BYLINE: If There's a Greater Nebraska, Is There a Lesser? ^By J.L. SCHMIDT
DOC.TEXT: Nebraska might be a great state, but some of its lawmakers don't think ``Greater Nebraska' is such a great name. They want people to stop using the terms ``outstate Nebraska, greater Nebraska and lesser Nebraska'' to describe areas of the Cornhusker state. And to make the point they adopted a resolution making such utterances punishable by a $50 fine _ even though such a resolution can't be enforced. ``I did it mostly for the education,'' said co-sponsor Sen. Sandy Scofield, who lives in greater Nebraska ... er, oops ... the Nebraska Panhandle. About one third of the state's 1.57 million residents live in the state two largest cities, Omaha and Lincoln, the state capital. The two cities are about 60 miles apart on the eastern edge of the state. The terms outstate Nebraska and greater Nebraska are often used for the vast area outside Omaha-Lincoln. The 1989 Nebraska State Government Directory is riddled with ``outstate'' listings. And even Gov. Kay Orr admits to having used the term ``greater Nebraska.'' The resolution adopted on a 14-4 vote on Monday calls on lawmakers, constitutional officers, state employees and representatives of the state to lead the way in eliminating ``the imprecise, divisive terms.'' The use of the term ``greater Nebraska ... implies some part of the state is lesser Nebraska,'' the resolution says. ``It's a serious matter if you live outside of Lincoln or Omaha. It gets more serious the farther west you go,'' said Scofield, who lives in Chadron, farther from Lincoln than any of her 48 colleagues in the Legislature. Another senator from far western Nebraska, Sen. Dennis Baack of Kimball, said he views the whole discussion as ``a great geography lesson.'' Baack, who thinks the state should be referred to by geographic areas, said the resolution is ``an effort to make sure people understand the geography of their own state better. We're all Nebraskans, I happen to live in and represent the Panhandle. ``But you don't have to call us Panhandlers.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Castigated For Influx Into Israel
DOC.TEXT: Islamic leaders Wednesday castigated the United States and Soviet Union for the influx of Soviet Jews into the Israeli-occupied territories as they gathered to mark the 20th anniversary of the Organization of the Islamic Conference. Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, said Washington and Moscow were guilty of the ``most dangerous decision against the Arab world at the turn of the century.'' ``The Jewish influx emanates from the Soviet Union and flows under the banner of human rights to settle in the land of their choice by dint of the new immigration laws in the United States and Europe,'' the emir said in a speech read by his minister of Islamic affairs, Khaled Ahmed al-Jassar. Al-Sabah is chairman of the Organization of the Islamic Conference, the umnbrella grouping for the world's estimated 1 billion Moslems. Israel has said it expects about 300,000 Soviet Jews to settle in the Jewish state in the next five years. Restrictions on immigration of Soviet Jews into the United States have led in part to the flood into Israel. The United States and Soviet Union oppose settling Soviet Jews in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, saying it is an obstacle to making peace with Palestinians who are fighting for an independent nation. On Jan. 15, Israel's prime minister, Yitzhak Shamir, caused widespread protests when he said Israel must hold onto the occupied lands to deal with the wave of expected immigrants. ``The makers of the law talk about the right of Jews to emigrate and settle where they wish and do not talk about the right of the Arab person to the soil of his homeland and that of his forefathers,'' said Al-Sabah. The anniversary ceremony attracted a number of officials, including the foreign ministers of Egypt, Senegal and Gabon. The Islamic organization was founded after an Aug. 21, 1969 arson attack at Jerusalem's Al-Aqsa Mosque, one of Islam's holiest shrines. The arson was attributed in Israel to a demented man and occurred two years after Israel had seized the West Bank and Gaza Strip from Egypt and Jordan. About 70,000 Jewish settlers live alongside 1.7 million Palestinians in the territories. Saudi King Fahd, in a speech read on his behalf by Defense Minister Prince Sultan, said the Islamic organization ``crystallized the call for Islamic solidarity and defense of Moslem rights and interests.'' The group's headquarters are in the Saudi port of Jiddah, and Saudi Arabia is the dominant force in the organization.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican to Restore Ties With Hungary
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican secretary of state arrived Wednesday for a visit officials said will include the re-establishment of diplomatic ties that were severed by the Communists 45 years ago. Cardinal Agostino Casaroli and Hungarian officials will sign documents during the five-day visit formally restoring diplomatic relations broken after the government expelled the Vatican's envoy in 1945, the Vatican said Tuesday. Hungary, in the Soviet bloc mainstream of reforms to establish Western-style democracy, will be the second Warsaw Pact country to restore relations with the Vatican. Ties with Poland resumed in July. ``Although the church does not play a direct role in politics, ... by virtue of educating the soul, reinforcing democratic and social values and shaping moral consciousness, it can play an important part in the social changes taking place,'' Casaroli told the Hungarian news agency MTI before leaving Rome on Wednesday. Negotiations between the Vatican and Hungary, which has a Catholic majority, had been going on for months, and both sides had earlier agreed Pope John Paul II would visit Hungary next year. Casaroli planned to celebrate Mass on Thursday at the basilica in Esztergom, the seat of the Hungarian primate. The square in front of the basilica will then be renamed after Cardinal Jozsef Mindszenty. A plaque dedicated to Mindszenty is to be unveiled, with interim President Matyas Szueroes in attendance. Thursday marks the 41st anniversary of the sentencing of Mindszenty on trumped-up charges designed to break the resistance of the Catholic Church to Communist rule. Mindszenty, who became a symbol of church opposition to communism, was freed from prison by Hungarian revolutionaries during the 1956 uprising. After the revolt was crushed by Soviet tanks, Mindszenty took refuge in the U.S. diplomatic mission in Budapest, where he stayed until Hungary agreed to let him leave in 1971. Mindszenty died four years later in Vienna at the age of 83. Hungary's reform-minded leadership has agreed to review the Mindszenty trial, and he is expected to be cleared of all charges. Parliament, which has shed the rubber-stamp role it had held for decades under the former Communist leadership, enacted a law Jan. 24 that separates the church from the state and grants all denominations full autonomy. Separate legislation is planned on the return of confiscated church assets. Under pressure from the Communist government, the Hungarian Roman Catholic church agreed on Aug. 30, 1950, to surrender its autonomy. As in other Soviet bloc countries, a law was subsequently established that institutionalized state interference. The law was annulled Tuesday during a meeting between Premier Miklos Nemeth and Cardinal Laszlo Paskai, the Hungarian primate, removing the final hurdle to the restoration of diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEAD: Key Political Reforms Under Gorbachev
With Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Political reforms in the Soviet Union since Mikhail S. Gorbachev took power March 11, 1985: June 1987: First experimental contested local elections. June 1988: Party approves reform to shift power from party to government. October 1988: Constitutional amendments proposed for contested elections. March 1989: First contested elections for parliament result in defeats for dozens of Communist leaders. May 1989: First Congress of People's Deputies opens. July 1989: First parliamentary opposition group forms. December 1989: Lithuania approves multiparty system and votes to form independent Communist Party. February 1990: Central Commitee leaders agree to give up party's monopoly on power.

DOC.HEAD: Glance At Communist Party Central Committee
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A brief look at the Communist Party Central Committee:
DOC.HEAD: COMPOSITION: The Central Committee is made up of leading members of the 20-million member Soviet Communist Party. In most recent years, the Central Committee has been made up of about 300 members, but last year the number was reduced to 251. Two members have since died. Membership includes leading figures of the Soviet Communist Party from regional party organizations, the national government and party organizations, and other prominent figures from the military, arts and sciences.

POWERS: The Central Committee is the policy-making body of the party. It is charged with guiding the party's work between the larger party congresses that are held every five years. Most major policy issues are brought before the Central Committee for a policy directive. Between congresses, the Central Committee alone has the power to change the composition of the Politburo, which is responsible for running the country on a day-to-day basis. It also may change the party leader.

SELECTION: The Central Committee is chosen every five years by the Communist Party congress. Between congresses, members can be retired and non-voting members can be promoted to voting membership. The last congress was held four years ago. The next one is scheduled for fall.
Constitutional Amendment Gives Party its Power Base
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution, which makes the Communist Party the ``leading and guiding force of Soviet society,'' is the key to the party's exclusive hold on political power. It is part of the constitution adopted Oct. 7, 1977, by a special session of the Supreme Soviet under the leadership of the late Leonid I. Brezhnev. It has been interpreted as ruling out the creation of competing political parties. Article 6 says: ``The leading and guiding force of Soviet society and the nucleus of its political system, of all state organizations and public organizations, is the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. The C.P.S.U. exists for the people and serves the people. ``The Communist Party, armed with Marxism-Leninism, determines the general perspectives of the development of society and the course of the home and foreign policy of the U.S.S.R., directs the great constructive work of the Soviet people, and imparts a planned, systematic and theoretically substantiated character to their struggle for the victory of communism. ``All party organizations shall function within the framework of the Constitution of the U.S.S.R.''

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Communist Parties' Loss of Power
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In the space of eight months, the hallowed and powerful role of old-line Communist parties in East Europe has eroded steadily. Here is a chronology of how their power has waned: June 10, 1989 - Under pressure from reformers, the Hungarian Communist Party and opposition groups agree to negotiate a multiparty system. On Oct. 7, the Communist Party formally disbands, reconstitutes itself as the Hungarian Socialist Party and says it aspires to democratic ideals. Nov. 29 - The Czechoslovak Parliament deletes the leading role of the Communist Party from the constitution. Dec. 1 - The East German Parliament removes a constitutional provision guaranteeing the party's leading role. Dec. 29 - The Polish Parliament eliminates a clause in the constitution that gave a leading role to the Communist Party. Jan. 12, 1990 - Interim Romanian President Ion Iliescu declares that the the Communist Party is outlawed. The order is rescinded later, but most leading party officials are arrested and the party's power is broken. Jan. 15 - The Bulgarian Parliament votes to abolish the guaranteed leading role of the Communist Party. Wednesday - The Soviet Communist Party Central Committee decides to recommend an end to the constitutional provision that guarantees the party supremacy in political life.

DOC.HEAD: Colonel Accused of Genocide Commits Suicide Awaiting Trial
DOC.TEXT: Army Col. Petre Moraru, who was awaiting trial on charges of complicity in genocide, committed suicide in his Timisoara prison cell, state television reported Wednesday. Moraru was scheduled to testify in court next week regarding his alleged role in the desecration of corpses following the violence in Timisoara, the western Romanian city where the revolution began last December that eventually toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The newspaper Romania Libera reported corpses were removed from a hospital in Timisoara on Dec. 18 and cremated, in an alleged effort to eliminate evidence of atrocities committed against residents. Other members of the Ceausescu regime have testified during trials that the Communist dictator ordered the army to shoot demonstrators in Timisoara. Ceausescu was executed with his wife, Elena, on Dec. 25, by the provisional forces that took over Romania and ended his 24-year rule of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Citizens Wait for News Outside Kremlin
With AM-Soviet-Party Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Clusters of people stood outside the Kremlin in the cold Wednesday, some from far corners of this vast and diverse land, wondering what was being decided inside and hoping it would improve their lot. ``We hope there will be changes, but the leaders all seem lost and now they don't know how to find their way,'' said Georgy Bogdanov, a lathe operator from Magadan province, 7,500 miles away in the Soviet Far East. The groups of citizens, and the score foreign journalists waiting with them, shouted questions at all who entered Red Square through the Spassky Gate next to St. Basil's Cathedral. ``Are you from the plenum?'' the crowd would yell. Most were Kremlin office workers who probably knew no more than their questioners about how and what President Mikhail S. Gorabachev and the Central Committee were doing. ``I especially came here to see what was going on,'' said Igor Posnyok, a medical student from Vitebsk in Byelorussia, 250 miles west of Moscow. ``I heard about the big democracy demonstrations and wanted to find out for myself what is happening because I couldn't believe it,'' On Sunday, about 100,000 people marched 60 abreast to the Kremlin to demand that the Communist Party give up its power monopoly and accept other radical reforms. Early in the afternoon, participants in the meeting came out with the news that the Central Committee had approved Gorbachev's proposal to end the guarantee of Communist power and introduce a multiparty system. ``We must have competition of parties so a person can decide which one to vote for,'' said Dima Sukhanov, 17, of Moscow. Bogdanov, from the Far East, wondered what it all was worth. ``Things are getting worse,'' he said. ``Five years of perestroika and what of it?'' Oleg Trifolov, 41, from the Crimean Peninsula on the Black Sea, spoke in the same vein: ``We the simple people don't see perestroika, only chaos and disintegration.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Soldiers Kill Palestinian; Protest Follows
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers killed an 18-year-old Palestinian on Wednesday and hundreds of residents of his Gaza Strip hometown marched in protest. Arab reports said at least 13 Palestinians, including a 9-year-old boy, were wounded in other confrontations with soldiers in the occupied Gaza Strip. Ayman Khalil Zakout of Rafah was shot in the stomach and pronounced dead at the local U.N. clinic, doctors said. The army confirmed the death and said it was investigating the circumstances. Arab reports said hundreds of young Palestinians marched through Rafah, waving the outlawed green, white, red and black Palestinian flag and chanting nationalist slogans. They shouted ``Death is an honor for us!'' and ``We are ready to die to liberate Palestine!'' Zakout's death raised to 653 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the 26-month-old uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 181 have been killed by other Palestinians, most on suspicion of collaboration, and 43 Israelis have died. Other members of Zakout's family have been involved in the uprising. His 16-year-old brother, Balatt, was killed in a clash with soldiers eight months ago and his mother, Fatimah, was sentenced to 18 months in prison in August 1988 for belonging to an illegal Palestinian organization.

DOC.HEAD: Garry Shandling to Be Host of Music Awards Show
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Garry Shandling will be host of the 32nd annual Grammy Awards presentation this month, the Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences announced Wednesday. Shandling is best known as the slow-talking star of the comedy television series ``It's Garry Shandling's Show.'' The Grammys will be presented Feb. 21 during a live, three-hour CBS-TV broadcast from the Shrine Auditorium. The awards honor artistic and technical recording achievements in 77 categories. Shandling was a writer for television comedies before developing a stand-up routine of his own in the mid-1970s. He has also appeared on ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson'' _ for which he often served as a guest host _ and ``Late Night With David Letterman.''

DOC.HEAD: High School Seniors Not Versed in Geography, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: High school seniors have a ``disturbing gap'' in their knowledge of geography, with only 37 percent able to find Southeast Asia on a world map, a study said Wednesday. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos released the first study of geography education by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, which said that the average student could answer just 57 percent of the questions and that the best score among more than 3,000 students tested was 59 percent. ``The results show a disturbing gap in our knowledge of geography: many of our young people do not know as much about our world as they should know,'' said Cavazos. Geography education, as defined by the assessment, includes knowledge of the physical characteristics of the planet, such as its topography and climate, as well as the ways that people and their environment interact. More than 3,000 high school seniors from 300 public and private schools nationwide were asked 76 multiple-choice questions dealing with such topics as locations, environmental issues, climate and erosion. Among the survey results: _On a world map, 87 percent identified Canada; 85 percent recognized the Soviet Union; 84 percent identified countries in the Middle East; 72 percent identified petroleum-exporting countries, and 71 percent located Latin America. _Only 37 percent could find Southeast Asia and 37 percent incorrectly said that India is part of the region. Thirteen percent said that either Saudi Arabia or Brazil was in Southeast Asia. _Only 27 percent could use a map to identify a likely area of soil erosion. But three-fourths of the students were aware that the United States is a major exporter of grain. _Seventy-nine percent answered questions on the control of acid rain, 69 percent on pollution from pesticides. Less than two-thirds were familiar with the concepts of latitude and longitude. _Fifty percent knew that the Panama Canal cut the sailing time between New York and San Francisco because ships no longer had to sail around the tip of South America. ``Some of the results are encouraging, but most are disturbing and confirm what we already know: An unacceptably high percentage of American high school graduates have not learned geography,'' said Gilbert Grosvenor, president of the National Geographic Society, which helped finance the study. The results, said Gregory Anrig, president of the Educational Testing Service, which conducted the survey, show that the nation's youth cannot fully appreciate ``today's historic events in Eastern Europe or respond to challenges of the global `greenhouse effect.''' Geography is not a priority in most schools, the report said, pointing to a recent survey of the Council of Chief State School Officers that found only 18 percent of the states require geography for high school graduation. When it is taught, geography is often integrated into other courses, such as history, social studies and science, the report said. Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, said geography instruction at the elementary level should become an integral part of the social science curriculum. At the high-school level, he said, ``We should teach about the need to balance environmental concerns with those of business and industry.'' The National Assessment of Educational Progress, popularly known as the Nation's Report Card, is a congressionally mandated project of the National Center for Education Statistics in the Education Department. It is the only nationally representative and continuing assessment of what American students know and can do in various subject areas.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Gives Final Passage To `Excellence in Education Act'
DOC.TEXT: The Senate overwhelmingly approved on Wednesday legislation providing nearly $1.5 billion to upgrade education and help the United States cope in an increasingly competitive world economy. By a 92-8 vote, senators passed and sent to the House the Excellence in Education Act, initially submitted to Congress by President Bush last spring. Final passage came after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., was thwarted in attempts to strike from the bill a provision awarding $25 million in federal funds over three years to the recently established National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. Helms and some others argued that the private board _ with federal money _ would have too great a voice in setting teacher-qualification standards that ought to be determined at the state and local level. The bill was passed after lawmakers agreed to an amendment by Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., which said no decisions by the board could be imposed on private educational institutions or parents who teach their children at home. The board was created in 1987 at the urging of the National Governors' Association. It is an independent organization governed by a 64-member board of directors, including representatives of teachers' unions. Activities so far have been low-key. The proposal to authorize $25 million for the board was part of a wide-ranging education bill estimated to cost close to $1.5 billion over five years. It seeks to combat drugs in public schools, establish a presidential merit schools program and increase aid to schools seeking to reduce dropout rates. Besides Helms, senators voting against the bill, all Republicans, were William Armstrong of Colorado, Jake Garn of Utah, Phil Gramm of Texas; Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire; James McClure and Steve Symms of Idaho and Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Foreigners Attacked Israeli Tour Bus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 4 to clarify that bus was among several traveling in the region Sunday sted of being in a convoy. Picks up 5th, `Many Israelis...'
DOC.TEXT: A terrorist attack on a tour bus that killed nine Israelis and wounded 20 was plotted abroad and carried out by foreigners, the interior minister said Wednesday. Maj. Gen. Abdel-Halim Moussa, who is responsible for internal security, said his investigators had found clues ``that I hope will lead us to the full dimensions of the incident'' and those responsible. One of Egypt's most lucrative tourist markets is drying up because of the attack Sunday. Except for journalists, Israelis are staying away from Egypt, the only Arab country that has a peace treaty with the Jewish state. Two men armed with automatic weapons and hand grenades attacked the bus, which carried 31 Israeli tourists, 40 miles northeast of Cairo. The bus, one of several carrying travelers from various countries that was touring the region Sunday, was the only one filled with Israelis. Many Israelis have canceled visits to Egypt, and President Hosni Mubarak's government seems aware of the problem. Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid said Tuesday in Saudi Arabia he hoped the attack would not deter Israelis from coming to Egypt. In the Wednesday statement distributed by the official Middle East News Agency, Moussa said: ``It's certain ... that the perpetrators of this crime are non-Egyptians, and that the plotting was done abroad.'' He did not elaborate, but newspaper reports mention a Palestinian connection. The bus driver, who police sources said had worked for the bus company less than a month, and the man who rented the car used by the attackers were said to be Palestinians. Sources said most of about 100 suspects detained for questioning were Palestinians. The sources, who demanded anonymity, said those questioned included a Palestinian suspected of driving the car the attackers were in. In Cairo, security was increased at the main synogue and seaports. Airports remained on alert. About 100,000 Israelis visited Egypt last year, but since Sunday, ``Israeli tourists have canceled planned trips up to the end of the month,'' said Anwar Hilal, an owner of Safaga Tours, which organized Sunday's bus trip. A day after the assault, the only Israelis entering Egypt on the route the bus had taken were reporters and television crews, said Hilal's partner, Gamal Galal. The number of tourists arriving from the Israeli port of Eilat through Taba in southern Sinai also has dwindled, they said. The bus came via Rafah in northern Sinai. ``Most tourists coming from Eilat are non-Israeli, but even that has been affected,'' Hilal said. ``It's the general atmosphere.'' An Israeli tourist who identified himself only as Ilan, waiting to board a sightseeing bus in central Cairo, said he and a friend were the only Israelis to travel overland from Eilat to Egypt the day after the attack. ``Everyone told us not to go, but we mustn't connect this incident with the attitude of the Egyptian people,'' said Ilan, a resident of Eilat. ``We're staying on for another week.'' Only five other passengers, all from Europe, were on the bus Monday from Eilat. ``The buses from Eilat are usually at least half-full, mostly European _ British, Germans, Swedes,'' said Ruth Eisenstein, tour leader of the group. Ms. Eisenstein, a guide with Israel's Galilee Tours, which works with Safaga, said most people canceled after news of the attack spread. ``People in Eilat especially feel like each one of them has been attacked when something like this happens,'' she said. Eilat residents remember October 1985, when an Egyptian policeman in Ras Burka, Sinai, went berserk and fired into a group of Israeli tourists. Four children and three adults were killed. ``I tell them they must come and try Egypt, but they won't,'' Ms. Eisenstein said.

DOC.HEAD: Austria Agrees to Pay $25 Million to Holocaust Victims
DOC.TEXT: Austria, which for years insisted it was itself a victim of Nazi Germany, has agreed to pay about $25 million in reparations to Jewish survivors of the Holocaust, officials said Wednesday. Under a plan worked out by the government and the New York-based Jewish Claims Conference on Austria, the $25 million will be invested in projects aimed at helping Jewish survivors of death camps or those forced to flee the Nazi terror in Austria, the officials said. Some government officials said Austria's new willingness to pay reparations implicitly weakened its traditional argument that it was itself a victim of Nazi aggression. Some Austrian Jews indicated the change of heart was a result of the uproar over the 1986 election to the presidency of Kurt Waldheim, when the nation was forced to confront its past. Waldheim, secretary-general of the United Nations from 1972 to 1982, has denied that he was involved in war crimes when he served as a junior officer in the German army in Yugoslavia in World War II. Much of the $25 million will be invested in homes for the elderly in the United States, Israel and elsewhere catering to large numbers of expatriate Austrian Jews, although some of the amount will likely be spent in Austria, said Finance Ministry spokesman Dietmar Ecker. He said the money is to be distributed over the next five years _ about $4 million this year, $5 million in the three subsequent years, and $6 million in 1994. Austria already pays small pensions to individuals both at home and abroad deemed to be victims of the Nazis, and it agreed in 1988 to provide them an additional one-time payment of several hundred dollars. But this is the first time a large sum will be paid exclusively to Austrian Jews. Ecker would not directly comment on whether the move meant Austria was distancing itself from its historic contention that the country was the first victim of Nazi Germany, saying only ``this act should be seen as a signal.'' But other officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, agreed that the move weakens the traditional argument. Prominent Austrian Jews pointed out that although the Allies themselves considered Austria the first target of Nazi Germany, which absorbed its southern neighbor in 1938, the high level of Austrian support for the annexation was ignored for decades. Also ignored was the fact that membership in the Austrian Nazi party at the end of the war was higher on a percentual basis than in Germany. Many notorious Nazi figures, such as Adolf Eichmann, were Austrian, as was Adolf Hitler himself. ``Earlier governments took the point of view that Austria itself was a victim and they had no reason to offer reparations,'' Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal said in a telephone interview. ``The Waldheim thing left its mark, it forced the Austrians to deal with their own pasts,'' said Wiesenthal, a prominent Austrian Jew who lost family members during the Holocaust. Weisenthal praised Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, who took office in 1986, for repeatedly attempting to dispell the myth ``that Austrians were only victims and not aggressors as well.'' Paul Grosz, leader of Vienna's Jewish community, said Austria's willingess to compensate Holocaust victims is not merely a belated attempt to deal with bad publicity over the Waldheim affair. ``This is not reparation for Waldheim, it's reparation for Nazi crimes,'' he said. East Germany, which until now has refused to consider reparations, is now also reconsidering. The new leadership held talks with Israeli officials earlier this month on the possibility of such payments as a way of establishing diplomatic relations. The Austrian sum pales in comparison to the more than $40 billion dispensed by West Germany to Jews and Israel under a 1952 agreement. But Grosz said the Austrian payment, while it could not begin to compensate for the genocide wrought on Austrian Jews, seemed equitable, considering that those who are alive to benefit now number only about 40,000. Some 68,000 Austrian Jews died in Nazi concentration camps during World War II, and more that 120,000 others were incarcerated in camps or fled the country. In all, the Nazis exterminated about 6 million Jews.

DOC.HEAD: Controversy Stirred by U.S. Aircraft Flying over Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency planes flying reconaissance, reportedly to provide security for an antidrug summit, are creating nationalistic furor one week before President Bush is scheduled to arrive. ``I ask myself why the gringos don't also let us send a Colombian air squadron to detect the cocaine distributors that provide the substance to 30 million drug consumers in the United States,'' said Alberto Santofimio, a presidential candidate and Liberal Party senator. ``This would be the only way for Colombians to know how many more mayors, in addition to Washington's, are possessed by the drug devil,'' said Santofimio in Tuesday speech that was published Wednesday in the newspaper La Prensa. He was referring to the U.S. capital's mayor, Marion Barry, arrested last month on a cocaine possession charge. The Colombian Civil Air Authority authorized flights this month of two Aerocommander aircraft belonging to the DEA. U.S. planes have been allowed to fly over the country for years to obtain information about cocaine labs and other drug operations. Colombia's attorney general, Alfonso Gomez, said earlier this week that he ordered an investigation to determine if civil aviation officials exceeded their authority by granting the planes permission to fly over the country. But the announcement has done little to soften the rhetoric of Santofimio and other politicians, angered by persistent press commentaries that the U.S. planes were violating the country's sovereignty. Santofimio is one of several Colombian congressmen whose U.S. visas were canceled last year. U.S. authorities gave no reason for their decision, but unconfirmed reports held that the Colombian officials had been linked to drug traffickers. U.S. Ambassador Thomas McNamara said any U.S. aircraft flying over Colombia are doing so with permission of the country's government. ``The people who are violating airspace are the drug traffickers flying cocaine into the United States,'' McNamara told reporters at a Tuesday briefing for the Colombian press. A transcript was obtained Wednesday. Colombian traffickers are responsible for processing and smuggling 80 percent of the cocaine sold on U.S. streets, according to U.S. officials. The Colombian news media have reported that the DEA planes are using sophisticated observation equipment to detect missiles or other weapons that might be used by drug traffickers to try to kill Bush during his visit. U.S. officials in Bogota have refused to comment on DEA operations. Last month reports surfaced in Washington that the Medellin cocaine cartel had obtained surface-to-air missiles to try to shoot down Bush's plane when it arrives on Feb. 15 for the antidrug summit. The Medellin cartel in phone calls to local media denied having any missiles. The controversy over the aircraft comes less than a month after the Bush administration recalled a U.S. fleet planning drug interdiction operations off Colombia's Caribbean coast. Bush apparently did not consult with Colombian President Virgilio Barco until reports of the fleet's movement toward the Caribbean surfaced in the news media. Bush is to meet with Barco and the presidents of Peru and Bolivia at the antidrug summit in the port of Cartagena, intended to ratify a plan for greater cooperation. Peru and Bolivia are the biggest producers of the coca leaf used by Colombian traffickers to process the drug. The United States is the world's largest consumer of cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Longtime Communist Ally Says It Will Join Opposition
DOC.TEXT: The Agrarian Party, for decades a powerless partner of the Communists, announced Wednesday that it will join the opposition. The move was another blow to Communist attempts to woo non-Communist parties into a government coalition pending free elections in May. The opposition has generally rejected such an arrangement, saying it would have little influence. Agrarian Party leader Angel Dimitrov suggested a union between his group and the Agrarian Party Nikola Patkov, an organization that has opposed the Communists since its creation several months ago. In a related development, the head of a group of Communist Party reformers predicted that the party will split along ideological lines Feb. 11, when liberal Communists will vote on whether to form their own party. Nikolai Vassilev, a leader of the Alternative Social Alliance, said he expects two-thirds of the delegates will vote at a special congress to leave the Communist Party and create a social democratic party. It is not known how many of the country's 980,000 Communist Party members support the alliance. Bulgaria's first free elections since World War II are planned for May and the Communist Party has been meeting with opposition groups to carry out some reforms in preparation for the balloting. At talks held Wednesday, the Union of Democratic Forces _ an umbrella group representing opposition groups _ proposed that parliament be presented with a constitutional amendment that would bar Communist Party organizations at work places. The state news agency BTA said the opposition charged that the Communist Party's ``wish to preserve its structures until elections gives it advantages, despite renunciation of constitutional guarantees about its leading role.'' The opposition plan also would ban any other political party from forming organizations at work places, BTA reported. The Communists said the issue of the party's role in the economy would be regulated in a law on political parties now being drafted and likely to be submitted to parliament in March, BTA reported. It gave no further details. Compared with their East bloc neighbors, Bulgarian Communists have given up relatively little power. Talks between the party and the opposition are to resume Feb. 12, BTA said.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Choice Bills Aimed at Men, Sponsor Says
DOC.TEXT: A legislator said she hopes the state Senate quickly kills three bills she introduced Wednesday calling for sterilization of child-support scofflaws and requiring counseling and spousal consent for vasectomies. Sen. Charlotte Pritt, a pro-choice advocate, said she thinks her bills are as worthless as those requiring that women undergo counseling and receive consent from their mates before having abortions. Pritt said she introduced the bills at the request of a constituent who was interested in encouraging lawmakers to think about repercussions of abortion-curbing legislation. ``I hope that none of this legislation is passed,'' she said. ``It is all repressive. If someone feels strongly about something, it's a legislator's courtesy to offer legislation to be introduced. The person may not agree with it, but will introduce it for the sake of dialogue.'' The bill was referred to the Senate Health and Human Resources Committee, where Committee Chairman Bob Holliday said he intends to let it die without having a vote on it. ``These are companion pieces to anti-choice legislation that affects women,'' Pritt said. ``I was asked to put in legislation that would be comparable but make men responsible for their actions.'' Pritt's legislation calls for a court to issue a contempt citation before ordering a person to be involuntarily sterilized for falling a year behind in support payments. Pritt also introduced a bill that calls for a physician to counsel the spouse regarding the performance of a vasectomy in cases in which he is counseling the wife about the performance of a tubal ligation. Her third bill would require a spouse's written consent before a man could obtain a vasectomy. ``Notice is not required if the performance of the vasectomy is necessary to save the man's life,'' the bill said. Several of the anti-abortion measures targeted by Pritt's package have been introduced by state Sen. Mark Manchin. ``My reaction is that I hope we wouldn't get caught up introducing frivolous companion legislation in order to make the other side look somehow unimportant,'' Manchin said. ``If these are sincere bills, with sincere intentions, fine. But if they are introduced solely to make other bills dealing with the same subject matter look frivolous or unimportant, I think the approach she's taking is wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Group Holding Dutch, Belgian Doctors, Agency Says
With AM-Sudan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A French aid agency reported Wednesday that two European doctors kidnapped over the weekend in southern Sudan are being held by the rebel Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army. Martin Ruppert, a 28-year-old from the Netherlands, and Christine Van Haegenoth, a 26-year-old Belgian, are in ``good health,'' said a statement from the Paris-based Medecins Sans Frontieres. It was the first identification of the assailants who took the two physicians Friday night from their home in Malakal, a garrison city on the Nile 370 miles south of the capital Khartoum. Medecins Sans Frontieres, or Doctors Without Borders, said talks are under way with the rebels to free the two doctors, who work for the non-governmental organization's Belgian branch. A spokeswoman for the group in Brussels, Inneke Van Velzen, said Monday that the doctors may have been kidnapped by the rebels to treat their casualties from the civil war. The rebels led by John Garang, a renegade colonel, have been fighting the Moslem-dominated government since 1983 for increased economic and political autonomy for the predominantly Christian and animist southern half of the country. Ruppert and Haegenoth were working on a long-term medical nutritional program to help the people of Malakal and the surrounding desert. The French section of Medecins Sans Frontieres recently withdrew its workers from Sudan after unidentified attackers shot down a plane carrying two of its doctors, a French pilot and a Sudanese working for the United Nations. The Belgian section has pulled out three workers since the abduction, Van Velzen said.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Expected to Approve Loan to China
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank will vote Thursday on a $30 million earthquake relief loan to China, its first loan since the Communist government suppressed a democracy movement in June. Bank President Barber B. Conable will present the loan to a closed-door meeting of representatives of the 151 governments that own the bank, said spokesman Peter Riddleberger. A series of earthquakes hit northern China in October, killing at least 29 people and destroying 5,000 to 8,000 houses. The World Bank is the biggest source of aid to Third World countries, lending more than $21 billion a year. Riddleberger said no other loan to China would come up at this session. Soon after government tanks rolled into Beijing's Tiananmen Square, Conable decided to hold back $780 million in loans to China that had been due for approval. Later, President Bush said he was asking the bank not to make the loans. Conable has said the bank considers only economic conditions when it grants loans. In June, he withdrew the bank's permanent representatives in Beijing but they returned within a few weeks. He said then that he hoped to resume lending to China soon. The United States is the biggest shareholder in the bank, but does not have a veto power over loans. China and India have been the biggest borrowers. The loan that goes before the board Thursday would be repayable in 40 years with only nominal interest. The United States is expected to be represented by its board member, E. Patrick Coady. A spokesman at the U.S. Treasury, which is responsible for relations with the bank, declined to say how Coady would vote. The U.S. government's own Export-Import Bank last week made an unannounced loan of $9.75 million to the China National Offshore Oil Corp. and was expected to announce another larger loan Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Urge Feds To Clean Up Their Own Yard
DOC.TEXT: The nation's governors pressed Congress and President Bush on Wednesday to speed the pollution cleanup of military bases, weapons plants and other federal lands, saying U.S. environmental laws ``are routinely ignored'' in cases where the states are hamstrung from enforcement. ``If you make a mess you clean it up. We're saying that goes for the federal government as well as private citizens,'' Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus told a Capitol news conference in behalf of the National Governors Association. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, acknowledged there is a ``compelling'' need to give states clearer authority to assess fees and penalties against federal government facilities where pollution laws are violated. ``In Congress we establish national environmental policy. Surely one of the goals of that policy is to assure that facilities owned by the federal government avoid contamination of our environment,'' said Mitchell. Andrus, co-chairman of the task force that developed the governors' report, said that while Bush has ``recognized the problem'' he has proposed too little money for the federal cleanup effort and has allowed the Environmental Protection Agency to remain ``hamstrung'' from taking enforcement actions against federal polluters. The governors' report said the extent of pollution on federal property, ranging from military bases, to weapons plants run by the Energy Department, to vast lands controlled by the Interior Department, is so broad that its full scope remains undefined. Various government estimates on the cost of cleaning up the nuclear weapons plants alone have ranged upwards of $100 billion. The governors called for an expanded program that would finish the task over the next 30 years. Meantime, the governors said, the Environmental Protection Agency should be set free to pursue federal as well as private polluters through civil lawsuits and enforcement actions. The agency's ``enforcement powers have been crippled'' by the Justice Department which has prohibited the EPA from filing lawsuits or taking unilateral enforcement actions against other federal agencies, said the report. ``The nation's chief environmental watchdog is forced to sit by as basic environmental statutes and regulations are routinely ignored at federally owned facilities,'' the report continued. Furthermore, the governors complained, state authorities often have been thwarted in monitoring and taking action against violators of environmental laws on federal property ``by claims of national security and sovereign immunity.'' Andrus, who was Interior Secretary under President Carter, suggested that Bush could resolve the problems between the EPA and Justice Department ``with one phone call.'' Andrus said that the proposed $4.5 billion allocated for various environmental cleanup efforts on federal facilities under Bush's fiscal 1991 budget ``is inadequate to do the job.'' He said less than half is devoted to actual cleanup activities. The Environmental Protection Agency lists 1,268 federal facilities earmarked for priority cleanup efforts and that number is expected to expand. For many years, federal facilities ``have been among the worst violators'' of federal pollution laws with neither the EPA nor state agencies able to hold facility managers accountable, the governors complained. The report added that in addition to the highly publicized violations of environmental laws at atomic weapons plants, fuels, oil solvents, paints, acids, heavy metals and other hazardous chemicals ``have been routinely stored and improperly disposed of'' by federal officials over the years.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Gets Names of Parents Owing Child Support
DOC.TEXT: The names of 2.6 million parents who owe child support have been given to the Internal Revenue Service so that any federal income tax refunds they are due can be used to pay their obligations, officials said. Last year, nearly $452 million was collected by garnishing federal income tax refunds under the program. Parents subject to garnishing are those who owe $500 or more in child support, or who owe at least $150 in child support and have children receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children assistance. The program is considered a cost-effective way to make sure children are getting the support they are due, said Eunice Thomas, acting director of the Office of Child Support Enforcement in the Department of Health and Human Services. Under the program, it costs an average of $4.54 per case to collect an average of $654 for non-AFDC cases and an average of $562 for AFDC cases, she said. The program, enacted by Congress, was begun in 1981 for AFDC families and expanded in 1984 to other families.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Says Greeks Attack TV Crew; Greece Denies It
DOC.TEXT: Turkey said Greek Christians attacked a Turkish state television crew Wednesday in an ethnically restive area of northwestern Greece. The Greek government denied it. A Foreign Ministry statement said Greeks attacked the crew in Komotini, near the Turkish border, where it was covering a bail hearing for Ahmet Sadik and Ibrahim Sherif, prominent members of the Moslem ethnic Turkish community. Sadik and Sherif were sentenced Jan. 25 to 18 months in prison each for describing their minority as ``Turkish Moslem'' in election campaign fliers last year. Greece recognizes only the religious identity of its 120,000 ethnic Turks and banned reference to their ethnicity in 1987. On Wednesday, a Komotini court refused to release the two ethnic Turks on bail while their appeal is pending. The Foreign Ministry claimed a West German television team and a West German lawyer representing Sadik and Sherif also were handled roughly. ``It is cause for anxiety that these ugly attacks took place in front of the Greek prosecutor and policemen,'' it said. ``Greek authorities have thus shown that they completely disregard international rules and principles applying to news media freedoms.'' Greece's Public Order Ministry said police protected the Turkish television crew throughout the three days in Komotini ``despite the fact that neither events nor conditions prevailing these days warranted any fears.'' ``Under these circumstances, the claims of the Turkish Foreign Ministry can only provoke regret at the distortion of the truth,'' the ministry said. Three days after Sadik and Sherif were sentenced, Christians in Komotini attacked Moslems who protested protested the verdict. Seventeen Christians and four Moslems were slightly injured and windows were broken in scores of shops belonging to Moslems. Greece ordered the Turkish consul in Komotini out of the country, accusing him of making inflammatory statements, and Turkey expelled the Greek consul in Istanbul in retaliation.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Suit to Allow Union to Advertise on MARTA
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday ruled that Atlanta's transit authority does not have to accept ads featuring the Rev. Jesse Jackson urging janitors to vote for union representation. U.S. District Judge Charles Moye ruled that the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority did not act arbitrarily. MARTA contended the ads were political and thus banned by its ad policy. The local chapter of the Service Employees International Union sued Feb. 3, claiming the ban violated freedom of speech. The union is seeking to win a representation election Feb. 16 and 17 which will involve about 800 Atlanta-area janitors. Moye said MARTA reasonably could be concerned about possible disturbances on buses because of what he termed the political aspect of getting people to vote for a union. Linda Riggins, president of the local, said union lawyers were preparing to appeal. The organizational drive is part of a 2-year-old campaign to organize janitors in big downtown office buildings, most of whom make about $3.75 and hour and receive few benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Admiral Kelso Lands Top Navy Job
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate Admiral Frank B. Kelso II to be the new Chief of Naval Operations, the White House announced here Wednesday. Kelso, now commander in chief of the U.S. Atlantic Command and supreme Allied Commander for the Atlantic, would succeed Admiral Carlisle A.H. Trost, whose term expires June 30. Kelso, 56, is a former commander of the U.S. Atlantic fleet and the Sixth Fleet. The Fayetteville, Tenn., native is a 1956 Naval Academy graduate.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Weather in West, Warmth in East
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell over much of the West on Wednesday, with up to a foot accumulating in Utah, while some cities in the eastern half of the nation _ including International Falls, Minn. _ hit record highs. Winter storm warnings were posted over the northern Oregon coast and northern Utah. At midday, rain and snow extended over western sections of Oregon and Washington, and the northwestern corner of California, and snow also fell from central Nevada across the northwestern third of Utah and Wyoming. Overnight snowfalls across Utah included 7 to 8 inches over the Cache Valley, 6 inches at Brigham City, 5 inches at Ogden, 8 inches at Heber, and 6 to 12 inches across the Wasatch mountains. Four to 8 inches of snow fell overnight across the mountains of northern and northwest Wyoming. Elsewhere, rain was scattered over the coast of Virginia. Temperatures hit record highs Thursday at Baltimore, with 57, Neguanee, Mich., with 42, and Philadelphia with 59. International Falls, Minn., which often has the official low for the Lower 48 states, tied its record of 43 and Williamsport, Pa., tied its record of 49 In the West, however, Redding, Calif., in the northern end of the state, cooled to a record low of 25. Much farther north, Anchorage, Alaska, hit a record low for the date of 23 degrees below zero. But interior Alaska got slight relief from a 14-day serious cold wave Tuesday, with some afternoon temperatures along the Alaska Highway climbing above 30 degrees below zero. Morning temperatures included 42 below zero at Fairbanks, 48 below zero at Nenana, and 54 below zero at Bettles. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 18 below zero at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 12 degrees at Yellowstone National Park to 84 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Adviser Expresses Reservations About Project
DOC.TEXT: White House science adviser D. Allan Bromley said Wednesday that construction work on the superconducting super collider should be delayed until industry proves it can manufacture the specialized magnets required by the massive atom smasher. Bromley, director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy in the White House, told members of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology that part of the $318 million requested for the supercollider in fiscal 1991 will be spent proving that such magnets can be built. ``It is prudence not to move forward until such time that we have demonstrated that we can make the magnets industrially,'' Bromley said during sharp questioning from members of the house committee. He said $300 million is to be used in 1991 for site preparation at the supercollider site near Waxahachie, Texas, about 30 miles south of Dallas. The science adviser said that work will be delayed until it is proven that the magnets can be built. Bromley said the supercollider will require 10,000 magnets made of superconducting material. So far, he said, it has not been proven that industry is capable of making such magnets in such large numbers. ``We're pushing technology to the absolute limit,'' he said. ``It will require tons of superconducting material.'' Bromley said a demonstration of magnet manufacturing is expected to be completed within a year and said no major site preparation for the project can begin until then. The superconducting super collider is an underground, 53-mile circular raceway that scientists will use to smash subatomic particles together at very high velocities. The particles will be compressed and accelerated by the powerful magnets placed along the circular tunnel. By smashing the subatomic particles, scientists hope to answer fundamental questions about the nature and origin of matter, a basic goal in physics. Bromley was sharply questioned by several congressmen who expressed concern about the rising price tag of the super collider. The device _ to be the world's largest research tool _ was first said to cost about $5 billion, but the projected cost has crept upward. Rep. Sherwood L. Boehlert, R-N.Y., said the Department of Energy, which is in charge of the project, has estimated the price of the collider now at more than $7 billion and the final cost may be even higher. ``Is there a point at which the SSC becomes simply too expensive to build?'' Boehlert asked. ``The simple answer to that is yes,'' said Bromley, but he did not put an upper limit on the cost. In a reference to an expensive toilet facility once built for an Air Force airplane, Boehlert said the rising cost of the super collider ``makes a $600 toilet seat look like a bargain.'' ``Let me approach this from the other end,'' Bromley injected. When the packed hearing room echoed with laughter, the science adviser ducked his head and noted, ``that was a singularly unfortunate expression.'' ``Well, we'll just flush that out,'' said Boehlert, triggering another burst of laughter. Browley said that the price of the super collider has gone up because experts have examined the original design and found ``shortcomings.'' ``The magnets are not perfect,'' he said. ``You run into trouble if the particles run too slowly. The consensus (of the experts) is that you must increase the speed of the particles as they enter the ring.'' To accomplish this, he said the design of the magnets and the aperture, where the particles are injected, must be changed. This raises the cost, Bromley said.

DOC.HEAD: Byrd Endorses Redistributing U.S. Foreign Aid
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., on Wednesday endorsed the idea of restributing foreign aid, praising a Republican proposal to trim aid from some big-ticket countries and give it to others. ``Everything is on the table,'' said Byrd, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee. Byrd also said the ``peace dividend'' _ money from cuts in defense _ will not increase the foreign aid pie. ``Our foreign aid budget has taken on a new and suddenly enhanced importance as an instrument of our goals and policies in the world,'' said Byrd, remarking on the need to influence changing event in Eastern Europe. ``It no longer can be viewed as a kind of well-heeled junior varsity lobbyist sport,'' he said of foreign aid. In a statement on the Senate floor, Byrd praised Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kan., for proposing to re-allocate foreign aid by cutting back on the amount of money traditionally given to five allies: Israel, Egypt, Turkey, the Philippines and Pakistan. They take up about 80 percent of the U.S. aid budget. ``Mr. Dole has done this body a service, and raised the issues publicly, taken criticism from all sides, sat out on the edge, so to speak, with his legs dangling over the side,'' Byrd said. Dole first suggested in an article in The New York Times that five countries absorb aid reductions of 5 percent, with the remainder redirected to Eastern Europe. Dole's proposal _ particularly his suggestion that aid to Israel be reduced _ drew immediate fire from a number of Repubublican and Democratic senators. Israel, the largest U.S. aid recipient, receives about $3 billion a year. But Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate appropriations subcommittee that divides up foreign aid, welcomed the debate. While not naming individual countries, Byrd said some of ``our historic aid recipients can probably take cuts substantially larger than 5 percent _ somewhere between 10 percent and 20 percent would be more realistic,'' he said. But Byrd disagreed with Dole on the practice of congressional ``earmarking'' _ setting aside certain amounts for various countries. Dole argued the practice limits the president's flexibility; Byrd said the practice is a congressional perogative. The Bush administration has proposed an aid package of about $14.8 billion for fiscal 1991, slightly more than the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Announces Legislative Agenda for `Choice' but No Abortion Mention
DOC.TEXT: House Republican leaders Wednesday unveiled a legislative agenda described as giving Americans ``the right to make the choice'' about their lives. It makes no mention of the most controversial ``choice'' issue: abortion. The national Republican Party has taken a strong anti-abortion stand, and conservative GOP House members said that wasn't affected by the legislative-goals list. House Minority Leader Robert Michel of Illinois, leadoff speaker among GOP lawmakers describing the list to reporters, said it had no overriding theme. He called it ``pretty much boilerplate Republican dogma.'' But Rep. Mickey Edwards, a key architect of the document, said, ``If there is a theme _ and we didn't approach it from that area _ it's a theme of empowerment, a theme of giving people the right to make the choice that is going to affect their life.'' Rep. Duncan Hunter said the legislative-agenda document referred to ``choice in education _ using choice in the sense of exercising freedom rather than choice in abortion, where you limit the freedom to live of one party. I think you see that common thread throughout the document.'' ``I think it very strongly reinforces the traditional Republican concept that freedom is important and that empowering people to make their own lives better, by giving them freedoms rather than restricting them by imposing governmental programs on them,'' the California Republican said. Rep. Vin Weber of Minnesota said that for purposes of dealing with the abortion, the House Republican leaders draw a distinction between themselves and the GOP hierarchy, choosing to let the Republican National Committee confront the issue. ``There was never a House Republican agenda that came forward that included the right to life,'' he said. ``It's been part of our (national party) platform.'' ``We basically leave it at that level within the party,'' Weber said, ``and to the vast majority of right-to-life leaders, that's an appropriate position for our party to take.'' Said House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia: ``My judgment is ... the Republican Party will be the party which wants to have the fewest possible number of abortions. The Democratic Party will be the party which has a very large wing which is capriciously unconcerned about when abortions occur.'' But Gingrich also said that ``the Republicans have to accept that some of our colleagues are going to disagree on an issue which is profoundly emotional and profoundly important, and we're just going to have to live within that framework.'' Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater told GOP leaders last month the party welcomes pro-choice candidates despite its anti-abortion stance. And he described internal debate over abortion as part of the ``growing pains'' of becoming a majority party.''

DOC.HEAD: Modrow Says Neighbors Must Agree to German Unity
With AM-Baker Trip, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East German Premier Hans Modrow said Tuesday that German unification could come about only with the agreement of neighboring states. He spoke at a 10-minute briefing following talks with Czechoslovak Premier Marian Calfa. He declined to take questions. Modrow said German unification was discussed at the talks, but that they centered on changing and improving economic ties between the two states, closely linked when they were ruled by hard-line Communist governments. Last fall, peaceful revolutions toppled the hard-line governments in East Berlin and Prague. Modrow said he and Calfa agreed ``that all processes on our continent, including that of unification of both German states, should only be completed in a process which respects and preserves the interests of neighbors and European states.'' The East German premier last Thursday introduced a plan for unifying Germany, envisaging it as a neutral state eventually governed from Berlin. Modrow made no other reference to reunification and the subject was not mentioned in a similarly brief statement from Calfa. Calfa said the two sides established working groups to discuss investment, prices and tourism. Under new leadership headed by President Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia has sought to improve ties with East Germany and West Germany. German unification is a sensitive issue in Czechoslovakia, which was occupied by Nazi Germany during World War II. Modrow spoke during a visit to Prague by U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III.

DOC.HEAD: Silicon Pioneer Dies at 80
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits to fix coding.
DOC.TEXT: Chemist Arthur J. Barry, a pioneer of the silicon industry, has died. He was 80. Barry, who had battled bone cancer for several years, died Saturday of heart failure, doctors said. Barry moved to Tucson in 1973 after a 30-year career in chemical research with the Dow Corning Corp. of Michigan. He was director of chemical research for Dow from 1957 to 1971, when he retired. At the University of Arizona, he was an adjunct professor of chemistry who in 1986 won the Distinguished Citizen Award for service to the school. During his years with Dow, he was one of seven scientists credited with the development of silicon products, now the foundation of the computer and electronics industry. Barry, who specialized in the use of silicon for waterproofing, registered 66 patents related to this industry. Besides his wife, Marjorie, he is survived by two daughters, a son, and five grandchildren. Services were scheduled for Thursday at First United Methodist Church.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Trip To Colombia Not `Macho' Exercise
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday defended anew his decision to attend next week's drug summit in Colombia and insisted he won't do anything ``stupid or macho.'' ``It isn't whimsical or a desire to be in harm's way,'' said Bush. He said he was sure the summit will be secure at the site at a well-fortified installation cut off from the Colombian mainland except for one entrance. ``I'm not going to do something stupid or macho,'' Bush told the Commonwealth Club. He added, laughing, that he loves the switch in his image. ``This guy they used to call timid is now macho man,'' he said. Bush will fly to Colombia and spend several hours at the summit in Cartagena on Feb. 15 with Colombian President Virgilio Barco and officials of Bolivia and Peru. He said it was important that he do nothing that might even ``inadvertantly'' signal to Barco that he should cut a deal with his country's drug cartels. ``I think we've got good arrangements and I think it is good, sound anti-narcotics policy to support President Barco, who is doing an awful lot to protect our kids from the scourge of narcotics,'' he said. Bush also drew applause from the crowd of more than 2,500 when he said, ``We've condoned things in this country that we should have condemned long ago in terms of narcotics.'' Among those joining in the applause was former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, seated at Bush's right. Shultz created a stir last fall when he called for legalizing illicit drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Medicaid to Get Own Office
DOC.TEXT: In one of her first actions as head of the Health Care Financing Administration, Gail Wilensky is proposing to centralize the federal operations of Medicaid in their own office, sources said Tuesday. Wilensky's plan is designed to help make Medicaid more responsive to the states, which share the cost of the program providing health care for the poor. The federal share of the program is about $40 billion a year. Creating a Medicaid bureau within the Health Care Financing Administration ``would change the environment within HCFA to permit Medicaid to get its share of attention,'' said a source close to Wilensky, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``The point of doing this is to make HCFA more responsive to the states and to encourage them to find more innovative ways of dealing with health care access.'' Medicaid operations currently are handled in several different offices in Wilensky's domain. Under her these would be centralized into a single bureau that would report to her. No staff would be cut. Wilensky, who took office on Monday, has presented her plan to her boss, Louis Sullivan, secretary of Health and Human Services. The federal Medicaid bureaucracy coordinates the operations of 56 different Medicaid programs run by the states, the District of Columbia and U.S. territories.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Heralds Star Wars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Bush comments on Soviet Central Committee actions, question and answer session, decoy motorcade used to confuse demonstrators. Edits to tighten. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday that Star Wars ``makes more sense than ever'' in light of recent changes in the Soviet Union and Estern Europe. Bush's comments came after he toured the nation's biggest nuclear weapons research lab, then told a group of business leaders he wanted to refrain from reacting to the Soviet Central Committee's apparent endorsement of Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political reforms. ``There's an awful lot to be hopeful for there,'' Bush said. But, he added, the ``last thing'' he wanted to do ``when you have the Central Committee meeting is to try to fine-tune it from San Francsico or Washington as to how they ought to conduct themselves.'' At a question-and-answer session at San Francisco's Commonwealth Club, Bush was asked how the United States could help Gorbachev achieve his reforms. ``I think we can avoid doing dumb things,'' Bush said. He told the business-community audience that the United States should continue to modernize its strategic weapons programs and the Strategic Defense Initiative. ``This purely defensive concept doesn't threaten a single person anywhere in the world. God forbid, if it ever had to be used, it would be used against missiles, not against people,'' Bush said after touring the nearby Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, where the bulk of Star Wars research occurs. ``In the 1990s, strategic defense makes much more sense than ever before,'' said Bush, who has proposed spending $4.5 billion on the space-based anti-missile system in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. ``I would rather be called cautious than reckless,'' Bush said about his defense policy. The president is on a three-day trip to focus attention on his proposed $292 billion Pentagon budget for fiscal 1991, which Democrats say gives too much to strategic weapons systems while closing bases. He tempered his proposal for wholesale closing of U.S. military bases with a vow for federal aid to help the communities and individuals affected. Civilians laid off will get top priority for other Defense Department jobs and the administration will help communities that lose bases ``develop powerful new economic assets, new ways to use old bases.'' Speaking in a heavily Democratic area where five military installations would be closed, Bush said: ``There have been no politics in these proposals.'' He was applauded when he said: ``Long-standing critics of defense spending should not turn around and block the closing of a base in their home districts.'' In a wide-ranging, half-hour question and answer session after his speech, Bush: _Called proposals for a reunified Germany that would be a member of NATO ``encouraging.'' The White House also announced that Bush had invited NATO General Secretary Manfred Woerner to Camp David this weekend to discuss the re-unification issue. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl will meet separately with Bush later this mounth. _Said he didn't think going to Colombia on Feb. 15 for a drug summit would be dangerous. ``I'm not going to do something stupid or macho.'' _Said the Soviet Union could help do more to bring about peace in the Middle East, including normalizing diplomatic relations with Israel. Several hundred protesters waged a noisy demonstration outside the San Francisco hotel where Bush spoke, many carrying signs protesting U.S. policy in Latin America and AIDS policy. The Secret Service sent a decoy presidential limousine and modified motorcade down Ellis Street to confuse the demonstrators, then hastily drove the president off in the opposite direction for the airport. Bush also was met by demonstrators as he toured the Lawrence Livermore lab and at a GOP fund-raising dinner Tuesday night. The president said he welcomed recent pro-democracy developments in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, but that ``we must not let impatience, born out of euphoria, jeopardize all we hope to achieve.'' `We must remain in Europe as long as we are needed and wanted. ... Let us not forget that ... the Soviets still have more than 10,000 (nuclear) strategic weapons. They are modernizing them. They have deployed two new mobile ICBMs, and their spending on strategic defense is comparable to their spending on strategic offensive forces.'' Bush was briefed on latest Star Wars technology during his tour of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, which is part of the University of California but is under an extensive long-term government contract to do nuclear-weapons research. ``If the technology I've seen today proves feasible, and I'm told it looks very promising, no war planner could be confident of the consequences of a ballistic missile attack. The technologies you are now researching, developing and testing will strengthen deterrence,'' Bush said. SDI has been controversial since President Reagan proposed it in 1983 as an impregnable shield capable of blocking incoming nuclear missiles. Congress cut $1 billion this year from Bush's request for a $4.8 billion Star Wars budget; Bush last week asked for a $1 billion increase for fiscal 1991. The president called the latest Star Wars concept, dubbed brillant pebbles, ``the most promising'' of all SDI programs. Thousands of the interceptors would be orbited in clusters on space stations, firing automatically at any intruding missiles and ramming them like shot gun pellets. Bush's next stop on his three-day tour of defense installations and Republican fund-raising events was to be Omaha, Neb., where he will tour the underground headquarters of the Strategic Air Command on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Forms Panel to Pursue Reunification
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 grafs after 2nd graf `Chief government...' to UPDATE with Kohl aide on chancellor's planned comment to Gorbachev. Pickup 3rd graf `Rudolf Seiters...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Honecker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A committee led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Wednesday began laying the groundwork for German unification after the Cabinet agreed to seek immediate talks with East Germany on joining the two countries' currencies. Chief government spokesman Hans Klein said Kohl would travel to Camp David on Feb. 24 to discuss German unity with President Bush. Government sources also said Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher will travel to Moscow on Saturday for talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Kohl advisor Horst Teltschik, speaking on West German television said the chancellor's message to Gorbachev will be ``to make clear that the (German) self-determination is advancing because the people in East Germany are deciding the process and the speed of self-determination, and no one else.''
