Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze suggested last week that that the issue be put to an international referendum. Rudolf Seiters, Kohl's chief of staff, said the ``German unity'' committee began its work immediately after its formation Wednesday. The panel will examine all the steps necessary for unification, including creation of a monetary union to make the West German mark East Germany's currency. Unlike West German marks, East German marks are not convertible. The West German central bank would be responsible for monetary policy of both states under the monetary union. According to Seiters, West Germany plans to discuss ``confederative cooperation'' with East Germany immediately after East Germany's first free elections, which are set for March 18. Seiters said immediate talks on monetary union are necessary because of the dramatic speed of developments in East Germany and the continuing exodus of East Germans to West Germany. Kohl on Tuesday proposed urgent talks on uniting the nations' currencies. With an average of 1,800 East Germans leaving the country daily, 66,000 have arrived in West Germany since the start of the year, adding to more than 340,000 who resettled across the border in 1989. The departure of skilled workers, along with strikes and absenteeism, are driving East Germany's economy to the brink of collapse, and the influx into West Germany is straining the country's social services. Klein told reporters in Bonn the government would start talks with the new East German government immediately after the March 18 elections ``on confederate cooperation between the two states in Germany with a view to their growing together further.'' ``Decisions will be required even before then,'' Klein added. ``The question of German unity has become a dominant theme. All political forces (in East Germany) are now committed to this objective.'' Klein said the special committee set up to study unification questions includes Cabinet ministers responsible for the following areas: Foreign Affairs, Interior, Justice, Finance, Economics, Education and Labor. He said the committee would work on formation of a monetary union, financial questions, economic reforms, energy and environment, infrustructure in East Germany, employment and social welfare systems, legal questions, and foreign and security policy matters. Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said that after East Germany's elections, the two nations would begin immediate discussions on the economic reforms necessary in East Germany. Haussmann said a ``German-German economic miracle'' like the one that made West Germany wealthy is possible as the two countries draw closer together. West German officials have acknowledged it will cost billions of dollars to rescue East Germany's economy and compensate for losses of jobs as the country adjusts to a free-market economy, one of the results of the fall pro-democracy movement. The peaceful revolution ended the Communists' monopoly on power, led to the opening of the country's borders in November, and led to the scheduling of the country's first free elections in March. Three leftist opposition movements agreed to join forces and campaign as a coalition in the elections, East Germany's official ADN news agency said Wednesday. The three are New Forum, Democracy Now and the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights, said ADN. New Forum is East Germany's best-known pro-democracy movement. Three conservative opposition groups, including the Democratic Awakening, have also joined forces for the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Quits, Accusing Council of `Dictatorial Methods'
DOC.TEXT: The tourism minister resigned Wednesday after accusing the National Salvation Front of using ``dictatorial methods.'' He was the fourth member of the provisional government to quit. The minister, Mihai Lupoi, is an army officer who played an important role in the revolution that overthrew dictator Nicolae Ceausescu on Dec. 22 by making the first public appeal by an officer for soldiers to join the revolt. Dan Radulescu, chief of the Front's press and public relations, said Lupoi had ``proved incompetent'' and ``had no chance of maintaining his post'' after elections scheduled for May 20. ``Lupoi was a mistake of the revolution,'' Radulescu said. ``Such mistakes are inevitable when things happen as quickly as they did here, and we are now correcting them.'' Lupoi, a 36-year-old army architect promoted to major after the revolution, said in an interview he also was resigning from the military. He said he had encountered hostility in the past month from Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru, an army general who came out of retirement. His resignation follows those of Silviu Brucan, the Front's foreign policy expert, Front spokesman Aurel Dragos Munteanu and its interim vice president, Dumitru Mazilu. Brucan said in an interview the Lupoi resignation had no connection with his and was ``not necessarily politically significant.'' Some of Lupoi's allegations against the government ``sounded like fantasy,'' Brucan said. The National Salvation Front took over after the fall of Ceausescu, who was executed Dec. 25, and rules by decree. Pressure has grown for it to become more democratic, and it agreed recently to share some power with other political parties in a National Unity Council that would govern until the elections. Lupoi said his resignation resulted from ``differences'' with Prime Minister Petre Roman on personal and professional matters. His original letter of resignation, given to Roman on Tuesday afternoon, contained a sharp denunciation of the leadership's methods. He said his attempt to reorganize the Tourism Ministry was impeded by ``excessive government bureaucracy ... dictatorial methods in the relationship between the government and the ministry'' and ``an improper and ill-defined division of responsibility between the government and the Front.'' At a meeting Tuesday evening, Lupoi said, other ministers accused him of ``trying to take the people into the streets'' against the Front and tried to fire him instead of letting him resign. Eventually, he agreed to submit a more moderate version of his letter and the resignation was accepted Wednesday morning, Lupoi said. The minister said the Front ``had to accept'' multiparty democracy ``because of popular demand, but they don't like it.'' On Wednesday afternoon, 200 people gathered outside the television headquarters in Bucharest to protest the Front's control of radio and television. They carried signs saying ``We want independent television'' and ``Down with Munteanu, down with Communism.'' Munteanu kept his job as broadcasting chief after resigning as Front spokesman. A report of the protest, the second this week for greater access to television, was broadcast on the nightly TV news. ``Opinion in the street is divided on whether TV is truly independent,'' the report said. Merchant marine cadets ended a 31-hour hunger strike in Victory Square after getting assurances Wednesday night that the government would remove their academy from military control. In a demonstration at the Education Ministry, vocational students demanded the replacement of many technical high schools with schools oriented toward the sciences and humanities.

DOC.HEAD: House Members Says Editing `Threatens' Integrity
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress approved a resolution Wednesday saying that editing changes in the Congressional Record ``seriously threaten the integrity'' of the House. The resolution, approved 373-30, came after remarks by Rep. Gus Savage, D-Ill., were deleted from the official record of House and Senate proceedings and debate. Savage took the floor last week to announce that the ethics committee had ended its investigation of him and to call the allegations against him a ``racist attack'' by the news media and government officials. Savage, who is black, attacked the motivations of the three white Democrats who had complained to the ethics panel: Reps. Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, Matthew McHugh of New York and Barney Frank of Massachusetts. The ethics committee concluded that Savage made ``improper advances'' to a Peace Corps volunteer during a trip to Zaire last March. The committee said that Savage's conduct was contrary to a House rule on member conduct but recommended no punishment. The resolution approved Wednesday, sponsored by Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., has no effect other than to direct the Committee on House Administration to make recommendations on changes in procedures for the official recording and reporting of House proceedings. Walker said the editing was suggested by House Parliamentarian Bill Brown because of House rules prohibiting attacks on other members. Walker said the remarks ``were unparliamentary in nature'' and should not have been made. But he said the larger issue was whether the Congressional Record should be edited so that it does not accurately reflect what is said on the floor. Members of Congress frequently exercise their power to rewrite their spoken remarks before they are officially published in the Congressional Record, and the House routinely grants speakers the right to ``extend and revise'' their remarks in print. But Walker and Rep. James F. Sensenbrenner Jr., R-Wis., said that because all House proceedings are recorded on videotape, the House should make the written record more accurate. ``The time has come ... that we address the problem of the accuracy of the Congressional Record,'' Sensenbrenner said. ``It should not happen that in the dead of night offensive words get X-ed out.'' The resolution cited the editing of Savage's remarks and ``numerous other examples of deletions.'' ``These omissions seriously threaten the integrity of the proceedings of the House,'' the resolution said.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Announces He's Not Running
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Neil Goldschmidt announced Wednesday that he will not run for a second term, saying he and his wife have agreed to separate. ``It's certainly no time to be running for governor,'' Goldschmidt said at a news conference in his office. ``It will require giving more of myself than I am prepared to give.'' The Democratic governor's aides recently denied rumors there were any problems in the 25-year marriage of Goldschmidt and his wife, Margie. Goldschmidt, 49, was a former Portland mayor and U.S. secretary of transportation under President Carter. After returning to Portland in 1981, he headed Canadian operations for the Nike athletic wear company. The governor took office three years ago after winning a hard-fought race with former Secretary of State Norma Paulus. His political career began in Portland in 1970 when he was elected to the City Commission. Two years later, he was elected mayor and presided over such projects as the construction of a light-rail transit system. As governor, Goldschmidt's energy and charisma initially earned him high marks. He started a regional economic development program, and began a major expansion of the state's prison system. He later focused more on social services with a Children's Agenda that focused on providing a wide variety of help to children. But critics said the governor's rhetoric sometimes outran his accomplishments, and he also was criticized for not always following through on his initiatives. In the past year, Goldschmidt has been vexed by persistent problems, including the January 1989 slaying of Corrections Director Michael Francke, which remains unsolved. The killing prompted investigations into alleged corruption in the prison system. He and his wife have two children: Joshua, 20, and Rebecca, 17.

DOC.HEAD: Days Inns Conference Being Held at Rival Hotel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to make Reagan `1980 opponent,' sted `archenemy.' INSERTS 1 graf after 15th graf, `We wanted ...,' to ADD no-comment on Reagan's fee; picks up 16th graf, `Ms. Campbell ...'
DOC.TEXT: When officials of the Days Inn hotel chain planned their annual conference, they didn't have to look far for a nice place to put up their guests _ they booked a block of rooms at the Marriott Marquis. And when the Atlanta-based Days Inns of America Inc. sought out a former president to address the gathering, instead of choosing Georgia native Jimmy Carter, it invited his 1980 opponent, Ronald Reagan. The choice of venue was simple: Days Inns needed about 600 rooms for the visiting franchise owners as well as space for meetings, banquets, more than 200 vendor exhibits and the speech by Reagan. Days Inns, which caters to a middle-class clientele, doesn't have a hotel in town with that kind of space. ``We have quite a lot to put under one roof,'' said Debbie Campbell, the chain's vice president for guest services and a chief planner of the three-day conference which begins Thursday. Most of the Days Inns in the Atlanta area are smaller hotels along interstate highways. The downtown Days Inn, just a short walk from the Marriott, has about 200 rooms. The Marriott has 1,673. Ms. Campbell said Days Inns has been holding its annual conferences at the Marquis for three years, and despite the competitive nature of the hotel industry sees nothing odd about it. ``We wouldn't be there if they didn't provide the service we need,'' she said. ``It's totally different _ we're not in the convention business, Marriott is.'' She said the idea of housing guests at Days Inns and having the exhibits and other events at a convention center _ for example, the cavernous Georgia World Congress Center _ was rejected because organizers wanted everything in one place. ``This is the one time all of our licensees gather under one roof,'' she said. ``We feel we lose people if we go (from a hotel) to a convention center.'' Day Inns' booking the gathering at a rival isn't really a surprise, said Dave Fowler, assistant director for convention services at the Marriott Marquis. He said several hotel chains, including Comfort Inn and Quality Inn, have used the larger convention-oriented hotels for meetings. ``It's great for us. We feel flattered that they come here,'' he said. The speech by Reagan on Friday will be his first visit to Georgia since leaving office. Reagan also was scheduled to address a state Republican Party function Saturday. ``We wanted to do something that was really going to knock their socks off,'' Ms. Campbell said. ``Who better than Ronald Reagan, our most recent ex-president?'' She would not say how much Reagan was being paid for his appearance. Ms. Campbell said previous conferences have featured speakers from within the company. Days Inns, which has a stated goal to ``replace Holiday Inn as the standard for the middle-class traveler,'' has experienced dramatic growth in the last decade. The chain, with hotels in all 50 states and four countries, expanded from 290 hotels in 1985 to 951 last year and from 46,594 rooms in 1985 to 120,725 in 1989. The chain was bought in November by its largest franchisee, Tollman-Hundley hotels, in a deal that included a $90 million cash payment and the assumption of $675 million in debt.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon: Pay More Attention to Arabian Peninsula
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's military leadership has been told it should focus additional attention on possible regional threats to the Arabian Peninsula, a senior Defense Department official said Wednesday. The guidelines are in the Defense Planning Guidance, the long-range planning instructions issued by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to help the services prepare their budgets for 1992-'97. The document was due last fall, but its release was delayed so planners could assess the changes that are sweeping the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The senior Defense Department official briefed a number of reporters about the classified document after reports of its contents surfaced in the media. Asked which regional threats are possible against the nations on the Arabian Peninsula, the official said the document does not cite nations by name, but he went on to say that ``Iraq and Iran have significant armed forces.'' The official, who spoke on condition he not be identifed by name, contended that contrary to media reports, the document does not instruct the services to drop the mission of defending Iran in the event of a Soviet attack, but rather places more emphasis on the Arabian Peninsula. ``Although we are focusing additional attention on the Peninsula, our policies should continue to consider the contingency of a Soviet attack into Iran,'' the official quoted from the document. The United States has had contingency plans to counter a Soviet attack into Iran since the Soviets invaded Afghanistan in 1979. The official, queried about the media reports, said the document takes into account that U.S.-Iranian relations are ``more problematic than they once were,'' and notes that the United States isn't capable of mounting a defense in Iran's Zagros Mountains. The planning document also instructs planners to assume a successful negotiation on conventional forces in Europe will cut Soviet forces there, and that therefore, U.S. forces would have a ``much longer warning time'' about a massive Soviet attack, the official said. The guidance instructs the services to plan for the possibility that the United States will have to give up more of its bases overseas and notes that Asian nations such as South Korea will be expected to assume more of their own defense burden.

DOC.HEAD: First Human Recipient of Lung-assist Device Dies After 4{ Days
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf to CORRECT name of school to `Frank Stone High School,' sted `North Lamar High School.'
DOC.TEXT: The first human recipient of an experimental lung-assist device, a teen-ager suffering from severe respiratory stress, died Wednesday, 4{ days after the bundle of fine tubes was implanted in her chest. Melicia Harvey, 16, of Arthur City, Texas, who had remained in critical condition, died at 5:30 a.m. of ``worsening pulmonary failure,'' said Tim Madden, spokesman at LDS Hospital. The experimental IntraVascular Oxygenator, implanted during a two-hour operation Friday, functioned properly until the girl died, he said, and the hospital's government-approved implants will continue. ``There were no clinical complications from the use of the device, which added oxygen to and removed carbon dioxide from the patient's blood,'' Madden said in a written statement. Miss Harvey's identity and details of her condition had been kept private at her family's request until a Texas newspaper, The Paris News, identified her and her father, Atrell Harvey II. With the family's permission, Madden confirmed her identity Wednesday. The girl's mother, Edith Harvey, 41, had died of undisclosed causes on Jan. 31, said Leon Williams, a spokesman for the Maxey Funeral Home in Paris. He said funeral arrangements for the daughter were not complete. Miss Harvey, whose father is an employee of the Campbell Soup Co., had been a member of the student council at Frank Stone High School in Paris, where students were taking Miss Harvey's death ``really, really hard,'' said Linda Bolton, secretary to the principal. The school's 740 students include Miss Harvey's brother and sister. Bolton said counselors were called in to talk with the grieving students. The IVOX, a 20-inch bundle of hundreds of synthetic tubes about as fine as human hair, with walls so thin that oxygen and carbon dioxide can pass through, was designed to give damaged lungs time to rest and recover. It is inserted via the neck or groin into the inferior vena cava, the large vein that brings blood to the heart. Two tubes the diameter of a soda straw are attached to the bundle of tubes and lead out of the body. One delivers oxygen to the blood while the other removes carbon dioxide. The IVOX was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in September for temporary implantation in up to 10 humans at LDS and three other medical centers: Hershey Medical Center at Pennsylvania State University, the University of Michigan Medical Center in Ann Arbor and the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center. Madden said that in its most severe forms, adult respiratory distress syndrome is fatal in 90-95 percent of all cases. It has a variety of causes and is characterized by an inability of the lung to transfer oxygen to the blood. Dr. J.D. Mortensen, chief developer of the IVOX, for a company called CardioPulmonics Inc., declined to discuss Miss Harvey's case, but indicated her death wasn't as a surprise to doctors. ``Ninety percent of this group (the 10 approved implants) are expected to die,'' he said. Mortensen said that while he and other doctors will spend months reviewing the case before making a final assessment, early indications are that the IVOX worked well. ``There were no complications,'' Mortensen said. ``It will take a long time to review the mountain of data we gathered with this case. From what we know with this case, it (the IVOX) was extremely successful.'' He said a second implant will be made. ``We're just waiting for the right case, at any one of the centers,'' Mortensen said. Miss Harvey also received conventional treatments, which ordinarily include mechanical ventilation, antibiotics, and medications designed to remove excess fluid from the body and support heart function, he said. Madden said no news conferences or briefings were planned. ``There isn't really anything more they (doctors) can or will say,'' he said. Before Miss Harvey died, it was unclear how long doctors intended to leave the device inside her. FDA guidelines limit implants to seven days, and Madden had said any further use would require FDA permission. Protocol set by the FDA stipulates that the device be used on patients requiring 100 percent oxygen who otherwise have no better than a 10 percent chance of survival. The IVOX, developed by Salt Lake City-based CardioPulmonics Inc., can satisfy as much as half of the body's need for oxygen delivery and carbon dioxide elimination. Mortensen said it isn't an artificial lung but eventually could lead to one. He has said the initial experiments will involve only patients with acute lung diseases like pneumonia or smoke inhalation, not chronic disorders such as cystic fibrosis or emphysema.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Dentists Indicted
DOC.TEXT: Three Arizona dentists were indicted Wednesday on a charge of conspiring to fix patient fees in the first felony antitrust charge brought against medical practictioners in 50 years, the Justice Department said. The indictment, returned by a federal grand jury in Tucson, Ariz., accused three dentists and their corporations of conspiring to fix co-payment fees of patients who are members of pre-paid dental plans. Aaron L. Alston, Ronald D. Walker and Richard B. Meyer were charged with price fixing, a violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act that carries a possible three-year prison term. Alston's professional corporation and Desert Valley Dental Ltd., operated by Walker, were also named as defendants in the one-count indictment. ``Price fixing among competitors is a crime,'' said Assistant Attorney General James Rill, head of the Justice Department's anti-trust division. ``Doctors enjoy no immunity from this well-settled rule.'' The Justice Department said the indictment marked the first time in 50 years that a felony antitrust indictment had been brought against a medical practicioner. A conviction also carries a fine that is the largest of three alternatives: $250,000, twice the gain of the defendant or twice the loss to victims. Corporations could be fined $1 million if that amount exceeds figures that are twice the gain or loss.

DOC.HEAD: Valenti Says Outlook for Movie Industry is Healthy
DOC.TEXT: Americans shelled out $5.03 billion at box offices across the country this past year, making 1989 the most successful year in motion picture history, the industry's chief spokesman reports. Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, recited the glowing figures in a speech to movie distributors, exhibitors and theater owners attending the annual ShoWest exposition. Valenti said the 1989 box office take was up 83 percent from the 1980 figure of $2.74 billion. The number of admissions increased 10.9 percent during the decade, from 1.022 billion in 1980 to 1.133 billion last year. Teen-agers are no longer as significant a force in the industry as they once were, Valenti said, dropping from 42 percent of the market in 1980 to 30 percent last year. The over-40 crowd picked up the slack, accounting for 23 percent of all attendees last year, compared to 13 percent in 1980. ``Thank God the over-40s are going to the movies now,'' Valenti told reporters before his speech. The movie chief said many parts of the country may see $8 ticket prices ``if inflation continues at 4 to 5 percent a year.'' The average movie ticket price is now $4.44, Valenti said. At the opposite end of the scale, Valenti said there is a proliferation of discount theaters willing to let patrons in for peanuts to hawk expensive popcorn and other treats. ``Concessions are a major profit center for every theater,'' Valenti said. ``Many theaters make 81 percent profit on their concessions. A $3 bag of popcorn costs 17 cents, a $2.25 Coke 12 cents. ``My guess is that most theaters would let people come in free if they could'' just to get the movie-goer to buy the inflated concessions. While theater owners make money from the box office and the concession stand, the film distributor earns only from the dollars deposited at the ticket window. ``The question is whether you can cut your admission costs down to 50 cents or 25 cents, stripping the distributor of his revenues,'' Valenti said. ``It doesn't make any sense. ``Discount houses are growing very rapidly, enticing people into theaters,'' Valenti said. ``They don't care about the box office. They want people to come in to buy the concessions.'' Valenti said the movie theater industry will continue to thrive despite television ``if you have a good movie and show it in a good, clean theater.'' Movies remain the ``cheapest game in town'' when compared to the cost of events like professional sports, Valenti said. Actor Jimmy Stewart was to present a special tribute to Universal Studios Tuesday night in honor of their 75th anniversary. ShoWest runs through Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Listen to the Boy, Prosecutor Tells Sex Mutilation Jury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with details of closing arguments, jury deliberating and retiring for night, judge's instruction to jury. Picks up 8th graf pvs: `She said ...' Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor told jurors Tuesday to listen to the victim when they deliberate the case of a man accused of raping a 7-year-old boy, cutting off his penis and leaving him for dead. But a defense lawyer emphasized discrepancies between the boy's description of his attacker's clothing and speech and those of defendant Earl Kenneth Shriner. Jurors deliberated nearly four hours after receiving the case, then retired for the night. Deliberations were to resume Wednesday morning. Shriner is charged with first-degree attempted murder and two counts of first-degree rape. Judge Thomas R. Sauriol gave the panel 20 minutes of instruction on the 6-day-old case and said they could reduce the charges against Shriner. Deputy Prosecutor Barbara Corey-Boulet told the Pierce County Superior Court jury that the boy's recall has been consistent on at least one fact: the identity of his attacker. ``(The boy) knows who attacked him,'' Corey-Boulet said. ``Listen to the voice of the child.'' Defense lawyers Lloyde Alton and Dino Sepe called no defense witnesses, pinning their case instead on an effort to discredit the boy's testimony. The child may have picked Shriner from a photo montage and in person because of seeing him previously in the neighborhood, Alton said in his closing argument. The boy said his attacker wore a ``green and white jacket with ... shiny material,'' Alton said, holding up Shriner's dull gray jacket. The child also described a fishing hat with hooks. But other witnesses said Shriner wore a white bicycle helmet that day, Alton noted. And although the boy failed to mention anything unusual in Shriner's speech, all other witnesses said Shriner had a speech impediment. ``They have focused on one individual and decided this is the guy,'' Alton told the jury. The prosecutor dismissed the failure of the boy, who has turned 8, to remember some details of the May 20 attack. She blamed his lack of recall on the shock caused by the savagery of the attack. She said Shriner lied when he told police blood on his jacket was from a bicycle accident. Laboratory tests proved the blood could have been the boy's but was definitely not Shriner's. Shriner, 40, has an extensive history of violence against young people and confinement in institutions for the retarded and deranged. The attack occurred in woods near where the boy lives. Police who interviewed the boy after the attack said Shriner lured him into the woods where he placed a yellow strap around his neck, raped him repeatedly and cut off his penis. An inmate in a cell near Shriner's testified that Shriner said he cut off the boy's penis because he refused to urinate on him. Doctors who treated the child at Mary Bridge Children's Hospital said the body's natural defense mechanisms, which direct blood to interior organs during times of extreme fear, may have saved his life. The boy has undergone corrective surgery, the cost of which was covered by a trust fund created with donations following the heavily publicized attack. Media coverage was so wide that the judge went 120 miles north to Bellingham to pick a jury for the trial in Tacoma. The vicious attack galvanized public opinion in the state and led to a governor's task force addressing the problem of sex predators. Since the attack, one former sex offender has been arrested and charged in the deaths of three young boys in the Portland, Ore., area. Police in Lynnwood, a Seattle suburb, and Tacoma have alerted the public when known sex offenders were released from detention, and the Legislature is nearing approval of a new law to crack down on sex predators.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Testifies She Saw Tanker Captain Drinking
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with defense examination of Coast Guardsman's wife. No pickup. Testimoney ended for day.
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood on Wednesday attacked testimony by a Coast Guardsman's wife who says she saw Hazelwood drinking in a bar hours before the tanker went to sea. The testimony by Janice Delozier, whose husband, Mark, was one of the first Coast Guard investigators to board the ship after it ran aground, puts Hazelwood at the Pipeline Club more than two hours before the defense contends he was there. The time element is critical in determining how much liquor Hazelwood might have consumed before taking command of the Exxon Valdez on March 23, the night it struck a reef, triggering the nation's worst oil spill. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is being tried in Superior Court on a felony charge of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted on all counts, he could be sentenced to up to seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Mrs. Delozier insisted she saw Hazelwood ordering a drink around 1:45 p.m. Hazelwood's shipmates have testified they had lunch with him in Valdez from 12:30 to about 2 p.m., dropped him off in a shopping center near the bar and didn't see him again until about 4 p.m. when they had drinks at the bar. The ship grounded shortly after midnight, spilling more than 10 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound. The spill killed thousands of birds, fish and other wildlife and blackened hundreds of miles of rocky shore. Mrs. Delozier came forward about 10 days after the accident to say she had seen the captain at the Pipeline Club, a Valdez bar. She said her memory had been prodded by seeing a picture of Hazelwood in the newspaper. ``My immediate reaction was, `Wow, I saw him,''' she testified. She recalled going to the club during a lunch break from her dental assistant's job and said she was drinking coffee when a man in a peaked hat came in and ordered vodka on the rocks. She said she's sure it was Hazelwood. Mrs. Delozier said she told her husband, who gave her two days to think about whether she wanted to tell authorities. Later, she was interviewed by the FBI and Coast Guard, she said, while her husband stood by and prompted her recollections. Defense attorney Michael Chalos vigorously attacked her account, noting the participation of her husband in the interview. He focused on her statement that she didn't come forward earlier because she thought people might find her story ``fishy.'' ``Why did you think people would think it was fishy?'' asked Chalos. ``Human nature. You know, two Deloziers. My husuband got a lot of publicity,'' she replied. ``Did you want to get publicity?'' asked Chalos. ``I didn't want anything to do with it,'' said the witness, speaking rapidly in a thick Southern accent. ``And then there were the ever-present questions, `What were you doing in a bar?''' Chalos asked ``how come'' Mrs. Delozier hadn't discussed her recollection with the woman who she says waited on Hazelwood. ``There's no `how come' involved,'' snapped the witness. ``I'm not the town crier.'' The defense attorney asked if it ever occurred to Mrs. Delozier she might be mistaken in identifying Hazelwood. ``It has occurred to me, sir,'' she said. Asked if she tried to verify her identification, she said, ``I didn't feel I had to.'' ``But if you had doubts?'' Chalos said before the woman cut him off. ``When did I say I had doubts? I knew who I saw 100 percent,'' she said. ``I wouldn't be sitting here under oath if I had those doubts.'' She acknowledged, however, that in an interview with a state police investigator last week she placed Hazelwood in the bar between 12:30 and 1:30 p.m. She said she was confused by the passage of time since the event.

DOC.HEAD: Lutheran World Federation Elects New President
DOC.TEXT: The Lutheran World Federation elected a new president Wednesday at an assembly in southern Brazil, a spokeswoman said. The new leader, Brazil's Gottfried Braqemeier, promised to work so that ``the cry of the people of Latin America, and all of the world's oppressed, is heard,'' spokeswoman Paula Voight quoted him as saying. Braqemeier, elected to a six-year term, is president of the Evangelical Church of Lutheran Confession, the largest Lutheran church in Latin America, Ms. Voight said. She said more than 1,000 Lutherans from more than 60 countries were participating in the assembly, being held in Curitiba, 505 miles southwest of Rio. Early Wednesday, about 100 conference participants sang songs and marched through Curitiba with a wooden cross to show support for agrarian reform to benefit Brazil's estimated 12 million landless peasants. Brazil's outgoing president, Jose Sarney, promised an agrarian reform program after taking office five years ago, but it was carried out only marginally. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, says more than 800 peasants have died in clashes with landowners during Sarney's five-year term. Voight said conference participants were expected to release documents supporting less burdensome terms of payment on Latin America's $400 billion-plus foreign debt before the weeklong meeting closes Thursday. They also were to protest the destruction of the Amazon jungle, she said. Gro Harlem Brundtland, the former prime minster of Norway and a member of the U.N.'s World Commission on Environment and Development, opened the meeting Friday. She said the assembly would deal mostly with Latin American problems. The Lutheran World Federation holds an assembly every six years.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Charge 20 Reputed Mobsters After Eight-Year Probe
DOC.TEXT: Twenty alleged mobsters were indicted on charges including murder, extortion and racketeering after an eight-year probe of the city's underworld, U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced Wednesday. ``These defendants are alleged to be major participants in the Chicago crime syndicate,'' Thornburgh said at a news conference. The government said those indicted by a federal grand jury were engaged in illegal gambling, high-interest loans and the collection of ``street taxes'' from other criminals. Several are accused of using murder and extortion as enforcement tactics. The indictments detail the cases of three independent bookmakers who balked at paying street taxes and were slain. Prosecutors say they believe the indictments represent a rare solution of underworld murders. ``Obviously, this was a powerful group of individuals,'' said acting U.S. Attorney Ira Raphaelson, citing what he described as their ability to operate rackets for years. Those indicted, Raphaelson said, operated as the Joseph Ferriola street crew, a segment of the city's crime syndicate. He refused to say how many street crews are believed to operate in Chicago, how big a role the Ferriola crew played in the mob or whether the indictments were expected to reduce crime in the city. Rocco Infelise, 67, of suburban River Forest, who allegedly succeeded Ferriola after his death last year, is charged with a variety of offenses, including murder, racketeering conspiracy, illegal gambling and tax cheating. Also charged with racketeering is Salvatore DeLaurentis, 52, of suburban Inverness. The FBI said Infelise and DeLaurentis were arrested Wednesday at O'Hare International Airport when they arrived on a flight from Florida. Of the other 18 defendants, all but one had been taken into custody. The government is seeking forfeiture of the homes of Infelise and DeLaurentis and $3.7 million in proceeds from alleged racketeering activities. Some of defendants also are accused of conspiring to bribe public officials in Illinois to protect the street crew and of planning to bribe officials in Wisconsin. Raphaelson said there isn't any indication the Wisconsin plans were realized or that any Wisconsin officials knew about the plan. The indictment alleges that three people were killed because they refused to pay street taxes _ fees to the syndicate for the privilege of running criminal activities. According to the indictment, Anthony Reitinger was fatally shot in Chicago in 1975, Robert Plummer was beaten to death in the Libertyville suburb in 1982 and Hal Smith was strangled in suburban Long Grove in 1985. The 102-page indictment contains 42 counts against the 20 defendants. In addition to Infelise and DeLaurentis, those indicted are Louis Marino, 56, of Palos Park; Robert Bellavia, 50, Addison; Robert Salerno, 55, Park Ridge; William Jahoda, 47, Itasca; Michael Sarno, 32, Chicago; Harry Aleman, 51, Oakbrook; Edward Stevenson, 71, Elmwood Park; Robert Covone, 34, Lombard; William DiDomenico, 47, Mount Prospect; Michael Zitello, 35, Brookfield; Robert Garrison, 54, Libertyville; Thomas McCandless, 56, Northbrook; Paul Spano, 59, Chicago; Ronald ReRosa, 28, Melrose Park; Frank Maltese, 59, Cicero; James Coniglio, 53, Berwyn; James Nicholas, 47, Hoffman Estates; and James Damopoulos, 34, Chicago. Authorities wouldn't say which one of the defendants remained at large.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Who Admitted Molesting 64 Children Faces New Charges
DOC.TEXT: The case of a 13-year-old boy who authorities say has admitted sexually abusing as many as 64 children in a church nursery is an alarming example of children who molest children, a researcher said. The youth admitted molesting dozens of boys and girls between the ages of 18 months and 4 years left at a church nursery while their parents attended services, according to Muskegon County Juvenile Court documents and Juvenile Court Judge Neil Mullally. The alleged incidents occurred between 1985 and 1988 in the Muskegon County town of Fruitport, 40 miles west of Grand Rapids. The boy, identified in court records as David Andrew Hawkey, pleaded guilty in May to second-degree criminal sexual conduct for molesting a 4-year-old. The extent of the case became known while he was undergoing court-ordered therapy, and confessed to molesting other children. ``In too many cases, signs are ignored and adults reduce it to sex play or experimentation and believe there's nothing to worry about. ... Then, you hear about something like this,'' said Dr. Toni Cavanagh Johnson, a researcher in the field of young sex offenders. She is not connected to the Fruitport case. David was charged this week with two counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct. He is at a residential treatment center, and if convicted of the new charges, could be sentenced to remain in treatment until he is 19. Authorities said David was able to name 47 children and provided descriptions of the rest. Nearly all of the cases have been corroborated through interviews and medical examinations, the judge said. David was a volunteer at the Fruitport Bethel Baptist Church. Nursery supervisors were always present but authorities said the boy molested the children in restrooms or while baby-sitting at church members' homes. The alleged molestations ranged from fondling to rape, authorities say. The boy's parents have refused to comment. David's 17-year-old brother, Paul, has also been charged with first-degree criminal sexual conduct for allegedly molesting a 4-year-old boy at the church in 1988. The elder boy's attorney has denied the charge. Johnson is clinical director of the Support Program for Abused-Reactive Kids at Children's Institute International, a private non-profit mental health facility in Los Angeles. She said she has interviewed 200 children who have molested other children and ``the majority have been sexually abused and nearly all of them have been exposed prematurely to sexuality. They are all extremely confused about sexuality and show an interest in it far beyond their age.'' Johnson said it's hard to gauge the severity of the problem because so few sex offenders under the age of 14 are prosecuted and little data is available. Johnson, who said she has seen children as young as 3 years old acting out sexual aggression, added that children living in an atmosphere of violence, promiscuity or neglect appear to be most prone to becoming sexually aggressive. ``Almost all of them have witnessed physical aggression at home; they seem to have paired sex and aggression in their head,'' she said in a telephone inteview Tuesday. In a 1988 report commissioned by the Michigan Department of Mental Health, researchers found that 96 percent of all juvenile sex offenders are male and that the median age was 14. The median age of their victims was 7. In most cases, the older child knows his victim, and uses threats, coercion or violence to keep the victim from disclosing the crime. In the Fruitport case, the boy admitted he threatened to cut his victims' heads off with a sword or lock them in the bathroom if they told their parents, said Juvenile Court caseworker Debra Jensen. Parents gradually became aware of the alleged assaults after some of the children began complaining of rectal pain, wetting their beds and recreating the incidents with other children, said the Rev. Billie Anderson, pastor of the church.

DOC.HEAD: Release of 1,000 Prisoners Backed, Sandinistas Seek U.S. Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 3rd graf `A landslide' to ADD that U.S. delegation blocked from entry is disbanded. Pickup 4th, `President Daniel...'
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinista-dominated National Assembly on Wednesday approved amnesty for more than 1,000 political prisoners, pre-empting a key opposition pledge less than three weeks before elections. The Sandinista party predicted it will win the Feb. 25 elections by a landslide and that the United States, unable to ignore the results, will move to normalize relations with Soviet-backed Nicaragua. ``A landslide victory will push normalization with the United States,'' read the headline on a front-page story about the elections in the Sandinista newspaper Barricada. Nicaragua, however, has refused to allow a 20-member U.S. congressional group named by President Bush to monitor the elections, and Sen. Richard Lugar said in Washington Wednesday that the delegation was disbanded. Former President Jimmy Carter heads a separate observer group. President Daniel Ortega, seeking another six-year term, made the amnesty proposal last week and the National Assembly rubber-stamped it Wednesday with a 76-4 vote. The amnesty covers 1,189 people, most of them accused of taking part in the U.S.-backed Contra insurgency. About 95 are already out of prison and under house arrest or restricted by conditional liberties. The amnesty also covers 39 ex-officers of the hated National Guard that defended Anastasio Somoza's rightist dictatorship, which the Sandinistas overthrew in 1979. The prisoners are expected to be released Friday and Saturday, said Sandinista lawmaker Danilo Aguirre. The government also freed 1,984 political prisoners last April, but the Permanent Commission on Human Rights, an independent group, claims at least 4,000 more are held in prisons and jails nationwide. Ortega, who has taken pains during the campaign to mend his often fractious relationship with the Roman Catholic Church, said he decided to ask for the amnesty at the urging of Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Nicaragua. Freedom for political prisoners, ending the military draft and reviving Nicaragua's shattered economy are key planks in the platform of Ortega's main opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, publisher of the opposition newspaper La Prensa and leader of the U.S.-backed United National Opposition. UNO, a 14-party coalition, is the Sandinistas' main challenger in the general election. The language in the Barricada article lacked the acrimony that usually accompanies government comments on the United States, and reinforced a common Sandinista theme of late, a desire for normal relations. Unlike earlier articles, the story was restrained in tone and referred to the United States by name instead of the usual ``Yankees,'' ``Gringo imperialist aggressors'' and other derogatory phrases. Barricada paraphrased Interior Minister Tomas Borge as saying the Sandinistas will garner at least 70 percent of the vote in the elections, placing them ``in unsurpassable conditions for the government of the United States not only to recognize the results, but to start normalizing relations with Nicaragua.'' But while the article's main thrust was one of reconciliation with the United States _ which supports the Contra rebels and imposed economic sanctions _ it also suggested the military may not obey a victorious opposition. ``For example, with the existence of (the Sandinista) revolutionary armed forces, how could officers obey the absurd orders of those who would become defense and interior ministers?'' Borge said at a meeting Tuesday night with 1,600 Sandinista activists. A $49 million non-lethal aid package to the Contras, approved by the U.S. Congress last year, will run out shortly after the elections, and Congress has shown no inclination to renew aid to the rebels. The Sandinistas have thrice expelled U.S. diplomats, accusing them of inciting violence and engaging in plans to destabilize the government. The United States has retaliated each time, expelling as many Nicaraguan diplomats from Washington. Political observers and non-U.S. diplomats generally agree that while the Sandinistas have an impressive campaign machine, widespread discontent over the economy might give UNO a victory at the ballot box.

DOC.HEAD: Juries Award More Than $475 Million In 10 Largest Civil Suits in 1989
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Juries awarded more than $475 million in damages in the nation's 10 largest civil lawsuits last year, but some attorneys say jumbo verdicts are declining as insurers and corporations lobby for limits on awards. The largest verdicts came in cases of medical malpractice, product liability, wrongful firing, defamation, sexual abuse and personal injury. Half of the judgments were against corporations, three were against city, county or state governments and agencies, and two were against individuals, according to the Boston-based Lawyers Alert magazine. The awards were topped by twin verdicts totaling more than $152 million awarded to two factory workers in Baltimore who got lung disease from exposure to asbestos. In the second-largest judgment, New York City's Transit Authority was ordered to pay $58 million to a 20-year-old man whose legs were cut off when he fell in front of a subway car. ``This shows that if a corporate defendant does something that offends the American public, they're going to get slammed,'' said Larry Bodine, publisher of Lawyers Alert. ``These juries are made up of regular folks, and if a company gets jurors mad at them, they're going to get creamed.'' But amid talk of a lawsuit crisis or reform of the tort system, in which civil actions are brought for wrongful acts, injury or damage, the number of million-dollar judgments is dropping. After peaking at 562 in 1985, the number of million-dollar-plus awards dropped in 1986 and 1987, the last years for which complete figures are available, according to Jury Verdict Research Inc. ``I think we are seeing the effects of the tort reform movement (seeking limits on awards) and the impact of advertising by insurance companies saying that there is a lawsuit crisis,'' said Tom Harrison, editor of Lawyers Alert. William Bailey, counsel for the Insurance Information Institute, an insurance industry trade organization, said whopping judgments showed ``the law has gotten carried away.'' ``Punitive damage awards are getting bigger every year, and they don't do any good,'' Bailey said. ``They don't alter the anti-social behavior of companies that we're trying to prevent.'' But Russ Herman, president of the Trial Lawyers Association of America, called tort reform ``tort deform'' and said it was an attempt by corporations to escape accountability for their actions. ``This is just another way for corporate America to increase its profits at the cost of American justice,'' Herman said. Herman said most damage suits involved corporations suing each other. Most of the top 10 awards involved individual injury or death, including: _ A $30 million verdict against New York City after attorneys showed a 7-year-old boy was paralyzed when he fell from a 15-foot high playground sculpture. _ $44 million awarded when a family of four was killed when the gas tank of their Toyota station wagon exploded in a collision. In two suits, plaintiffs were awarded damages for being wrongfully fired. However, just because damages are awarded doesn't mean they are received, Bodine said. The status of the top 1989 awards wasn't available. ``In many cases, the full amount is never collected,'' Bodine said. ``The award may be reduced on appeal, or the defendant may just go belly-up and say, `I don't have the money.'''

DOC.HEAD: Blacks March On City Hall; Schools Closed in Race Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with schools ordered closed Thursday, ADD that demonstration lasted 45 minutes; picks up 5th graf, `Protest leaders ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MY3
DOC.TEXT: Public schools were closed and several hundred blacks chanting ``soul power'' and ``I am somebody'' marched on City Hall on Wednesday to protest white leadership of Selma's mostly black school system. The crowd peacefully went to the City Hall council chamber for 45 minutes of prayers and speeches in support of Norward Roussell, the first black school superintendent in this 1960s battleground of the civil rights movement. Roussell was dismissed last week by the Board of Education, a majority of whose members are white. But amid protests, the board reinstated Roussell and he returned to the job Wednesday. The board closed all 11 public schools in Selma's 70 percent black, 6,000-student system Wednesday after racial tensions rose and there were scuffles between white and black students Tuesday morning. Roussell announced Wednesday afternoon the schools would remain closed Thursday and until ``we are able to assure the safety and security of our students and staff.'' Protest leaders called on the board to extend Roussell's contract beyond June, when it is set to expire. They also demanded that blacks be given an equal voice on the school board, and that board members be elected, rather than appointed by the City Council, which also has a white majority. ``Indeed, we must turn Selma right side up and wrong side out,'' demonstrator Spiver Gordon told the cheering crowd at City Hall. Yusef Salaam, a legal services attorney, noted that demonstrators came peacefully to City Hall on Wednesday. But, he said, ``there's no telling how we will come tomorrow.'' The dispute goes back to December, when the six white members of the 11-member board voted to let Roussell's $80,000-a-year contract run out in June. They cited an evaluation critical of his managerial skills. Roussell said the evaluation was unsubstantiated, and black protest leaders said he was being fired because he is black. After the December vote, the five black members of the board announced they were resigning, though they have yet to sign formal resignation papers. The controversy led to periodic school boycotts. The protests turned confrontational after the board decided last week to remove Roussell as superintendent immediately, rather than waiting until June. Four blacks were arrested on misdemeanor charges Monday after a melee at Mayor Joe Smitherman's office. Rose Sanders, one of the four arrested, was injured. Wearing a neck brace, with one arm in a sling, she spoke from a wheelchair at a hospital Wednesday, saying she was hurt when she was carried bodily from Smitherman's office by police. She said she was dragged out of the mayor's office and up the steps of the Police Department. Smitherman has said the four were allowed to leave his office however they wanted and that all four refused to move unless carried. Mrs. Sanders' husband, Democratic state Sen. Hank Sanders, said Wednesday he would use ``any means necessary'' to personally respond to what he described as abuse of his wife. Smitherman said he was working to resolve the school conflict even though he isn't officially part of the education system. He said he was a ``readily available symbol'' for black frustrations. After the threat of violence forced the closing of two schools Tuesday morning, the white members of the school board reinstated Roussell as superintendent and urged the five black members of the board to resume work. The reinstatement came after the interim superintendent, the Rev. F.D. Reese, a black who is principal of Selma High School, announced his resignation so Roussell could return to the job. Roussell met for two hours Wednesday morning with principals and his central office staff to discuss ``the safety of our students and the security of our schools.'' ``We are in a crisis situation,'' he told reporters. ``The press is not my priority right now. My priority is getting those kids back in school.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Man of Sexually Mutilating, Raping Boy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4, `Shriner looked...,' with three grafs to CORRECT that special verdicts increase maximum sentence by 8 years, RESTORE dropped word `swallowed' in 3rd graf; picks up 5th graf, `We want ...' Changes byline.
DOC.HEAD: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A man with a long record of violence toward young people was convicted Wednesday of raping, sexually mutilating and trying to kill a 7-year-old boy during an attack in woods near the child's home. The jury, brought in from 120 miles away because of pretrial publicity, deliberated 4} hours, after six days of testimony, before finding Earl Kenneth Shriner guilty of first-degree attempted murder, two counts of first-degree rape and first-degree assault. Shriner looked frightened when the jury returned the verdict. He swallowed visibly and bit his lower lip as the guilty announcements were read. The jury also returned two special verdicts finding Shriner used a deadly weapon in committing the rapes. Under state sentencing guidelines, that added 8 years to the maximum sentence of 91\ years. Deputy Prosecutor James Roche said prosecutors would ask for a longer sentence under rules allowing a judge to exceed the maximum term in extraordinary circumstances. ``We want to see that he never gets out again,'' Roche said. Pierce Count Superior Court Judge Thomas R. Sauriol set sentencing for March 26. Helen Harlow, mother of the boy, said she was relieved by the jury's decision. ``It's over for me,'' she said. ``The sentencing is next.'' The boy's family sighed and wept quietly. Betty Foote, the boy's grandmother, said the child, now 8, was at school and that his mother would tell him about the verdict when he came home. ``He'll be able to put all this behind him almost immediately,'' Ms. Harlow said. Dolores Shriner, the defendant's mother, left the courtroom quickly but later told a reporter: ``How would you feel if you were his mother?'' Jurors signed a form saying they didn't want to speak with the news media after the trial. Prosecutors said Shriner, 40, used threats to lure the boy into a wooded area near their south Tacoma homes, then raped him orally and anally, cut off his penis, choked him with a strap or cord around his neck and left him for dead. A jail inmate testified that Shriner said he mutilated the boy because the youngster would not urinate on him. Neighbors found the boy, naked, bloody, covered with mud and practically incoherent, soon after the attack. A trust fund established with donations has financed extensive corrective surgery for the boy, but he faces more operations when he approaches adulthood. Defense lawyer Lloyde Alton did not call any witnesses, including Shriner, but attacked the boy's identification of his client. In a 24-year history of violent attacks on young people, Shriner has been confined at Rainier School for the retarded; Western State Hospital, a mental institution, and the Washington Corrections Center, but the jury was barred from hearing of his background. The jury was chosen 120 miles away in Bellingham because of pre-trial publicity, which also helped galvanize public sentiment for tougher laws on sex predators. Deputy prosecutor Barbara Corey-Boulet and Alton agreed that the most compelling evidence was the boy's own testimony. Corey-Boulet said the most consistent feature of all the boy's accounts was his identification of Shriner. ``(The boy) knows who attacked him,'' she told jurors. ``Listen to the voice of the child.'' Alton said the boy might have picked Shriner from a police photo montage and later identified him in person as the attacker because of previous, unremembered encounters in the neighborhood. He said the boy's description of his assailant consistently deviated from descriptions of Shriner offered by other witnesses before and after the attack. The boy said Shriner wore a shiny green and white jacket, gray pants and a camouflage style fishing hat with fishhooks in it, and said nothing about Shriner's speech impediment. But Alton noted that a bloodstained jacket seized from Shriner was a dull gray with maroon lining, the pants he was wearing were blue jeans, he was seen throughout the day of the attack wearing a white bicycle helmet. The attack helped lead to formation of a governor's task force on sex predators and the Washington Legislature is close to enacting the task force's recommendations, including longer prison terms and civil commitment for incorrigible sex offenders.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Monitors, Denied Visas, Disband
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 4-8 bgng: ``The White,'' with White House stamnt
DOC.TEXT: A 20-member congressional group named by President Bush to observe this month's elections in Nicaragua has been disbanded after members were denied visas by the leftist Managua government, Sen. Richard Lugar said Wednesday. Lugar, an Indiana Republican, said President Bush concurs that there is no chance for the group to serve its intended function of determining whether the Feb. 25 balloting is free and fair. ``The Nicaraguan government has remained intransigent in arbitrarily choosing those it wished to observe the election and making a point of hostility to any official U.S. observers,'' Lugar said. The White House said in a statement it was ``disappointed that Sandinista stonewalling has brought this about.'' The visa refusals and other actions ``bring into question the Sandinista commitment (to free elections). These include continued violence and coercion against opposition activists; imbalance in access to the media and the use of state resources to help the Sandinista candidates,'' said the White House statement, telephoned to news agencies Wednesday night by spokesman Roman Popadiuk. ``Politically motivated delays by the Sandinistas to disbursement of non-partisan campaign funds to the opposition for such activities as voter registration and election monitoring have forced cancellation or curtailment of critical election support programs.'' The campaign funds, $9 million, were voted by Congress to help all parties compete in the elections. ``Sandinista actions thus far are troubling but we continue to remain hopeful that the desires of the Nicaraguan people for full freedom will prevail,'' said the White House statement, which said a free and fair election and fulfillment of other Nicaraguan pledges ``offer the possibility for a stable peace in Nicaragua and for improved relations with the United States.'' At the same time, former President Jimmy Carter, who heads a separate observer group, briefed members of the House and Senate on his trips to Nicaragua and gave a largely optimistic report about chances for free and fair elections. ``He feels pretty good about it,'' said Lugar, who attended one of the briefings. Carter believes that so far, ``as a Central American election goes, this one is probably in the ballpark,'' he said. Carter also is inviting some members of the defunct presidential observer group to join his team, Lugar said. He said he and Rep. Anthony Beilenson, D-Ind., the co-chairman of the presidential group, have declined to go. Carter told reporters he hoped that as many as 1,500 international observers would be deployed across Nicaragua at election time to give as complete a picture as possible of how fairly the voting is conducted. He acknowledged that ``there have been some serious problems, most of which have been corrected,'' an apparent reference to violence against opposition supporters early in the campaign season and to alleged Sandinista foot-dragging in funneling U.S. aid to the opposition. Lugar said he believed the denial of the visas was ``a foreign policy blunder'' on Managua's part that squandered a chance to help ease relations between Nicaragua and the United States. ``We have a problem back here however this election comes out,'' he said, predicting intense U.S. debate on how to forge a new relationship with Nicaragua. ``This (election) is a pivotal event.'' Congressional sources, speaking only on the condition of anonymity, said the Sandinista government had signaled privately that three people on the 20-name list were particularly objectionable: Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., and Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., and Connie Mack, R-Fla., all strong supporters of the anti-Sandinista Contra rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Candidate, Others Wounded in Police Confrontation
DOC.TEXT: Police firing birdshot to break up a leftist campaign march Wednesday slightly wounded presidential candidate Henry Pease and three others, Pease said. Speaking in a radio interview after the incident, Pease said he was leading a group of supporters of his United Left coalition on a march through Lima's downtown when police opened fire with anti-riot shotguns, water cannon and tear gas. Witnesses said the marchers tried to cross the Plaza de Armas, the public square in front of the Government Palace, where President Alan Garcia lives. The square has been closed off by police for several months for security reasons as Peru combats a rebel insurgency. Police detoured the marchers down a side street, where the confrontation occurred. Pease said the group was walking ``without disturbing transportation or anyone.'' Pease, slightly wounded in the leg by birdshot pellets, was treated at a local clinic and released. Also slightly wounded in the incident were two congressional candidates and one of Pease's bodyguards, Pease said. The United Left is a coalition of Marxist parties supporting Pease in the April 8 presidential elections. Public opinion polls show writer Mario Vargas Llosa, candidate of the center-right Democratic Front coalition, far ahead of other candidates in the April 8 election. Trailing him are Alfonso Barrantes of the Socialist Left coalition, Luis Alva Castro of the governing center-left Aprista party, and Pease. Garcia is ineligible to run again. As part of his campaign Pease visits public markets to speak with voters. Wednesday's march was intended to end at a popular market a few blocks from the Government Palace.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Praises Soviet Communist Party Vote
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday praised the Soviet Communist Party's vote to give up its monopoly on power. ``Further than we could ever have thought five years ago,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``A lot still to be done but a great decision, a great decision.'' Mrs. Thatcher spoke to reporters outside her 10 Downing St. office standing alongside the Soviet Communist Party's ideology chief, Vadim A. Medvedev, who arrived for a six-day visit. Medvedev, a member of the Soviet Politburo, flew into London shortly after the vote in Moscow and said the decision ``opens up a new page in perestroika.'' During an hour of talks with the prime minister, Downing Street officials said, he gave her a long and substantial message from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that marked increasingly close relations between their nations. Medvedev heads a seven-member delegation invited by British lawmakers. Perestroika is the term Gorbachev uses for his program of restructuring the Soviet economy and society. Medvedev said perestroika in British-Soviet relations began when Mrs. Thatcher and Gorbachev first met in 1984, a few months before Gorbachev became Soviet leader in March 1985. ``We set the tone five or six years ago. We set it well.'' said Mrs. Thatcher.

DOC.HEAD: Bell Labs Says New Form Of Matter Confirmed
LaserPhoto NR2
DOC.TEXT: AT&T said Wednesday that researchers at its Bell Laboratories have confirmed the existence of ``quasi-crystals,'' a new and much-debated form of matter that could be used to improve electronic equipment. Scientists in university and private research say X-rays and other techniques have already helped prove quasi-crystals exist, but say Bell Labs' research gives the most straightforward description of the matter. Discovered in 1984, quasi-crystals have been the focus of some of the most intense study in the scientific community along with superconductivity and cold fusion, say scientists familiar with the subject. Researchers praised Bell Labs' announcement, but said it could not be considered a breakthrough, as the company claimed. Paul Horn, director of physical science at International Business Machine's Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown, N.Y., called the development a ``nice piece of science.'' But he said, ``It didn't tell us anything we didn't expect.'' While research has revealed the presence of quasi-crystals in bulk form, Bell Labs provided the first glimpse of a quasi-crystal surface, helping refute arguments that previous manifestations were a quirk of nature, said Lionel Kimmerling, who heads Bell Labs' materials interface research department in Murray Hill west of Newark. The company used a scanning-tunnelling miscroscope, which is exact enough to probe individual atoms. Researchers cut atoms on a plane and used the microscope to move a fine-tipped probe over the surface. The image of each atom was then projected on a television screen, said Kimmerling. ``It's the first time that people have used a scanning-tunnelling microscope to get an image of the surface of the material,'' Horn said. ``It confirms what people believed and what people had very good evidence for ...'' The three states of matter are solid, liquid and gas. The solid state is divided into amorphous _ or unorganized _ solids, such as glass, and crystal, which includes rocks and metals. The quasi-crystal _ in this case composed of an alloy of aluminum, cobalt and copper _ falls in between the two known categories of solids. Bell Labs' finding was published in the Jan. 8 edition of Physical Review Letters, the journal of the American Physical Society. ``It's definitely in the revolutionary category,'' said Kimmerling. ``Now we have a new material and we're anxious to find out what it will do that substances not structured like this cannot do.'' The outlook for uses of quasi-crystals is mixed. AT&T officials said the material used to make quasi-crystals is durable, lightweight and can withstand a range of temperatures, qualities valuable in making electrical fuses and resistors. But Kimmerling said any practical uses of the technology are years away. ``I don't think we're ready at this point to say ... this is where the technological impact is going to be,'' said Earle Ryba, an associate professor of metallurgy at Penn State University. Bell Labs' research also shows quasi-crystals to have an arrangement of atoms with a pentagon-shaped symmetry, which many scientists doubted could happen. Perfect five-sided shapes could not fit together without holes and breaks, but the quasi-crystal shows pentagons of many shapes and sizes comprising the atoms, AT&T officials said. ``What they have done is provide more direct experimental proof that this in fact happens,'' said Robert Metzger, a professor of chemistry and a crystallographer at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa, Ala. ``Beforehand, the experimental process used was a long-range look at the pattern,'' Metzger said. ``Now they have confirmed it in exact detail.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Tell Jurors Deliberations Are ``Give and Take''
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the assault trial of reputed mob boss John Gotti interrupted jury deliberations Wednesday evening amid reports the jurors were fighting among themselves. Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin dismissed the jury for the night, ordering them to return Thursday. ``I ask you to continue to listen,'' McLaughlin said. ``You haven't really been at it all that long.'' The jury is deliberating assault and conspiracy charges against Gotti, 49, and co-defendant Anthony Guerrieri, 61. They are charged with commissioning the Westies, an Irish-American gang, to shoot John F. O'Connor, former vice president of Carpenters Union Local 608, on May 7, 1986. He was wounded in the buttocks and survived. Prosecutors claim Gotti, alleged boss of the Gambino crime family, arranged the shooting because O'Connor ordered thugs to trash Bankers and Brokers, a mob-run restaurant that was being built with non-union labor. The judge addressed the jurors after they sent out a note about 6:30 p.m. indicating problems in their deliberations. ``I wouldn't know what's going on in there but questioning somebody's lineage or intelligence is not the way to come to grips'' with the problem, McLaughlin said. ``Jury service is a give and take, as gently as possible,'' the judge said. ``It's not a contest to see who can get in the most cutting, triumphant gibe at the end.'' The jury's note, which the judge read from the bench, said, ``I feel we have a juror who has brought a previous bias into this room. Please advise. This juror has indicated he had some opinion on guilt or innocence before the trial started.'' Notes to the judge normally are sent out by the jury foreman but the judge refused to say who had sent it out and who had signed it. The note didn't contain any reference about anyone's lineage or intelligence. The judge declined to answer reporters' questions about that, but there was an indication that McLaughlin had heard the reference about lineage and intelligence from another source. Earlier Wednesday, the judge refused a defense motion for a mistrial based on a report that some jurors would agree to talk to reporters at a news conference after the verdict, sources said. In asking for a mistrial, defense attorney Bruce Cutler said, ``We're concerned that they're more worried about becoming media stars then in being jurors.'' The case is based on secretly recorded tapes. They include conversations in which Gotti allegedly says, ``We're gonna, gonna bust him up,'' and another on which members of the Westies gang allegedly say they shot O'Connor as a favor to Gotti. The defense has ridiculed the tapes as inaudible and claims prosecutors transcribed them to suit their theory that Gotti had O'Connor shot. The prospect of a mistrial arose earlier when one of the 12 jurors was taken to a doctor at midday Wednesday, as jurors broke for lunch. If that juror were too ill to continue, an alternate could replace him or her only with the consent of the defense. The defense almost certainly would object. If convicted, Gotti could face 25 years to life in prison as a persistent felon because of convictions in 1969 and 1974. His attorneys contend Gotti is being persecuted because of his reputation. The judge told the jury they could convict the defendants only if the prosecution proved they arranged the shooting and not simply because they might be members of organized crime.

DOC.HEAD: China Says Communist Party Power Inviolable
DOC.TEXT: The government said Thursday the Communist Party will not give up its leading role in society, and that the nation would descend into chaos without the party in control. The strongly worded editorial in the party's official People's Daily came a day after the Soviet Communist Party voted to end its constitutional guarantee of power. The People's Daily editorial was a rejoinder to events in the socialist world, although it made no mention of the Soviet Union or East Europe, where the communist parties of other nations already have allowed multiparty politics. Instead, it attacked Western democracies as being playthings of the rich. China's conservative leaders have suppressed all dissent and criticism of the Communist Party since calling in the military to crush the student-led democracy movement in June. Leaders reportedly are deeply concerned that events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union could rejuvenate popular opposition to the government. The commentary was pegged to a party document made public Wednesday that urged the party to pay greater attention to the opinions of eight tiny and tame ``democracy parties'' allowed to exist after the Communist takeover in 1949. The main thrust, however, was that a Western-style multiparty system can never be accepted in China, and the Communist Party will always have a constitutionally guaranteed right to lead the nation. ``In China, without the strong leadership of the Communist Party, new turmoil and wars would surely arise, the nation would be split, and the people, not to mention state construction, would suffer again,'' the editorial said. It said party rule was ``endorsed and supported by the whole nation rather than proclaimed'' by the party. The ``elite'' who stirred up the ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' _ the official term for the student-led pro-democracy movement _ sought to deprive the party of its leading role, it said. ``Some people always think that the parliamentary democracy in the West is advantageous,'' the editorial said. But it said Western democracies were controlled by the rich and ``the broad masses of working people have never had the right to take part in the administration of state affairs. ... Those who have more money will have more freedom and have more right to talk in the democracy. Such democracy means nothing to those who do not have enough to eat.'' The editorial called on the party leadership to study the document released Wednesday, which said China's small political parties and non-communists should get more legislative and bureaucratic positions and have a voice in policy-making. The party has always stressed the consultative role of its ``united front'' _ the small parties, mass organizations, the army and regional groups. But the Communists have all leadership positions and absolute decision-making power. The eight small parties have about 300,000 members, most of whom are leftist intellectuals from pre-1949 days _ many now in their 80s. The Communist Party has 48 million members. All of the small parties pledge allegiance to Communist Party rule, and in the past four decades no new parties have been recognized.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 9-11: ``Apparently concerned,'' with further White House spin control
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he believed a reunified Germany could remain part of NATO _ perhaps a NATO somewhat different from today's alliance. ``I think it can be managed in such a way that it will not bea threat to Western Europe or the free world,'' Bush told the San Francisco Commonwealth Club. Meanwhile, Bush invited Manfred Woerner, secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to meet with him separately on the reunification issue. Woerner will visit Bush at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., this weekend, White House aides said. Kohl will confer at Camp David later this month with Bush, the White House announced. Bush told his audience that when he heard both Kohl and West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher ``talking about a Germany that remains tied in to NATO in some way _ maybe not the NATO in exactly the same form it is _ but that's encouraging,'' Bush said. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater afterward said in an elaborating statement that Bush ``meant that Germany would remain as a member of NATO, but NATO may have a changing mission.'' The changing mission would involve ``an increased political role for NATO,'' Fitzwater said. Apparently worried that Bush's words might be used by advocates of a unified Germany outside the western alliance, top officials hastened to reinforce Fitzwater's footnote during the president's flight to Omaha, Neb. on Air Force One. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft told reporters on the plane, ``The president said something which could be interpreted as being ambiguous about Germany remaining a part of NATO. Both Chancellor Kohl and Foreign Minister Genscher have said a reunififed Germany ought to be a part of NATO. We strongly support that view.'' With White House chief of staff John Sununu at his elbow, Scowcroft added that the role of the western military alliance may change. He said ``if the security situation continues to change in Europe then NATO may take on more of a political character,'' leaving unspoken the notion that the military character of NATO would be less. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is now in Moscow, reportedly carrying the outline of an allied plan on German reunification.
