One of the major stumbling blocks to union of the two Germanys is Western insistence that Germany stay in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the alliance forged after World War II to defend against attack from the communist East Bloc. The Soviets and its allied states formed the Warsaw Pact in response, but now that military pact appears to be disintegrating. The White House, in a statement, said the Feb. 24-25 visit by Kohl ``will provide an opportunity for the president and the chancellor to exchange views about prospects for German reunification, East-West relations, possibilities for further progress in arms control, objectives for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe ... assistance to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe and U.S. relations with the European community.'' East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow has called for a unified Germany that would be neutral, siding with neither NATO nor the Warsaw Pact. Genscher has floated the idea of united Germany in NATO, with NATO troops barred from what is now East Germany _ where Soviet troops might remain for a time. Baker reportedly was told by Vaclav Havel, the new president of Czechoslovakia, during a visit to Prague Tuesday thatGerman neutrality was out of the question. Bush administration officials have suggested lately that the United States might accept a reunified Germany with ``ties'' to NATO, but not formal membership.

DOC.HEAD: Former Revenue Director Charged With Felony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comments, details of charge. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Florida's former chief tax collector was charged Wednesday with falsifying records, one day after she resigned amid allegations she singled out a political opponent of her husband's for an audit. Katie Tucker was charged with one count of official misconduct for falsifying records, a felony that carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $5,000 fine, said Florida Department of Law Enforcement spokesman Mike McHargue. ``I've done no wrongdoing,'' Ms. Tucker said after she surrendered to authorities and was released on her own recognizance. ``I wish they'd just let me get on with my life.'' Ms. Tucker, 46, had headed the Department of Revenue since June 1988. She resigned her position Tuesday, two weeks after being suspended for ordering a 1988 tax probe of a political opponent of her husband, AFL-CIO state president Daniel Miller. Ms. Tucker contended the tax probe was intended to be part of a larger investigation, and was not meant to single out the businessman. According to an affidavit, Ms. Tucker produced a memo dated Dec. 21, 1988, to support her case. Authorities allege that Ms. Tucker probably wrote the memo during a night visit to her office on Jan. 31. Much of the evidence was found on a cartridge ribbon from a typewriter, according to the Department of Law Enforcement.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Gallons of Heavy Water Spills at Savannah River; Two Exposed to Radiation
DOC.TEXT: Twenty gallons of heavy water spilled at the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant Wednesday, sending a plume of radioactive tritium into the air, but there was no threat to workers or area residents, officials said. Two workers at the Savannah River Site who were splashed with the water received small doses of radidation, about the equivalent of half a chest X-ray, officials said. Crews were unable to detect radioactivity at the plant or along its boundaries, said Dennis Stevenson, manager of health protection operations for Westinghouse Savannah River Co., which operates the plant for the U.S. Department of Energy. Tritium is a highly radioactive gas used in the production of nuclear warheads and is manufactured only at the Savannah River plant. The spill occurred at 12:05 a.m. while two workers were replacing a flange, or connecting joint, on water pipes to heat exchangers on the K Reactor, one of three reactors at SRS shut down for safety modifications in 1988. About five gallons of water runoff is expected when replacing a flange, and officials said they were uncertain why 20 gallons was in the pipe. Operations at the plant were back to normal less than eight hours after the spill, and clean-up was expected to be completed by the end of the day, said John Patterson, deputy director of DOE-Savannah River Reactor Restart Special Projects Office. The spill was first declared an alert at 2:20 a.m. but was downgraded to an unusual event at 5:41 a.m., the DOE said. An unusual event is the lowest of four nuclear emergency classes. As the area where the spill occurred was ventilated through the reactor stack, monitoring equipment detected the tritium release, which triggered the alert, said Charles Peckinpaugh, deputy general manager of reactor operations A small amount of tritium, 825 curies, was released into the atmosphere, Stevenson said. Based on weather conditions, the projected radiation dose at the plant boundary was .003 millirem, ``about one-one-thousandth of the dose you would get from natural background radiation,'' he said. One worker was exposed to 10 millirem of radiation, the equivalent of half the radiation emitted during a normal chest X-ray, officials said. They said the second worker received about the same amount of radiation but had no figures. About 100 other employees were in the reactor at the time, but were not evacuated, officials said. Patterson said Westinghouse and DOE would conduct a joint investigation of the incident. The K reactor is expected to be the first of the plant's three reactors to be restarted once safety modifications are completed, possibly before the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Rocker Billy Idol Moved from Intensive Care to Own Room
DOC.TEXT: Rock star Billy Idol, who suffered a severely broken leg and a broken arm in a motorcycle accident, was moved Wednesday from intensive care to his own room as fans flooded the hospital with flowers and phone calls. ``He's alert, he's talking, but he's still listed as serious but stable,'' said Idol's publicist, Ellen Golden. Idol, 34, was recovering from seven hours of surgery for compound fractures to the right leg and a broken right forearm suffered when his Harley-Davidson motorcycle and a car crashed Tuesday morning. The switchboard at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center received more than 100 calls from fans asking where to send flowers and gifts, and flowers have already started arriving, said spokesman Ron Wise. Idol, who had just wrapped up an album called ``Charmed Life,'' was driving home from a Hollywood recording studio when he ran a stop sign and sideswiped a car, police said. The car's driver was not injured. It was not clear whether the accident would affect Idol's plans to release ``Charmed Life'' in late April and launch a concert tour in July, Golden said. Idol, known for his sneer and spiked blond hair, reached stardom with his 1984 album ``Rebel Yell,'' which produced hit songs including the title track, ``Eyes Without a Face'' and ``White Wedding.''

DOC.HEAD: Communist Leaders Agree to Give Up Monopoly on Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 9th pvs `Gorbachev has' with Brent Scowcroft saying Gorbachev got his way, SUBS 10th to conform; picks up 11th, `You don't...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1,MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party that for decades swore its red tide would cover the globe bowed to a very different revolution Wednesday, agreeing to let alternative political parties compete for control of the Soviet Union. That amounts to an acknowledgement that new political forces have taken root and no longer is possible or desirable to stamp them out with past tactics of repression that ranged from mass murder under Josef Stalin to the arrests and imprisonment preferred by Leonid I. Brezhnev. ``The party does not assume full government authority,'' Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov told a news conference, reading from notes on the final wording adopted by the party Central Committee. ``Its role is to be a political leader with no particular role to be included in the constitution,'' he said. The party will propose repeal of Article 6, which guarantees the Communists a monopoly of power. ``There will be a multiparty system; there will be a normal democracy,'' Svyatoslav Fyodorov, a noted eye surgeon and a participant, said in an interview on Red Square during a break in the closed meeting. He called the move ``fantastic.'' The nearly unanimous vote on the new party platform was a triumph of political maneuvering for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He packed the meeting of the 249-member committee with more than 700 other officials, many of them progressives who took the floor to demand radical reform. In two votes, first by the Central Committee and then by all present, only dissident Communist Boris N. Yeltsin voted against the platform, which a Central Committee source said also calls for direct election of the president. Yeltsin, who addressed a huge crowd Sunday that marched to the Kremlin to demand reform, favored an even more radical program that demanded a virtual apology by the party for decades of totalitarian rule. Gorbachev has struggled nearly five years to transform the Soviet Union into something resembling a modern democracy. He dropped his long-standing public opposition to alternative political parties only three weeks ago in Lithuania, so it was a surprise when he proposed Monday that the policy be put into law. Asked if Gorbachev got his way, Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, said in Washington, ``Well it seems that way. The outcome (is) pretty much based on the proposals that Gorbachev introduced in the Central Committee.'' Gorbachev's close Politburo ally, Alexander N. Yakovlev, said at the news conference Wednesday the move had been under consideration for some time. ``You don't really need much acumen to realize that if we are venturing on the path of democratization of the country, it is bound to affect all socio-political movements,'' Yakovlev said. ``If we were to say in 1985: Come on folks, go ahead and set up 154 parties, I can imagine the mess it would have brought about,'' he said. Yakovlev said the Soviet leaders had to reckon with their nation's history, including its democratic and anti-democratic cultures. Unlike Eastern Europe, where alternative political groups have existed for years and quickly became genuine opposition parties, the Soviet Union has no national alternative to the Communists. The party also has great financial resources and controls much of the press. Because of those factors, voters are unlikely to oust the Communists from their actual power monopoly immediately, except in regions like the Baltic republics that have strong local political movements. Constitutional changes must be approved by the Supreme Soviet legislature, which convenes next Wednesday, and the larger Congress of People's Deputies. The Congress is to meet in the spring, but could be called into special session. At its last meeting in December, the Congress heeded Gorbachev's plea for delay and blocked an effort by reformers to repeal Article 6 of the constitution. The Soviet Union already is in the midst of campaigning for local and regional elections spread over the next three months, and the Central Committee decision could cause a frenzy of organizing. ``We Communists are not going to surrender our positions. Just as any party in the world, we shall be waging a struggle for our rights,'' Politburo member Vitaly I. Vorotnikov told visiting Brazilian legislators, the official news agency Tass reported. Yakovlov said: ``This does not mean the political situation is out of control. This does not mean that we cannot lead the people.'' Instead, he said, it puts the party back in front, leading the way to democratic reform. He acknowledged the Central Committee argument was stormy, but said the final version was essentially Gorbachev's. ``A large portion'' wanted to retain Article 6 and others favored barring certain kinds of parties, he said. Yakovlev said the final platform called for banning only groups that condone ethnic strife or violent overthrow of the government. The Central Committee also decided to advance the date of the next party congress from October to the end of June. For the first time, delegates will be elected by the nation's 20 million Communists, not chosen by the leadership. Yakovlev said the congress would elect a new Central Committee and could either choose the party leader, now Gorbachev, or let the rank-and-file do so. Reformers see the committee as the bastion of conservatives wary of Gorbachev's program. The congress would give Gorbachev another chance to alter the committee. Pavel Zinoviev, party chief for the Kamchatka Peninsula in the Soviet Far East, said the committee recognized a small loyalist faction of Lithuanian Communists as the true party in the Baltic republic. He told reporters the Central Committee appealed to a larger group of Lithuanian Communists who declared themselves independent to return to the fold before the Congress, implying they could not send delegates otherwise. Officials at the news conference indicated the platform made no change in the party's opposition to private land ownership.

DOC.HEAD: Fight During Debate Between Jewish Leader, Member of Extreme Right
DOC.TEXT: A brawl broke out during a live television debate between a Jewish leader and a member of an extreme right-wing organization, and the scene was rebroadcast repeatedly Wednesday. The fight, which interrupted the weekly ``Ciel Mon Mardi'' public affairs program Tuesday, began when a spectator clambered onstage and slugged Olivier Mathieu of the right-wing National French and European Party. Mathieu had been debating the state of the far-right in France with Jewish leader Jean-Pierre Pierre-Bloch, president of Licra, the French acronym for the League Against Anti-Semitism and Racism. After Mathieu was attacked, a free-for-all broke out among other spectators and participants for about two minutes before host Christophe Dechavanne reimposed order. Mathieu left the stage and the debate continued on the show, which is broadcast over national network TF-1.

DOC.HEAD: New Honduran President Says No Permanent U.S. Bases
DOC.TEXT: President Rafael Leonardo Callejas on Wednesday described relations with Washington as ``excellent'' but said he will not allow the United States to have a permanent base in Honduras. The United States has conducted joint military maneuvers with Honduras since 1954 and has stationed 1,200 men at Palmerola air base since 1984 on a rotating basis but has no permanent installation. ``The position of my government is very clear. We are not willing to establish permanent U.S. military bases in our territory,'' Callejas said at a news conference. Callejas, who took office Jan. 27 after winning elections in November, emphasized: ``All of this is framed in the Honduran government's foreign policy.'' For two years, Washington has been pressuring Honduras to sign an agreement that would allow improvements at Palmerola, 50 miles northeast of Tegucigalpa. ``We will not negotiate with the United States about installing permanent bases,'' Callejas said. ``Military maneuvers between the United States and Honduras have a temporary, not permanent, character.'' The United States and Honduras have had joint military maneuvers for 26 years. Since then, more than 100,000 U.S. soldiers have participated in 80 maneuvers with the Honduran army's 22,000 men. ``These operations serve to improve the defensive capacity of our army and our national security,'' Callejas said. ``Relations between the United States and Honduras remain unchanged and excellent.'' During the campaign last year both Callejas and the candidate of the governing Liberal Party, Carlos Flores, were U.S.-trained engineers with relatively conservative economic views and pro-U.S. foreign policies but opposed to making Palmerola a permanent U.S. base.

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet to Remain Army Chief `As Long As Necessary'
DOC.TEXT: President Augusto Pinochet said Wednesday he will remain as army commander ``as long as necessary'' after relinquishing the presidency next month because of the threat of the ``Marxist germ.'' Pinochet told a group of women in Iquique, 1,150 miles north of the capital, that the danger of Marxism has diminished as a result of the democratic changes in eastern Europe. But, he added, ``We still have to be careful, because this threat can persist. The Marxist germ is the danger, and women must always be alert.'' Pinochet is in Iquique as part of a nationwide farewell tour he organized under the motto, ``Mission accomplished.'' He told the women that some leftist exiles who have recently returned from exile are planning to kill him. ``They have returned with hatred, and I understand that,'' he said. ``They want to kill me, and I also understand that. They say they have sentenced me. I thank them for the information, but I know things are like that, and I am not afraid.'' Pinochet survived an assasination attempt in September 1986, but six of his bodyguards were killed. Several leftist guerrillas who participated in that attack escaped from a Santiago prison last week and one, Victor Diaz Caro, sent a recorded tape to local newspapers saying ``the death sentence of Pinochet is still pending.'' Pinochet, who seized power in a 1973 coup that toppled elected Marxist President Salvador Allende, is scheduled to relinquish the presidency on March 11 to Patricio Aylwin, a centrist leader who won a landslide election victory in December. Pinochet was obliged to call the election after losing a referendum in October 1988 on a military proposal to extend his rule until 1997. The 74-year-old general called the 1973 coup ``not only a national victory, but a world victory. We were the first ones to defeat Marxism, and we now see that our desires and aspirations are the same desires and aspirations of the (Eastern) European peoples, who are throwing away the Communist yoke.'' The 1980 constitution written by his military regime allows Pinochet to remain as head of the powerful 65,000-men army for eight more years after stepping down from the presidency. He has vowed to stay, dismissing a plea by Aylwin to retire. In a face-to-face meeting last December, Aylwin told Pinochet his continuation as army chief would be ``inconvenient, both for the army and for the country.'' Pinochet replied that, as head of the army, he would be ``the best guarantee for the stability'' of the Aylwin government. ``I`m going to continue always to your service, until the end of my days, as long as I can,'' Pinochet told the women in Iquique. Pinochet said he may soon move his residence, and probably the army command headquarters, to Iquique, and establish the first army corps.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Convicted in Disappearance of Wealthy Woman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf, ``He had...1988,' to UPDATE with defense considering appeal; picks up 6th graf, `Winn is ...' INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf, `The 74-year-old ...,' to UPDATE with son's comment; picks up 9th graf pvs: `U.S. District...
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Wednesday convicted a Florida attorney in the 1988 disappearance of a Jackson multimillionaire's wife. The jury found Newton Alfred Winn, 65, guilty of one count each of conspiracy to kidnap, extortion and perjury around 6 p.m. after about 3{ of deliberations. Winn sat impassively as the jurors were polled. In closing arguments earlier in the day, the prosecution said the St. Petersburg, Fla., attorney blamed his financial woes on Annie Laurie Hearin's husband. ``He had a motivation of revenge,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Patricia Bennett said after telling jurors jury how and why the government claimed Winn abducted the woman on July 26, 1988. Defense attorneys said the government has the wrong man. John Collette, one of Winn's attorneys, said an appeal was likely. Winn is accused of conspiracy in having a ransom letter mailed from Atlanta on Aug. 11, 1988. He also is charged with extortion and lying to a federal grand jury about his knowledge of the case. No one has been charged with actually abducting Mrs. Hearin. The 74-year-old Mrs. Hearin, wife of Robert Hearin, hasn't been seen since she disappeared from her Jackson home following a bridge party with friends. Doctors have said the woman had a health problem that required daily medication. After the verdict was read, the woman's son, Robert Hearin Jr. said the family had been informed that the search for Mrs. Hearin was still active. ``The investigation into whatever happened to my mother is continuing, and on that basis, I am pleased with the result reached today.'' U.S. District Judge Tom S. Lee gave final instructions to the jurors, explaining each of the three counts of the indictment against Winn. On hand for instructions and final arguments were two key government witnesses: Don Ward, who once worked for Winn; and Marilyn Taylor, who describes herself as a one-time lover of the defendant and who has testified that she mailed a letter which prosecutors say was a ransom note. A splattering of blood was found on the front door of the Hearin home along with another ransom note demanding that Hearin reimburse 12 individuals, including Winn, for losses they suffered in dealings with School Pictures of Mississippi Inc., a firm in which Winn was once a primary stockholder. Winn ``blamed Mr. Hearin for all of his problems with School Pictures,'' Bennett said. ``This case is about the kidnapping of Annie Laurie Hearin,'' Bennett said. ``This case is about this defendant conspiring to kidnap her. This case is about this defendant causing a letter to be mailed from Atlanta for the return of Mrs. Hearin. This case is about this defendant. . . lying under oath.'' Defense Attorney Ed Marger, describing the case as having a ``Perry Mason scenario,'' charged that the government based its case on questionable witnesses and physical evidence that prosecutors later attempted to downplay. During seven days of testimony, jurors were treated to a soap opera-style plot that included a two-state love affair between Winn, 65, and Taylor, 29, of De Land, Fla. Taylor testified she disguised herself and mailed the ransom note, and said she and Winn once plotted to kill her former husband, Mark Phillips. In his closing arguments, Marger repeatedly attacked the credibility of Taylor, who testified after receiving immunity from prosecution. He also said tapes of converstions between Winn and Taylor made by the FBI and introduced into the trial revealed nothing other than the defendant saying such things as, ``I don't know what you are talking about.'' Marger said: ``The truth is what this case is all about, but so is proof.''

Congressional Democrats are raising images of democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and the U.S. civil rights movement to pressure President Bush into backing a House-passed bill easing voter registration. Over the objections of the White House and some other top Republicans, the House approved the legislation 289-132 on Tuesday and sent the measure to the Senate. Sixty-one of the chamber's 175 Republicans broke with party leaders to vote for the proposal. The so-called motor voter bill requires states to include voting registration forms with drivers' license applications and to establish procedures to sign up voters by mail and at numerous government offices. It would take effect in January 1993. States would have to search voting lists at least once every four years for people who have moved or have registered fraudulently. The federal government would provide up to $50 million to help states pay for the new procedures.

Mailing a love letter, paying the phone bill and chewing out your congressman likely will cost more next year _ postage rates appear headed up again. The Postal Service is poised to launch the long, complex process of raising prices on March 6. Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank says a 30-cent stamp seems likely for first class mail in 1991, although the final price could be from 28 cents to 32 cents. First class postage rose to the current 25-cent rate on April 3, 1988. If things follow the normal course, the new charges would take effect about 11 months after the filing, or in February 1991.

Arizona's voter-approved ``Official English'' law is kaput. Finis. Finito. Terminado. U.S. District Court Judge Paul Rosenblatt threw out the law on free speech grounds Tuesday, and Gov. Rose Mofford _ the only person with legal standing to appeal _ said she would let the ruling stand. ``I am happy the courts ruled it unconstitutional,'' Mrs. Mofford said in a brief statement. She said she considered the law, which made English the state's official language, ``flawed from the beginning.'' Backers of the measure said the Democratic governor should appeal the decision, noting a state court had upheld the measure's constitutionality last year and because similar laws in 16 other states had been allowed to stand.

Blacks are twice as likely as whites to have vision problems that cannot be corrected with glasses, according to a survey of more than 5,300 people over age 40. The study's authors could not explain the finding and were ``in the process of exploring what those reasons might be,'' said James A. Tielsch, co-author of the study that appears in this month's Archives of Ophthalmology. It was conducted over a four-year period in east Baltimore, a working-class section, and was designed to provide data typical of multiracial urban populations in the United States, said Tielsch, an ophthalmology professors at Johns Hopkins' Wilmer Eye Institute. Almost 12 percent of those studied were visually impaired even though they wore glasses and saw an eye doctor regularly.

DOC.TEXT: The former president of the Southern Baptist Woman's Missionary Union has endorsed a moderate candidate for the denomination's presidency and said she's willing to run as his vice president. Carolyn Weatherford Crumpler, who for 15 years headed the WCTU until last year, endorsed the Rev. Daniel Vestal for the top post from the pulpit of his church in suburban Dunwoody, and said she was ready to run with him. Fundamentalists have won the presidency of the 14.8 million-member denomination for the past decade, achieving majorities among trustees of the denomination's institutions and agencies. Mrs. Crumpler, married last summer to a Cincinnati pastor after she left leadership of the women's organization, said she is concerned because a ``takeover'' group has muzzled denominational executives and the denomination's news agency, Baptist Press. Vestal, who narrowly lost the presidency last year to the fundamentalist incumbent, the Rev. Jerry Vines, said he had asked Mrs. Crumpler to work with him and seek the vice presidency to bring reconciliation to the faction-torn denomination. Its annual convention comes this June in New Orleans.

Chicago Catholic Women, an organization advocating fuller women's rights in Roman Catholicism, urges the church to open its all-male priesthood to women and creation of a new seminary system to train them.

A TV-monitoring organization, Christian Leaders for Responsibile Television (CLeaR-TV), reports that the amount of sex, violence and profanity on all three major networks dropped 32 percent last fall from that in the previous spring season. ``The dramatic drop ... from the spring monitoring to the fall monitoring shows the direct impact which the CLeaR-TV boycott is having,'' said the Rev. Billy A. Melvin, chairman of the group, which includes leaders of most denominations. It has urged boycotts of some products because sponsored shows were found to contain high amounts of material considered objectionable. Melvin called the results ``a successful first step toward television programming that is not so destructive to the quality of life we enjoy in this country.''

Jewish, Moslem and Christian leaders participate this Sunday and Monday in a convocation on peace in the Middle East, supporting both secure borders for Israel and Palestinian rights to a homeland in the West Bank and Gaza. Expressions of that view by representatives of all three groups should ``encourage a much more active U.S. role in prusuit of this vision of peace,'' said Ronald Young, executive director of the interreligious committee sponsoring the affair.

United Methodists gave $115.8 million in 1989 to support their denomination's domestic and international programs, up 9 percent from the $106.3 million in 1988, reports the church's council on finance and administration.

Several Roman Catholic scholars have criticized a Vatican-issued draft of a proposed universal catechism that has been distributed to bishops for their reactions. Following a symposium, the scholars told a news conference there were serious deficiencies in the document, particuarly in failing to make distinctions between essential truths of faith and peripheral elements. The 430-page document is intended as a comprehensive summary of Catholic beliefs. Lawrence Cunningham, a theology professor at the University of Notre Dame, said one of the document's ``most glaring weaknesses'' is that it ``suffers from what computer people would call an `information overload''' lacking guidance on ``what's more important and what's less important.'' Bishops are supposed to submit responses by May 31. Bishop Rayumond F. Lucker of New Ulm, Minn., who participated in the symposium, said, ``I'm hoping there will be substantial changes.''

DOC.HEAD: Protestants Credit Mom For Faith But It's Found Limited
DOC.TEXT: Ask 10,000 people what or who had the most positive influence on their religious faith, and the most likely answer for every age group, men and women, boys and girls, is ``my mother.'' That _ which traditional sentiment always has assumed _ is among the findings of one of the largest, most comprehensive studies ever made of faith and its development among Americans. A full report of the 3{-year study won't be disclosed until a national conference March 24-27 in St. Louis, but some of its conclusions are being circulated and discussed. While it turned up numerous previously indicated conditions, some of them, when laid out in hard, overwhelming statistics, come as a bit of a shocker. One of these is that only a third of U.S. Protestants have what is termed an ``integrated faith'' that embraces both basic beliefs and their practical implications in life. Another somewhat surprising conclusion is that what matters most in building mature faith is not the commonly emphasized classes for the young _ important as they are _ but adult Christian education. Further, this most important stage of learning is found to be widely neglected in the churches. The huge, landmark study, involving completion of 374-question questionnaires by 10,000 church people bringing out information never available before about beliefs and values, was made by the Search Institute of Minneapolis. It was sponsored by six mainline Protestant denominations through a grant from the Lilly Endowment, Inc. Titled ``Effective Christian Education: A National Study of Protestant Congregations,'' the project also probed the methods, programs and activities of congregations in conducting educational work. In addition, trained observers visited 54 congregations with exceptionally strong educational programs to examine and describe the techniques that are getting results. Peter Benson, president of the institute that made the study, said it found ``that faith is not particulary well-developed'' in many church members, and programs to develop it are ``less than effective.'' ``Unless this issue is faced head-on in the early '90s, members will increasingly drop away or seek spiritual nurture elsewhere,'' he writes in The Lutheran, organ of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. It and other denominations involved in the study have been declining in membership for about 20 years. The others are the United Methodist Church, Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), United Church of Christ, Episcopal Church and Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). In the study, faith was examined in two basic dimensions, one called ``vertical,'' involving personal relationship to God, and the other ``horizontal,'' involving active commitment to social service and justice. About a third of church members scored low on both dimensions, reflecting an ``undeveloped faith'' both in belief and in translating it into action. Another third showed a one-dimensional faith, usually holding firm beliefs but not seeking much application in life. Only a third were found to have a balance of both dimensions, a mature ``integrated faith.'' ``There is evidence of great hesitance to connect one's faith to one's community, work or politics,'' writes Benson. ``Combine this with the reluctance to talk about one's faith and it seems that many adults hold a private faith. ``They are unsure how to go public in words or actions. ``For many, faith lies dormant, waiting for nudges, inspirations, revelations and personal experiences to help it develop. It is private and quiet, more in the head than the heart and hands and feet, uncomfortable in its dormancy but afraid to let go.'' Despite the two-thirds found with one-dimensional or undeveloped faith, the study found that the proportion of those with a mature, integrated faith increases with age, from youth onward. Also women were found to have a higher faith level than men. The study also found that growth in mature faith depended not so much on the warmth and friendliness of a congregation, but on the degree to which it challenges thinking and encourages questions. Of such stimulating programs, Benson writes: ``Members are challenged to think, discuss, debate and even argue about the stuff of faith, including values, theological issues, politics and Scripture. There is active intellectual engagement.'' Benson and Carolyn H. Eklin, the institute's director of survey services, said one reason church members rarely named Christian education as significantly influencing them is they've had so little of it. In a year's time, adults average a total of no more than 11 to 20 hours in Christian educational efforts. Consequently, it scarcely got a mention when people were asked to choose, among 30 potential influences, the five with the most postive impact on their faith. Below the top-ranked ``my mother,'' men ranked their spouse, father, pastor and worship services, while women listed God's presence, worship, prayer, and last, their father.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Budget Revives Line-Item Veto Issue
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Tucked away in President Bush's budget there's a proposal that would give the White House power to trim and tailor federal spending and tax bills with itemized vetoes. It isn't going to happen. But it revives a handy,standby issue for the Republican administration. Bush and Ronald Reagan have been campaigning for years for changes in the way the government decides how much to spend and how to spend it. ``Earlier in our history there was an unwritten law that the annual budget should be balanced except in time of war or depression,'' according to the new Bush administration budget. ``That law is no longer honored, and only a change in the Constitution is likely to assure a return to habitually balanced budgets.'' Bush wants a balanced budget amendment and another to give presidents the power to veto specific items in an appropriations bill without rejecting the whole bill. His budget says that also should apply to bills that authorize federal programs with automatic spending provisions. And he wants presidents to have the same authority over revenue measures, which means tax bills. All of that would change the balance of legislative power. Item vetoes could be overridden by two-thirds votes in both houses of Congress. But a congressional majority could no longer force a president to accept something he doesn't want in order to get things he seeks. That's the kind of forced compromise that goes on every session, and it may indeed be one of the reasons the federal budget has been balanced only once in the past 30 years. But it also would cede powers that no Congress is likely to yield to the executive branch. That goes double for a Democratic Congress in the era of Republican presidencies. ``The president, as representative of the general interest, should have the power to strike from legislation provisions that reflect only narrow local or special interests,'' the administration argues. The Democrats aren't about to accept the premise that the president represents the national interest while Congress caters to parochial, special interests. Not that it isn't true at times. But so is the reverse. And the debate about which are special and which are national interests is part of the political process. Forty-three state governors have the line-item veto power Bush wants bestowed on presidents. But state laws vary, and most of them provide ways to settle differences on veto targets through reconsideration and compromise. The White House said last fall that Bush might try to exercise the power without a change in the law or the Constitution, just to see if it would work. Democrats replied that they would challenge any such action in court. The Supreme Court never has addressed the question directly, but it did rule in 1975 that Richard M. Nixon had exceeded his authority when he refused to spend funds Congress had appropriated for state water pollution projects. The Bush budget seems to concede that it can't be done under current law, saying that ``the time has come to amend the Constitution and achieve this change.'' The balanced budget amendment doesn't quite match its name; the version the administration pushed during the Reagan years would make deficits more difficult, but would not necessarily end them. It would require three-fifths votes of both House and Senate to approve deficit spending except in time of war. Reagan made the balanced budget amendment a major, repeating issue during his two terms while federal deficits were soaring. The Senate approved it once, and came close a second time, both while Republicans held the control they lost in the 1986 elections. Reagan never could get it to a House vote. Bush advocates a balanced budget amendment with a built-in renewal of his central campaign pledge: ``It should include safeguards against achieving the balance through higher taxes.'' Forty-nine states require balanced budgets; Vermont is the lone exception. The requirement is written into 42 state constitutions; the rest have balanced budget laws. State rules and enforcement provisions vary widely. In a study published by the conservative Heritage Foundation, budget analyst Stephen Moore says the federal government should enact state-style spending and deficit restraints because the states have demonstrated that they can work. A 1985 law requires automatic spending cuts if the government fails to meet deficit reduction goals, but both Congress and the administration have used loopholes and gimmicks to meet the target estimates. And actual deficits have exceeded the limits every year anyhow. Nevertheless, Moore said, that law has helped restrain deficits, and the other measures would serve the same purpose. ``The federal budget process suffers from too little discipline, not too much,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Move Over, Flintstones, ``The Simpsons'' Have Arrived
DOC.TEXT: ``The Simpsons,'' five pop-eyed suburbanites with funny overbites and bad hair, could become America's favorite TV family _ and the biggest prime-time cartoon hit _ since ``The Flintstones.'' ``Unquestionably, Fox has a hit of the first magnitude,'' said David Marans, media research chief for J. Walter Thompson advertising. It even could outshine Fox's other hit, ``Married .. . with Children,'' he said. The Fox Broadcasting cartoon series, shown on Sunday nights, is, as the Monty Python gang used to say, something completely different. Homer Simpson is an accident-prone supervisor at the local nuclear power plant, Martha is his unenlightened hausfrau, Lisa is a Good Little Girl, Bart is a pre-teen rebel and Maggie, well, Maggie sucks on her pacifier. They bear no resemblance to those Stone Age suburbanites Fred and Wilma Flintstone, who came to prime time in 1960 from Hanna-Barbera Productions and stayed for six years, then lived on through syndication. The Simpsons blunder through a surreal suburbia with a vague sense that Something is Wrong in the Republic, a key theme of their creator, ``Life in Hell'' cartoonist Matt Groening (rhymes with ``complaining,'' as he has noted). Not everyone is comfortable with its satire of American culture, but it's well-animated, with colors that glow and dazzle, and the cutting humor underlines a basic affection for things Simpsonian. It is clever writing. It's also clever programming, said Betsy Frank, a senior media analyst for the giant Saatchi and Saatchi advertising conglomerate, because it appeals to the young, hip audience that Fox so very much wants to attract. Ms. Frank said Fox deserves its reputation for taking risks with ``The Simpsons'' and other unconventional programs. ``Granted, they had not a lot to lose,'' she said, ``but this is certainly a risk that's paid off for them.'' ``The Simpsons'' began Dec. 11 as the No. 1 show in its early prime-time Sunday slot in the key demographic groups of adults 18 to 49, teen-age boys and girls, and children, said Fox Entertainment Group president Peter Chernin. ``The only thing it wasn't No. 1 in was adults 55 and over,'' Chernin said. ``I think this looks like a big hit show.'' The show's Christmas special helped lead Fox to its highest-rated Sunday evening. On Feb. 4, ``The Simpsons'' beat competing ABC and NBC sitcoms in its time period, finishing a distant second to CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote,'' which is aimed at older viewers. ```The Simpsons' has done better among men 18 to 49 than such notable hits as `Golden Girls,' Bill Cosby, `L.A. Law' and `60 Minutes,''' Marans said. ``What's really impressive about this is that Fox isn't available in about 12 percent of the country.'' ``I don't think we expected to do quite this well,'' Chernin said. Indeed, it's heady stuff for a company that, as he put it, ``had trouble premiering a show to a 10 share,'' 10 percent of the audience in a given time period. Running against the Jan. 28 Super Bowl blowout, ``The Simpsons'' had a 17 share, and it consistently has placed in the high teens or low 20s. ``I would be thrilled if it keeps at the same level,'' Chernin said. ``The Simpsons'' began life as ``bumpers,'' brief segments that cushioned the commercials, on ``The Tracey Ullmann Show,'' but it was announced last March that the cartoon family would venture out on its own. John Rohr, a programming consultant for Blair Television, which represents 145 television stations, said it's too early to tell whether ``The Simpsons'' is a hit. ``I think that it's still being sampled,'' he said. ``I am encouraged by the numbers,'' Rohr said. ``Certainly you feel a lot better seeing big numbers early on than you do by seeing small numbers.'' Several major animation houses _ most notably the Disney Studios and Hanna-Barbera _ have prime-time animation projects in the works, but are not discussing them. ``When a program is extremely innovative, you run the risk that it's going to peak,'' Ms. Frank said, citing ``Miami Vice,'' the pastel-hued police drama that built an audience in its first two seasons, then steadily declined. ``As long as the writing stays good,'' she said, ``I can't see why it wouldn't perform like any good situation comedy, because that's absolutely all that it is _ a situation comedy that happens to be animated.'' __ Elsewhere in television ... DEPT. OF SIBYL THE SOOTHSAYER: CBS News' ``48 Hours'' is devoting tonight's show to psychic phenonema, including telepathy, clairvoyance and telekinesis. There's no word yet on whether any clairvoyants interviewed for the show know in advance its ratings. KOPPEL IN SOUTH AFRICA: Ted Koppel, who celebrates his 50th birthday today in South Africa, tonight will anchor the second of six ``Nightline'' broadcasts from that racially segregated country. The final broadcast, on Feb. 14, will be a South African ``Town Meeting'' from Johannesburg.

DOC.TEXT: The trouble with many young TV executives is that they revert to their happy childhood memories when the ratings dragon roars. Bring back the old shows, they think, and the bad dragon will go away. This might explain why CBS, which will unleash a new ``Love Boat'' movie Monday and plans a TV movie based on the ``Green Acres'' series, is offering a TV movie tonight about the Brady bunch of yesteryear, ``The Bradys.'' This all-American clan already has been in two series and one short-lived variety series. Isn't that enough? Nooo. They had a Christmas movie two years ago and it made the ratings dragon go away. Ergo, here we go again. True, knocking ``The Bradys'' is like drop-kicking a wounded butterfly. But tonight's two-hour premiere of their new Friday series is so dim it's not even suitable for goofing on. But it does show the passage of time. Middle-class Mom and Pop (Florence Henderson and Robert Reed of the original cast), parents of six children, now are grandparents. Their kids are all grown, most are middle-class and all have problems of their own. Oh drat, we gave away the plot. However, those who decide to practice tuba tonight instead of watching this show should know they'll miss its major crisis, which occurs because Bobby the Youngest (Mike Lookinland) is a rookie race-car driver. He's facing The Big Race, the Nashville 500. Most of the family is watching, in person or via TV. His disc jockey sister (Susan Olsen), in Nashville to broadcast the race for her station, urges listeners to ``Root along with me! Yayyyyyy, Bobby!'' Bobby gets in his stock car. The starter says ``Gentlemen, start your engines.'' Then the track announcer says, ``And there's the famous call for `Gentlemen, start your engines.''' All this means the race will begin. A few laps, then it's uh-oh time, screeching tires, crunching metal. There's a pause in the action. The track announcer says ``Boy, this is a full-course yellow.'' A little Brady asks, ``Is Uncle Bobby going to be okay?'' Later, Uncle Bobby, in his hospital bed, also wonders. He asks his anxious parents, ``Mom, Dad ... am I going to walk again?'' Only time and therapy will tell. But at least it draws the family together to gently illustrate the problems of the disabled, resolve lesser crises that have been brewing, and provide a sure cure for insomnia. There are many lesser crises to pick from. The one that stands out seems to have become Topic A in shows about thirtysomething married couples _ the desire of yuppie wives to have a baby before it's Too Late. Here, the wife is Jan (Eve Plumb), an architect wed to Phillip (Ron Kuhlman), a college professor. Every time she ovulates, she summons him and they rush home and hop into bed. But no baby. Not even a romantic sea voyage does the trick. This lovemaking by the numbers gets kind of grim for him, even though she smiles a lot. He asks if there cannot be just a bit more romance. She smiles and says this: ``Phillip, we tried romantic even on the ship. No baby. Now's the time for persistence. Remember _ the tick, tick, tick of that old biological clock.'' The show might have been better had one of Bobby's lines gone to Jan's sex-wearied husband, who could ask his parents-in-law: ``Mom, Dad ... am I going to walk again?'' But let us count our blessings, even though we're no good at fractions. The Bradys aren't entirely whitebread now. Bobby's chief mechanic in tonight's show is black. One character who probably will marry into the family is Jewish. And a little Korean girl joins the cast at the finale, which also features a wedding because TV executives thinking weddings increase ratings. This one includes singing by Henderson. On the bright side, she doesn't sing ``Feelings.'' We know you'll want to tune in for next week's episode of ``The Bradys,'' in which the crisis is the city's plan to run a freeway right through Ma and Pa Brady's posh suburban neighbhood. You may root for the freeway. __ Elsewhere in television ... WHERE THEY ARE NOW: Former NBC Sports correspondent Bill Macatee, who left the Peacock Network to be one of four anchors on ``USA Today on TV,'' is back in the sporting life following the demise of that syndicated series. He has signed on with the USA Network, hosting its coverage of the golf matches the cable network will show this year.

DOC.HEAD: Jamaicans Told To Tighten Their Belts
By ROBERT GLASS
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: While the moneyed people from elsewhere crowd their beaches and resorts, Jamaicans are being told by the year-old government of Prime Minister Michael Manley to tighten their belts. Manley is imposing harsh austerity measures to satisfy Western creditors and cope with Jamaica's crippling $4.3 billion deficit. The measures include a 19.5 perscent increase in the price of basic foodstuffs like flour and cornmeal, an average 32.5 percent rise in electricity rates and a 50 percent surcharge on dozens of luxury items such as Christmas tree lights and TV satellite dishes. The government also devalued the Jamaican dollar by 7.1 percent, to 7 per U.S. dollar from 6.50, to dampen demand for imports and ease a chronic shortage of foreign exchange. It was the latest round in a series of price rises and monetary controls, including higher interest rates, imposed by Manley since returning to power in a landslide election victory Feb. 9, 1989. His repeated manipulation of the economy, which officials acknowledge has hurt the poor most, has cut into his popularity. A poll late last year by political analyst Carl Stone, who has accurately predicted election outcomes since the 1970s, indicated that 52 percent of Jamaican voters were not satisfied with Manley's People's National Party government, 40 percent were satisfied and the remainder were undecided. Columnist Byron Buckley, writing in the Sunday Gleaner, an independent weekly, accused the prime minister of failing to follow through on his party's election campaign slogan to ``put the people first.'' ``Never before in the nation's history has a newly elected government proceeded so quickly to renege on the basic tenet of the election platform,'' Buckley wrote. Jamaican business and political leaders said, however, that in his first year Manley has thoroughly lived up to his pledge to abandon the radical socialism of his previous two administrations in the 1970s. In those years, Manley appropriated private farms, heavily taxed business and forged close ties with Cuba's Fidel Castro, antagonizing the United States and Western investors and pushing Jamaica to the edge of economic collapse. Many say the cost-cutting, free-enterprise regimen of Manley's new social democratic administration is barely distinguishable from that of his predecessor, the conservative Edward Seaga of the Jamaica Labor Party, who during the eight years in office was regarded as former President Ronald Reagan's closest ally in the Caribbean. ``It was amazing, I never thought he could do it,'' Anthony Barnes president of the influential Jamaica Manufacturer's Association, said of Manley's political conversion. ``As a businessman, I unhesitatingly say that I find the new Manley a very refreshing individual.'' Indeed, Barnes said, Manley's government has been ``a lot more responsive and a lot more willing to listen to the productive sector.'' ``I consider it to be a major and significant difference between the two leaders,'' Barnes said. In foreign affairs, Manley has fostered good relations with the Bush administration and assumed a high profile in the drug war, winning United Nations approval for a proposed global anti-narcotics strike force. Barnes and others said the Manley administration still appears to be feeling its way and has not yet demonstrated the decisiveness and managerial competence of the Seaga team. ``There is an image problem with this goverment that they may not have the discipline to handle the really difficult problems,'' Barnes said. The opposition doesn't see it that way. ``You get the impression that this government is in a quandary and doesn't know what it's doing,'' said Bruce Golding, chairman of Seaga's Jamaica Labor Party. ``Ineptitude is perhaps an appropriate team to use.'' In a speech Jan. 28 preparing the nation for the belt-tightening, Manley said he was being forced to take the action under terms of a 15-month agreement with the International Monetary Fund. The agreement, which went into effect Jan. 1, provides a $108 million loan and was required for negotiations with commercial banks on rescheduling of $400 million of Jamaica's foreign debt and for any new loans from the World Bank and European and Caribbean lending agencies. The government contends it has been forced to make repeated economic adjustments because of pressure arising from Jamaica's foreign debt, which doubled during Seaga's years. With 2.4 million people, Jamaica has one of the world's largest per capita debts, brought on mainly by soaring oil prices in the 1970s and the near-collapse of the Jamaican bauxite industry in the 1980s. Nearly 50 cents of every dollar coming into the Treasury is used to pay interest on the debt. In addition, Jamaica imports 100 percent of its energy needs, mostly oil, which must be paid for in U.S. dollars. Without the IMF agreement, Manly said in his speech, ``Jamaica would be in serious trouble in four weeks or less.'' He added that it was a matter of ``nothing less than self-preservation.'' The new austerity measures had long been expected and immediate criticism was subdued. The government avoided any immediate rise in gasoline prices, which was the trigger for widespread civil unrest in 1985. To further soften the blow, the government amended its wage-price guidelines to allow unions to negotiate for pay raises of 12.5 percent, up from the previous 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Firings High Among Baptist Pastors; Half of Victims Quit Ministry
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Congregations hold a potential ax over the careers of Baptist pastors and many times, swing it. Often it's a shock to the victim. He hadn't foreseen it. But he's out by choice of his flock. Such terminations have become a painful problem in the big Southern Baptist Convention, hundreds of whose pastors are summarily fired each year by disgruntled congregations. ``It's personally and professionally shattering for the minister,'' says the Rev. Ernest O. White, director of the Dehoney Center for Study of the Local Church. ``It's traumatic for him and his family. ``It's also detrimental to the church. The name of Christian faith is scarred by that kind of thing.'' However, unlike most major denominations, Baptists in their organizational system stress the autonomy of local congregations, free to hire or fire their pastors at will, without intervention. ``Our polity declares that the pastor must be reasonably pleasing to the congregation,'' White said in an interview. ``This places some limits on the pastor in confronting controversial subjects.'' In Roman Catholic, Eastern Orthodox and United Methodist churches, bishops designate pastors. In the United Church, Lutheran, Presbyterian and Episcopal churches, it's a mutual procedure of congregations and overseeing entities. But for Baptists and various independent-style churches, it's solely up to the local congregation to pick or oust a pastor, and Baptist studies have found that the toll of dismissals is immense. A 1988 study found that more than 2,100 pastors were fired during an 18-month period. That means 116 ministers were fired each month, a 31 percent increase over the rate found in a 1984 study. ``Most every one of them is a tragedy in our view of the experience,'' said White, whose center recently did a special study of such firings in Missouri. ``It's detrimental both to the church and the ministers.'' The 14.8 million-member denomination, the country's largest Protestant body, has about 37,000 local congregations. White said the center's Missouri study found that about half the ousted pastors eventually find other pulpits, but the other half are lost to the ministry and go into other kinds of work. ``After they've had their dream of being a minister, after four years of college and three years of seminary, they get busted,'' he said. It's also after an average five years in the ministry, the study found. White, who teaches preaching at the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary in Louisville, Ky., where the study center is situated, said the blame can lie with either side. However, he said ``many congregations have a kind of conflict mentality that repeat these firings.'' They often are engineered ``by factions and power groups that want to control the church more than by leadership of the pastor.'' Some other congregations have a ``winning coach'' view that causes the trouble, he said. ``If the church isn't growing numerically, or winning, then get rid of the leader and get another one.'' They see ``expansionism as the only criteria of validity,'' even in areas not conducive to expansion, he said, and put all the responsibility for it on the pastor, rather than seeing the congregation's part in the task. The study found that most ousted pastors have full seminary training and in their seminary idealism couldn't ``conceive the possibility that life in the parish would be rough and tumble,'' White said. ``But politics in the churches is not too different from politics in the courthouse.'' Pastors also can sometimes be at fault in being either ``too authoritarian or too self-effacing and paralyzed in their leadership,'' he said. ``These are ditches on either side of the road.'' Also, most ousted pastors, apparently not adequately sensitive to member attitudes, weren't even aware of a problem in advance, he said. ``The first time they knew they had a problem is when they were asked to resign.'' White, 60, a pastor himself for 32 years, said the relationship between a pastor and congregation is somewhat like a marriage and the partners need to get better acquainted before sealing their pact. To try to ease the problem, state directors of missions are now sometimes invited by congregations to intervene in difficulties about the pastor and seek a solution, he said. ``This is one of the hopeful signs,'' White said. He himself often serves as a consultant-adviser in such situations. But such interventions can only be at invitation of congregations, and that usually comes when the situation has deteriorated too far to repair. Such intervention by regional ministers to forestall and mediate such conflicts has become customary procedure in another denomination whose policy provides congregational autonomy _ the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ).

DOC.TEXT: Several Roman Catholic scholars have criticized a Vatican-issued draft of a proposed universal catechism that has been distributed to bishops for their reactions. Following a symposium, the scholars said at a news conference that there were serious deficiencies in the document, particuarly in failing to make distinctions between essential truths of faith and peripheral elements. The 430-page document is intended as a comprehensive summary of Catholic beliefs. Lawrence Cunningham, a theology professor at the University of Notre Dame, said one of the document's ``most glaring weaknesses'' is that it ``suffers from what computer people would call an `information overload,''' lacking guidance on ``what's more important and what's less important.'' Bishops are supposed to submit responses by May 31. Bishop Rayumond F. Lucker of New Ulm, Minn., who participated in the symposium, said, ``I'm hoping there will be substantial changes.''

United Methodists gave $115.8 million in 1989 to support their denomination's domestic and international programs, up 9 percent from the $106.3 million in 1988, the church's council on finance and administration says.

Jewish, Moslem and Christian leaders are participating Sunday and Monday in a convocation on peace in the Middle East, supporting both secure borders for Israel and Palestinian rights to a homeland in the West Bank and Gaza. Expressions of that view by representatives of all three groups should ``encourage a much more active U.S. role in pursuit of this vision of peace,'' said Ronald Young, executive director of the interreligious committee sponsoring the affair.

A TV-monitoring organization, Christian Leaders for Responsibile Television, says the amount of sex, violence and profanity on all three major networks dropped 32 percent last fall from that in the previous spring season. ``The dramatic drop ... from the spring monitoring to the fall monitoring shows the direct impact which the Clear-TV boycott is having,'' said the Rev. Billy A. Melvin, chairman of the group, which includes leaders of most denominations. It has urged boycotts of some products because sponsored shows were found to contain high amounts of material considered objectionable. Melvin called the results ``a successful first step toward television programming that is not so destructive to the quality of life we enjoy in this country.''

Chicago Catholic Women, an organization advocating fuller women's rights in Roman Catholicism, has urged the church to open its all-male priesthood to women and creation of a new seminary system to train them.

The former president of the Southern Baptist Woman's Missionary Union has endorsed a moderate candidate for the denomination's presidency and said she is willing to run as his vice president. Carolyn Weatherford Crumpler, who for 15 years headed the WMU until last year, endorsed the Rev. Daniel Vestal for the top post from the pulpit of his church in suburban Dunwoody, and said she was ready to run with him. Fundamentalists have won the presidency of the 14.8 million-member denomination for the past decade, achieving majorities among trustees of the denomination's institutions and agencies. Mrs. Crumpler, married last summer to a Cincinnati pastor after she left leadership of the women's organization, said she is concerned because a ``takeover'' group has muzzled denominational executives and the denomination's news agency, Baptist Press. Vestal, who narrowly lost the presidency last year to the fundamentalist incumbent, the Rev. Jerry Vines, said he had asked Mrs. Crumpler to work with him and seek the vice presidency to bring reconciliation to the faction-torn denomination. Its annual convention is scheduled for June in New Orleans.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: the South.
DOC.TEXT: Beyond disagreements over slavery, it was a vicious campaign, with Lincoln subjected to endless personal attacks from Southern newspapers. ``He has most unwarrantly abused the privilege, which all politicians have, of being ugly,'' the Houston Chronicle sneered, commenting on Lincoln's thin, pock-marked face and unruly hair. ``A horrid looking wretch he is,'' added the Charleston (S.C.) Mercury, ``sooty and scoundrelly in aspect, a cross between the nutmeg dealer, the horse dealer and the night man.'' But Lincoln, who would soon follow the advice of little Grace Bedell of Westfield, N.Y., and grow a beard, said nothing, making no formal speeches during the campaign. And thanks to the Democratic split, he easily won the election while receiving only 40 percent of the votes. By his inauguration in March 1861, however, seven Southern states had already seceded and rumors of an assassination attempt had forced him to alter travel plans the previous month. In his inaugural address, Lincoln pleaded for a peaceful settlement to the slavery issue: ``We must not be enemies. Though passion may have strained, it must not break our bonds of affection. The mystic chords of memory, stretching from every battlefield and patriot grave, to every living heart and hearthstone, all over this broad land, will yet swell the chorus of the Union, when again touched, as surely they will be, by the better angels of our nature.'' On April 12, the Confederates opened fire on Fort Sumter in Charleston harbor and captured it two days later. Lincoln, vowing to ``repel force by force,'' called for a militia of 75,000 and ordered a blockade of Southern ports. The Civil War had begun. ``Except in respect to military matters, Lincoln was not the kind of president we expect today,'' Fehrenbacher said. ``He didn't give leadership in domestic affairs because he didn't think that was his job. The Whigs had been opposing the `dictatorship' of (President) Andrew Jackson. They believed that was the leadership of Congress. He took the leadership role in war, and also in regards to emancipation.'' With typical caution, Lincoln dismantled slavery. In 1862, he drafted the Emancipation Proclamation, but waited for a Union victory before officially issuing it on Jan. 1, 1863. ``What good would a proclamation for emancipation from me do, especially as we are now situated,'' he worried. ``I do not want to issue a document that the whole world will see must necessarily be inoperative, like the Pope's bull against the comet! Would my word free the slaves when I cannot even enforce the Constitution in the rebel States?'' The turning point in the Civil War came that summer, outside Gettysburg, Pa. For three days one of the war's bloodiest battles was fought. Nearly 50,000 soldiers were killed and the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia was forced to retreat. In November, Lincoln was a last-minute invitee to the dedication of the Civil War Cemetery in Gettysburg. The Gettysburg Address, under 300 words long, was a modest prayer that, despite the war, ``government of the people, by the people and for the people, shall not perish from the earth.'' Ironically, Lincoln predicted in the same speech, ``The world will little note, nor long remember what we say here.'' ``It's quite obvious that he realized this was an occasion that something important could be said about the meaning of war and the meaning of America,'' Fehrenbacher said. ``He saw it a new birth of freedom, and it's obvious he gave a great deal of thought to what he was saying.'' The Republican Party overwhelmingly chose Lincoln as its candidate in the 1864 elections. The Democrats selected Gen. George B. McClellan, whom Lincoln had dropped as commander-in-chief of Union forces in 1862. With the Union deadlocked on the battlefield, Lincoln seemed sure he would lose, even writing a ``Memorandum of the Probable Failure of Re-Election'' on Aug. 23. But he easily won in November. ``With malice towards none; with charity for all; with firmness in the right ... let us strive to finish the work we are in,'' Lincoln urged at his inaugural in March 1865, hoping for a peaceful way to ``bind up the nation's wounds.'' Once victory seemed assured, Lincoln's thoughts moved beyond winning the war and focused instead on reconstruction, the subject of his last speech, given on April 11, two days after Gen. Robert E. Lee's surrender at Appomattox. On April 14, while attending a play at the Ford Theatre in Washington, Lincoln was shot in the head by actor John Wilkes Booth, who cried out ``Sic Semper Tyranus'' (``Thus Ever to Tyrants,'' the motto of Virginia). He died the following morning. Lincoln had long worried about death, thinking, speaking and even dreaming of his assassination. In his early 50s, he was already referring to himself as an old man, and he reflected on mortality in an 1862 letter to young Fanny McCullough, whose father was killed in battle: ``In this sad world of ours, sorrow comes to all; and, to the young, it comes with bitterest agony, because it takes them unawares. The older have learned to ever expect it. I am anxious to afford some alleviation of your present distress. Perfect relief is not possible, except with time. ``... The mrobably would have continued as a writer, Fehrenbacher said. ``In the presidency he was increasingly concerned with the art of writing. That shows in his best works, and that's one more thing that John Wilkes Booth took away from us.''

DOC.HEAD: THE GRAMMYS 1990
The Grammys Honor Nat King Cole's Unforgettable Voice
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: His voice was unforgettable. His songs took us down memory lane, Route 66 to be exact, to those lazy, hazy, crazy days of summer. And if you were lucky, his ballads recalled the very thought of you. Nat ``King'' Cole was loved for sentimental reasons. During World War II, his love songs offered a warm balm for soldiers away from home, allowing them to make believe they were home with their sweethearts. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences will honor Cole with a Lifetime Achievement Award during its Grammy presentation on Feb. 21, six days after the 25th anniversary of his death at age 45 from lung cancer. During his 23 years with Capitol Records, until 1964, Cole recorded hundreds of songs, and many went on to become industry standards: ``Unforgettable,'' ``The Christmas Song,'' ``Route 66'' and ``Ramblin' Rose.'' Cole's voice was a lovely work of art _ a beguiling Mona Lisa of sound _described as everything from three parts fog to one part frog; a pussy willow; and a breathy swatch of velvet. Lore has it that he began his career as a crooner by accident. A tipsy customer at a small Hollywood bistro where he was playing piano insisted he sing ``Sweet Lorraine'' and, to keep the drunk quiet, Cole obliged. Once he began singing, however, he quickly became a fluent vocalist, changing styles and rhythms with ease, weaving together sets that easily combined swinging bebop hits and honey-coated love songs. His wife, Maria Cole, said it was his voice that truly launched him. ``He never would have been the international figure he became if he hadn't been singing,'' she said in an interview. ``I know in my heart he wanted it. He liked the attention.'' Born in 1919 to a Baptist minister in Montgomery, Ala., Nathaniel Adams Coles grew up in Chicago's South Side. He later dropped the ``s'' from his last name and added his nickname, King. At the age of 4, he was able to pluck out the tune ``Yes, We Have No Bananas'' on the piano and later played the organ in his father's church. When he was 14, he organized a 14-piece band, and made himself piano player and leader. ``I was always crazy about show business,'' Cole once said, ``and I was particularly crazy about bands. Why, I used to stand in front of the radio and lead bands all the time.'' After high school, he worked with several bands without great success until 1937, when he got hip, took a timely trip and motored West. It was in California that he formed the King Cole Trio _ a piano, a guitar and bass _ playing gigs for $75 a week. With Cole on the piano, Oscar Moore on guitar and Johnny Miller on bass, the trio generated a following and began to tour. In New York in 1946, already married to Nadine Robinson, Cole met the then Maria Ellington, a striking beauty who was rehearsing for a show at the chic Club Zanzibar. ``It's terrible, I feel funny when I tell this story because I'm usually so doggone dignified. But he did say it. He said, `Boy, if she looks as good from the front as she does from the back,''' the second Mrs. Cole recalled, breaking off in a peal of laughter. ``And then, of course, I ignored him. He didn't interest me.'' Cole persevered, sending her tickets a boxing match, which he couldn't attend because of a gig. But a few weeks later he took her to a horse race and the romance got past the starting gate. He divorced his first wife, and he and Maria were married a year later. During their 15-year marriage, they had five children: Carol, Natalie, Kelly and identical twins Timolin and Casey. Cole, an ardent babeball fan, named his last child for the late manager Casey Stengel. ``He was basically introverted,'' Mrs. Cole said, ``except for when he talked about music and baseball. But those things he knew! And he knew he knew them! There was no holding back when it came to either one. ``That was wonderful that I loved sports because I would have been home a lot by myself.'' Natalie, a Grammy winner, remembers her father's passion for racing around in his sports car. ``He liked to go for drives,'' she said in an interview. ``He had a sports car, a Jaguar, and I think I was the only one that would get in with him _ he was a fast driver.'' As far as musical influences, Natalie recalled her father singing children's songs. ``He didn't go around the house singing `Mona Lisa,''' she said. ``They were children's songs, fun songs. And those are the songs that I remember, and those are the songs that I've passed on to my son.'' She then launched into one: ``Oh Mary Mac, Mac Mac ... all dressed in black black black, with silver buttons, all down her back back back.'' Not all of her associations with her father, however, are as warm. ``For me, I didn't really feel like I was in his shadow until I chose (singing) as my career. And then all of the sudden it loomed up as something pretty intimidating and overwhelming.'' Natalie wanted to be recognized for her own talent, and not just for being the namesake of Nat King Cole. ``For a long time I really wished I could change my name,'' she said. ``It's been since about six years ago that I really have been able to carry it gracefully and hopefully in a way that is proud and becoming to his flesh and blood.'' In 1956, Cole started his own network television show, ``The Nat King Cole Show'' on NBC. But national advertisers were leary about backing a show hosted by a black man, the first of its kind, and the program was eventually forced off the air. ``Madison Avenue is afraid of the dark,'' Cole concluded. Cole also appeared as the blues composer W.C. Handy in the movie ``St. Louis Blues,'' and had a role in the Jane Fonda film ``Cat Ballou.'' ``He was full of humor,'' Mrs. Cole said. ``Many people don't know this. He was very funny. He'd make dry, wonderful remarks. .. . ``He was a fun man to be with. I had a wonderful life. I miss him more now that I'm older, so I'm just very happy that he's getting his due.'' Her favorite Nat ``King'' Cole song? ``Our Love Is Here to Stay.''
