DOC.HEAD: CHICAGO: quickly changed.
DOC.TEXT: The children were not allowed to go outside all summer, court records show. Andrea Harbin, a neighbor, testified she heard the boys crying ``mostly every day.'' Their apartment, No. 612, had no furniture except a sofa. The older boys' bedrooms were closets, their beds were cardboard, and they were fed ``about once a week,'' Cornelius testified. In haunting testimony, the boy said ``J.G.'' had twice tied him up with a rope and hung him upside down in the closet, once for two days. He showed the judge scars on his shoulders he said were from Campbell's burning cigarettes. Cornelius said Campbell had taken a hot iron and ``put it on my brother's chest and he put that iron on my butt.'' The boy said his mother was ``in the living room watching TV'' at the time. He told about seeing Campbell throw a screaming Lattie into a bathtub of hot water, scrubbing the boy's skin with a rag ``and his skin started peeling off.'' He told of seeing Campbell tie Lattie's wrists to his ankles and hang him upside down in the closet. Once, Cornelius said, his mother helped tie up Lattie. Campbell had prior battery convictions and a history of mental problems and said he drank a fifth of alcohol a day and often free-based cocaine. He told authorities he beat the children because he thought they were gay. ``I saw what they were doing. They were doing things like swishing their butts and screaming like little girls, and snapping their fingers ...,'' he told a psychiatrist in an interview included in court records. ``I wanted to put him in the cupboard so he wouldn't do these things,'' Campbell said. ``I figured that the pin holes would make him stop.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Feb. 11

DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent his first economic report to Congress and promised to restrain government spending and push for tax cuts to foster more prosperity. Bush said Tuesday he would continue his fight to get Congress to reduce the capital gains tax and pledged anew to fight protectionist trade barriers. Many private economists say the administration's economic outlook for the next five years is too optimistic.

Savings and loan depositors withdrew $4.9 billion in November as the thrift industry continued to shrink in response to tougher financial standards enacted last summer, the government said. It was the lowest level of withdrawals in four months, but was still the 17th outflow in 18 months and brought total deposits at the nation's 2,889 S&Ls down to $947 billion, the Office of Thrift Supervision said Tuesday.

General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. plan to begin transmission production in their first joint manufacturing venture next year at plants in New York state and Indiana. Chrysler Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald said Tuesday the agreement starts a new era for the American automobile industry. Before the establishment of New Venture Gear Inc. between GM and Chrysler, collaboration between major U.S. automakers had been limited to several research projects.

The board of financially sagging Pan Am Corp. still is considering possible combinations with several airlines but made no decisions at its latest meeting, sources said. The airline's board of directors met Tuesday amid speculation that it was ready to disclose a deal, possibly with Northwest Airlines, but finished for the day with no announcements.

The pilots of Trans World Airlines Inc. said they would not accept Chairman Carl Icahn's request for $80 million in further wage and benefit concessions and asked their boss to stop seeking the cuts. The response Tuesday comes a day after Icahn said he would buy new jetliners and expand the moneylosing carrier's operations if the 3,500 TWA pilots accepted the concessions. ``We've given him $500 million over five years and that's enough. He hasn't used it properly and there's no point to giving him another penny,'' said Kent Scott, chairman of TWA's pilot union's master executive council.

OPEC slashed oil production last month but not enough to meet its promised goal, according to new estimates. The International Energy Agency said Tuesday in its Monthly Oil Market Report that the 13 OPEC nations produced about 23.3 million barrels of crude oil a day in January. That was about 700,000 barrels below December's peak levels but still well above the 22-million-barrel limit OPEC pledged late last year.

First Hawaiian Inc., parent company of the state's second largest bank, agreed to buy privately held First Interstate of Hawaii Inc. in a cash deal valued at $140 million. The deal announced Tuesday would raise the assets of First Hawaiian to about $6 billion, according to Chairman Walter A. Dods Jr. First Interstate, the state's fourth largest banking company, has 20 branches.

Hallmark Cards Inc. began an offer to buy back at a discount some $270 million in debt securities used to finance Univision Holdings Inc., under a plan to ease the debt burden on the unprofitable Spanish-language broadcaster. The action announced Tuesday by Hallmark, which owns a 63.5 percent stake in Univision, followed Univision's failure to make $10 million in interest payments due last week on some of the debt.

Japanese government and industry officials suggested the dollar might have to weaken by another 30 percent or more against the yen in order to reduce the U.S. trade deficit with Japan enough to satisfy Congress. ``Congress wants a quick fix, so ... your demand for imports has to go down,'' Kazuo Nukazawa, managing director of the powerful Japan Federation of Economic Organizations, said Tuesday.

The stock market slumped in sluggish trading Tuesday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 16.21 points to close at 2,606.31. Bond prices fell. The dollar ended mixed against other major currencies. Gold and silver futures prices slipped; oil futures were mostly lower; orange juice futures rebounded; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Downtown Resorts Cooperating to Lure Tourists to Casino District
DOC.TEXT: Competition has given way to cooperation for Reno's hotel-casino owners, who hope to breathe new life into the city's sluggish gaming business by building new shopping attractions downtown. ``I remember when casinos, through checkerboarding, would hang onto a little piece of property downtown just to prevent another casino from building,'' said Buddy Frank, director of marketing and advertising for the Fitzgeralds Group hotel-casinos. ``That doesn't happen anymore,'' he said. Patrick Cruzen, president of Reno's Flamingo Hilton hotel-casino, agreed. ``I think part of the attitude of cooperation is people coming together and saying, `If we really want to make this city grow then we have to work together,''' he said. That attitude is focused today on development sites around the Rio Grande Railroad's downtown tracks. Rio Grande decided to sell the plots, which haven't been touched for 121 years, after a merger with another railroad a few years ago. Fitzgeralds, Flamingo Hilton and two other casino groups have purchased land bordering the tracks from Rio Grande in the past year. They plan to spend millions to build retail shopping facilities, parking and, in one case, more casino space, to lure tourists who want other diversions to go with their blackjack and slot machines. ``A large percentage of people who come here really want to go shopping,'' said Pete Claudianos III, vice president of Sands, which bought one of the development sites. ``Now, our customers are having to ask how to get a city bus or a cab to Reno's malls.'' The development sites straddle railroad tracks that cut through the heart of the downtown casino district, home to almost all of the city's more than 30 gaming houses. Tourists face steep odds of finding much to do other than gamble downtown, though. J.C. Penney Co. has a store there along with F.W. Woolworth, but they're joined by an array of small souvenir shops, jewelry stores and pawn shops. Most of the city's 250,000 or so residents live outside the downtown area and shop at two big suburban malls or other outlying commercial areas. ``The few stores we do have downtown have real limited selections and aren't the best of retail,'' Frank concedes. So Fitzgeralds has teamed up with a gaming competitor, Eldorado, to buy a 2.32-acre parcel. They would like to build a retail mall on the site that could include specialty shops, recreational and sports facilities, a restaurant and parking, Frank says. ``We're in the process of doing public opinion polls right now and don't have any firm plans, but it looks like the best thing for that property is to develop non-gaming uses for it,'' Frank said. ``We're even talking about building skyways to connect the four casino properties around the railroad tracks and keep people in the area,'' he said. John Metzker, chairman of Fitzgeralds' Group, said two feasibility studies should be finished by late March, allowing final plans to be drawn. ``I view this development as mandatory if we want to continue advancing our community,'' he said. The city could use a shot in the arm. Reno is the state's No. 2 tourist attraction after Las Vegas, attracting more than 7 million visitors last year, according to the Reno-Sparks Convention and Visitors Authority. But casino revenues have been sluggish, showing single-digit growth in recent years compared with double-digit gains in southern Nevada. And unlike Las Vegas, where a building boom has spawned several new casinos, Reno hasn't seen a new casino go up in years, although there has been a little expansion of existing facilities in the last two years. The Sands has purchased a parcel the size of half a city block adjacent to a hotel it is constructing. The company plans to build a shopping center on the site with 40 specialty stores on two levels and 1,000 parking spaces on upper floors, Claudianos said. The resort needs city approval for the development but could finish the shopping center in 1991, he said. A block from the Sands parcel, the Flamingo Hilton has bought a 1.6-acre lot on which it plans to raise a 26-to-28-story, 1,100-room hotel and casino. Plans also call for a health spa, outdoor pool and two restaurants at the site. The project is estimated to cost $80 million to $100 million and take 22 months to complete, Cruzen said. The resort has obtained government approval but its board of directors still must approve the plans before construction can begin this spring, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Want Hearings Delayed
DOC.TEXT: Creditors of the Federated and Allied retailing chains want a federal bankruptcy judge to delay hearings scheduled this week on the companies' financing plans to operate under Chapter 11 reorganization. A delay could threaten $700 million in bank financing the two department store chains have arranged, which in turn could make it difficult to keep store shelves stocked and cash registers ringing while the companies try to sort out their debt problems under bankruptcy court protection. The creditors filed the objections Monday and Tuesday with U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. He has scheduled a hearing Thursday to consider Federated Department Store Inc.'s financing proposal and Friday on Allied Stores Corp.'s proposal. ``The primary objection is the lack of time we've had to evaluate the structuring and financing of the proposal,'' said Chicago lawyer Lewis Rosenbloom, representing unsecured creditors of Federated. The creditors also said they need more information to assess the proposed financing plans and how they would affect the long-term business and financial prospects of Allied and Federated. The two Cincinnati-based companies represent the 260-store U.S. retailing operations of Toronto-based Campeau Corp. Together they employ about 100,000 people. Rosenbloom said Tuesday the creditors asked Aug to grant a delay of at least 30 days to satisfy their concerns about how loans to Federated and Allied would be structured and whether they might hurt the companies' abilities to obtain loans from merchandise suppliers or middlemen. Aug gave interim approval for the financing approvals on Jan. 25, and he told creditors' lawyers then that he intends to reach a final decision on the financing as quickly as possible to help ensure that Federated and Allied can continue operations to the long-term benefit of creditors. The proposals include agreements under which Federated negotiated a $400 million line of credit and Allied obtained agreements for $300 million in financing. Lawyers for the Citibank-led consortium guaranteeing Federated's financing said the alliance is committed to providing the financing only if approval is obtained by Feb. 14. After that, the commitment expires and there is no guarantee that banks could be found to participate in a new agreement, said Harvey Miller, a lawyer for Citibank. Miller said about 60 percent of the consortium's banks are foreign and their managers do not necessarily understand the bankruptcy reorganization procedure. Federated and Allied filed Jan. 15 for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act while they develop a plan to reorganize their finances. It was the largest such filing in American retailing history. The companies are struggling under $7.5 billion in debt, most of it accumulated when Campeau bought Federated in 1988 and Allied in 1986. Allen I. Questrom, the former Federated vice chairman hired Friday from the Neiman-Marcus retailer as the new chairman and chief executive officer of Federated and Allied, met Tuesday with managers at the companies' Cincinnati headquarters. The bankruptcy court last week approved the hiring of Questrom under a five-year contract that will pay him $1.2 million annually.

DOC.HEAD: BAT To Open Bidding For Field's and Saks Retail Chains
With PM-Federated-Allied, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Loyal customers and an upscale image make Marshall Field and Co. attractive to those hoping to buy the department store chain from BAT Industries Inc., retail analysts say. ``Most Chicagoans fit it into their shopping on Sunday,'' said George Rosenbaum, president of the Chicago-based research firm Leo J. Shapiro Associates Inc. ``It's a store that doesn't have to win customers but a store that can expand its business by selling more to customers it already has,'' he said. At least half a dozen parties, including Field's management, are expected to join the bidding for the 135-year-old retailer, which has 24 stores in four states. The process begins Thursday when the investment firm Goldman Sachs & Co. hands out confidential prospectuses to would-be bidders for both Field's and the larger Saks Fifth Avenue chain, according to a spokeswoman for Batus Inc., a subsidiary of BAT headquartered in Louisville, Ky. London-based BAT, Field's owners since 1982, hopes to announce the winning bid sometime in May, the spokeswoman said Tuesday. Observers have estimated Field's will fetch $600 million to $1 billion. BAT shareholders in October approved a plan to sell the company's U.S. retailing operations as part of a restructuring designed to thwart a $21.7 billion hostile takeover bid led by Anglo-French financier Sir James Goldsmith. Field's Chairman Philip B. Miller and May Department Stores Co. have said publicly that they want to buy Field's. Others reportedly interested in the chain include Dillard Department Stores Inc., Dayton Hudson Corp., JMB Realty Corp. and several U.S. investment firms representing foreign money. The winner will get a thriving, determinedly upscale chain that commands 15 percent of the crowded Chicago retail market despite stiff competition from Bloomingdale's, Nieman-Marcus, Saks and others. Retail analyst Robert F. Buchanan of Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore said the availability of Field's and Saks represent a ``brilliant opportunity'' for someone to become a clear leader in the high-priced end of American retailing. ``There's going to be a lot of growth there in terms of buying power through the end of this century,'' he said. ``It's going to be a very fertile area of retailing.'' Miller, who moved to Field's from the president's office of Nieman-Marcus in 1983, has engineered a financial turnaround at Field's, overseen an extensive remodeling of the company's flagship store on State Street and expanded its reach into Ohio and Texas. The company also has stores in Wisconsin. The prospective bid by Miller, in conjunction with a yet-to-be identified partner or partners, has generated a good deal of excitement here, fueling hopes that Field's will be returned to local ownership. Miller declined to comment on the bidding but in an October interview with the Chicago Tribune, he pledged to fight for control of Field's. ``The worst scenario would be to have someone come in here and treat it like any old department store and have it become just another store,'' Miller said. ``This is clearly not what Chicago wants or deserves.'' In the interview, Miller said that under his leadership, Field's annual sales have gone from about $650 million to more than $1.1 billion and annual profit has doubled to an estimated $90 million in 1989 from $45 million in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: As Heads Roll on Wall Street, Resumes Flow, Headhunters Busy
DOC.TEXT: As heads roll during a recession on Wall Street, highly paid professionals are searching for new jobs out of fear their departments will be the next to get the ax. ``At all levels people are more willing to sit down and think about what their options are,'' said Joan Zimmerman, executive vice president at the executive search firm GZ Stephens Inc., which places Wall Street executives. Headhunters report that resume and phone inquiries about locating new jobs have zoomed in recent months. Amid growing paranoia, Wall Street professionals are keeping their ears to the ground for word of openings _ often for less money. ``A year ago, people still had this idea it was a God-given right they make $300,000 a year. It's not the case (anymore),'' said Erica Henner, president of Henner Associates Inc., a Chicago-based executive search firm. Since the October 1987 stock market crash, the securities industry has lost about 35,000 jobs nationwide. In New York, Wall Street employment is down to 145,000 from a peak of 163,000, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Merrill Lynch & Co., the nation's largest securities firm, is cutting more than 3,000 jobs. No. 2 Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. slashed 800 positions in December and has extended cuts into its elite investment banking corps. ``People are going on more interviews than they were before,'' said a 26-year-old executive at a major Wall Street firm. ``You just don't know. The cutbacks keep coming.'' Following the roaring '80s that turned Wall Street into a river of money, investment firms are damming up expenses, from fancy dinners and travel budgets to unproductive workers and entire departments. Personnel traditionally accounts for as much as 60 percent of expenses at Wall Street firms, and industry officials said firms are seeking to trim such costs through layoffs, lower salaries and reduced bonuses. ``For the average guy there's some degree of panic and a lot of caution,'' said Steven Littman, managing partner at the executive search firm E.J. Rhodes Associates Inc. ``People are concerned about the stability of their future,'' said Littman, whose firm is receiving about five times as many calls and resumes as six months ago. ``Business heads are falling, things are changing and people are concerned about what's going to happen over the next year or two.'' Some Wall Street firms are taking advantage of the insecure environment to upgrade departments by luring away talented deal-makers, often for less money than in the mid-'80s. Lower 1989 bonuses have made some executives take job offers more seriously, although the most sought-after still command higher compensation when they jump firms. After reducing bloated sales and trading forces last year, the latest cuts are in investment banking, which thrived on multimillion-dollar fees in the takeover-mad 1980s but has fallen on hard times with dwindling merger activity. Unlike the money-driven '80s, many Wall Street pros are concerned about quality of life and company stability. Investment bankers, for instance, are joining second-tier or foreign-owned firms that haven't had to shrink because they didn't expand with the reckless abandon of major firms, recruiters said. ``There seems to be less loyalty these days. I think people are concerned about their own welfare and not the firm's welfare,'' said Gary Goldstein, president of The Whitney Group, an executive search firm. Brokerages also have scrapped computer development projects, cutting programmers and technicians, while back-office workers who process trading paperwork have been laid off as trading volume declines. ``Since two years ago in October, our business has decreased drastically,'' said Jack Talabisco, president of Botal Associates Inc., a data processing search firm that now places about 10 people a month compared with 40 in 1986-87. Jim Zamparelli, president of Cross Personnel Agency Inc., said Wall Street firms are hiring more part-time back-office workers, saving money on salaries and benefits. He said his firm gets 50 to 75 resumes daily. Despite the layoffs, times aren't that tough for executives who still have jobs. Recruiters said investment bankers with several years' experience are pulling in around $200,000 a year, down from $400,000 or more in 1986-87. But drumming up business isn't easier. ``You know that if you're lucky enough to stay you're going to be working harder for less pay,'' said a 28-year-old former vice president whose job was eliminated in a reorganization at a major firm late last year. He added that after several years of six-figure earnings, ``Learning to live on $50,000 a year is not that difficult.''

DOC.HEAD: Shows Fourth-Quarter Profit But Securities Weak
With PM-Wall Street-Headhunting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Like other slumping Wall Street firms, Salomon Inc. said its securities business was barely profitable in the 1989 fourth quarter while its commodities division recorded a loss. The first-tier Wall Street firm Tuesday said it managed to turn a $68 million quarterly profit because of a strong performance by its Phibro Energy oil refining and trading subsidiary, which apparently benefited from a strong rise in oil prices during the period. The earnings ended an up-and-down year for the securities giant, which reported a record $28 million first-quarter loss, followed by a record $253 million second-quarter profit and $177 million third-quarter gain. In a year of weak performances across Wall Street, Salomon fared better than some firms. Although Salomon didn't disclose details of its securities trading, analysts said the firm absorbed large fourth-quarter losses stemming from the stock market's Oct. 13 mini-crash and declines in the value of its junk-bond portfolio. ``You put it all together and it was not a bad year'' compared to the rest of the industry, said analyst Lawrence Eckenfelder of Prudential Bache Securities Inc. ``But I certainly think investors like to see more consistency.'' Salomon took a beating during the market drop because it held 300,000 shares of UAL Corp., the airline company whose stock price plunge after a takeover deal collapse that sparked the market sell-off, Eckenfelder said. In addition, Salomon's $500 million portfolio of high-yield debt securities was reduced in value because of a steady decline in the junk-bond market beginning in September, he said. For the period ending Dec. 31, Salomon reported earnings of 42 cents a share. That compared with a loss of $38 million, or 42 cents a share, in the same 1988 quarter. Quarterly revenue rose to $2.51 billion from $1.81 billion. Salomon's pre-tax earnings for the quarter totaled $81 million, down sharply from $233 million in the 1988 period. Its Salomon Brothers securities division reported $1 million in pre-tax earnings and the energy segment $125 million, but commodities recorded a $45 million loss. In the 1988 quarter, the securities segment made $81 million before taxes and the commodities division $10 million. The energy group reported quarterly pre-tax profits of $142 million a year earlier. A $180 million after-tax charge to cover the cost of shifting capital from Switzerland to the United States gave Salomon a net loss in the 1988 quarter. For the full year, Salomon reported earnings of $470 million, or $3.20 a share, up 68 percent from $280 million, or $1.63 a share, in 1988. Revenue rose to $5.76 billion from $3.63 billion. Overall pre-tax earnings totaled $740 million, down from $753 million in 1988. The securities group made $490 million before taxes in the full year, about level with $485 million in 1988. Salomon said lower investment banking revenue, reflecting slower merger activity and a drop in securities underwriting, was offset by revenue growth in equities, government bonds and foreign exchange trading. The commodities division reported a pre-tax loss of $117 million in 1989, compared with a $48 million profit in 1988. Salomon attributed the loss to costs associated with discontinued operations and first-quarter trading losses in non-ferrous metals. The energy segment made $367 million before taxes last year, up from $220 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Board Meets; No Announcements
DOC.TEXT: The board of beleaguered Pan Am Corp. is still considering possible combinations with several airlines, but no decisions were made at its latest meeting, sources say. The airline's board of directors met Tuesday amid speculation that it was ready to disclose a deal, possibly with Northwest Airlines. The board finished for the day with no announcements, however. The board held a regularly scheduled meeting Tuesday morning that ended around noon EST, Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said. She declined any further comment on the meeting and said Pan Am didn't plan any announcements. Northwest spokesman Doug Miller in Eagan, Minn., said the company, the nation's fourth-largest airline, would have no comment. Pan Am Chairman Tom Plaskett reiterated to the directors that the airline must combine with another carrier to ensure its survival. Northwest was mentioned as a possibility, as were other airlines, said a source close to the situation, who asked not to be identified. The directors were not asked to make any decisions, the source said. William F. Genoese, director of the Teamsters' airline division, said over the weekend that Pan Am management had leaked word that a major announcement, probably a deal with Northwest, would come out of the board meeting. Genoese said Tuesday that Pan Am still was trying to work out ``some sort of a merger arrangement'' with the larger Northwest. A deal under discussion would cut Pan Am, the nation's eighth-largest carrier, to one-third its size, Genoese said in a telephone interview. He said Pan Am is seeking a joint marketing arrangement with Northwest for the next five years, with the two carriers continuing to operate independently under the umbrella of NWA Inc., Northwest's parent. After five years, ``a full merger might be put into effect,'' Genoese said in a statement. ``Pan Am faces bankruptcy,'' the statement read. ``It is trying to structure a business plan that would satisfy Northwest's management and would also satisfy the banks, which would have to provide financing.'' Genoese said he was scheduled to meet with Plaskett on Thursday. Ms. Hanlon would not confirm or deny that such a meeting was planned. Pan Am shares finished down 12{ cents at $3.62{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock surged 25 percent on Monday in a rally market watchers attributed to Genoese's weekend comments. The two airlines have held discussions recently, but ``We're a long way from a Northwest-Pan Am deal,'' said one source familiar with the talks. Airline analysts cited rumors that, short of merging with Northwest, Pan Am might sell some of its prized trans-Atlantic routes or other assets to the carrier. New York-based Pan Am has lost nearly $2 billion since 1981 and is saddled with $841 million in debt. Last February, Plaskett said the airline needed to merge with another carrier in order to survive. Pan Am offered about $3.3 billion last May for NWA, but was outbid by a $3.65 billion offer from a group led by investor Alfred Checchi. ``They have to do something one of these days,'' said Louis Marckesano, an airline analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. ``It probably would take some time to resolve.''

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Opens Copyright Case, Shows Duplicate Systems
DOC.TEXT: Three video screens sitting in a federal courtroom became the first key witnesses in Lotus Development Corp.'s copyright suit against two competing software companies. As Charles Sullivan, a Lotus product marketing manager, punched out financial tables, first using the Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet program and then the programs from the two competitors, the court was faced with nearly identical images on each screen. Lotus is trying to prove that Paperback Software International, of Berkeley, Calif., and Mosaic Software of Cambridge, copied its popular 1-2-3 program. The case does not focus on the inner codes of the programs, which experts agree fall under copyright protection, but instead concentrates on the keyboard commands associated with the programs and how the images appear on the screen. Lotus contends those elements _ known as the user interface _ signify the expression of an idea and are thus protected under copyright laws. Legal experts, however, say this area of the law is unclear. On Tuesday, Lotus representatives spent more than three hours presenting computer displays as they opened their case. Three video screens were installed so people in the courtroom could watch the results of each command. U.S. District Judge Robert E. Keeton, meanwhile, had his own private screens to monitor the proceedings. There were a few technical glitches, such as when one screen broke down for several moments, forcing the judge to share his screens with defense attorney Paul Gupta. Sullivan gave the court a basic lesson in organizing a spreadsheet, placing sample financial results in various columns and rows. He also demonstrated more complex functions, such as setting up graphs and mortgage rate charts. ``I've done this 10,000 times before'' for prospective customers, Sullivan said during a break. ``Obviously I've never done it here before.'' Sullivan then performed the same basic functions on the two other screens, setting up a financial chart using Paperback Software's VP-Planner program, and then with Mosaic's Twin Classic program. Sullivan went through similar sequences of keystrokes and commands, and the result was three screens sitting side by side, showing identical arrangements of columns and rows for the 1-2-3, VP-Planner and Twin Classic programs. The only significant difference between the two displays was that the Lotus program had a menu of options _ such as ``file,'' ``copy,'' and ``edit'' _ at the top of the screen, while the other two programs had the menu at the bottom. In contrast, Lotus demonstrated another competing program, Microsoft Excel, which required different commands. ``Basically I created the same spreadsheet as I did on 1-2-3, but did it in a totally different manner,'' Sullivan said. But Gupta, representing Paperback Software, said after the hearing that the comparison with Microsoft Excel was unfair because that program operates on different types of hardware. Gupta planned to elaborate his points when he cross-examined Sullivan on Thursday, when the attorneys also are scheduled to present their opening arguments. Gupta contended that Tuesday's hearing demonstrated ``instructions for a machine rather than the expression of an idea.'' But in its court affidavits, Lotus countered that assertion, saying the system of commands and screen images were the product of careful thought. Mitchell Kapor, who was Lotus' founder and co-author of 1-2-3, outlined in one affidavit how he helped develop the program and decided upon each element. ``The choice of words selected to represent commands and their organization in the menu tree, I believed, would be critical to the success of the user interface, especially for the novice user,'' he said. Lotus also provided statements from Bernard Galler, a professor of electrical engineering at the University of Michigan, who said the ``creation of the user interface requires the software developer to make subjective choices, decisions and judgments.'' Galler said the 1-2-3 program ``reflects one of many possible models'' for spreadsheets, but the VP-Planner and Twin programs virtually duplicate Lotus' product. Court affidavits filed by the defense included statements from James Stephenson, the designer of VP-Planner. Stephenson said he was working on his program, and was taking an approach similar to Lotus', before the commercial release of 1-2-3 in January 1983. But as the Lotus program grew in popularity, it became apparent to Stephenson that his product, which was introduced in October 1985, should be compatible with 1-2-3. ``VP-Planner could not offer the functional attribute of macro compatibility unless keystrokes entering the same letters or moving the cursor to the same location would bring about the same functional result as in Lotus 1-2-3,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Indiana Manufacturer, Hong Kong Firm Wage War of Letters
DOC.TEXT: A Hong Kong investment firm's battle for a seat on the board of Cummins Engine Co. has moved to the nation's capital with both sides seeking the hearts and minds of Congress. Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., through its parent, New Zealand's Brierley Investments Ltd., asked Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., to stay out of the fray until the outcome of a federal lawsuit by Cummins. That request was included in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Dingell has asked the SEC to review IEP's dealings with Cummins. Dingell is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which oversees the securities industry _ particularly the SEC, its federal regulator. Late last month, Indiana's congressional delegation wrote Dingell asking him to request an SEC review of IEP's investment activities with U.S. companies, including Cummins. IEP owns a 15-percent stake in the company. Without making specific allegations, the letter to Dingell said ``if IEP treats Cummins as it allegedly has several other U.S. companies, a strong American business could be dismembered.'' The congressional letter went on to describe IEP as ``a Hong Kong corporate raider'' and ``an entity with a history of greenmail.'' Greenmail is the payment made by a company to buy back its own stock _ at above-market prices _ from an unwanted suitor. But Brierley Chairman Bruce A. Hancox, in a letter of his own to Dingell, said the Indiana delegation have been misled by ``false, baseless and libelous allegations.'' ``Cummins would have you believe that we invest for `short-term plunder rather than long-term growth.' That is simply not so,'' he wrote. Dingell asked the SEC and the Federal Trade Commission, which oversees antitrust matters, to review the IEP actions, an Energy and Commerce Committee staffer said. The staffer said the committee had not seen Hancox's letter, and therefore could not comment. Cummins filed its suit against IEP at federal court in Indianapolis last month after IEP sought a seat on Cummins' 15-member board. ``As one of 15 directors and the only non-U.S. director, I doubt I would have posed a threat to corporate policy,'' Hancox said in his letter to Dingell. In another filing with the SEC on Monday, IEP said it was re-evaluating its Cummins holdings.

DOC.HEAD: Casino City Shows First Volume Decline Since Gambling's Start in 1978
With PM-Reno Development, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Casino industry officials are trying to put the best face on figures showing Atlantic City suffered the first decline in visitors since gambling was legalized in 1978. ``This may just be a temporary hiatus or dip,'' said Steve Richer, the president of the Atlantic City Convention & Visitors Bureau. Richer and industry analysts on Tuesday described the 3 percent drop in annual visitors as the inevitable leveling-off of the casino boom. ``I don't think it's drying up,'' said John Uphoff, a casino analyst with Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. ``It's kind of getting a second wind, if you will.'' The figures compiled by Anthony Marino, an Atlantic City Expressway executive, show that 32.1 million people visited the seaside resort last year, down from 33.1 million in 1988. The number had risen steadily since the 7.0 million recorded in 1978, the year Atlantic City's first casino opened. Blair Learn, a spokesman for the convention bureau, said the figures include many repeat visitors. The actual numbers of people who came last year range between 5 million and 6 million, Learn estimated. Uphoff said the drop probably could be attributed to the opening in November of Steve Wynn's Mirage casino in Las Vegas, Nev. In addition, he said potential visitors might be awaiting the opening of Donald Trump's Taj Mahal casino _ to be the world's largest _ this spring in Atlantic City. Uphoff predicted Atlantic City would rebound this year with the introduction of the Taj Mahal and the ``lottery-type'' excitement generated by a linked multi-casino progressive slots system known as ``Megabucks.'' The statistics show a 12 percent decline in the number of people reaching the city by bus, a development Richer said he welcomed because bus passengers typically stay for less than a day and do not spend money outside the casinos. That compares poorly to Las Vegas, which Richer said the average visitor stay is 2.7 days. Car travel rose last year from 17.8 million to 18.3 million and air visitors increased from 440,000 to 523,000. The Casino Association of New Jersey, an industry trade group, said the modest 2.6 percent growth in casino gross profits in 1989 and a peaking of drive-in customer levels point to a need to boost air service to the city.

DOC.HEAD: Clean-Coal Unit to be Installed at West Virginia Plant
DOC.TEXT: An agreement with the federal government to build a $660 million, clean-burning coal generator marks a step toward easing the acid rain associated with high-sulfur coal, a utility company executive says. American Electric Power Service Corp. announced Tuesday the agreement with the U.S. Department of Energy to build a generator that will have sharply reduced emissions of the substances that cause acid rain. American Electric Power Co., AEP Service's parent company, is the nation's largest buyer of coal. The project is part of the DOE's $5 billion Clean Coal Technology Program, which aims to develop coal-burning generating plants that reduce emissions of sulfer dioxide and nitrogen oxide by as much as 95 percent compared with existing plants. The DOE has agreed to pay $185 million of the cost of building a Pressurized Fluidized Bed Combustion Unit at American Electric Power's 40-year-old Philip Sporn plant in New Haven, W.Va., the utility said in a news release. ``Our goal is to demonstrate that PFBC is capable of helping the nation meet its environmental goals more effectively than current technology,'' said James J. Markowsky, senior vice president and chief engineer of AEP Service, the management and technology arm of American Electric Power. The project was outlined in a report by the DOE to Congress Tuesday. Government funds for the plant can be granted following a 30-day congressional review, the department said. Pressurized fluidized bed combustion technology will allow the Sporn plant to burn high-sulfur coal cleanly and boost the plant's electric output, the DOE said. The project will replace two conventional coal-fired boilers. The technology could be critical for American Electric Power, which relies largely on coal to supply power to 7 million customers in seven Midwestern and Appalachian states. Clean air legislation pending in Washington could force the utility to cut its emissions sharply in coming years. The project also has implications for the region's coal industry, which mainly produces coal with a high sulfur content. A fluidized bed system captures acid-rain causing pollutants inside the coal boiler as part of the combustion process. To capture sulfur gases, limestone is mixed with crushed coal and fed into the boiler. As the coal burns, sulfur pollutants are absorbed by the limestone and removed as solids from the bottom of the boiler, the DOE said. Boilers using the process can burn coal at a lower temperature than conventional boilers, which reduces nitrogen oxide emissions. When the refitting is finished, the Sporn plant will be the world's largest pressurized fluidized bed plant, with a capacity of 330 megawatts. With conventional equipment, the Sporn plant produced a maximum 300 megawatts of power, the DOE said. Testing at the Sporn plant is to begin in the summer of 1996. The plant is jointly owned by the Ohio Power Co. and the Appalachian Power Co., both wholly-owned subsidiaries of Columbus-based American Electric Power. American Electric Power said it will begin operating a 70-watt pressurized fluidized bed plant this year at Brilliant designed to test the technology. The utility cautioned that its efforts to commercialize the clean-burning technology could be hindered if Congress enacts clean air legislation requiring utilities to fit scrubbers on existing plants or retire plants early. It said it doesn't have the resources to pursue both strategies.

DOC.HEAD: Price of Mailing a Letter Heads for 30 Cents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Mailing a love letter, paying the phone bill and chewing out your congressman likely will cost more next year _ postage rates appear headed up again. The Postal Service is poised to launch the long, complex process of raising prices on March 6. Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank says a 30-cent stamp seems likely for first class mail in 1991, although the final price could be from 28 cents to 32 cents. First class postage rose to the current 25-cent rate on April 3, 1988. If things follow the normal course, the new charges would take effect about 11 months after the filing, or in February 1991. Frank doesn't expect the new proposed raise to play well. Noting a 5-cent increase would be a 20 percent raise, substantially above the 14 percent he projects that consumer prices will have risen from 1988 to 1991, Frank said recently he was ``committed to paying back to the American people that 6 percent'' difference. To do that, he has pledged to keep future increases below the inflation rate and said Tuesday, ``We may very well be able to hold increases in rates after the 1991 adjustments to one more increase in the balance of this century.'' The Postal Service managed to operate about $404 million in the black for the first quarter of this fiscal year, but the agency expects a record $1.6 billion deficit for the full year ending Sept. 30. The postal service is required to break even over the long run. Frank has cited a number of reasons for the planned 1991 rate increase. ``We were required in 1988 and 1989 to contribute $800 million to deficit reduction even though we don't use a penny of tax money. Health benefit costs are out of control _ a problem we share with the private sector,'' he said. The first official step in raising rates will be taken March 6, when the Postal Service's board of governors is to vote on the proposed increase. The independent Postal Rate Commission then will ask for comment _ that should produce tons of reports and appeals from various interest groups _ and hold lengthy hearings before making its recommendation. It then will be up to the Postal Service board to put the new rate into effect. Frank's comments came in a Jan. 25 speech to the Economic Club of Indianapolis. The Postal Service made a text of his remarks available Thursday. Frank has said he wants to lengthen the period between rate increases, but his efforts have been complicated by federal budget woes. The Postal Service was separated from the federal government in 1971 and its tax subsidies were eliminated. It was returned to the federal budget in the 1980s, when the agency was showing a surplus. It then was taken back off the federal budget, but was also required to take over some retirement and medical payments for employees of the former U.S. Post Office, at a cost of millions of dollars. While public attention focuses on the rates for first class mail, the rate increase will cover all classes. Details on the other proposed increases are not yet available, although those increases are expected to spark opposition from advertisers, charities and publishers of magazines and newspapers. Here is a rundown of the cost of mailing a first-class letter since 1863, when the first flat rate was created at 2 cents per half-ounce. In 1885 prices were set to cover a full ounce. July 1, 1885 _ 2 cents Nov. 3, 1917 _ 3 cents July 1, 1919 _ 2 cents July 6, 1932 _ 3 cents Aug. 1, 1958 _ 4 cents Jan. 7, 1963 _ 5 cents Jan. 7, 1968 _ 6 cents May 16, 1971 _ 8 cents March 2, 1974 _ 10 cents Dec. 31, 1975 _ 13 cents May 29, 1978 _ 15 cents March 22, 1981 _ 18 cents Nov. 1, 1981 _ 20 cents Feb. 17, 1985 _ 22 cents April 3, 1988 _ 25 cents

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in quiet trading early today as European markets awaited the outcome of the Soviet Union's Communist Party Central Committee meeting. Gold prices fell. Foreign currency dealers predicted the dollar would come under pressure as soon as attention shifted from political factors to economic ones. ``As soon as (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev demonstrates he has the internal situation under control, the dollar reverts to its economic context,'' said a trader in Milan, Italy. ``In the economic context we have inferior interest rates against the (West German) mark, limited economic growth and inflation not really under control.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.20 yen to a closing 145.10 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 145.35 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.6570 West German marks, unchanged; 1.4798 Swiss francs, up from 1.4770; 5.6422 French francs, up from 5.6405; 1.8710 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8680; 1,234.00 Italian lire, down from 1,235.00; and 1.1892 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1874. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.7022 to buy one pound, compared with $1.7015 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $419.50 a troy ounce, down from $420.85 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $419.90. In Zurich, the bid price was $419.90, down from $420.75 bid late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $1.72 to close at a bid $417.75. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.29 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $5.31.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Edges Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index plunged today as government bond prices slumped, while the dollar edged up against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 364.96 points, or 0.97 percent, closing at 37,301.87. It had gained 35.42 points Tuesday. ``The poor performance in the (Japanese) government bond market made stock investors, especially institutional ones, step off to the sidelines,'' said Kozo Hasunuma, a dealer with Yamaichi Securities Co. While dealers made position adjustments, other investors sold spot issues to collect profits from the price spread between the future and spot markets, Hasunuma added. The Nikkei began falling as soon as Wednesday's trading opened amid uncertainties over the U.S. government bond auction and the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee meeting, said a Nomura Securities analyst, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said many market participants expected Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's performance in the meeting to lead to further reforms and stability, but ``they can't wipe out all the uncertainties.'' Meanwhile, Japanese reportedly bought 30-35 percent of the three-year U.S. government bonds auctioned on Tuesday, but uncertainties remained over the two remaining days of bidding for 10- and 30-year bonds. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 145.10 yen, up 0.20 yen from Tuesday's 144.90-yen close. It opened at 145.18 yen, and ranged between 145.03 yen and 145.34 yen. The dollar had fallen 0.70 yen on Tuesday after a five-day rise totaling 2.38 yen. ``The dollar-yen dealing was inactive in the absence of fresh market-affecting news,'' said Kenzo Shinomiya, a trader with Fuji Bank. Traders said investors were buying West German marks in anticipation that Gorbachev's initiatives in the Soviet party meeting would help maintain stability in Eastern Europe, expected to benefit West German companies. Shinomiya said the currency market reacted positively to Japanese purchases of three-year U.S. government bonds, but Japanese investors were expected to buy fewer of the 10- and 30-year bonds. This would reduce demand for dollars to pay for the bonds.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Secretary Says His Group Will Need Help to Meet Future Demand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subroto is cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: World demand for oil is projected to increase in the 1990s, but the OPEC nations will need financial help to meet that need and avoid another oil crisis, the organization's general secretary says. In an address to some 400 international energy industry executives, Subroto said Tuesday the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will have to increase production capacity to meet the projected demand for oil in this decade. While world demand for oil is projected to rise in the 1990s, non-OPEC supply is expected to fall, Subroto said during a two-day meeting on oil and gas strategies in the 1990s. Subroto said research by OPEC also indicates an oil crisis would ``come at the point when our organization no longer has the production capacity to meet the rising level of demand.'' ``Thus, there is a requirement to expand OPEC production capacity rapidly,'' Subroto said. But such an increase will cost money, he said, and OPEC members would financial assistance from non-OPEC parties in the international oil market. ``We are, simply, talking about a level of expenditure well in excess of our financial capabilities as a group of 13 developing countries,'' said Subroto, who is from Indonesia. ``If we wish to avoid a crisis, we have no alternative course to follow, for without an adequate _ and rapid _ expansion of production capacity, there will sooner or later be a tightening of supply and a rapid rise in prices, followed by years of severe fluctuations in market behavior and considerable wastage of our finite oil reserves,'' he said. But Subroto said the amount of money needed to raise production capacity is ``indeterminable at this stage, and this requires a detailed study in its own right.'' He also called for increased communication, cooperation and mutual trust and respect between OPEC members and non-OPEC parties. ``The atmosphere of confrontation, which for so long characterized relations between OPEC producers and the consuming countries, must be put firmly behind us,'' he said. In addition, he cautioned against implementing protectionist measures on oil products. ``The introduction of discriminatory import levies and extra taxes on oil products, to protect high-cost domestic energy industries, or to reduce budget deficits, would make the goods of such a country less competitive in international markets,'' he said. Meanwhile, the International Energy Agency estimated Tuesday that OPEC slashed oil production last month but not enough to meet its promised goal. The agency said the OPEC nations produced about 23.3 million barrels of crude oil a day in January. That was about 700,000 barrels below December's peak levels but still well above the 22-million-barrel limit OPEC pledged late last year. OPEC ministers agreed in November to cut daily production to 22 million barrels for the first half of 1990. Although the ceiling was 20.5 million barrels a day in the final quarter of 1989, actual production had reached 24 million barrels a day in December boosted by excess flow from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Analysts had expected OPEC members to rein in production even more in January to try to meet the new limit, which was intended to boost oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: Plant Operators Promise Pound of Prevention
DOC.TEXT: The operators of a pesticide unit in a highly populated valley have promised to notify officials of deadly gas leaks after a release of of methyl isocyanate renewed debate over chemical plant safety. The small amount of methyl isocyanate, the same gas that killed 3,500 people at Bhopal, India, escaped from Rhone-Poulenc's Institute plant on Friday and injured seven contract workers. Plant management thought the leak was of little significance and did not report it until Monday. ``In the area of getting information to the public, it's very clear that we misjudged the situation,'' plant manager Ron Bearer said Tuesday at a special meeting called by Kanawha County officials. ``To correct this situation in the future ... all releases of acutely toxic materials, no matter how small, will be communicated.'' The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating to determine why workers were injured. Rhone-Poulenc, which shut down the unit last Wednesday for a scheduled week of maintenance, said it now would be closed indefinitely. Mark Wolford, Kanawha County's emergency services director, said the county rather than the company would determine whether the Kanawha Valley's 250,000 residents should be notified. ``When there is a product that is leaked that would impact on the health of the community, we have to let the people know,'' Wolford said. He added, however, that the county also must not go overboard with its alerts. The Rhone-Poulenc plant is a former Union Carbide operation and includes the only true sister unit to a Carbide unit that leaked in Bhopal in December 1984. In the five months after the Bhopal leak, Union Carbide shut down the unit at Institute and installed millions of dollars worth of safety equipment to prevent leaks. It sold the unit in December 1986. During a routine maintenance operation Friday, plant workers trying to jar a stuck pipe lowered vacuum pressure designed to keep the gas from escaping into the atmosphere. When they loosened the pipe, a gust of methyl isocyanate blew past them. Bearer said it won't happen again. ``They were given the leeway to adjust the vacuum as required,'' he said. ``What we are doing now is going through and changing those procedures. Clearly, we want to maintain a vacuum on there. It's very important. It's a change that has to be made.'' The Institute plant is 10 miles west of Charleston along West Virginia's 15-mile-long Chemical Valley, which includes a string of two dozen chemical plants. Methyl isocyanate is an ingredient in agricultural pesticides, primarily the popular Temik. Rhone-Poulenc usually has 200,000 pounds on hand to convert to intermediate compounds, Bearer said. Union Carbide said the Bhopal leak occurred after saboteurs let water into a storage tank, setting off a reaction. The Indian government accused Carbide of shoddy workmanship. The parties agreed to a $470 million settlement that a new Indian government is seeking to void.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Dismantling Development Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp. is dismantling the Cincinnati-based subsidiary that was to develop new shopping centers around Federated and Allied department stores owned by Campeau. Campeau Development Corp., created in September 1988, was to build as many as 100 shopping centers, mostly joint ventures with the Edward J. DeBartolo Corp. of Youngstown, Ohio. Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., based in Cincinnati, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Act on Jan. 15 listing $7.5 billion in liabilities. Federated Stores Inc., the holding company Toronto-based Campeau formed for the retailers, has scuttled development plans, according to FSI spokeswoman Carol Sanger. ``The CDC's function will be disbanded in three to six months,'' she said. Dissolving the developer will affect about 10 employees, but FSI doesn't know whether it will lay them off or transfer them to new posts, Ms. Sanger said. Campeau Corp. (Canada) will assume CDC's list of projects, which includes a $400 million venture in downtown Columbus, Ohio, Ms. Sanger said. The group's largest project was the $750 million Boston Crossing project where an office, hotel and retail complex was planned.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Transmission Venture to Begin Production Next Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to make f0020 a 1st Ld-Writethru; SUBS grafs 10-13, beg. ``The Muncie plant has been ...'' to CORRECT references to Zimmer; picks up 14th graf, ``David Zimmer ...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT5
DOC.TEXT: The first joint manufacturing agreement between two of the nation's Big Three automakers began like ``the mating of porcupines,'' a Chrysler official said. Chrysler Corp. and General Motors Corp. announced the formation Tuesday of New Venture Gear Inc., a Troy, Mich.-based company operating two plants in New York state and Indiana. Big Three automakers have been involved in joint research projects before, but never a manufacturing business. ``It began as if it were the mating of two porcupines,'' Chrysler Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald said at a news conference. ``The agreement begins a new era for the American automobile industry.'' Greenwald and GM Executive Vice President William Hoglund said no other joint venture between the two automakers or with Ford Motor Co. was in the works. ``It has taken some time to bring us this far,'' Greenwald said. Each of the Big Three has joint vehicle manufacturing agreements with other automakers, mainly Japanese. The GM-Chrysler transmission proposal sailed through federal antitrust review, prompting some critics to complain that the government wasn't taking a strong enough role in regulating big business. Chrysler will own 64 percent and GM will own the rest of New Venture Gear, which will have its headquarters in Troy. The new company will operate plants in Muncie, Ind., and Syracuse, N.Y., and make manual transmissions and components. The Muncie plant now is operated by GM's Hydra-matic Division and the Syracuse factory is run by Chrysler's Acustar subsidiary. Combined, the factories employ about 3,100 people. The Muncie plant has been operating at about 40 percent capacity recently and was in danger of closing, putting its 1,100 employees out of work, said Tom Zimmer, general manager of GM's Hydra-matic Division. The Syracuse plant was working at full capacity. Officials said New Venture Gear was formed to fill out the Muncie plant's capacity and ease the pressure on the Syracuse plant. No layoffs are expected because of the joint venture. Jointly produced elements for manual car and truck transmissions will roll off the lines next year. Representatives of both companies first met in April 1988, said Zimmer. GM and Chrysler signed letters of intent to form the joint venture last October. David Zimmer, president and chief executive officer of New Venture Gear, said the current contracts between the two automakers and the United Auto Workers union would remain in effect at the plants until Sept. 14, when the union's agreements with each of the Big Three end. David Zimmer, no relation to Tom Zimmer, said the company planned to negotiate its own contract with the UAW.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Creates Committee to Pursue Reunification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with new comments from Seiters and economics minister, Honecker and three others to be tried next month. Pickup 10th graf, `Kohl said...' TRIMS from bottom.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: The West German government today created a committee to prepare for eventual German reunification and agreed to pursue immediate talks with East Germany on using a single currency. Rudolf Seiters, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's chief of staff, said the select committee began its work today under the chancellor's leadership. Other panel members include Cabinet ministers in Kohl's government. Seiters said the panel will examine all the steps and decisions necessary for unification, including creation of a monetary union, East German economic reforms and legal questions, as well as issues of foreign policy and security. West Germany will discuss ``confederative cooperation'' with East Germany after East Germany's first free elections on March 18, Seiters said. He made the announcement after Kohl's Cabinet met to hear the chancellor's proposal for urgent talks with East Germany on uniting the two nations' currencies, which would be a giant leap toward reunification. A monetary union would make the West German mark East Germany's currency and turn over much of East Germany's economic sovereignty to West Germany and its central bank. Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said a ``German-German economic miracle'' like the one that made West Germany wealthy is possible as the two countries draw closer together, but that much work needs to be done. Kohl, under domestic pressure to relieve the influx of thousands of East Germans seeking better jobs and housing in the West, said Tuesday: ``People in East Germany must see now that citizens of West Germany are ready to help.'' Nonetheless, new signs are emerging that both German states may have to make huge sacrifices to rescue East Germany's ailing economy. A newspaper quoted officials as saying that under reunification, West Germany would have to pay billions to salvage East Germany's economy. In East Berlin today, three leftist opposition movements agreed to join forces and campaign as a coalition for East Germany's March 18 elections, said the ADN news agency. The three are New Forum, Democracy Now and the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights, said ADN. New Forum is East Germany's best-known pro-democracy movement. Three conservative opposition groups, including the Democratic Awakening, also have joined forces for East Germany's first free elections. Also today, authorities said ousted East German Communist Party leader Erich Honecker, who faces charges of high treason, will be tried together with three of his former lieutenants before the country's Supreme Court next month. Lother Reuter, deputy attorney general, said the four face charges including ``blatant human rights violations,'' ``complete hindrance of media freedom'' and ``deformation of the people's economy.'' Kohl said details for talks with East Germany on reunification would be worked out when Premier Hans Modrow of East Germany visits Bonn next week. Kohl did not give a deadline for the monetary union, but government sources said on condition of anonymity that Kohl shared Finance Minister Theodor Waigel's view that it should come before the end of the year. The newspaper Bild said Waigel wants East Germans to be able to exchange their currency for West German marks at a 1-1 ratio. The current official rate is three East marks for one West mark. But Waigel also expects the process of creating a free-market economy in East Germany will result in a huge loss of jobs until new positions under new economic conditions can be created, Bild reported. According to Bild, Waigel is proposing that West Germany pay out unemployment benefits to East Germans left jobless by economic overhaul and has estimated that would cost $6 billion annually. Helmut Geiger, head of the West German Savings Bank Association, said monetary union would cost the West Germans a ``double-digit billion-mark sum.'' He said that would probably lead to tax increases in West Germany, higher budget deficits and an end to talk of shorter work weeks. The head of West Germany's central bank, Karl Otto Poehl, also has voiced reservations about a speedy monetary union. East German officials, while acknowledging that sharing the same currency could ease some immediate problems, generally have resisted such a move because of fears that it would erode the value of East German savings. They also fear that unprofitable, state enterprises would have to close, forcing large layoffs. An accelerating exodus to West Germany, strikes and absenteeism are driving East Germany's economy toward the brink of collapse.

The stock market was broadly lower in early trading today, pressured by ongoing concerns about this week's Treasury's refunding. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 20.27 points to 2,586.04 at 10 a.m. EST, 30 minutes after the opening bell. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a margin of nearly 5 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 835 issues down, 178 up and 378 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 24.08 million shares. Analysts said weakness in the bond market kept stocks under pressure. The market's worries stem from the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction and whether yields will have to be forced higher to attract Japanese investors. The three-day auction, which began on Tuesday, comprises $30 billion in notes and bonds. Tuesday's refunding included $10 billion of three-year notes. Today's refunding will include $10 billion in 10-year notes and the final part on Thursday will comprise $10 billion of 30-year Treasury bonds. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 1.47 at 180.86. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 354.01, down 0.73. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, Harcourt Brace was down [ to 2, Pan Am was off [ to 3{, AT&T was down { to 39 and American Express had slipped { to 28}. Among the Big Board gainers, Baxter International was up [ to 23], IBM had gained [ to 101[ and Hong Kong Telephone had advanced \ to 20. On Tuesday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.21 to 2,606.31. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 578 up, 909 down and 499 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 134.07 million shares, only slightly ahead of the 130.95 million shares traded on Monday in the slowest session to date in the new year.
