DOC.HEAD: Is New England a Flashback To Texas?
Graphic in AP Access under BANKWOES
DOC.TEXT: In June 1988, U.S. Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke told banks that aggressive uncontrolled expansion can lead to deep trouble. ``Growth for growth's sake, or growth without the resources to back it up, is a highly risky strategy because it leaves the bank exposed when the economy turns down,'' he said. Those words read like an epitaph for the Texas banking industry, where eight of the 10 largest holding companies were failing, crushed by awesome credit losses during a bust in the oil economy. But up in New England, Clarke's message was a prophecy of things to come. Banks caught in the euphoria of a construction boom have watched the economy turn sour. The real estate market has tumbled, giving banks a staggering amount of bad loans and putting one of the region's largest banks _ Bank of New England Corp. _ in a fight for survival. These troubles echo the story in Texas, but analysts say New England should not have a repeat performance, even though bankers apparently failed to learn from mistakes made in the Southwest. ``I suppose they thought it could happen to dumb Texans, but not happen to wise, conservative Yankees,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. ``Poor management shows up when the economy goes bad.'' The New England banking industry in recent months has resembled an infirmary's list of wounded. Among the nine states that showed the biggest increases in troubled real estate loans from December 1988 to last September, six were in New England, industry estimates show. Bank of Boston Corp., the region's largest bank, reported a record $125 million loss for the third quarter of 1989, and for the year it had a 78 percent drop in earnings. Bank of New England said osses in 1989 should surpass $1 billion, and it is trying to sell $6 billion in assets. Analysts say Bank of New England has been one of the biggest victims of the regional real estate slump, since it competed aggressively to make construction loans earlier in the 1980s, sacrificing sound credit policies in order to build its empire. The eagerness shown by Bank of New England and other banks to lend their money for construction projects is one of the biggest similarities to what happened in Texas, experts say. The economies in both regions had been robust; in Texas the driving force was oil and energy while in New England it was largely the high-tech and defense industries. The growth in these economies fueled rapid buildups in office space and housing, providing a quick avenue for banks to boost assets by making construction loans. In both cases, however, this led to excessive speculation by developers, which resulted in overbuilding. Thus, as the Texas economy, and then the New England economy, began to slide, building projects had trouble finding tenants, developers couldn't make loan payments, and the banks lost money. ``It was one big party,'' said Gerard Cassidy, a banking analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc. in Portland, Maine. ``Then the party stopped, and now the hangover started.'' ``There were projects built that should have never been built, no question,'' said Leo Spang, senior vice president of commercial real estate at Shawmut Bank in Boston. But Spang said the trouble is more manageable in New England, partly because the economy is more diversified and there simply was much less speculation. Analysts agree with that assessment, and they say New England should not experience the flurry of bank closings similar to what occurred in Texas. ``The Texas debacle was so much greater in size and magnitude,'' Cassidy said. But he added: ``There are too many similarities to rule out that New England will become another Texas.'' Banks in Texas and in New England each made the same mistake in judgment, said Alex Sheshunoff, president of Sheshunoff & Co., a banking information and consulting firm in Austin, Texas. ``They underestimated the capacity of builders to overbuild,'' he said. ``As the phrase goes, `The demand was for a million square feet of space, and 10 developers went out and built it.''' Some banks in New England showed more restraint. Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc. in Providence, R.I., for example, quit making loans for condominiums about three years ago, said Robert Lougee, a company spokesman. The condo market, in particular, has been a major source of troubled loans, but at Fleet-Norstar ``there were obviously some who saw overdevelopment going on,'' Lougee said. He noted, however, that banking officials foresaw a downturn in the real estate market based on their own experiences, not on any lessons from Texas. ``It's sort of the history of finance,'' said Robert Litan, a banking expert with the Brookings Institution in Washington. ``No one learns from the last disaster, especially when they didn't have any part in it.'' The federal government, though, appears to have learned from the Texas experience, and analysts say regulators have been more swift to crack down on New England banks. ``Here it's taking (regulators) only several weeks to realize what's going on,'' said Mas Kakutani, a banking analyst with Moody's Investors Service Inc. in New York. ``The deterioration of New England banks has been more severe than anything we saw in Texas, in terms of quickness.'' ``We are certainly trying to reflect some of the lessons learned from Texas,'' said Seidman at the FDIC. Seidman said regulators were taking a cautious look at New England before the serious problems surfaced, and he said officials in the future will pay closest attention to banks that grow the fastest. ``Once bitten, twice shy,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Feb. 11

DOC.HEAD: Existing Home Sales Rose in Last Quarter of 1989
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 6th graf, The Realtors, to make increase of 4.3 percent, to $93,100, for the year, sted last quarter.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes, responding to lower interest rates and weaker prices in some areas, rose 2.1 percent during the fourth quarter of 1989 but were still down 4.3 percent for the year as a whole, a real estate trade group said today. The National Association of Realtors said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.85 million units during the October-December period. Sales for the year, which were buffeted in the first half by double-digit mortgage interest rates, fell to 3.78 million units from 3.95 million in 1988. After rates peaked in March and dropped into the single digits in July, sales perked up in the final two quarters. Realtors President Norman D. Flynn said the 1990 housing market is expected to be much like 1989 _ strong in some areas, average in others and sluggish in parts of the nation where the economy is weak. Sales include single-family detached homes, town houses, apartment condominiums and cooperatives. The Realtors said the national median price of existing homes rose 4.6 percent to $92,800 during the fourth quarter of 1989 and were up 4.3 percent, to $93,100, for the year. The median means half of the homes cost more and half cost less. Honolulu had the highest fourth-quarter median price for a home, $280,900, compared with $47,200 in Peoria, Ill. Twenty-nine states had sales increases in the fourth quarter, ranging from a 0.9 percent gain in Hawaii to a 30.5 percent hike in Vermont. Only the Northeast and the Midwest posted sales growths below the national average of 2.1 percent in the October-December period. Sales were down 2.6 percent in the Northeast to an annual rate of 701,000 units while they rose 1 percent to 1.04 million units in the Midwest. Sales were up 2.8 percent to an annual rate of 1.45 million in the South and 8.2 percent to 660,000 in the West, the Realtors said. The West also had the biggest jump in median prices, a 9 percent advance to $141,600, in the fourth quarter 1988. It was followed by gains of 5.9 percent to $71,700 in the Midwest, 4.3 percent to $83,100 in the South and 0.9 percent to $144,000 in the Northeast. In addition to Hawaii, three other Western areas held the top median prices in the quarter. The San Francisco Bay area was second with a $260,600 median price, followed by Orange County, $247,900, and Los Angeles, $217,000. For the decade, median existing home prices rose 49.7 percent, from $62,200 to $93,100.

Stock prices bounced back from earlier lows but remained mixed as investors continued to focus on today's Treasury refunding. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 1.57 points to 2,607.88 at 11 a.m. EST. The blue-chip indicator was 20.27 points lower an hour earlier. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a margin of about 9 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 737 issues down, 404 up and 515 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 56.94 million shares. Analysts said blue-chip stocks were reviving, led by sharp gains in IBM issues, although weakness in the bond market continued to pressure stocks. ``The trend is back to more positive,'' said Dennis Jarrett, technical analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``People are starting to discount what's going on with the refunding.'' The market's worries stem from the Treasury's quarterly auction and concerns about whether yields will have to be forced higher to attract Japanese investors. Although Tuesday's $10 billion auction of three-year notes was considered successful, analysts said concerns persisted that Tuesday's activity might run out of steam for today's $10 billion sale of 10-year notes. The final auction on Thursday will comprise $10 billion of 30-year Treasury bonds. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.24 at 182.09. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 0.13 at 354.61. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, IBM was up 2[ to 103[, Haliburton had gained 1| to 44 and Federal National Mortgage had advanced 1\ to 34\. AT&T, meanwhile, was down [ at 39], Bank of New England had lost ~ to 5~ and Burlington Northern was off ] to 31\.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Advance In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting stronger cash markets for soybeans and improved foreign demand for U.S. grains. Broadly underpinning the gains were reports that Communist Party leaders in the Soviet Union have approved sweeping political reforms recommended by their leader, Mikhail Gorbachev. The Soviets' swing toward democracy is seen as increasing the chances the United States will grant most-favored-trade status to the Soviet Union, which could lead to bigger grain deals with the United States. A slowdown in farmer selling is helping to boost soybean futures, as is an increase in soybean meal demand in Europe, analysts said. Signs of stronger export demand for corn are helping corn prices while wheat is gaining amid indications of a sale of U.S. wheat to Egypt. In early trading, wheat futures prices were \ cent to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.83{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent higher with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent higher with March at $1.36 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 1} cents higher with March at $5.64{ a bushel. Cattle futures were narrowly mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures were mostly higher. Live cattle futures were .20 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 79.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .05 cent higher with March at 82.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .30 cent higher with February at 49.02 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .03 cent to .25 cent higher with February at 50.70 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Tuesday; pork bellies were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Sets Date for Vote on Recap Plan
DOC.TEXT: Georgia Gulf Corp. said Wednesday it scheduled a meeting April 19 for shareholders to vote on a recapitalization plan intended to discourage a takeover by Texas investor Harold C. Simmons. NL Industries Inc., a Houston-based chemical supplier controlled by Simmons, has launched a $1.1 billion tender offer for Georgia Gulf despite the proposed recapitalization. The Atlanta commodity chemical maker said shareholders of record Feb. 18 will be eligible to vote on the proposal, valued by the company at $55 a share. NL's offer is $45 a share. Georgia Gulf stock was up 25 cents a share to $41.75 in early New York Stock Exchange trading today. In January, Georgia Gulf announced the recapitalization proposal after months of speculation over Simmons' intent. He owns about 9 percent of Georgia Gulf and had indicated an interest in boosting the value of his investment. The proposed recapitalization had been regarded by Wall Street analysts as a move to placate Simmons by paying a special dividend of more than $50 a share. A recapitalization generally involves a company borrowing a large sum of money to pay shareholders a special dividend or to expand the company. Georgia Gulf Chairman James R. Kuse earlier this week appealed to stockholders to delay making a decision on NL's buyout offer until the company's management reviews the bid and makes a recommendation.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at noon was 424.03 up 0.04 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Wants Administration to Detail Farm Bill Spending Needs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with today's testimony.
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee criticized the Bush administration today for not recommending specific price support levels and other spending details in its 1990 farm bill proposal. ``We can't write a farm bill without an idea of what the administration wants,'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., told Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter at a hearing of the agriculture committee. ``I want specifics.'' Yeutter said he would immediately start negotiations over spending with the committee if Leahy desired. But he said he thought such talks should be in a private setting, instead of a public hearing. ``The administration will not declare today what it's position is on target prices,'' said Yeutter. He noted that the fiscal 1991 budget called for $10.2 billion overall for target prices, but would not say how the money should be distributed. He also refused to suggest target price amounts for the other four years of the five-year farm bill. Leahy said the administration was putting Congress in a ``damned if you do, damned if you don't position'' on spending. Yeutter said he preferred to work it out with the committee so he would not be alone in sticking out his neck. ``I want to make sure there are 20 necks there instead of just one,'' he said. ``This document doesn't deal with budget, it deals with policy,'' Yeutter told a news conference Tuesday in unveiling proposals for the 1990 farm bill. ``I see no reason why we should not be able to provide net farm income that would give a very satisfactory standard of living to farmers even though the federal contribution will decline,'' he said. Leahy said there were positive aspects in Yeutter's proposals, such as planting flexibility and emergency food aid programs. But, he said, ``the administration still refuses to actively help farmers cut pesticide and chemical use.'' Shortly before Yeutter unveiled his proposals, 11 national consumer and environmental groups released a report outlining certain environmental objectives they want incorporated into the next farm bill. ``The public is demanding that we protect our environment and safeguard our food supply,'' said Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., an Agriculture Committee member who spoke at a press conference with the coalition. He said the nation needs ``a stronger and less begrudging commitment to integrated pest management, low-input farming and other promising alternatives in USDA research and extension programs than we have seen up to now.'' Leahy said in a statement that proposals by the organizations ``will be an important part of the debate over the 1990 farm bill and will be taken seriously.'' The groups offered suggestions for preserving water quality, wetlands and fertile soil and promoted incentives for ``sustainable'' agriculture, a farming method that avoids extensive use of chemicals. Yeutter also offered groundwater proposals and said the planting flexibility he would like in the new legislation should please those promoting sustainable agriculture, which uses crop rotation among other methods to protect the environment. House Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, played down the importance of the administration proposals. He and Rep. Edward Madigan, R-Ill. introduced their farm bill Monday. De la Garza said the administration proposals ``may have an impact as we deliberate our bill. There are no items in our bill and the administration proposals that cannot be worked out.'' Highlights of Yeutter's recommendations include: _A ``normal crop acreage'' concept to allow farmers to plant crops based on market demand without loss of farm program benefits. It would define crops that could be substituted for program crops, authorize crop-specific acreage reduction programs and provide authority to plant on idled acres in exchange for giving up specified deficiency payments. _Replacing crop insurance with a new crop disaster resistance program patterned after the ad hoc disaster legislation passed in 1988 and 1989 following the drought. It would eliminate need for such ad hoc bills, Yeutter said. _A grain reserves and stocks policy based on annual contracts that give the farmer more say in when stocks should be released into the marketplace. _Making the trigger for acreage reduction programs more consistent with market and farmer needs. _Extending the loan rate formula for wheat and feedgrains to upland cotton, extra longstaple cotton and rice. The 1985 loan rate formula for soybeans also would be extended. _Incentives to use perennial cover crops on set-aside acreage as a means to naturally improve soil fertility. _Methods for cutting down fraud in use of food stamps; grants to organizations that test innovative ways to get food stamps to the homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Anheuser-Busch Income Falls on Price Discounts But Firm Picks Up Market Share
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. said Wednesday its recently announced discount program held fourth-quarter earnings to a 2 percent increase, but the move helped the company improve its share of the national beer market share by a full point. Earnings for the fourth quarter were $128.1 million, or 45 cents per share, on sales of $2.49 billion, compared with earnings of $125.5 million, or 44 cents per share, on sales of $2.37 billion in the same period a year ago. August A. Busch III, chairman and president, said that as a result of the price discounting program, beer sales grew by 2.2 million barrels in 1989, widening the company's lead over its nearest competitor by 700,000 barrels and increasing its market share by one point to 42.1 percent. ``Our volume increased by 2.8 percent, reaching a total of 80.7 million barrels during the year,'' said Busch. ``Our growth rate gave us a larger volume and market share increase than any other brewer.'' Busch acknowledged that fourth quarter earnings were affected by the discounting program, but he said increases in sales to retailers were encouraging. ``We anticipate that our long-term market share growth strategy will ultimately pay off in an even stronger market position and in higher earnings for the company and its wholesalers,'' he said. Earnings for the full year reached $767.2 million, or $2.68 per share, on sales of $10.28 billion, up from earnings of $715.9 million, or $2.45 per share, on sales of $9.71 billion in 1988. Busch said the company's goals in the next five years are to increase beer wolume to achieve a 50 percent market share and to further expand its non-beer profit base with additional investments. Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewer, has led the industry in sales every year since 1957.

DOC.NOTE: $adv07
DOC.HEAD: For PMs Wednesday Feb. 7
Locking In Dividends
DOC.TEXT: While many conservative investors are chasing interest rates in the bond and CD markets, a lesser publicized group is loading up on corporate dividends. Surprisingly, the dividend rates of some pretty solid companies equal and sometimes exceed rates available from bonds and certificates of deposit. Among them: General Motors and Ford Motor at better than 7 percent, Manufacturers Hanover Bank at about 10, Great Northern Iron about 9, Perkins Family Restaurants at 8, Occidental Petroleum, nearly 9. Lesser known, but often higher paying, are several investment trusts. For example, the Massachusetts Financial Service's Multimarket Income Trust and the Hancock Investment Trust both offer about 10 percent. Meanwhile, U.S. Treasury debt securities, super-safe investments, generally are in the range of about 8.5 percent, high-grade corporate bonds about 9 percent or slightly more, and tax-exempts around 7. While some advisers recommend locking-in the current yields on bonds before _ and if _ they rise in price, the same advice can be given for dividends. Stocks too can rise, sometimes sharply, adding to the investor's total return. In fact, based on long-term records, some stocks paying high dividends may also be underpriced. General Motors, for example, is selling at between six and seven times earnings, and Ford only four times, well below market averages. The reason dividends get overlooked has a good deal to do with the changing nature of the market. Decades ago, the level of dividends was often the primary consideration among investors. That was before the go-go days. In the past two decades, market advisers have tended to emphasize short-term price performance _ to look for takeover candidates, for stocks that might rise with the introduction of new products, for companies with sudden earnings increases. In such an atmosphere, long-term dividend prospects count little. Rather pallid looking dividend payments didn't help, especially in the stock market boom following the early-1980s recession. In 1978 and 1979, dividends averaged 6 percent, but since 1986 they've averaged under 4 percent. Averages always permit exceptions, however, and included in the exceptions are companies that appear underpriced by long-term standards. Should they rise in price, there is a chance the dividends might even increase. However, even if the dividends do not increase, the price of the stock might. International Business Machines, for example, offers a dividend yield at just under 5 percent. It is also selling at 15 times earnings, well below its norm. Should it return to form, current owners would have locked in both a solid dividend _ plus a hefty return from the appreciated value of their stock. Nobody knows what the future holds, but there is a sense in Wall Street and other investment centers that the emphasis might return to longer-term performance and that investors might be ready to re-emphasize fundamentals. If so, it is possible that you might hear ordinary investors listening for tips about overlooked companies with solid earnings and solid dividends. In short, what investors used to look for before the swingers moved in.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Wednesday Feb. 7

DOC.HEAD: Graphic
Electronic Filing Speeds Refund Process, But You Pay Extra
DOC.TEXT: If you're tired of waiting the usual six to eight weeks for your income tax refund, Uncle Sam will gladly let you cut in line, but the privilege costs money. The Internal Revenue Service has expanded its electronic tax filing system nationally this year, allowing anyone due a refund _ or about 70 percent of the 110 million expected returns _ to file directly into the government's computers. Those owing money can't participate. Last year, 36 states were plugged into the system, up from 14 states the previous year and three cities when it was first tested in 1986. The IRS says the high-tech approach will save an over-burdened agency about $200 million in processing costs over 10 years and substantially reduce errors. That will mean speedier refunds for taxpayers filing electronically _ about three weeks, vs. the usual six to eight weeks from filing the old-fashioned way by mail, tax experts say. Those choosing to receive their refund through direct bank deposit can expect the money in about two weeks. But like anything else the taxpayer must pay for this efficiency. Many accountants warn that unless you're expecting a refund well into four figures, it may not be worth it. ``The economics are clearly not there for some people,'' said Stephen Corrick, a tax partner for the accounting firm Arthur Andersen & Co. ``It's also not for people with complicated returns.'' The IRS's embrace of pre-approved electronic filing has spawned a new type of accounting service that will transmit your return via computer for a fee. Individuals can't use personal computers to file directly on their own yet. Filing fees range from around $20 to $50, with costs usually lower for individuals whose returns are prepared by the same services. Many companies will advance you the return within days for an additional $30 to $35 fee. For those needing money in a hurry or without available credit lines it may be worth paying the added expense. ``(But) you have to ask yourself what is the time value of the interest associated with my getting the refund,'' said Richard H. Lager, a managing partner with the Grant Thornton accounting firm. For example, if you invested a $1,000 refund check in a money market account at 9 percent interest, that interest compounded annually would amount to only $7.50 a month. It's probably a lot cheaper to get a one-month cash advance from your credit card _ even at the 18 percent interest _ than to pay the fee of the electronic filer, Lager said. Kansas City, Mo.-based H&R Block Inc. is clearly the largest of the nation's tax preparers to participate in the program. Last year it filed 70 percent of the 1.2 million returns sent electronically, said Harry Buckley, president of H&R Block's tax preparations division. In addition, niche companies, such as San Diego, Calif.-based InstaTax, have set up thousands of storefronts nationwide in which consumers can fax their forms to a data processing center, which, in turn, enters the return immediately on a computer connected to the IRS. Customers who use these services still have to send out a short form, which is their proof of signature, and attach their their W-2 forms and other documentation. Some electronic tax filing services accept floppy disks or direct transmission from an individual's personal computer. Store-bought programs such as McInTax will do the arithmetic. PC-users may some day be able to file directly on their own, but IRS spokesman Frank Keith that's a long time away since the technology is not quite there yet. This year, though, the IRS is working with a handful of banks in the Boston area testing how taxpayers who owe money can file electronically and have the amount deducted from their accounts, Keith said. For now, the IRS is promoting its refund electronic filing system, offering lists of accountants and companies hooked into its computer for those calling a toll-free number. As of Feb. 1, the IRS received 608,350 electronic returns, about 8 percent of all the returns received so far. Keith says the agency predicts it will get at least 2 million electronic return this tax season, up from 1.2 million for 1989. Only 25,000 were received when the program began four years ago. By the end of the century, the IRS predicts that at least 30 percent of all returns will be electronically, Keith said. --- EDITORS NOTE: The IRS toll-free number is 1-800-424-1040.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday, Feb. 8

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: Prices fell in a roller coaster session on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday on uncertainty over the outcome of the ongoing U.S. Treasury bond auctions. Wall Street opened on weak footing and continued lower throughout most of the London afternoon. Later, a mid-session reversal took New York prices higher and pulled London equities up from their session lows. ``We've got a return of the roller coaster days of a few weeks ago,'' said one director at a large U.S. brokerage firm. Commentators said investors were unsettled by weakness in the West German bond market. Some worried that Wednesday's auction of 10-year Treasury bonds would be turbulent. The auctions end Thursday. At the London closing, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was down 13.7 points, or 0.6 percent, at 2,307.4, well above its session low of 2,299.1 but down from a midmorning peak of 2,320.6. Volume amounted to a light 368.1 million shares, compared with 407.8 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: If There Is A Peace Dividend, Give It To The People
DOC.TEXT: There is no peace dividend yet and there may never be one, but proposals for spending it already are being offered by individuals and groups with a cause. Now comes an original one: Don't spend it. Give it back to the people. The proposals to spend the dividend, some say, are examples of the urgency with which advocates, activists, elected officials and supporters of big government promote private agendas at the public's expense. As imagined, the peace dividend would result from a quick cutback in the United States defense budget as world tensions ease, freeing billions of dollars for use elsewhere. But it will never exist, says economist Stuart Butler, ``so long as Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union remain in turmoil and so long as there is no consensus in the United States regarding future defense needs.'' In spite of this, Butler and his Heritage Foundation colleagues said they found advocates of various programs already holding news conferences to propose ways in which to spend the money. Therefore, they offer theirs. Butler, director of domestic policy studies at Heritage, a conservative think tank, proposes 11 tax cuts totaling more than $107 billion a year in relief. Each member of Congress was scheduled to receive a copy this week: 1. Reduce the tax burden on the elderly by eliminating the Social Security earnings test. Currently, Americans between ages 65 and 69 who earn more than $9,360 are required to give up $1 in Social Security benefits for every $3 they earn. ``This is an effective 33 percent tax on earnings, on top of all the other federal, state and local taxes that are deducted,'' according to the paper. The effect, it says, is to drive such people out of the work force. 2. Index the Social Security benefits tax for inflation. 3. Roll back Social Security payroll taxes and return Social Security to pay-as-you-go financing. This is the proposal already put forth by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y. 4. Increase the personal income tax exemption to $6,300 for each child under 18 years of age, from its current level of $2,000. Commentary: If the tax burden on families were reduced, ``most families could meet their children's needs according to their own priorities and would not need new government programs.'' 5. Provide tax credits to households to cover medical expenses and health insurance premiums. 6. Provide tax incentives for the purchase of long-term care insurance. 7. Designate 100 federal enterprise zones to spur economic development in the inner cities. 8. Reduce the capital gains tax. 9. Expand the Earned Income Tax Credit, or EITC. The EITC is a tax credit for low-income workers with children. Butler and staff maintain that when combined with other welfare programs, an expanded EITC might lift a single mother from poverty even if she earned the minimum wage. 10. Provide a toddler tax credit. The Heritage analysts say the current child-care crisis, as it is sometimes termed, could be solved by giving money directly to parents so they could determine how best to care for their children. 11. Restore IRA eligibility to all individuals. The 1986 Tax Reform Act sharply curtailed the number of people who could qualify for Individual Retirement Accounts, in which savings accumulate free of taxes. Says Butler: Remind your representatives in Congress that dividends are normally paid to investors (the people) not kept by the corporation (Congress).
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday, Feb. 8

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Company Announces Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co. will lay off more than 10 percent of its employees by Feb. 23 because of reduced defense spending by the government, company president William P. Brown announced today. The move will involve about 400 workers each at the company's base plant here and at its California Manufacturing Center in Culver City, Calif. The company employs 5,900 in Mesa and 1,650 in Culver City. ``We must reduce our workforce to meet the reality of our delivery schedule with the U.S. Army,'' Brown said in a prepared statement. The plant here has been producing Apache helicopters for the Army at the rate of 10 per month. Brown said that number would be reduced to six a month in June under a contract which ends in mid-1993. He said the company still has good prospects of international sales of Apaches. The other step in the company's retrenchment is elimination or delay of discretionary spending, Brown said. That means postponing a proposed expansion here to accommodate production of the new MDX and MD-520N and MD-530N helicopters. The expansion was scheduled to begin last month, but Brown said the plan had been put on hold. Other casualties of the moratorium on non-critical spending will include employee travel, participation in industry trade shows and replacement of non-essential equipment. ``Competing in world markets, particularly with reductions in defense spending, requires strong measures to be taken,'' Brown said. ``McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co. continues to be an industry leader in financial strength as well as in the quality of the products we produce.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar finished mixed against major currencies Wednesday in nervous European trading with continued interest in the West German mark. Gold prices rose. A lack of market-moving news made dealers reluctant to trade heavily and kept the dollar within a narrow range. Dealers said the developments in Moscow, with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev winning Communist Party support for his sweeping reforms, had already been factored into the foreign exchange markets. ``There just isn't any trend,'' said a trader at a large Frankfurt bank. ``It's very difficult to make money.'' In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 145.10 Japanese yen from 144.90 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 145.45 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6995 from $1.7015 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's levels were: 1.6545 West German marks, down from 1.6570; 1.4805 Swiss francs, up from 1.4770; 5.6335 French francs, down from 5.6405; 1.8650 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8680; 1,234.50 Italian lire, down from 1,235.00; and 1.1932 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1874. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $423 a troy ounce from $420.85 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $422.25 from $420.75 bid late Tuesday. DOC.HEAD: Some Venture Capitalists Invest In Broccoli, Cruise Ships
Graphic planned
DOC.TEXT: When Jack Hesse talks about ``seed'' capital, he means, well, seeds. Broccoli seeds. Onion. Carrot. Corn. Most venture capitalists use ``seed capital'' to describe money invested in a range of risky startup companies to help them sprout a product. Hesse, who heads the Boston-based Plant Resources Venture Fund, is one of a growing number of venture capitalists to concentrate investment on just one industry. So-called focused funds may target only chemicals, or retailing, or biotechnology, or entertainment, for example. In Hesse's case, it's agribusiness. Focused funds evolved partly because of disappointment in the mixed performances of much broader venture capital funds in recent years. ``In the 1980s there were too many plain-vanilla funds using the same (investment) strategies,'' said Mark Radtke, a vice president at the Boston-based investment firm Advent International Corp. ``But to perform well, you must have a competitive advantage.'' Because managers of focused funds usually have extensive experience in the industry they invest in, they are better equipped to spot innovation and far more likely, many say, to back startups than large, diversified venture capital companies. Charlie Bass holds a Ph.D. in electrical engineering and has founded and run a handful of telecommunications companies. His 4-month-old Bass Associates Inc. in Palo Alto, Calif., invests strictly within that industry. Bass recently pumped money into Racotek Inc., a mobile radio startup in Minneapolis that links truck radios with personal computers. ``The large, general-purpose funds are both less able and less willing to play in these early-stage, specialized markets,'' Bass said. In addition, they ``don't have as much time to do hands-on work with smaller companies,'' said Larry Coleman, president of Franklin Venture Capital Inc. in Nashville, Tenn. Coleman, a former executive of Hospital Corp. of America and a biochemist-immunologist by training, invests in medical product and service companies. In less than three years, his $18 million fund has invested in 16 companies, more than half of them startups. A year ago Coleman backed Flying Nurses Inc., a nurse staffing startup in Dallas that has grown more than tenfold in both revenue and income, he said. Proponents of focused funds say it's much too early to judge their success rate. Nonetheless, some venture capital experts say the focused strategy is flawed because it's so narrow. ``Are there enough deals that are good financial investments and fit in a particular sector?'' Radtke said. ``The more focused you are, the harder it can be to generate deals.'' Focused fund managers Don Phillips and Cece Smith dispute that argument. They say they review 600 to 700 business plans a year before picking the four or five choicest prospects. Phillips is a former chief executive of Pearle Health Services, which runs a chain of eye-care centers. He and Smith, another ex-Pearle executive, formed Phillips-Smith Specialty Retail Group, a Dallas-based fund that invests only in innovative retailers, mostly startups. After three years, the group has $70 million under management, making it a startup success in its own right. Despite the success stories, the venture capital business is in flux. The amount of venture money invested over the past few years has varied between about $3 billion and $4 billion. But the amount of new money raised for venture capital funds has fallen. Last year, for example, private venture funds raised an estimated $2.4 billion, down 43 percent from the 1987 peak of $4.2 billion, said Venture Economics Inc., a Needham, Mass.-based research concern. ``The money is declining, and there's probably some consolidation going on,'' said Tom Baruch, a partner of Chemicals and Materials Enterprise Associates in Boston. ``People with special expertise will be sought out.'' Baruch enticed corporate giants including 3M, Exxon and Ford Motor Co. to contribute at least $3 million apiece to a fund investing in materials technologies. ``They see it as an opportunity to get a window on new technologies,'' he said. Focused funds are crossing international boundaries. Representatives of Advent Western Pacific Management, for example, have been visiting financial institutions in the United States and Asia, seeking $35 million to be funneled into Australia's tourism industry. The Melbourne-based fund already has raised $8 million, part of which has financed cruise ships that tour Sydney harbor and the Murray River. The fund also has an equity stake in the Sydney aquarium and theme park. Venture capitalists are maverick and often eccentric businesspeople whom entrepreneurs turn to when banks reject their loan applications. Typically, money is exchanged for a stake in the company and, perhaps, a seat or two on its board of directors. Rather than take a passive role, venture capitalists nurture a company, often forming close ties with the entrepreneurs. The big payoff theoretically comes when venture capitalists either sell a company or take it public in a stock offering. Returns can be astronomical. But the ability to divest a company largely depends upon the prevailing mood in the marketplace. This can put focused funds at a special disadvantage. ``You are at the mercy of what the stock market is saying about the industry,'' Radtke said. ``You don't have complete control over what the background economy is going to be when you want to exit these companies.'' An inability to divest a company ``is definitely an issue,'' said Bass of Bass Associates. ``It puts an added premium on working in a robust segment of the market.'' It is too early to measure the success of focused funds against their diversified counterparts. Funds younger than three years old are still investing and probably have no returns. ``They're like a child,'' said Stephen Piper of Venture Economics, ``you don't know if they'll grow up to be a criminal or the president.''

Times Mirror Says Earnings Dropped 23.5 Percent in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Times Mirror Corp. posted profit declines of 23.5 percent for the fourth quarter and 10.2 percent for the year, due in part to lower earnings at many of its Eastern newspapers and in its consumer magazines and broadcast TV operations. The big communications and publishing company said Wednesday it earned $74.1 million, or 57 cents per share, in the October-December quarter, compared with $96.8 million, or 76 cents per share, in the same period in 1988. Revenue rose 1.1 percent for the quarter, from $925 million to $935 million, despite the fact that the quarter included six fewer days of newspaper operation than the same period of 1988. Fourth-quarter 1989 results reflected a loss provision of 6 cents per share on the expected sale of newspaper press equipment. The comparable 1988 earnings included a gain of 1 cent per share from asset sales. Excluding those factors, per-share earnings would have declined 16 percent, from 75 cents to 63 cents, Times Mirror said. For the year, Times Mirror reported earnings of $298 million, or $2.30 per share, compared with $332 million, or $2.58 per share, in 1988. Revenue rose 5.5 percent to $3.52 billion from $3.33 billion. Excluding net gains of 5 cents per share in 1989 and 31 cents per share in 1988, yearly per-share earnings would have fallen by 1 percent, from $2.27 to $2.25, the company said. Timberlands and other assets were sold in 1988; a gain from selling timberlands in 1989 was offset to some extent by the fourth-quarter loss provision on the expected sale of the press equipment. ``1989 was a year of mixed results,'' Times Mirror Chairman Robert F. Erburu said. ``Most of our Eastern newspapers, our consumer magazines and our Broadcast Television group experienced difficult operating conditions.'' However, he said, results were impressive from Times Mirror's flagship newspaper, the Los Angeles Times, and Times Mirror's cable-TV operations and publishing companies. For the full year, earnings improved at the Los Angeles Times, the Baltimore Sun newspapers and The Morning Call of Allentown, Pa., Times Mirror said. But Newsday's profit was sharply lower, and results at The Hartford Courant and the company's southern Connecticut newspapers also declined.

DOC.HEAD: Inventor Concocts Gizmos That Give Him Love-Hate Relationship with Cops
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Police may like Kip Fuller for keeping drunks off the road, but they're not too happy that he helps speeders outwit radar traps by turning cars into ground versions of a Stealth bomber. Fuller invented the Guardian Interlock, which deactivates a car's ignition system if the driver can't pass an alcohol breathalyzer test. They are used by law enforcers in at least 18 states. The Denver inventor's latest innovation is known as a stealth car bra, so named because it resembles a brassiere strapped to the front of a vehicle. Made of radar-absorbing carbon fibers, the bra enables a car to fool police radar until it reaches close range, permitting drivers to spot the trap and slow down before their speed is clocked. ``I'm not anti-government,'' said Fuller, 33. ``I try to develop products that assist the government in doing its job.'' But how does a stealth car bra help the government? Fuller smiled. ``It keeps them on their toes.'' His idea for the Guardian Interlock stems from his conviction for driving under the influence at age 19. Afterward, Fuller recalled in an interview, he asked himself why someone hadn't thought of a product that would help prevent drunk driving. ``The `why' part of that question got me thinking about a method of prevention. It sure would have helped me back then,'' he said. To start a car equipped with the Guardian Interlock, a driver must breathe into a mouthpiece attached to an alcohol sensor for 4 seconds. If the driver's alcohol level is above the level deemed safe, the ignition remains locked. Judges around the country are ordering convicted drunk drivers to buy and install the $300 system in their vehicles as an alternative to paying fines or serving jail time, Fuller said. Fuller's stealth car bra also resulted from experience. ``Honestly, I was a little tired of getting speeding tickets. But more than that, I believe the government uses radar technology to generate revenue. The public has a right to defend itself if the government uses clandestine methods,'' Fuller said. Radar, he said, often gives inaccurate readings because the beam from a radar gun spreads like the light from a flashlight. Stealth technology forces a police officer to wait until the vehicle is closer to get a speed reading, improving a driver's chances of spotting the officer and slowing down first. ``The bra protects drivers from unfair readings that result in unjustified speeding tickets,'' he said. The bra, which starts at $299 depending on the auto make and model, is custom-made to fit most domestic and foreign cars. Fuller's creations have gained him national and international recognition. As president and founder of Innovisions Research Co., he has combined inventiveness and marketing savvy to create a growing business. Innovisions Research, in operation just over a year, employs seven people full-time and makes use of about 20 subcontractors. Revenue for 1990 is projected at around $2 million, Fuller said. Fuller's career as an inventor _ or innovator, as he prefers to be called _ began when the drums he made from chlorine cans won second prize at a third grade school fair. ``Inventing was a way of getting things my parents or I couldn't afford,'' he said. Fuller's first commercial success, or so he thought, came at age 22. A sports fanatic, he designed a fold-away trailer to haul his motorbikes and other equipment too large to fit in compact cars. Only after taking out a second mortgage on his home to finance the venture did he realize he was losing $25 per trailer because of distribution problems. Still, he was undeterred. ``An idea has very little value until it's proven to be a commercial success,'' Fuller said. His first financial success came was the Servitron Robot, a vinyl, 4-feet-tall, remote-control toy that serves drinks at parties. It racked up nearly $3 million in sales its first year. The mechanical influx of cash made it possible for Fuller to develop and market other creations: orthopedically designed pants for skiers with bad knees; a condo for cats; handles for skis, and mitts for ice-scrapers. ``I just look at different areas objectively. Sometimes people in a specific industry are so close to the subject that they can't see the areas where improvements or additions are necessary. I try to remain the observer so I don't get too wrapped up in a product,'' Fuller said. One of Fuller's latest demonstrations of technological shrewdness is an electronic alarm that guards parking spaces. Set at the front end of a parking space, Park Guard 1000 uses ultrasonic waves to detect unidentified vehicles that come within 5 feet of the alarm. A voice message then is triggered: ``Warning! Reserved Parking! Please move your car or it will be towed.'' If the vehicle is not moved, a shrill alarm sounds. Fuller said his inventions serve two functions _ they are fun, like his Aqua Tunes, which allows lap swimmers to listen to music while they swim, or they provide a public service, like the Guardian Interlock. Although he now enjoys a comfortable life because of his business success, Fuller said his ideas are largely a result of working for himself and avoiding a dreary 9-to-5 job. ``That's why most adults aren't so creative,'' Fuller says. ``Who has the time to create? I'm lucky. I get to make the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mostly Higher, Led By Soybeans
DOC.TEXT: Grain futures prices closed mostly higher Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, paced by moderate gains in soybeans amid signs of tighter supplies and worsening growing conditions in South America. Farmer selling of soybeans has been slow recently and analysts noted some movement of beans out of deliverable positions against the March futures contract. The movement indicates that the prices that both soybean crushers and Gulf Coast shippers are paying are high enough to cover the costs of transporting the beans to them, said Anne Frick, senior oilseeds analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Broadly underpinning the gains in all markets were reports that Communist Party leaders in the Soviet Union have approved sweeping political reforms recommended by their leader, Mikhail Gorbachev. The nation's swing toward democracy is seen as increasing the chances the United States will grant most-favored-nation trade status to the Soviet Union, which could lead to bigger grain deals with the United States. At the close, wheat futures were { cent lower to 1} cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.82} a bushel; corn futures were 1 cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $2.39 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 1} cents higher with March at $1.37 a bushel; soybeans were 3} cents to 5 cents higher with March at $5.67} a bushel.
The stock market was higher in fairly brisk afternoon trading today. About five minutes before the closing bell, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 33.33 points at 2,639.64.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Rallies
DOC.TEXT: The stock market snapped out of an early depression to close sharply higher, helped by program trading and a rally in blue-chip stocks. ``It's a blue-chip rally,'' said Brad Weeks, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The market opened sharply lower in what analysts said was a response to weakness in the bond market due largely to worries about the Treasury's quarterly refunding. The Dow Jones industrials were down more than 20 points shortly after the opening bell. Analysts said a rally in high technology stocks, along with heavy bouts of computerized program trading, helped revive the blue chip sector before midday. Stocks retained their upward momentum in the aftermath of the Treasury's sale of $10 billion in 10-year notes despite continued weakness in the bond market. ``It looks like the refunding is going well,'' said Weeks. ``Reports are the Japanese bought about 25 to 30 percent of the notes.'' The three-part auction, which started Tuesday with the sale of $10 billion in three-year notes, culminates on Thursday with the auction of $10 billion in 30-year Treasury bonds. Worries about the refunding have plagued the bond market and depressed stock prices in recent sessions. In particular, investors were concerned that yields would be forced higher to compete against overseas rates and attract Japanese investors. Foreign investors, particularly the Japanese, are an important source of funds into U.S. credit markets. Despite the rally, which some observers attributed to technical factors, some Wall Street analysts said underlying market fundamentals remained bearish and predicted a continued short-term downtrend in the market once the refunding is over.

DOC.HEAD: Operator Companies Warned of Government Regulations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Dixon, testifying ...,' to CLARIFY intent of bill. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Companies that provide telephone operator services for travelers were warned Wednesday that they may face stiff government regulation because of widespread complaints they are picking the pockets of unwary callers _ including members of the U.S. Senate. Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., said the Federal Communications Commission, which last year issued rules to govern alternative operator services companies, is receiving 150 complaints a month from angry callers who feel they're being overcharged or not being allowed to use the long-distance carrier of their choice. The operator companies contract with hotels, hospitals, airports and other public institutions to handle ``dial O'' calls on long-distance lines leased from a major carrier. The operator companies pay a commission to the premises owner. Dixon, testifying before a Senate subcommittee considering two bills that would crack down on alleged abuses and possibly regulate prices, noted that under the FCC rules five major AOS companies were to identify themselves and allow callers, upon request, to reach their own long-distance carrier. ``I submit to you that this not being done, and our constituents continue to fall prey to these unscrupulous practices,'' Dixon told the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation telecommunications subcommittee. He said callers were getting bills from a city where they never were, resulting in two charges for one call _ often well in excess of rates charged by American Telephone & Telegraph Co., MCI or US Sprint, which actually carry the calls for the operator service companies. Dixon said a staff survey of four Washingon hotels and one restaurant served by the operator companies found violations of the FCC rules, particularly that signs be placed on phone informing callers of the name of the service provider. Dixon told of being charged $16 for three calls from operator services companies that would have cost $7 using a pre-subscribed long-distance carrier. That prompted subcommittee Chairman Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, to acknowledge that he too had had a bad experience with one of the alternative operator service companies last month. Inouye said that when such things occur to a subcommittee chairman ``some action can be expected.'' Representatives of the companies and the chief telephone regulator at the FCC, Richard Firestone, said complaints have dropped by half since the FCC rules went into effect. The company officials said they are beginning to police themselves after a period of ``growing pains'' and that they soon will have the technical capability to connect callers with all long-distance companies. The companies have flourished since the breakup of AT&T opened competition in the $12 billion market for assisted telephone calls. Critics say the commission system gives the operator companies no incentive to hold down prices. Dixon's bill would deny commissions to any institution that did not allow phone users to reach the long-distance carrier of their choice. If a company continued to serve a facility that blocks calls, the operator companies would not be allowed to charge more than the lowest rate available from other long-distance companies for the same call. Dixon's bill also would prohibit a alternative-operator company, when it cannot complete a call, from handing off the call without warning to another long-distance company. That results in two bills _ one of which is from a location where the customer never was. Sen. John Breaux, D-La., has introduced a bill identical to a measure passed by the House last year. His bill incorporates the FCC rules and requires that the companies file prices for approval by the FCC.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Official Predicts Smoother Debt Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, Costa Rica... to CORRECT spelling of `principle.'
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations to relieve the crushing debt burden on Third World countries should progress more smoothly now that Mexico and its creditor banks have signed a debt reduction agreement, a senior Bush administration official predicted Wednesday. ``The strengthened debt strategy is very much alive and well,'' Treasury Undersecretary David C. Mulford, architect of the administration debt plan, told the House Banking subcommittee on international development. The Mexican agreement signed Sunday in Mexico City is the first under the administration's year-old Brady plan, named after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. The strategy emphasizes reducing a borrowing country's debt and the interest it must pay, in contrast with the Reagan administration strategy that sought to provide new loans in return for economic reforms by the borrowers. Mulford acknowledged that 10 months had passed since the start of talks between Mexico and representatives of its 450 creditor banks. But, he said, the pact eased the way for agreements by other countries. Banks now accept that they must reduce the debt of developing countries and the borrowing nations have a more realistic expectation of how much relief they can get, he said. ``The banks at the time of the Mexican negotiation were in the early phase of coming to terms with the elements of the strategy. ... The principles of debt reduction and debt service reduction are now established and I sense a greater flexibility at this point on the part of banks,'' Mulford said. Costa Rica and the Philippines both have reached agreement in principle on new financing packages and Venezuela and Morocco are actively negotiating with banks, he said. However, Delegate Walter E. Fauntroy, D-D.C., chairman of the subcommittee, said, ``The pace of negotiations clearly needs to be speeded up if ... countries ... are to receive relief within a reasonable period.'' Rep. Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass., said the debt pact, while moving in the right direction, did not provide the Mexican government with enough relief to revive its economy. But Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa, said the Mexican deal, compared with other relief packages for foreign countries, was surpassed only by the Marshall Plan aid to Europe after World War II. ``It's always easy to say a good program isn't good enough. ... The fact of the matter is this agreement ... has to be seen as truly historic and monumental,'' Leach said. Mulford said the agreement reduced Mexico's overall foreign debt from $95 billion at the end of last year _ half of it owed to foreign banks _ to about $80 billion by March 1. From 1989 to 1992, Mexico's annual interest payments will be reduced by about one-third, to $1.5 billion. Principal payments will be $6.7 billion less over the period. Mexico also will get about $1.5 billion in new loans from banks. Mulford said that proved ``new bank lending and debt reduction can co-exist in the same financing package.''

DOC.HEAD: Yields at Closely Watched Auction Rise To Highest Level Since May
DOC.TEXT: Yields on 10-year Treasury notes rose in Wednesday's auction to the highest level since last May as the government's quarterly refunding reached its midpoint. The average yield was 8.59 percent, up from 7.94 percent at the last auction on Nov. 13, 1989. It was the highest rate since 10-year notes averaged 9.18 percent on May 10. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8{ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,940.40. A total of $10 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $23.9 billion. The refunding continues Thursday with the auction of $10 billion in 30-year bonds. In Tuesday's auction, the Treasury sold $10 billion of three-year notes with an average yield of 8.43 percent, up from 7.77 percent at the last three-year auction Nov. 9 and the highest since such notes averaged 9.12 percent last May 9. Bids totaled $34.1 billion. The notes and bonds are regularly sold at auctions held four times a year to replenish the government's coffers. In announcing this week's auctions, Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber said $18.1 billion would be used to refund privately held notes maturing on Feb. 15 and to raise about $11.9 billion in cash. In addition, the Treasury sold $7.7 billion in three-month bills and $7.6 billion in six-month bills at its weekly bill auction Monday. It also plans to sell $9.5 billion in one-year notes Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Mixed
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed higher against major currencies in domestic trading Wednesday but the West German mark continued holding center stage on world foreign exchange markets. Gold prices declined in U.S. dealings but moved mostly higher abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $418.10 a troy ounce, $3.20 lower than Tuesday's close. Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $418.10 as of 4 p.m. EST, down $2.60 from Tuesday's late bid. The dollar has been playing a supporting role to the mark lately because reforms in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are expected to benefit the West German economy, said Keith Raphael, second vice president of foreign exchange at Chase Manhattan Bank. Meanwhile, negative sentiment toward the dollar has prevailed amid speculation that a softening U.S. economy will be accompanied by interest rate declines. Lower U.S. rates would reduce returns on dollar-denominated investments, tending to curb demand for dollars. Regardless, the dollar managed to gain against its foreign counterparts in what U.S. dealers described as a technical rebound. Overseas, the dollar turned in a mixed performance. Dealers said developments in Moscow, with Soviet Communist Party leaders agreeing to give up their monopoly on power as proposed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, already had been factored into foreign exchange markets. A lack of market-moving news made dealers reluctant to trade heavily and kept the dollar within a narrow range. The dollar began its trading day in Tokyo by rising to 145.10 Japanese yen from 144.90 yen at Tuesday's close. Later in London, it rose to 145.45 yen. At the end of New York's trading day, the dollar was quoted at 145.60 yen, up from 145.245 yen Tuesday. The dollar ended the day in New York at 1.6580 West German marks, up from 1.65605 marks on Tuesday and from the 1.6545 closing level Wednesday in Europe. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6995 from $1.7015 late Tuesday and to $1.6960 from $1.7030 in New York. Gold bullion prices were mixed while silver rose. In London, gold rose to a late bid of $423 a troy ounce from $420.85 bid late Tuesday. In Zurch, gold rose to a closing bid of $422.25 from $420.75 bid late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.72 to close at a bid of $417.75 a troy ounce. DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices finished mixed in light, featureless trading Wednesday. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 19 cents to end at $22.32 per barrel. Crude contracts for delivery in April, May and June also declined, but later months rose. Among refined products traded on the exchange, the March contract for regular unleaded gasoline fell 0.68 cent to 61.20 cents a gallon. Other contract months also retreated. Advancing issues overpowered losers by a marin of about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 941 issues up, 567 down and 443 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 186.71 million shares, up sharply from 134.07 million in the previous session. The market opened lower in what analysts said was a response to weakness in the bond market, reflecting worries about interest rates and the Treasury's quarterly refunding. The Dow Jones industrials were down more than 20 points shortly after the opening bell. ``Investors were almost waiting for the market to go lower so they could get some good bargains,'' said Michael Metz, technical analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. ``As soon as that happened they all came into the market at the same time and that sparked a rally.'' High technology stocks, which lead the advance, helped revive the blue chip sector before midday. Bouts of computerized program trading fueled the upward move once the rally got under way, traders said. Stocks retained their upward momentum in afternoon trading after what appeared to be a good turnout for the Treasury's sale of $10 billion in 10-year notes. Bond prices rallied in the aftermath of the auction and were up fractionally late in the day. ``It looks like the refunding is going well,'' said Brad Weeks, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ``Reports are the Japanese bought about 25 to 30 percent of the notes.'' The three-part $30 billion auction, which started Tuesday with the sale of $10 billion in three-year notes, ends on Thursday with the auction of $10 billion in 30-year Treasury bonds. Worries about the refunding have plagued the bond market and depressed stock prices in recent sessions. In particular, investors were concerned that yields would be forced higher to compete against overseas rates and attract Japanese investors. Foreign investors, particularly the Japanese, are an important source of funds into U.S. credit markets. Despite the rally, some Wall Street analysts said underlying market fundamentals remained bearish and predicted a continued short-term downtrend in the market once the refunding is over. ``The real problems are floundering profits and rising interest rates which are deadly for the stock market,'' said Larry Wachtel, equities analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``When the refunding is out of the way then the problems will reoccur,'' said Weeks. ``People will start talking of poor corporate earnings again and about what might happen in the first quarter and the market will go down again.'' Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 220.5 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $31.638 billion, or 0.99 percent, in value from Tuesday. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks added 1.98 to 184.31. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, IBM jumped 2[ to 103[, Haliburton rose 3 to 45], AT&T gained { to 40 and General Electric added | to 62|. Among other computer stocks, Compaq Computer rose 4} to 86[, Digital Equipment advanced 1~ to 79[ and Hewlett Packard increased 2] to 47|. Standard & Poor's industrial index finished 5.30 higher at 385.39, and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 4.09 to 333.75. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.80 to 426.79. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 356.35, up 1.61.
