DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Rise on Signs of Stronger Demand
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose moderately Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid signs of stronger demand and drier growing conditions for the South American crop. Most grain futures also advanced. On other commodity markets, gold futures retreated; energy futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. Soybean futures settled 3{ cents to 5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March up 5 cents at $5.67} a bushel. Wheat futures settled { cent lower 1} cents higher with March at $3.83 a bushel; corn futures were 1\ cents to 1} cents higher with March at $2.39 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 1} cents higher with March at $1.37\ a bushel. The soybean rally occurred on light trading volume and was not remarkably strong compared with the market's permitted daily limit of 30 cents. Yet the 5-cent gain represented the market's sharpest upward move since Jan. 29, when it staged a reversal that many analysts interpreted as a sign that soybean prices had bottomed. March soybeans rose 4{ cents on Tuesday. Analysts said some of Wednesday's buying probably reflected a growing belief that the market is indeed heading higher. Also, the day's little news was bullish. Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., noted that farmer sales of soybeans have slowed recently and that some owners of physical soybeans have been moving them out of deliverable positions against the March futures contract. The movement indicates that the prices that both soybean crushers and Gulf Coast shippers are paying are high enough to cover the costs of transporting the beans to them, Ms. Frick said. Furthermore, the weather has turned drier in Southern Brazil, a prime soybean-growing region, after good rains last week, which may have prompted some buying. Analyst Walter Spilka of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said active buying of soybean and corn futures by Cargill Inc., a large grain merchant, sparked speculation of new export sales of those commodities. Reports that Spain was bidding 50,000 metric tons of U.S. soybeans took traders by surprise and also helped the rally, Spilka said. ``If you want a bottom line to this whole thing, prices have fallen enough in the near term to stir a little export interest, at least on a short term basis,'' he said. Gold futures sank on New York's Commodity Exchange on selling related to a strong late rally in the stock market. Gold settled $3.20 to $3.50 lower with February at $418.10 a troy ounce; silver futures finished 0.1 cent 0.5 cent higher with March at $5.336 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures finished mixed with bullish chart signals offset by Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory report, which showed larger-than-expected U.S. supplies of crude oil and refined products. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 19 cents lower to 10 cents higher with March at $22.32 a barrel; heating oil futures finished .30 cent lower to .50 cent higher with March at 55.89 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .20 cent to .95 cent lower with March at 61.20 cents a gallon. Cattle futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in a technical rebound after Tuesday's decline. Pork futures rose amid expectations for stronger cash markets. Live cattle futures finished .03 cent lower to .37 cent higher with February at 79.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent lower to .20 cent higher with March at 82.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .03 cent lower to .48 cent higher with February at 49.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .28 cent higher with February unchanged at 50.50 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Trans Ocean Ordered To Liquidate Assets
DOC.TEXT: Trans Ocean Airways, an international air charter service based in New Iberia, has filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy protection and was ordered to liquidate all its assets. Bankruptcy Judge Donald Boe of Opelousas, La., ordered liquidation Tuesday after owners of three planes petitioned the court to terminate their contract with Trans Ocean. Trans Ocean allegedly defaulted on its lease payments for three planes and was ordered to return them to Aviation Sales Co. of Miami. Roy Holleman, president of the Iberia Industrial Development Foundation, said the bankruptcy could be a big loss for Iberia Parish. Trans Ocean employed 600 people, including 115 in New Iberia. Its fleet included McDonnell Douglas DC-8s and Boeing 727s.

DOC.HEAD: Ashton-Tate Posts $1 Million Loss in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Software maker Ashton-Tate Corp., still suffering from a recall of its flawed dBase IV computer program, on Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $1 million. The loss for the October-December quarter, equivalent to 4 cents a share, compared with a net profit of $13.4 million, or 51 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. Fourth-quarter revenue fell 29 percent to $62.1 million from $87.3 million. Ashton-Tate's fiscal year used to end on Jan. 31. As of 1989, the company changed to a calendar year ending Dec. 31. Therefore, its latest results are compared with results for the period ended Jan. 31, 1989. For the year ended Dec. 31, Ashton-Tate lost $28.6 million, or $1.09 a share, compared with a net profit of $47.7 million, or $1.83 a share, in the year ended Jan. 31, 1989. Annual revenue fell by 14 percent to $265.3 million from $307.3 million. The dBase programs are Ashton-Tate's core products. The dBase IV version, designed to help small businesses and office work groups track data, was released in October 1988, then had to be pulled off the market when Ashton-Tate was besieged with complaints about glitches. Since then, Ashton-Tate has been forced to lay off 15 percent of its work force and has shown big losses as it struggles to bring to market an improved version of dBase IV known as dBase IV 1.1. The latter program is nearing the end of an extensive pre-release series of tryouts with software developers, corporate users and distributors. Ashton-Tate Chairman Edward M. Esber Jr. said reaction to it has been good. ``We believe that the worst is behind us,'' he said in a conference call with reporters Wednesday. Asked about the chance of additional layoffs or if Ashton-Tate might be a takeover target, he said: ``No company can honestly give you assurances on either one.'' But he added, ``We do not plan any layoffs at this time and plan to remain independent.''

DOC.HEAD: Joint H-P, Oki Deal in Puerto Rico Finalized
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. and Oki Electrical Industry of Japan said Wednesday they reached final agreement to build a $40 million printed circuit board plant in Puerto Rico. The deal calls for construction of a 115,000-square-foot plant at a Hewlett-Packard site in Aguadilla to be completed in 1991. Two hundred employees will work at the plant, which will make boards for computer products in HP's Puerto Rican operations. Oki's share of output will be sold on the open market. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, is an international manufacturer of computer and measurement products with 95,000 workers and revenues of $11.9 billion in 1989. Oki makes telecommunications and information processing devices. It has 20,000 employees and posted revenues of $4.2 billion in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Expand, Lease Nation's Oil Reserves
DOC.TEXT: Capacity of the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve would be expanded from 750 million to 1 billion barrels of crude oil under legislation introduced Wednesday by Sen. J. Bennett Johnston. Johnston, D-La., said his bill also would provide for the leasing rather than the purchase of crude oil to fill the vast Louisiana and Texas underground salt domes where the emergency oil is kept. The Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, of which Johnston is chairman, has scheduled hearings Feb. 27 on the legislation. Johnston said 150 million of the additional 250 million barrels of crude would be stored in one of several Louisiana sites being considered. The balance would be put in one of three possible Texas locations. Johnston quoted industry sources as saying the Louisiana expansion could result in up to 1,000 construction jobs, several hundred permanent hirings and an economic impact ranging from $400 million to $500 million. He said expansion of the reserve was needed because its original intended capacity was 1 billion barrels and numerous studies have supported that capacity. ``The message from DOE is: `Don't worry, be happy' with a smaller SPR, a weaker insurance policy and a shorter lifeline for this country if oil supplies are threatened,'' Johnston said in a news release, referring to the U.S. Department of Energy.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Welcome Reported Resignation of Apple's `Visionary'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Later Wednesday ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with report that employees told of Gassee's departure in a memo.
DOC.TEXT: Analysts generally welcomed a report Wednesday on the imminent departure of Jean-Louis Gassee, Apple Computer Inc.'s flamboyant new-product developer, who often was touted as the visionary for the personal computer maker. Gassee once was considered a possible successor to John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive officer. His reported resignation comes during a tumultuous reorganization of the company, which has suffered declining sales for a year. ``It appears that the speed with which new products were being kicked out the door is the major complaint against Gassee, and to the extent that this is an attempt to correct this very serious problem, the resignation is both good and bad news,'' said Abigail Christopher, an analyst at International Data Corp., a high-technology research firm in Framingham, Mass. ``They've got to make a change. It's painful, but it's got to be done,'' said Paul Gillin, executive editor of Computerworld, an industry newsweekly. ``In the long term it's going to be positive because what Apple needs is a shakeup.'' Gassee, 46, who has headed the Cupertino-based company's new-product development for five years, will leave the company within the next few weeks, according to a report Wednesday in The Wall Street Journal. An industry source who used to work at Apple, speaking on the condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press some Apple employees were notified of the resignation in a memo on Tuesday. However, Apple officials said Gassee's departure was far from certain. ``No announcement has been made,'' said Apple spokesman Christopher Escher. ``And Jean-Louis Gassee continues as the president of Apple products. Obviously, because of recent organization changes, Jean-Louis Gasee has been in discussions with John Scully for some time regarding Jean-Louis' future role within Apple.'' Escher declined to comment further. Apple's stock lost $1.50 a share to close at $33.25 Wednesday in national over-the-counter trading. The report of Gassee's departure follows by a week the resignation of Allan Z. Loren, who headed Apple's domestic sales and marketing division, the company's largest. The same day Loren's departure was disclosed, Apple named Michael H. Spindler, the company's chief of European operations, to the new post of chief operating officer. It gave Spindler supervision of the domestic operations as well as two departments that had been under Gassee's oversight since 1988, product marketing and manufacturing. The Journal reported Sculley had pressured Gassee to accept a demotion. Since the 1985 departure of Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, Gassee, who once headed the European operations, concentrated on improving the technical depth of Apple's Macintosh. Under his direction, Apple introduced an updated version of the original Macintosh, called the SE, and a redesigned version called the Macintosh II, Apple's first machine with a color monitor and a full range of add-on options. But Gassee was criticized for failing to introduce new low-priced models and for the company's portable computer, which many of the company's legions of stalwart users complain is bulky, slow, expensive and difficult to read. Gassee's departure will leave a ``giant hole'' in the management of the company, said Bruce Lupatkin, an Apple analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco brokerage. But while it will be difficult to replace the colorful Gassee _ who often wore an earring and once cursed at a reporter's question during a news conference _ Lupatkin said it would not be impossible. ``Since Jobs' departure (in 1985), he had been promoted as the individual responsible for the company's vision, but if you look at what's he's delivered, I don't think there's a great loss in vision,'' Lupatkin said. Peter Rogers, an Apple analyst with Robertson Colman Stephens in San Francisco, was more blunt: ``It's difficult to exalt him.'' In its latest quarter, Apple suffered an 11 percent decline in profit from the comparable period a year earlier. It was the third consecutive quarter the company reported a decline in both revenues and profit from the previous year, with most of the problems centered in Loren's division. As a result, Apple, which had revenues of $5.3 billion in 1989, said it would cut employment by 5,500, mostly through attrition and reassignment, but would not rule out the possibility of layoffs. It also froze salaries for six months and made other cutbacks. Rogers said Apple, the world's No. 2 personal computer maker after International Business Machines Corp., needs to replace Gassee quickly and smoothly. ``More than the loss of the man himself, Apple doesn't need a lot more turmoil,'' Rogers said. Many industry observers fear the personnel changes and the possibility of layoffs are damaging morale at the company, which once was famed for its collegial operations. Besides losing sales, Apple faces a critical year in 1990 from major competitors who will be introducing or improving their own graphical interface products, the programs that use symbols to allow the user to tell computers what to do.

DOC.HEAD: Playboy Reports Nearly Flat Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Playboy Enterprises Inc. earned $500,000 during the second quarter of its fiscal 1990, about one-third of the company's profit for the same period a year earlier. Playboy said its publishing group, which produces Playboy magazine, showed a decline in revenue and earnings during the three months ended Dec. 31. Profits were boosted in the year-earlier quarter by $2.1 million in revenues generated by the sale of a portion of the company's collection of LeRoy Neiman paintings. The $500,000 profit, or 5 cents a share, came on revenues of $45.5 million. For the same period a year earlier, net income was $1.5 million, or 16 cents a share, on revenues of $48.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Prepares to Fire Picketing Mexican Workers
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Wednesday told employees who have picketed a plant in Mexico for almost a month that they will be fired if they don't return to work. The Cuautitlan plant, about 15 miles north of Mexico city, was closed by Ford on Jan. 8 after armed thugs entered and beat and shoot several workers. One of the nine injured workers died the next day. Workers have picketed the plant since the closure, charging some union officials are corrupt and pro-management. The company called picketers back to work on Jan. 30, but most refused to return, demanding assurances from the Mexican Labor Federation that union members would be able to elect their own leaders. Of about 3,800 workers, more than 1,300 are back on the job, said Al Chambers, North American communications manager for Ford. Under Mexican law, Ford can terminate any worker who accumulates more than three unexcused absences over a 30-day period and the company is taking steps to do so. ``The company is advising that workers that under Mexican law they can terminated,'' Chambers said Wednesday from company headquarters. ``By today there should be an estimated 300 to 400 workers who have been notified of their termination.'' He said Ford asked the federation for help in finding replacement workers. Authorities are holding 10 men on homicide and criminal conspiracy charges in connection with the Jan. 8 incident. The state attorney general has ordered the arrest of union local head Hector Uriarte for masterminding the violence. Picketers say Uriarte was imposed by the powerful federation, which has controlled the union for more than 20 years. The protestors also demand that Ford pay back-wages for lost time and guarantee plant security. They say Ford has acted in unison with the federation, providing company clothes to the thugs who entered the plant. The plant is turning out about 40 vehicles a day. Under normal conditions, the Cuautitlan plant turns out 450 cars and trucks daily for the Mexican market. Ford's production of 1,300 four-cylinder engines daily at its plant in the Chihuahua City in northern Mexico, has also been set back by a collective bargaining contract strike initiated Feb. 1. The plant's production is mostly for export to Canada and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Adds $46 Million to Patent Judgment Against Mattel
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ordered $46 million in interest added to the $24 million judgment won in an inventor's 12-year court fight with toymaker Mattel Inc. over its ``Hot Wheels'' toy cars, the inventor's lawyer said Wednesday. U.S. District Judge Charles Kocoras refused Mattel's motion to overturn the November judgment in the patent-infringement case or grant a new trial. He also refused to triple the damages awarded to New Jersey inventor Jerome Lemelson or to force Mattel to pay lawyer's fees for the plaintiff. But in his final order, entered late Tuesday, Kocoras did set out the procedure and percentages to be used in setting the amount of interest Mattel must pay. Lemelson's attorney, Gerald Hosier, said it works out to $46 million _ making the total judgment about $70 million. Mattel said in a statement Wednesday that it will appeal the patent infringement decision and is confident it will prevail. Lemelson, 66, a prolific inventor from Princeton, N.J., with more than 400 creations to his credit, sued Hawthorne, Calif.-based Mattel in 1977 for ``willful'' infringement on his patent for a flexible track that is part of the company's ``Hot Wheels'' toy car system. In its statement, Mattel said there are differences in its track from the patent, and a similar product previously existed. Hot Wheels brought Mattel $545 million in sales between 1972 and 1986 and is the company's most popular offering after Barbie dolls. Lemelson, who got his patent for the track in 1969, said he filed papers on his creation with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office in the mid-1960s, some time before Mattel's 1968 introduction of Hot Wheels. The case was filed in Chicago because its courts have a reputation for finding in favor of inventors.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Company Announces Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co. said Wednesday it will lay off 800 employees and postpone a $20 million expansion planned for its commercial helicopter line because of reduced U.S. military spending. The company also threw a blanket prohibition on discretionary spending such as employee travel and replacing non-critical equipment. ``A number of elements have made these steps necessary,'' company president William P. Brown said. ``Competing in world markets, particularly with reductions in defense spending, requires strong measures to be taken,'' he said in a statement. ``McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co. continues to be an industry leader in financial strength as well as in the quality of the products we produce.'' His statement mentioned participation in trade shows as a casualty in the retrenchment. Ironically, Brown and other top officials could not be reached for comment because they were attending a helicopter show in Dallas. Brown said the permanent layoffs will affect about 400 workers at the base plant here and another 400 at the company's California Manufacturing Center in Culver City, Calif. The layoffs will begin Feb. 21, and the last day of work for those affected will be Feb. 23, he said. The company plans to host an employment fair to try to help employees find new work in other ways, Brown said. Together, the layoffs affect more than 10 percent of the company's workforce. The company, the helicopter-making subsidiary of McDonnell Douglas Co. of St. Louis, employs 5,900 in Mesa and 1,650 in Culver City. McDonnell Douglas Helicopter laid off 450 Apache workers and reduced part-time and contract work last May. About 3,200 production workers here manufacture the Apache. ``We must reduce our workforce to meet the reality of our delivery schedule with the U.S. Army,'' Brown said. The plant has been producing the $9.9 million Apache for the Army at the rate of 10 per month. Brown said that would be reduced to six a month in June under a contract which ends in mid-1993. In addition, the company recently wrote off $137 million on helicopter programs after re-estimating material costs of several government contracts. The writedown contributed to a $17 million operating loss in the fourth quarter of last year. Brown said the company retained hopes of strong international sales of Apaches.

DOC.HEAD: January Inflation 79.2 Percent; Feb. Figure May Not be Much Less
DOC.TEXT: Inflation was 79.2 percent in January, pushing up the cost of living a hyperinflationary 8,164 percent over the past 12 months, according to the official National Institute for Statistics and Census. Also Wednesday, the austral slipped 15.5 percent against the U.S. dollar, falling to a rate of 2,960 to the dollar from Tuesday's closing rate of 2,500. The plunge since last Friday's closing rate of 1,990 to the dollar amounts to 32.8 percent. Bankers and analysts say the expansion of the money supply by the Central Bank is fueling inflation and pushing investors to get rid of their australs by buying dollars. The Central Bank, in need of funds to cover the national budget deficit and to pay off bonds that are falling due, printed 1.3 trillion australs ($439 million at Wednesday's rate) in January, an amount equivalent to 35.5 percent of the money supply. The government's inability to control inflation, the fiscal deficit and the austral's value prompted International Monetary Fund negotiators on Tuesday to withhold payment of the $230 million second installment of a $1.4 billion loan approved last October. ``I can't claim things are going well because that would be lying,'' President Carlos Menem told reporters. But he insisted the economic situation was stabilizing, and the government will not reimpose exchange controls to prop up the austral. The cost of living rocketed to 197 percent last July, the month Menem took office. It gradually fell to single digits before increasing six-fold last December to 40 percent. Inflation in 1989 was 4,923 percent. Inflation for the 12 months between February 1989 and January 1990 was 8,164 percent. Private economists say triple-digit wage increases recently approved by the government, and triple-digit hikes in public service rates, are likely to push up the cost of living by at least 60 percent in February.

DOC.HEAD: Crazy Eddie Founder Asserts Fifth Amendment on Bringing Back Funds
DOC.TEXT: Eddie Antar's lawyers said he refuses to repatriate $52 million because it might incriminate him, but a judge said the reclusive founder of Crazy Eddie Inc. would have to come to court himself if he wants to exercise his Fifth Amendment rights. The Securities and Exchange Commission says it wants the money brought back to this country in case it wins its insider trading case against Antar. U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan last month ordered the money to be placed in the care of a trustee in the United States. The judge rejected arguments Wednesday that the mere act of repatriating the money could be seen as an admission of guilt, and hence a violation of Antar's Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. After his ruling, attorney Jack Arseneault said his client refused to send back the money, and offered a sworn statement by Antar asserting his right against self-incrimination. Politan was not satisfied. ``I think I got to see his body,'' said the judge. Antar is believed to be living in New York City. Later in the day, Politan issued an order requiring Antar to respond at 9:30 a.m. Thursday to why he should not be held in contempt of court. Antar is expected to respond by pleading the Fifth, which will then give his lawyers the opportunity to appeal the contempt and repatriation orders to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Without a contempt hearing, said Arseneault, Antar probably could not appeal the repatriation order. The SEC sued Antar and other top officials of the chain for insider trading. Antar allegedly directed a ``massive financial fraud'' to artificially boost the company's income, enabling him to sell his stock at falsely high prices and reap millions of dollars in illegal profits. The SEC says Antar transferred the proceeds to bank accounts in Israel and Grand Cayman Island in 1987. Through his attorneys, he has denied the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Nickel Increase Seems Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf before table to ADD CPI comparison. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: It looks as if it'll cost a nickel more to mail a letter next year. The increase, which would be the first since 1988 and the largest ever, will be before the Postal Service Board of Governors when it meets March 6. If things follow their normal course, rates would go up in February 1991 _ 11 months after the process begins. There have been proposals to raise the first-class rate to 28 cents to 32 cents for the first ounce, but Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank sees 30 cents as the most likely. And he doesn't expect the raise to play well. Noting that a five-cent increase would be a 20 percent raise, substantially above the 14 percent he projected that consumer prices will have risen from 1988 to 1991, Frank said recently that he was ``committed to paying back to the American people that six percent'' difference. To do that, he has pledged to keep future increases below the inflation rate and said Tuesday that ``we may very well be able to hold increases in rates after the 1991 adjustments to one more increase in the balance of this century.'' That, he told the Postal Service board, ``would be no small achievement.'' Assuming the Postal Service board begins the process of raising rates for all classes of mail, the independent Postal Rate Commission will then ask for comment _ that should produce tons of reports and appeals from various interest groups _ and hold lengthy hearings before making its recommendation. It will then be up to the Postal Service board to put the new rate into effect. Only once since the rate commission was created in 1971 has it proposed a lower increase than the board had asked for. In that case, the board overruled the recommendation and did what it had proposed. While public attention focuses on the cost of sending a first-class letter, the real battles occur over second- and third-class charges. Advertising firms, charities and publishers of magazines and newspapers inundate the rate commission with pleas to hold down their portions of the overall rate hike. Although the Postal Service managed to post a $404 million surplus in the last three months of 1989, the agency expects a record $1.6 billion deficit for the fiscal year that will end Sept. 30. The outcome of contract negotiations this summer could make the deficit even worse. Frank, addressing postal costs in remarks late last month, also noted that the Postal Service was required in the last two years ``to contribute $800 million to deficit reduction, even though we don't use a penny of tax money,'' and that ``health benefit costs are out of control _ a problem we share with the private sector.'' Frank's comments came in a Jan. 25 speech to the Economic Club of Indianapolis. The Postal Service made a text of his remarks available Thursday. The Postal Service was separated from the federal government in 1971 and tax subsidies were eliminated. It was later returned to the federal budget _ at a time the agency was showing a surplus. Subsequently the Postal Service was taken back off the federal budget, but was also required to cover some retirement and medical payments for employees of the old U.S. Post Office Department. That expense has added millions of dollars to the service's annual costs. Here is a rundown of the cost of mailing a first-class letter since 1863, when the first flat rate was created at 2 cents per half-ounce, together with the average Consumer Price Index for the year shown. The CPI figures take the 1982-1984 average as 100. CPI figures are unavailable for years before 1947. 1885 _ 2 cents per ounce. 1917 _ 3 cents. 1919 _ 2 cents. July 6, 1932 _ 3 cents. Aug. 1, 1958 _ 4 cents, CPI 28.9. Jan. 7, 1963 _ 5 cents, 30.6. Jan. 7, 1968 _ 6 cents, 34.8. May 16, 1971 _ 8 cents, 40.5 March 2, 1974 _ 10 cents, 49.3 Dec. 31, 1975 _ 13 cents, 53.8 May 29, 1978 _ 15 cents, 65.2. March 22, 1981 _ 18 cents, 90.9. Nov. 1, 1981 _ 20 cents, 90.9. Feb. 17, 1985 _ 22 cents, 107.6. April 3, 1988 _ 25 cents, 118.3

DOC.HEAD: Cable Operators, GE Reported to Be Close to Announcing Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: A group of the nation's largest cable television system operators and a subsidiary of General Electric Co. are near agreement on a joint venture that would test the viability of delivering programming directly to customers via satellite, a source familiar with the talks said Wednesday. The joint venture would include up to nine parties including the cable giants Tele-Communications Inc., American Television and Communications Inc. and Comcast Corp., according to the source who spoke on condition that he not be identified. He said the deal could be announced as early as Thursday if there are no last-minute hitches. The venture is being viewed as a test of a service that could augment programming delivered by existing cable TV systems, freeing up channel capacity on the systems, as well as a way to deliver programming to rural areas not already served by cable. Recent reports in trade journals have indicated that the venture would make use of GE's existing Satcom K1 Ku-band satellite for the service. A report in Satellite Business News on Jan. 24 said the joint venture would invest $100 million in research and development and said it will take about 1 million subscribers to make the service viable.

DOC.HEAD: Freddie Mac Elects Shareholders at First Public Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen shareholders were elected to the board of Freddie Mac on Tuesday at the company's first shareholders meeting. Freddie Mac's voting stock, once owned exclusively by savings and loans, began trading publicly for the first time last year. S&L legislation enacted in August provided for an 18-member board to govern the company, formally known as the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Previously, Freddie Mac was controlled by federal regulators. The company finances about one in eight of U.S. homes, primarily by purchasing mortgages from lenders and repackaging them into securities for sale to investors. In addition to naming Leland C. Brendsel, Freddie Mac's president and chief executive officer, to the board, the shareholders named him the board chairman. The other new board members are: John C. Etling, General Reinsurance Corp.'s president; David W. Glenn, Freddie Mac's executive vice president; George D. Gould, former Treasury undersecretary; Barbara C. Jordan, a former member of Congress; Economist Henry Kaufman; Banc One Corp. Chairman John B. McCoy; Great Western Financial Corp. Chairman James F. Montgomery; Russell E. Palmer, dean of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania; Dorman & Wilson Inc. Chairman Ronald F. Poe; Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Co. Chairman Donald J. Schuenke; MacKay-Shields Financial Corp. Chairman Christina Seiz; and FL Industries executive William J. Turner. In addition to the 13 shareholder-elected board members, President Bush is to appoint five directors, with one appointee from each of the homebuilding, mortgage banking and real estate industries.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Chief Asked to Explain Meeting With CIA Director On Thrift Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To update with Justice inquiry, inserts new grafs 6-7: Meanwhile, Attorney .... Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a House subcommittee has asked CIA Director William Webster to meet with the panel behind closed doors to discuss a published report of possible involvement of the spy agency in the savings and loan crisis. Rep. Frank Annunzio, chairman of the House Banking Committee's financial institutions subcommittee, asked Webster in a letter Monday to meet with the panel about a story in last Sunday's Houston Post linking loans from 22 failed thrifts to people with ties to organized crime or the CIA. ``The allegations relating to the involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency, its employees, or individuals associated with the agency, are serious and troubling,'' Annunzio, D-Ill., said in the letter. The Houston newspaper said its sources suggested the CIA may have used part of the proceeds from S&L fraud to help pay for covert operations that Congress was unwilling to support publicly. Meanwhile, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said he has asked Justice Department investigators to determine ``if there is any shred of credibility due the article'' linking the CIA to failed thrifts. Thornburgh, appearing on a National Public Radio listener call-in program, said the inquiry was triggered by the newspaper account. The attorney general stressed that he had no independent information. A CIA spokesman has denied that the agency used S&L funds to finance covert activities.

DOC.HEAD: Court Chides DeSoto But Upholds Poison Pill
DOC.TEXT: A Delaware court on Tuesday upheld DeSoto Inc.'s ``poison pill'' takeover defense but chided the company's directors for failing to seek the best value for shareholders. DeSoto officials declined comment on the Chancery Court ruling. But New York investor William Spier, who is heading a hostile takeover bid for the Des Plaines, Ill.-based paint-and-chemical maker, said the ruling left DeSoto with few choices. ``DeSoto must now accept our $50 (a share) offer or provide greater value to its stockholders,'' Spier said in a statement issued by his takeover vehicle, Sutton Holding Corp. The court ruled that DeSoto had not taken steps necessary to assure maximum shareholder value after rejecting Sutton's $300 million offer in November. DeSoto has been fending off Sutton with a shareholder rights plan, known as a poison pill, that increases the number of outstanding shares, thus making a takeover prohibitively expensive. Sutton had asked the Delaware court to strike down the poison pill, but the court upheld the takeover defense. DeSoto also is seeking a buyer for its paint business, the core of its operations. DeSoto says it no longer wants to compete in the paint business but Sutton contends the proposed sale is a desperation move designed to avoid a takeover. Last week, Sears, Roebuck and Co. said it was canceling its contract with DeSoto, which has supplied paint to the retail giant for 80 years, because of DeSoto's decision to sell its paint operations.

DOC.HEAD: Residents, Officials Angry Over Delay in Announcing Leak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with details, quotes from meeting with county commissioners, apology from plant manager. EDITS to conform. Picks up 10th graf, ``Any situation ... Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A pesticide plant that built public confidence by installing safeguards and promising full disclosures voided that trust by waiting three days to announce a leak of a chemical that had killed 3,500 people in India, a county official said Tuesday. Kanawha County commissioners called Rhone-Poulenc managers to their offices to ask why Friday's one-ounce leak of methyl isocyanate wasn't disclosed until Monday. At Tuesday's meeting, the plant's manager, Ron Bearer, apologized and said the unit that leaked would remain closed pending a safety review. ``In the area of getting information to the public, it's very clear that we misjudged the situation,'' Bearer said. ``To correct this situation in the future ... all releases of acutely toxic materials, no matter how small, will be communicated.'' The MIC unit had been shut down and Friday's leak occurred during routine maintenance. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration said it would investigate whether any laws were violated in the incident, which injured seven. ``We've worked from the county commission's end with the people at the plant to build up public confidence in the Institute area,'' county Manager Ron Gregory said. ``In one day, with one ounce of MIC, they have destroyed that.'' The letters ``MIC'' cause fear among many in West Virginia's Chemical Valley, a concentration of two dozen chemical plants along a 15-mile stretch of the Kanawha River. The Institute plant, 10 miles west of Charleston, is a former Union Carbide operation that contains the only true sister unit to a Carbide operation at Bhopal, India. A December 1984 leak at Bhopal killed more than 3,500 and injured tens of thousands more. Engineers retooled the Institute MIC unit afterward and installed millions of dollars worth of safeguards. The plant was sold to Rhone-Poulenc in late 1986. Bearer, named the plant's manager just two weeks ago, said Monday the company didn't have to inform the county about Friday's leak because it involved less than a pound of material, none of which would have escaped the plant. The chemical, used in agricultural pesticides, is so potent that the amount in Friday's leak can injure eyes of workers 100 yards away. Federal regulations require disclosure only if the incident involves more than a pound of material or if there is a potential for health threats beyond the plant border. Gregory said that when the chemical is MIC, stricter rules must apply. ``Any situation where you don't tell the public what's happening, the worst comes to mind,'' Gregory said. ``They alarmed the public. If they would have announced on Friday that we had a one-ounce leak of MIC, I don't think they would have had this problem. Gregory said the Rhone-Poulenc plant had three minor incidents Friday. Full details of two were called in to emergency service personnel in Charleston. About the MIC leak, ``their planner did call the metro 911 operation and said, `We have a problem with a little vapor escape,''' Gregory said. ``Two minutes later, they called back and said, `All clear.' ``Not once did they mention it was MIC,'' Gregory said. The seven workers injured were employed by a Houston construction contractor. The Rhone-Poulenc employees working on the MIC unit weren't injured, Bearer said. Paul Pribyl, manager for Brown & Root Construction said it is plant policy to notify personnel when potentially hazardous work is being done nearby. ``For some reason it wasn't followed in this instance. There was some sort of breakdown in communications,'' he said. In August 1985, Union Carbide officials waited 20 minutes to notify emergency officials about an aldicarb oxime and methylene chloride leak that injured 135. Union Carbide said the Bhopal leak occurred after saboteurs let water into an MIC storage tank, setting off a reaction. The Indian government accused Carbide of shoddy workmanship. The parties agreed to a $470 million settlement that a new Indian government is seeking to void.

DOC.HEAD: Halliburton Reports Rise in 1989 Net Income
DOC.TEXT: Halliburton Co. reported its net income quadrupled in the fourth quarter of 1989 as its oil patch services recovered. The company on Tuesday reported fourth quarter net income was $45.7 million, or 45 cents a share, up from $11.8 million, or 11 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Operating income on oil field services and products totalled $66.5 million in the latest quarter, compared with $800,000 a year earlier. The division benefitted from an upturn in oil exploration and development spending sparked by the rise in oil prices during the period, Halliburton said. Operating income in engineering and construction services rose to $18.5 million from $8.8 million, while insurance services fell to $5.7 million from $7.9 million. Net income in all 1989 was $135 million, or $1.27 a share, up 44 percent from $93.6 million, or 89 cents a share, in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Austral Plunges Another 14.8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The fall of the austral accelerated Tuesday as Argentina's currency plunged by 14.8 percent. At the close of the business day, Argentines were paying 2,500 australs to buy one U.S. dollar, compared with 2,130 australs on Monday and 1,990 last Friday. Analysts said the decline stemmed from the printing of unbacked currency by the country's central bank. Inflation soared by 40 percent in December and is projected at 70 percent for January and February. In part because the government failed to meet economic targets promised earlier, an International Monetary Fund negotiating team decided to withhold disbursement of $230 million this month to Argentina. That sum would have been the second payment of a $1.4 billion loan approved last October.

DOC.HEAD: Dealer Awarded $7.8 Million From Toyota
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for a dealer who was awarded $7.8 million from Toyota's American distributors says he is considering a class-action suit over the companies' method of alloting cars to dealers. ``I think this case will make a lot of dealers at least consider they might want to do something,'' said James Brandenburg. ``Quite frankly, I've already had dealers contact me about a class-action suit on behalf of Toyota dealers across the country.'' A U.S. District Court jury made the award to Pappas Toyota of St. Charles Friday. Pappas contended in the three-year-old suit that he was unfairly treated by Toyota Motor Distribution and Toyota Motor Sales, both of Torrance, Calif. Brandenburg said the jury found Toyota had acted in bad faith between 1982 and 1987 in allocating cars and trucks to Pappas, resulting in lost sales for the dealer. The key witness for Pappas was a University of Arizona faculty member who did a lengthy study of Toyota distribution. Brandenburg said the so-called ``turn and earn'' system that required dealerships to earn new cars by selling the ones on their lots violated the contract between the dealer and the company, which allowed the dealer to order whatever vehicles he desired. Jonathan Ries, an attorney for Toyota, said he was disappointed by the verdict and is considering filing an appeal. He said Toyota treated Pappas fairly. It was not the first time the issue has been tried in court. Brandenburg said he represented Jim Lynch Toyota in 1986 when Lynch won $2 million in a similar lawsuit. The money awarded to Pappas represented the amount that the dealership would have made had it been able to take delivery on more vehicles from 1982 through 1987, Brandenburg said. Toyota has about 1,000 dealers in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Forbes' Forecast: Banner Decade After Shaky 1990
DOC.TEXT: The 1990s will be a banner economic decade for America despite a shaky beginning, the president and deputy editor of Forbes Magazine predicted. ``It's going to be choppy in 1990, but after that we should have what could be one of the best decades of this century,'' Malcolm ``Steve'' Forbes Jr., said Tuesday. ``I think that by the year's end the economy will start to pick up.'' Forbes, in Reno to promote a special Nevada advertising section in his magazine, said Congress' failure to cut the capital gains tax and instability in the value of the dollar are holding back an economic boom in the United States. ``All of these things are reversible,'' said Forbes, who has won four awards for economic forecasting from USX Corp. ``The key is the capital gains tax cut. That needs to pass to get things going,'' he said. ``If we can avoid raising taxes, bashing the dollar or getting into a trade war we should do well,'' he added. Forbes, a Republican, said people shouldn't worry about the federal budget deficit because it amounts to only about 2 percent of the country's gross national product. He also said the nation's intractable trade deficit isn't a worry because it leads to growing foreign investment in this country. ``People forget that for the first 100 years of this country there was a trade deficit,'' Forbes said.

DOC.HEAD: American Cyanamid Reports 37 Percent Drop in Fourth Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: American Cyanamid reported a 37 percent drop in fourth quarter earnings, blaming most of the drop on losses suffered by a foreign subsidiary. The Wayne, N.J.-based biotechnology and chemical company reported fourth quarter earnings of $38.5 million, or 41 cents a share, compared with $60.8 million, or 65 cents a share, in fourth quarter 1988. Unauthorized borrowings and previously unreported losses at an overseas subsidiary reduced earnings by about $24 million, or 25 cents a share, the company said in a statement. Fourth quarter sales were $1.15 billion, up 4 percent from $1.10 billion a year earlier. Net earnings in 1989 were $292 million, or $3.12 a share, compared with $295.6 million, or $3.16 a share in 1988.
